SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lees Sen M.H.

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That this Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The speech read as follows—
The Food Labelling Bill 1993 is a Private Senator's Bill introduced with a very simple aim.

SPEECH.PARA: That is to make it quick and easy for consumers to identify the country of origin of any food product, and, in particular, to identify whether that food is genuinely a product of Australia.
Under the legislation the terms `Australian Made' and `Made in Australia' are banned from use for food products and the definition of Product of Australia is tightened dramatically.
Foods cannot be labelled as `Product of Australia' unless:

PARA.TAB: (a)all of the ingredients of the food are grown or produced in Australia; or
(b)ingredients of the food that make up at least 90 per cent by volume of the food are grown or produced in Australia and the remaining ingredients are commercially unavailable foods; and
(c)all of the steps that have gone into making up the food have occurred wholly within Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: (`commercially unavailable foods' means foods that are prescribed, being foods that are not able to be made in Australia in commercially available quantities.)
The use of Australian symbols—such as a map of Australia, a kangaroo or the flag—is restricted to foods which meet the new product of Australia definition.

The terms Made in Australia and Australian Made are deliberately banned—for food—because I believe they have become so devalued they are now in effect meaningless. Consumers have no confidence in their integrity at all. We need a fresh start and they should go. I have no problem with the use of `Processed in Australia', because that gives a clear indication of exactly what has taken place here.
The Bill also makes compulsory a Table of Product Contents, detailing each ingredient, its percentage by volume in the product and its country of origin, in letters at least 4mm high (example below).
Content % by volume in product Country of origin
Apricots 70% Australia
Water 20% Australia
Sugar 8% Australia
Flavouring 621 1% USA
Stabilisers 577 and 1202 1% Netherlands
Made optional under the legislation are the use of three new categories of food—`A', `B' and`C'.
A category `A' food is one which meets the new Product of Australia definition and which is produced by an Australian citizen, partnership or company.

Foods meeting category `A' requirements can be labelled with the letter `A', `Category A Food', `100% Australian' or the expression `Processed and packaged in Australia, from Australian materials by Australians (or by an Australian company)'.
A category `B' food is one which meets the new Product of Australia definition and which is produced by a person, partnership or company who or which is not Australian.
Category `B' foods can be labelled with the letter `B', `Category B Food' or the expression `Processed and packaged in Australia, from Australian materials by a [country of control] company'.
A category `C' food is one in which the ingredients are at least 50 per cent by volume grown or produced in Australia and which is processed and packaged in Australia.
Category `C' foods can be labelled with the letter `C', `category C Food' or `Processed and packaged in Australia, from more than 50% Australian materials'.
The `A', `B' and `C' categorisation scheme is the one I used in my food labelling trials with the Foodland supermarket group in South Australia.

It is important to note that both Category A and Category B foods can be `Product of Australia'. The distinction is with the nationality of company control. It is also important to note that their use is optional, so producers can judge for themselves whether they wish to provide ownership information to consumers.

The Democrats, unlike the Government, believe the issue of ownership is important, and, indeed, that there is a demand from the public for information regarding ownership. The popularity of the AusBuy Guide published by the Australian Owned Companies Association and the outcry over the sale of Arnotts are an indication of that.
That is a brief outline of the Bill. I now turn to why it is needed.
I do not think it is too far off the mark to suggest this Bill is needed because our current labelling laws are a shambles.
The example I like to use is coffee. Everybody knows we produce very little coffee in this country. We produce it in `boutique' quantities at best.

Yet you can walk into the supermarket and pick up a 250 gram jar of Nescafe or International Roast, and the label says Product of Australia. How is this so? Because the coffee beans go through their final processing stage here. This product should be labelled `Processed in Australia'.
We all know almost intuitively that this is not a product of Australia, and we tend to laugh it off.

But apply the same logic to a can of tomato soup or a jar of jam. They are labelled Product of Australia, and we assume the contents are made from Australian tomatoes or Australian fruits or berries. Yet in exactly the same way that coffee can be labelled Product of Australia, so could soup or jam made from overseas sourced tomatoes, fruits or berries.

People do not laugh at that. They believe—and they have every right to believe—that in those cases Product of Australia means just that—that the contents are Australian. Australian grown and Australian processed.
The slackness of the current laws misleads consumers, disadvantages Australian businesses and costs this country jobs and our companies profits.

There is wide public acknowledgment that that is the case. There is also wide public demand for genuine, easy to understand country of origin labelling. You only have to walk down any supermarket aisle in the country and you will see shoppers reading boxes and cans trying to discern exactly where a product is from.
And they have very little confidence in the current system. That is why we need a completely new broom.

Surveys also show us that where there is a choice and prices are similar, people will buy Australian. Eighty-eight percent of respondents to a Morgan Gallup poll in July 1991 indicated they thought people should buy Australian in those circumstances.
The problem for that 88 per cent of the population is in identifying Australian products.

The fact that two of the largest supermarket chains in the nation, Coles and Woolworths, decided last year to implement their own costly Australian product identification schemes indicates clearly a public demand for such information. Their need to do it indicates the current poor state of our labelling laws.
The products and Australian producers affected by our current labelling shambles are extensive. Peanuts, orange juice, apple juice, fish and pork are well known examples.
Vegetable and food imports increased by $86 million or some 22 per cent ($382 million to $469 million) in the year from June 1991 to June 1992.

Imports of meat and meat preparations rose 14 per cent to $42 million; fish imports rose $30 million to $474 million; orange juice imports soared from $9 million to $23 million; apple juice from $5 million to $13 million; and frozen vegetables recorded an increase in imports of almost 30 per cent to $24 million.
Grocery imports are reported to have increased by 21 per cent and 16 per cent respectively in the September and December quarters of 1992.

There are a number of questions surrounding these dramatic increases. Tariff levels, dumping, foreign subsidies, quotas and simply genuine price competition are all issues connected to those figures. I do not want to enter into those issues here.

The question I wish to raise is how much of that increase is because consumers simply cannot tell from the labels what is Australian and what is not? I do not know, but the point remains—how many of us can make the choice to genuinely buy Australian if we want to?

A study by the Printing and Allied Trades Employers' Federation of Australia suggests the Australian printing, packaging and labelling industry is losing some $50 million every year as a result of poor, misleading or non-existent country of origin information.
They consider the wider Australian economy is losing some $500 million from the problem. That translates to some 500 jobs in the printing, packaging and labelling industry alone.

I believe proper labelling can aid us to create jobs and curb our food import bill. It is not—as some would have us believe—a protectionist device. In fact, the economic purists should love it because it helps fulfil one of the conditions of a perfectly functioning free market—perfect information.
The more information consumers have the better they can make rational judgments and genuine—not imperfect—`market' outcomes will be achieved.
As I mentioned earlier, the Democrats consider the issue of ownership is also important, in both philosophical and practical economic terms.

We have noted the concerns of groups such as the Grocery Manufacturers of Australia (GMA) who believe it is `inappropriate and confusing to consumers to differentiate between products on the basis of ownership'.
The GMA of course represents the Australian arms of several enormous multi-national food corporations who may—if consumers decide—stand to lose from accurate labelling.
The Federal Minister for Consumer Affairs, Ms Jeannette McHugh, has also suggested ownership is irrelevant. She suggests the AusBuy Guide—which outlines ownership alone—threatens Australian jobs.

We have taken on board those concerns and made the provision of ownership information optional. The provision of such information in our scheme is not in isolation. It is in conjunction with accurate country of origin labelling, which the GMA supports. Companies which want to provide ownership information can. Consumers can then decide whether it is important to them or not.
The Democrats believe the issue of ownership is important in economic terms. We do not oppose foreign investment, as long as it has demonstrable benefits for the nation.

Where foreign investment represents new business or guarantees improvements or expansion in existing businesses, fair enough. We need capital. However, in the five years to June 1991 only 13.4 per cent of the $120 billion of foreign investment approved by the Foreign Investment Review Board was for new business. The remaining 86.6 per cent—or $103.7 billion—was to take over existing business.

This has increased our national expenditure on interest and dividends and contributed not insubstantially to our continuing current account deficit. Profits which previously remained in Australia now go overseas. In the five years to June 1991 $88.25 billion was paid out in interest and dividends (versus $20 billion coming in). Whether the benefits of investment match the net flow out is, I believe, questionable.

Where foreign investment represents acquisitions of existing businesses, there must be stringent tests of provable net benefit applied. If the Foreign Investment Review Board and the Government will not do that, then perhaps consumers will.
But all that is an aside to this Bill. Once again, we are merely providing companies with the opportunity to inform consumers, who can then do with that information what they will.
I wish to close by briefly outlining the history of our involvement with this issue.

Food labelling is an issue which has been of personal interest to me for many years, firstly as a mother, and then as someone made personally aware of the problems being faced by vegetable producers around Mount Gambier, where I lived for many years.

The Democrats first outlined an alternative scheme—the A-B-C scheme—in our Getting To Work document in July 1992. It received some media coverage and the public reaction to the idea was extraordinarily positive.

The Managing Director of the independent South Australian supermarket group Foodland, Mr Paul Pilkington, heard me talking about the idea on the ABC's Adelaide Drive-time show, hosted by Murray Nichol, and suggested Foodland stores run a trial of the scheme.
Following that was a period of exhaustive research, as my three electorate staff contacted Foodland's 400 suppliers seeking details of product content and ownership for some 16,000 product lines.

We were then contacted by a South Australian company, Fasson Australia, which offered to donate label material (Fasnature Recycled) and a Western Australian printing company, Supa Stik Labels and Labelling Systems, which offered to print the trial labels.

By October we had enough information to get up and running (despite a lack of co-operation from GMA members) and on October 27 we launched a trial of the A-B-C labelling scheme in seven Foodland supermarkets in Adelaide, placing coloured labels on the shelves next to the price tags.

The feedback we got back from shoppers was again extremely positive. Many people wanted to know why it had never been done before, and many more suggested the information should appear on product packaging.
Those comments were the inspiration for this Bill. In December last year I tabled a draft Food Labelling Bill for public comment, and now, six months later, in May 1993, introduce a final version.

The tabling of this Bill is timely, given the release earlier this week of the Report of the Working Groups on Country of Origin Labelling of Consumer Products. The working groups were established by the Government last year at least in part, I would suggest, in response to the attention the Democrats were receiving for our proposals.
The fact that the working groups apparently sent their research questionnaire to Foodland, and not to other, larger supermarket chains, tends to confirm this.

I hope the tabling of this Bill at this time will continue to concentrate the mind of the Government on the need for action. The options outlined in the working parties' report include a `do nothing' option. That would be entirely unsatisfactory.

One criticism I have received is that this Bill relates to food labelling only. Indeed I recognise the problems in other areas such as clothing and textiles. With the limited resources available to me it has been very much a matter of taking things one step at a time. If the government continues to prevaricate, non-food products will be next.

In the meantime this Bill represents a further push for the government, to make sure we do achieve real change in food labelling—people want it, people need it, and, one way or another, the Democrats will ensure they get it.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.

COMMITTEE E

TALK.START.PARA: —The committee is considering Appropriation Bill (No. 5) 1992-93. When the Bill was last considered, the committee was considering subprogram 1.6, relating to the Department of the Environment, Sport and Territories.

—When consideration was interrupted and other business intervened, I was asking the Parliamentary Secretary about the possibility of grants being made to groups wishing to make submissions to the Shoalwater Bay inquiry. I asked whether a submission had been received from a conservation group. The Parliamentary Secretary asked me to advise the name of the conservation group, which I had but which I did not read at the time. It is the Central Queensland Wildlife Protection Society. Press reports suggest that it is asking the Government for a $50,000 grant to make a submission to this inquiry, for which the Government has set aside $500,000. I ask again: has any application been received from the Central Queensland Wildlife Protection Society? If it has been received, what is the fate of the application? What parameters does the Government adopt in handing out taxpayers' money for people to make submissions? If it has not yet been made, what basis would the Government use to determine whether that grant is likely to be made?

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —A submission seeking funding of $50,000, as Senator Macdonald mentioned, has been received. The submission was unsolicited. There has not been any formal advertising seeking submissions or statement of the parameters for requests for funding. So at this stage the Government cannot indicate on what basis moneys will be allocated to any groups, if any.
—What criteria would the Government use in assessing such an application?

—At this stage, we cannot give the honourable senator any detail on that because the matter has not been considered yet. When the list of terms of reference is drawn up and presumably advertisements are placed in some way or notifications are given to organisations, then the list of those terms of reference can be made available to him. At this stage, that process has not even commenced.

—Mr Chairman, I wonder whether I could seek from Senator Sherry, on behalf of the Government, an assurance that, if money is being given out to groups to make submissions, the Rockhampton City Council will receive the same consideration as conservation groups receive in determining whether or not they get assistance.
—The answer is yes.
—If there is nothing further on subprogram 1.6, we will move to subprogram 4.3.

—Has any advance been made? At the estimates committee hearings, the Australian Sports Commission people indicated to me that they were looking at possibly getting some other quotations, or at another way—possibly a less expensive way—of cleaning the statues at the Institute of Sport, rather than continuing the allocation of $35,000 for cleaning and maintaining six life-size statues out there. I just wonder whether, in the last two weeks, there has been any advance on what might happen in the future.

PARA.TAB: While the Parliamentary Secretary is receiving instructions, I point out that, for the money involved, students at the institute could probably have got a couple of hundred pairs of good running shoes or 1,200 basketballs or footballs. It did seem to me at the time that the priorities at the Institute of Sport may have been a little misguided. If the money is available to be spent, one would have thought it might be better spent on facilities for the students rather than on cleaning some brass statues.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am advised that there have been no further developments on this matter since Senator Macdonald asked the question at the estimates committee hearing. I am assured that, whatever the process outcome, the cheapest possible tenders will be sought. Again, we can keep Senator Macdonald informed if there any developments on this issue.
—As there are no further matters on subprogram 4.3, we move to program 5, especially subprogram 5.2.

—In the questions on notice for this estimates committee, I submitted a question with regard to the date of the start-up of the casino operations on Christmas Island. I received a formal reply through the committee that the latest advice received from the developer on the opening of the Christmas Island casino is that the date is 8 August 1993. Mention is then made in the answer of the consequential budget changes that apply as a result.

PARA.TAB: The saga of the start-up of the Christmas Island casino has now been going on for a number of years and has resurfaced, obviously, in the considerations of the estimates for this department. I appreciate that this is a private development; nevertheless, it is underpinned by a particular agreement between the Federal Government and the developing company.

In light of the fact that there is a constant slippage in the date of the commencement of this major project, that the capital investment, I understand, in the casino on Christmas Island has now exceeded well over $50 million, and that it appears to me that we are constantly being faced with deferments of this issue, I would be keen for the Parliamentary Secretary to indicate whether there have been any alterations to the understanding or the agreement between the Government and the developer and what the principles are of any of these changes in the past six or 12 months.

TALK.START.PARA: —I can advise the honourable senator that to date there have been no changes to the agreement other than the obvious, that the date has slipped back. It is anticipated that it will open on 8 August this year.

—Is the Government aware whether there has been any change in the owning shareholding of the development company? This was subject to FIRB approval some time ago. Whilst the agreement may well be in place, I am keen to ascertain whether, given that the principals of the company are, I think, 90 per cent Indonesian owned and very closely linked to a number of prominent business and political personalities in Indonesia, the shareholding of the development company has in any way changed.
—I am advised that there have been no recent changes in the ownership. Any time there are changes they are notified to the Australian Federal Police and the Foreign Investment Review Board.

—To save the time of the committee, I refer also to several other questions and answers that I have received under different programs, all impinging on this same issue. One is related to the continued operations of the airline from Perth to both Cocos and Christmas islands, on which I received a lengthy answer which set out the financial arrangements for this year and the subsidy arrangements that applied.

PARA.TAB: Also, I received from the Department of Transport and Communications an answer to a question at this committee which related to the contemplation of international air travel carriers operating to and from Christmas Island and the need for the agreements and arrangements that would be put in place. That answer refers particularly to the approval that has been given to PT Sempati Air to operate services from Indonesia to Christmas Island, but at this stage, the answer implies, the airline has not advised a start-up date.

Given that it is now indicated that the casino is to commence operation on 8 August of this year, I would have thought that there would be in some way a coordinating committee or some tourist promotional arrangement being coordinated by this department to ensure that the operation of air services from Australia to the island at the same time as this important casino will start and the operation of the Sempati Air facilities to the island were coordinated. I am keen to establish that the department is facilitating this and is ensuring that air services, both international and domestic, will be sufficiently coordinated to ensure that there is no initial frustration once the casino starts operation in August.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Sempati airline is a private organisation which does have direct contact with the developers of the casino on Christmas Island. The Government has not played any role in coordinating the links between Sempati airline—the private airline—and the developers. Presumably there are some ongoing discussions or arrangements with them, but the Government is not involved directly with that in any way. The Government is involved, however, in conjunction with the local council on Christmas Island, in seeking the development of domestic airline carriers from Australia to fly to Christmas Island. It is involved in attempting to establish those sorts of links with the island from Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would merely reiterate and stress my concerns that this is a matter that needs very delicate and careful coordination. There will be the establishment of a $50 to $60 million casino, principally to serve the Indonesian market or the Asian market. From the discussions I have had with the developing company and with officials, both on the island and with the department here, I gather that the casino will be primarily dedicated to high-flying gamblers and to that special market of people that probably go in for a weekend with more than $100,000 in their pocket. Nevertheless, I would not want to see the Government in an embarrassing situation later this year because these air services have not been properly coordinated.

PARA.TAB: As I said, the answer I received from the Department of Transport and Communications merely indicated that Sempati Air had been granted approval, although it had not advised a start-up date. Further on, the answer states:

SPEECH.PARA: The process has generated interest amongst a number of the bidding airlines to consider operating beyond Christmas Island to other international destinations.

So I would hope that we would see a situation in the future where this department and the Department of Transport and Communications and, I would hope, the Government's new initiatives for tourism would also be very carefully coordinated in this regard. Otherwise, we are going to see the establishment of a very specialist casino stuck out on an island in the Indian Ocean and principally serving only people who cannot gamble in Indonesia for legal reasons of the Indonesian regime. Our island of Christmas Island will be used as a safety valve, if you like, for the gambling community of Indonesia.

PARA.TAB: At the same time, I appreciate that we will pick up the royalty income that will naturally flow from the operation of the casino on Christmas Island. There have been indications in previous estimates and forward estimates that this is going to be considerable. Probably something in the order of $10 million or more per year will flow through to the revenue of the Commonwealth, which, of course, can then be used to offset the other services for the island.

The Federal Government has announced a very extensive rebuilding and construction program for Christmas Island over the next five years which exceeds $40 million. I would want to see that reciprocal benefit of the income flowing from the operation of the casino in order to fund the rebuilding and development projects on Christmas Island, otherwise the liability is going to fall totally onto the Australian taxpayer to provide these benefits on Christmas Island for a very small community of 1,300 people. They certainly need the services, I appreciate that; but unless the tourism projects are properly coordinated we could end up with a very great embarrassment on our hands, particularly given the nature of Asian politics and Asian gambling.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I certainly appreciate Senator Tambling's concerns. He may or may not be aware that I have a background of involvement in the casino industries, so I do have some first-hand knowledge of the problems, particularly as many of the employees on Christmas Island will come from my home State of Tasmania.
—And your union or their union?

—Their union, unfortunately. So I do have some constituency concern—that those people can travel, on a reasonable basis, from Christmas Island back to the mainland of Australia. The current arrangement between Perth and Christmas Island is a charter arrangement. As I have said, the department is concerned to have an appropriately scheduled domestic airline flying to and from Christmas Island. In terms of the points made about the revenue flow and about the current arrangement being used largely by Indonesians, I certainly appreciate that. But it is not a dissimilar situation, frankly, from the Tasmanian casino in its early days when it drew a very large part of its revenue from Victorians; there was a transfer of income from Victoria to Tasmania. I have to say, from a Tasmanian perspective, that we very much appreciate it. But that is changing somewhat with the opening of casinos, so we appreciate the honourable senator's concerns. I have a personal interest in this issue, so I can assure Senator Tambling that, with the Minister, we will maintain an accurate file of information for him on the matters he has raised.

—My other reservation concerns housing policy on Christmas Island. Again, I thank the Minister and the department for the extensive reply that I received to a question on notice relating to the details of the expenditure proposed as part of the rebuilding program for the housing policy that has been announced. With the anticipated changes in tourism development on the island, I believe that the housing situation on Christmas Island will undergo extreme pressures in the next 12 months or so. This will be inevitable with the large number of staff that will be required for the casino and also for the construction program generally. I am a bit concerned that the forward estimates relating specifically to housing may not meet the current need.

PARA.TAB: I am also aware that there is an ongoing dispute between the Federal Government and the union of Christmas Island workers with regard to the provision of housing. This has blown up in the Asian press because many of the island residents' home communities are either in Singapore or in Malaysia. Officials of the union of Christmas Island workers have been reported in both the Singaporean and Malaysian media as implying that the Federal Government's initiatives with regard to housing are a form of racism. I am concerned that that sort of media criticism damages Australia's reputation and may be out of proportion to the extent of the problem. I draw to the Government's attention the concerns of island residents.

The second issue with regard to housing is that a number of island residents have been unable to purchase the accommodation which they presently occupy. I am aware that there are disputes on the island in this regard. In particular, I refer to the dispute that has been ongoing with the former Minister, Ms Fatin, and correspondence to the current Minister, Mrs Kelly, from Mrs Patricia Power and Dr Holger Rumpff of Christmas Island, which would indicate that there has been a degree of lack of resolution by the Minister in being involved in trying to determine equity and fairness between island residents, yet recognising the needs of people on that community. Is the Parliamentary Secretary aware that these matters have been drawn to Mrs Kelly's personal attention? Is it intended to seek early resolution so this will not result in extensive court actions and appeals—apparent at present—which will obviously be very costly to the department?

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —In terms of the current dispute, the department is taking an active interest in having the matter finalised, and it is currently reviewing its public housing policy on Christmas Island. Part of the recognition of the problems that exist on the island is the allocation of the sum of $432,000 in these appropriations for public housing on Christmas Island.
—We move to program 6, especially subprogram 6.2.

—During 1988, 1989 and 1990, loans and subsidies were paid by this Government to a company called Plywood and Plastics Pty Ltd, which at the time was the owner of the sawmill at Ravenshoe. This total loan and subsidy of some $7.59 million was part of a structural adjustment package to that company as a result of the World Heritage listing of the wet tropics.

PARA.TAB: The company made one repayment of about $300,000, and so the net amount of taxpayers' money that was given by this Government to Plywood and Plastics Pty Ltd was $7,293,841. That money went missing, and after a lot of urging by me and by others in this chamber an investigation into the recovery of the amount that was to be repaid and the proper use of the subsidy money was entered into—somewhat reluctantly, I think. Senator Richardson was very much involved in that at the time. He had been run out of the town of Ravenshoe when he was the environment Minister, and the whole question has been a complete fiasco since those days.

The $7.2 million that has disappeared has had fairly catastrophic effects on the town of Ravenshoe. The Parliamentary Secretary might note that the money that was given to that company was supposed to be used by that company to pay wages and also to pay suppliers to the company. It was to pay little people: small businessmen and single traders who gave the company credit because they knew that the Commonwealth Government was lending these huge amounts of money. They assumed wrongly, as it turned out, but one can forgive them for doing so. They assumed that because the Commonwealth Government was putting so much money in there, the Commonwealth Government would be exercising some rudimentary oversight of the operation of the company. So all these little people—small businessmen, sole traders—gave the company credit beyond that which they could really afford to give.

When, after a period of time, Plywood and Plastics went into liquidation and no trace could be found of this money, those small businessmen did not get their money back. They had extended this credit beyond their means because the Government was lending this company money. Many of them now have joined the ranks of those who are not only unemployed, but also bankrupt. They have joined the huge ranks of the bankrupt that have formed since this Government has been in power, particularly in the last few years. It was as a direct result of this Government's mismanagement of those funds that these people lost their businesses, lost their livelihoods and lost their houses—lost everything.

The Government will never accept responsibility for that. Members of the Government say it is a commercial decision, and nothing to do with them. They say the businesses gave the credit. But the fact is that if the Government had exercised even rudimentary oversight then this money would not have gone missing, those people would have been paid, and the tragedy which has resulted for those people would not have occurred.

Over the period that I have been in the Senate, I have constantly inquired about this. We have had one series of put-offs after the other. I think we even censored Senator Richardson at one time over his handling of this matter and, towards the end, Senator Richardson seemed to become somewhat contrite. He promised me that he would try to get the Minister to make good that money that those small business people lost. Then with the machinations that happen in the Labor Party from time to time, Senator Richardson got shuffled around and dismissed. The new Minister who took over was not terribly interested. I think Senator Richardson, after a lot of time, had been convinced of the merit of the argument. But, when he went, the sympathy and the compassion that the Government was starting to show disappeared. That is the background to all of that.

The question that I reserved relates to the Government's attempt to recover some of this money. I had asked, and others in this chamber had asked, for details of the action being taken to recover the money. We were promised and promised that we would be kept informed. The ASC and the Attorney-General were going to tell us what was happening but, in spite of inquiring every now and then, I got no sensible information. I got one letter from the ASC, but it asked me to keep it quiet; I was quite happy to do so at the time. Then—lo and behold!—I see that in the further estimates some money is wanted for a court case to recover this money. I was not advised about this and I was very disappointed that the Government did not comply with its undertakings to keep me informed of that.

We now find that the Government has instituted some proceedings. I asked at the estimates what these proceedings were all about. The answers that I have been given show that the Government is suing Plywood and Plastics. One of the directors, a man by the name of Hugh Ferguson Macdonald, is being sued. I hasten to add that, although the spelling is the same as mine, he is absolutely no relation to me; I have never set eyes on the man. I have been told that it is for deceptive and misleading conduct, I think it was. One of the allegations was that he aided and abetted, counselled or procured or was knowingly concerned in deceptive and misleading conduct.

The Government is suing for the recovery of $968,841. Why only that amount? What is happening to the other $6,325,000 that seems to have gone missing? The answer given to me suggests that this is the civil claim being taken by the Australian Securities Commission. There are a final couple of lines that say that there may be prosecutions by the Director of Public Prosecutions, but that if I want to find out about that I should direct some questions to the Attorney-General. I do not find that very satisfactory. It has all come out of this department. I want to know, and I asked the Parliamentary Secretary to tell me this, why we are only suing for that amount. Is any action being taken to recover the balance of the $7 million-odd that went missing because of this Government's ineptitude?

Whilst I do not want to interfere with any criminal proceedings that the DPP might be instituting, I would like an indication from the Parliamentary Secretary as to whether proceedings are being instituted. And, without disclosing things that may make those prosecutions more difficult, could the Parliamentary Secretary indicate to me the general ambit of criminal proceedings to be instituted, when they are likely to be and what the course envisaged for those proceedings might be.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —Firstly, I reject any notion, in what was largely a political statement rather than a question, that the Government was directly responsible in any sense for what occurred in terms of the missing moneys. The moneys were passed over to a private company, and the private company, regrettably, did not continue in existence. I do not know the reasons for that, whether there was theft or fraud involved or whether the company just ceased because of economic circumstances. But certainly I reject any inference or direct allegation from Senator Macdonald—
—I don't think Senator Richardson would.

—I certainly reject it on behalf of the Government and on behalf of Senator Richardson. I know that has been the subject of debate here on previous occasions. The current case is for recovery of the second subsidy payment of $968,841. That case is being taken under sections 51A and 52 of the Trade Practices Act and is being conducted on the basis that a former director may have misled or engaged in deception within the meaning of the Trade Practices Act. The reason why that case is proceeding is that there is some evidence for that case to proceed.

PARA.TAB: With respect to the other moneys, the $4.5 million or the first subsidy payment of $2.125 million, the Commonwealth will be proceeding on the basis of available evidence. That is still the subject of investigation by the Australian Federal Police and the Australian Securities Commission. I do not have any information as to when any legal action is likely.

Finally, I would make it clear that my advice is that Senator Macdonald has been kept well informed of developments on this issue; that he has received detailed responses to numerous questions on these matters over the past three years; and that the Minister, Mrs Kelly, has been corresponding with Senator Macdonald on these matters as recently as 10 February 1993, according to a copy of a letter that I have.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Chairman, I ask Senator Sherry to give me a copy of that letter. I do not mind whether he tables it formally or sends it around. I would appreciate that. I will not go back and forward over whether I have been kept informed. I do not think that I have been kept sufficiently well informed, but I guess that depends on where one sits. Did Senator Sherry indicate to me that criminal prosecutions were being looked at by the Director of Public Prosecutions?

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —Firstly, I am very happy to table a copy of the letter that was sent from Mrs Kelly to Senator Macdonald on 10 February. We cannot indicate at this point what form the legal actions would take. As I have indicated, the gathering of the evidence by the Australian Securities Commission and the Australian Federal Police is still continuing. Until the evidence gathering is completed, we certainly cannot indicate what form of action the legal proceedings will take.

—Mr Chairman, I ask Senator Sherry to think this through carefully. The $7 million was given to the mill to use to upgrade the mill. It got small businessmen and private contractors to do the work. Many of those small businessmen have not been paid. The money was given by the Government for that purpose. It should have gone to those small businessmen.

PARA.TAB: In the event of the Government being successful in recovering money from either the director or the company, the Government will then have its money back, but the work was done by some businessmen. Would the Government then consider an ex gratia payment to those businessmen and others who gave credit and spent their money to do the work for which the Government gave $7 million? If the Government gets the money back, will Senator Sherry consider an ex gratia payment to those small businessmen who have done the work and have never been paid?

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —The question is extremely hypothetical, because we have not yet recovered the moneys. But I will transmit Senator Macdonald's concerns and his view to the Minister.

—The department has, obviously, sued for $900,000—which it expects to get; I assume that otherwise it would not have instituted the proceedings. If $900,000 is recovered, bearing in mind that the money owed to those small business people is about $300,000 to $500,000, depending on which group of figures we take, I would have hoped that Senator Sherry could give those people a little bit of encouragement by suggesting to me, with the necessary qualifications, that, if the money is recovered, an ex gratia payment to them will at least be considered.
—All I can do is to refer Senator Macdonald to my previous answer. Any hypothetical assessment of what will be obtained at this stage is premature.

—Just for the record, I do not know why Senator Sherry and the Government do these things. This letter that he referred to, sent to me by Mrs Kelly, has nothing to do with the court proceedings that I asked to be kept informed about. It is simply answering a submission that I continuously make to the Government to do something for these small business people who have lost so much money. This letter is from Mrs Kelly saying, `Go and get lost. We are not interested'. Although the letter does not say so, the attitude is, `Had it been a union which had some members put off, we would have given redundancy payments'. If it had been union members, workers, who were put off, they would get redundancy. They would get looked after. Because these happen to be small businessmen, this Government does not seem to care at all. To suggest that this letter is keeping me informed of the court proceedings in accordance with the undertakings given by Senator Richardson, Senator Tate and others is a bit dishonest.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I reject yet again Senator Macdonald's political hyperbole. His comments are speculative in nature, in terms of how this matter would be dealt with if a trade union were involved. I am aware that the Government cares a great deal about this issue and is doing all in its power to ensure that the moneys are recovered.

—That concludes the examination of the estimates for that department. We move to the Department of Transport and Communications. We move to program 1, on aviation. Before we come to subprogram 1.1 there are on the running sheet a number of general matters in relation to aviation. Are there any questions on those?

—I refer briefly to the CT4 aircraft. I raised this matter with Senator Ray the other day, although I think Senator Collins was half involved. We were trying to find out about the aircraft that were being auctioned—last Saturday, I think.
—Are these defence aircraft?
—Yes, they are.
—They have nothing to do with me.
—They are on the running sheet. Who is the responsible Minister?
—I have no information on them.

—This Minister may recall that I tried to ask him the other day. This is a CAA question, actually. As I understand the proceedings, the aircraft have been flying around in Australian airspace for years. They are being sold out of the RAAF, as I understand it, to private buyers but, because the aircraft are no longer being flown by the RAAF, suddenly they have got to have, I think, $40,000 worth of improvements or modifications made to them. My question simply is: if it was okay for them to fly around in the airspace with RAAF pilots without these modifications, why do they now have to have modifications to be flown around in the same airspace by civilian pilots?

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Transport and Communications)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Chairman, I will seek detailed advice for Senator Macdonald. Could I just say to Senator Macdonald that, from my own experience in the cost of maintenance on aircraft, for $40,000 people might get a new decal on the tail and a coat of paint if they were lucky. I would suspect, but I will get more precise advice because this is a CAA issue, that an amount that small in terms of aircraft would probably not involve any matters relating to the safety of the aircraft at all. It would be like slapping a fresh coat of paint on the house.

PARA.TAB: The ex-military CT4 trainer aircraft as they stand are not eligible for the issue of a full civil certificate of airworthiness. Pacific Aerospace Corporation of New Zealand holds the type certificate for a civil CT4 aircraft which meets full Australian civil certification standards. These standards are based on those applying internationally. It may be possible to modify the ex-RAAF aircraft to enable a full certification of airworthiness to be granted. However, the details and cost of this are entirely a commercial matter between an applicant and Pacific Aerospace. It was made clear to potential purchasers that without modifications the aircraft are eligible only for a permit to fly as ex-military aircraft. The permit carries a number of restrictions.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will not pursue this, but could the Minister for Transport and Communications (Mr Collins) tell me how much the aircraft sold for last Saturday, if he has some idea? Whilst he says $40,000 is not much money, some air cadet schools were wanting to buy them but I understand that the price was to be a couple of hundred thousand. Was it? That $40,000 extra was a lot of money. It may not mean much in safety but it is a lot of money if people are buying them. My question, which I suspect the Minister has probably answered, is: if it is safe for them to be flown by RAAF people around the airspace, why is it not safe for civilian people to fly these aircraft? They are the same aircraft. What is the difference? People out there find it hard to follow the bureaucratic regulations when RAAF pilots can fly them around but civilians cannot without spending another $40,000 on them.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Transport and Communications)

TALK.START.PARA: —I will just say again that for $40,000 people would get practically nothing done to an aircraft.
—Did you hear the question?

—Yes, I did hear the question. Mr Chairman, I will seek detailed advice for Senator Macdonald, which I do not have at the moment. In conclusion, I will say to Senator Macdonald that I recall from the pilots dispute committee—which is ancient history—that when the question of civilians being carried on military aircraft was raised, there were certain aspects about military aircraft which did not in any way impinge on the actual safety of the aircraft in terms of flying which were not required for military aircraft but which were required for civilian aircraft. I am just trying to assist Senator Macdonald.

PARA.TAB: I suspect that that would probably be the case in these aircraft, but I will get a detailed response. In closing, I am certain that these modifications would not involve major matters of the actual safety of the aircraft in terms of their flyability. They would probably be modifications required for civilian aircraft to operate that are simply not applicable to military aircraft because they have a different use.

TALK.START.PARA: —Does the Minister understand my point? I think they were only sold for a couple of hundred grand. Would that be right? There are flying schools wanting to buy them. How much were they?

—Following CAA's approval, CT4 trainers were auctioned by the RAAF last weekend. Senator Macdonald is wrong by a country mile, I am pleased to say for the exchequer. The auction brought $1.8 million, not the—
—But there were 36 aircraft. How much for each one?
—I do not know. I have actually been given strict instructions by the Whip which I am now transgressing. I have got to try to keep my answers in Estimates as short as possible.
—Good advice.

—I am trying. All I can say is that I do not have—and that is reasonable, I think—the detailed information about the individual price that was given for every one of the 36 aircraft, but I will ensure that Senator Macdonald's questions are answered promptly and in detail.

—I will not take it on. If one divides 36 into $1.2 million one would probably get to—someone work it out—$100,000. For the training school to buy it, $40,000 may not do much, but it is a lot of extra loot. It is half as much again as it paid for it. That is the point I am making. I do wish the Minister would listen.
—You have asked the question three times.

—Yes, but the Minister never addresses it. It is like the way he handles most things; he just does not listen. The Minister anticipates what people are going to ask him and what his department is going to advise. That gets him into all sorts of trouble. If he would just stop talking for a moment and listen, he might not get into the trouble that he gets into. I am just trying to help—it was not an argumentative question—some Australian citizens who want to buy an aircraft and who cannot understand why, if they are paying $100,000 for it, they have got to pay an extra $40,000 before it can be flown, especially when the RAAF has been flying exactly the same aircraft for many years but did not have to spend $40,000 to get the aircraft ready for flight. That is the only point I am trying to make to the Minister.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Transport and Communications)

TALK.START.PARA: —In conclusion, nobody can buy those aircraft. They have been sold; they were sold last weekend. I will provide Senator Macdonald with a detailed response to his questions.

—Could the Minister indicate to me when the Bureau of Air Safety Investigation report into the 1992 incident at Brisbane airport, involving the Ansett 727 aircraft, will be tabled. During the estimates committee hearings, Senator Collins indicated to me that it would be available on 30 May. I wonder if that date is still relevant. That incident, which I pointed out to the Minister two weeks ago in the estimates committee hearings, has subsequently come up in Question Time—the issue of the series of fiascos. I think the comment made in the report, which I quoted to the Minister at the estimates committee hearing, was that it was a bit like keystone cops. Is 30 May still the date for the release of that report or will it be a bit earlier?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Transport and Communications)

TALK.START.PARA: —I have as much interest in seeing this report as Senator Macdonald. As with many other incidents involving aircraft around the world, one thing that I have found common in the reports on these incidents is that generally a combination of things go wrong, not just a single thing. I am sure that will be the case here. I will read into Hansard an answer that I think will satisfy Senator Macdonald:

SPEECH.PARA: While the draft report has been circulated to the various parties involved in the occurrence, the final report will not be generally available until late June or early July. This delay is necessary to ensure that all parties have sufficient time to make comments on the draft, and for those comments to be considered by the Bureau, before the final report is released. The parties referred to include the engine and airframe manufacturers in the USA, the flight crew and company management of Ansett Australia, as well as the CAA and the FAC etc.

. . . Because of Senator Macdonald's interest in the occurrence, the Bureau would have no objection to a copy of the draft being provided to him, pending the publication of the final report. A second copy of the report is provided should it be required for this purpose. The Senator should be advised—
I am sure he will respect this—
that the report has not yet been approved for public release under the provisions of the Air Navigation Regulation 283, and is provided solely for his information.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister for that. I do not know whether I should even take it on that basis.
—If you don't want to, I think it would be better if you didn't.
—Is the Minister saying that it is not possible for me to discuss it with any of my colleagues in the Senate?

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Transport and Communications)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am just trying to cooperate with Senator Macdonald. This is the routine procedure for the way BASI prepares draft reports. I might add that BASI reports would be worthless if it were not done this way. BASI draft reports often contain critical comment about engine components, airframe components or whatever. The draft reports are always circulated to the people involved—in this case, engine manufacturers, airframe manufacturers and so on—for their detailed responses to the comments made in the report. That is the process that is currently under way. If Senator Macdonald wishes to see a confidential copy of the draft, it can be made available to him now. However, it has got to be on the basis that it is strictly not for public consumption.

—I thank the Minister. I will accept it, if it can be put in a sealed envelope in the course of the next half-hour. I will seek some advice from my more experienced colleagues about taking documents in that way. If it did get out and it was fairly widely published, there would be a suspicion that it had come from me. I will get some advice from some more experienced colleagues on what I should do, but at this moment I will say, `Yes, thank you; I will accept it'.

PARA.TAB: The Minister was pretty definite that it would be released publicly on 30 May, as I recall. Is there some particular reason why it is now to be in late June or early July? I know what he said, but what has changed in the last two weeks? The Minister should have known all of these things two weeks ago, when he quite dogmatically told me that it would be released at the end of May. I am just wondering what has happened in the last two weeks that has made this report now not available for another four to six weeks.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Transport and Communications)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Chairman, I have explained it. What I said in the Senate was that I knew there was a draft report that had been completed by BASI. That is correct. What is now happening is that the report is being circulated and, as I have just said, apart from anything else, it has had to go to the United States of America.

—Why did the Minister not know that two weeks ago? Two weeks ago he told me that it was expected to be released on 30 May. He should have known then that it had to go to the United States. Why did the Minister tell me two weeks ago that it would be available today, tomorrow or the next day, and what has changed in the last two weeks? That is what I want to know.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Transport and Communications)

TALK.START.PARA: —Jesus Christ, five times in a bloody row!
—Order!

—Mr Chairman, this is getting ridiculous. I have given the answer to the question five times. Can I say to Senator Macdonald for the sixth time now that it was not, as Senator Macdonald has just revealed by reading the Hansard, a dogmatic assertion by me at all. Senator Macdonald is a lawyer. He should read the simple English definition of what he has just said. I expected it to be; yes, I did. I do not involve myself, nor can I, in the detailed examination of the internal investigations of the Bureau of Air Safety Investigation into aircraft accidents. What I do interest myself in is its final report.

PARA.TAB: I knew that a draft had been completed. That is what I knew. That is why we made the offer we have just made. I am not quite sure what I am expected to do. What have I done since Senator Macdonald asked his question? I have made a detailed inquiry of BASI about the particular report, as the letter clearly indicates. I will table it, if Senator Macdonald wants me to. I then got a detailed response from the Bureau of Air Safety Investigation as to where the report is at. That is what has changed since Senator Macdonald asked his question. There has been a draft done, as I told him. It has been circulated to the engine manufacturers and the airframe manufacturers for comment. It is now expected to be finally produced in June or July. But, in the meantime, I am prepared to make a copy of the draft available to Senator Macdonald now, if he wants it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macdonald Sen I.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister said, and I quote for the second time:

SPEECH.PARA: It may save the time of the committee if I repeat again that the full report is expected to be released on 30 May.
It was on 11 May that he told me that. Now, two weeks later, he is telling me that it is not going to be ready until the end of June or early July.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Chairman, I cannot add anything useful to the six answers I have just given on the same matter.

PARA.TAB: The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN (Senator Chapman)—We move now to program 2, Broadcasting.

TALK.START.PARA: —The questions that I raised before the Senate committee related to the possible location of ABC pay TV. The Minister was helpful in his responses to my requests and had indicated to me that a decision had not yet been made on where to locate this facility, but indicated also that there would be no technical reasons why it should not be located in Melbourne, for example. It raised an important issue and I now seek some response from the Minister. I note his constructive comments in the estimates committee and I hope that we can continue on that basis.

PARA.TAB: I have had the opportunity in the last few weeks to look fairly closely at the structure of the ABC, and where the staffing and facilities of the ABC are located. I think there is concern about this and I have spoken to a number of other colleagues who can give me feedback from their own States. There is concern that whereas the ABC markets itself as—and certainly tries to be—the national broadcaster, to a certain extent it can be seen as, and has been criticised as being, the Sydney broadcasting corporation. People say this because of the huge concentration of ABC resources in that city. They note, for example, that the ABC is largely financed by taxpayers right around the country.

I do not know whether all Australians give their 8c a day, but a high proportion of that 8c—I suspect that it is about 5c of that 8c—is spent, not in their own States, but in Sydney. There may be some basis in history for this level of expenditure and concentration of resources, but the first thing I put to the Minister is that, whatever the historical reason, the advent of new technology such as satellites and e-mail has meant that—in my view and from advice I have received—there is no longer the need for that concentration of resources in Sydney.

On the issue of pay TV, the ABC was most forthcoming in regard to questions that I put to its representatives about where the expenditure of ABC TV revenue was made. I think I am correct in saying that $270 million of taxpayers' funds are spent on ABC TV, and some 70 per cent of that is spent in New South Wales. Then we looked at other aspects of the structure of the ABC and we found that virtually all the senior TV executives are based in Sydney as, indeed, are all the radio executives, perhaps with the exception of one. So not only is ABC expenditure concentrated in Sydney; decision making is also concentrated in that city.

There is a feeling around Australia that when a decision is being made about placing a facility here or there, this will lead to a bias towards placing that facility in Sydney. In relation to the Asia TV experience, I notice it is not entirely by coincidence that that facility was placed in Darwin. I am not complaining about that. I think that it is fully in line with the philosophy that I am proposing—a decentralisation of ABC resources—and the Minister has perhaps already moved sharply to endorse that philosophy. I certainly do not make any complaint about that because this is precisely in line with the approach that I am proposing. I ask the Minister: where is the actual decision about the location of pay TV made in the ABC? Is it actually a management decision or is it a decision which would go to the board?

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Transport and Communications)

TALK.START.PARA: —I will just clarify a few issues first. The decision, however welcome, to locate TV Asia in Darwin was made by the ABC. I can just explain one of the reasons why. Prakash Mirchandani has just come back. It is actually cheaper to fly from Darwin to points in South-East Asia than it is to fly from Sydney to Darwin, the reason being that it is half the distance. For TV Asia to be truly effective, and in terms of the interaction between the region and the broadcaster, which is what they want, it cuts the administrative expenses down enormously to have it based in Darwin, rather than have to fly twice the distance from Sydney to the last Australian—
—We are not questioning the decision.

—There was just a hint there, but it was in fact an ABC decision. I just make that clear. Of course, I must say that I welcome it; and Senator Kemp is quite rightly lobbying for Melbourne to be the headquarters of pay TV.
—And Port Pirie.

—`Senator Kemp', I said, Senator Teague. I can give Senator Kemp some precise information on this. The ABC is actively looking at sites in both Sydney and Melbourne. They are the two cities in which they are actually examining property. No decision has been taken yet. So all I can say is, `Lobby away, Senator Kemp, and good luck to you', because no final decision has been taken. As far as the final decision on the location is concerned, obviously there will be a management decision on it, but that would be a matter that would be referred either to the board of the ABC or to the board of the subsidiary organisation. Of course, in this case they are setting up a separate organisation for pay TV, but obviously the board either of the ABC or of the subsidiary would have to finally ratify the decision. The matter, I can assure Senator Kemp, is still open and Melbourne is being considered as a site.

—I thank the Minister and I welcome his comments that my home town is being actively considered. I note that the Minister was not sure whether the final decision would be made by the board or by the separate board of ABC pay TV. It seems to me that if—
—Do you want me to give you a list of whom to lobby?

—I would certainly appreciate that. The Minister may use the word `lobby'; I say `put a carefully considered and reasonable view to them'. Is the pay TV board appointed by the ABC board or is it appointed by the Minister?
—I have got nothing to do with it. It is appointed by the board, and I will be happy to provide Senator Kemp with an accurate and detailed answer of who will make the decision.

—If the board of ABC pay TV was comprised largely of members, for example, from Sydney, it would not be surprising if, in the consideration of this matter, they looked carefully at their own home town. I think these are real problems and because it is such a fundamental issue—
—It is an important question.
—It is an important question. If I could have the names of the members of that board and if I could also have just where their home town is, that would be of particular interest.
—I will even find out the colour of their socks!

—The Minister does not have to do that. But I think it is a very important policy decision. I hope the ABC board will recognise the point that not only is there a concentration of ABC TV activities in Sydney already but also that the other taxpayer funded TV channel, run by the Special Broadcasting Service, is located in Sydney. I put it to the ABC board, of which I think four members come from Sydney and the rest from other places in Australia—
—How many regional ones?

—I do not think the Minister is concentrating fully here. I put it to the board that it is a matter in the wider context of just how the ABC sees its role as a national broadcaster and whether it is prepared to continue to concur with the view that so much of ABC activities will be located in Sydney.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Transport and Communications)

TALK.START.PARA: —I have been mentally going around the table of the board—I have had the pleasure of being at board meetings. There is a pretty fair spread, actually. There is a South Australian, there is a Western Australian—
—Which board are we talking about?

—The ABC board. There is certainly at least one Melburnian; considering the quality of people from Melbourne, there only needs to be one. Someone from Melbourne is probably worth three people from anywhere else! That is my recollection. We will certainly provide Senator Kemp with a list of the board members. There is a conscious decision taken to provide a regional spread as well as a skills spread, and I think the honourable senator will find that it is pretty well spread in regional terms. I do not think there is a Tasmanian on it; there is certainly not a Territorian on it. There is a Territorian on the SBS board. I do not know how I missed out there—I will have a look at that. But in terms of the major States, I think there is a reasonable spread. I will provide Senator Kemp with a list of the members of the board and of any of the subsidiaries that are involved in this, and he can go for his life.

—I thank the Minister. I seek his further assistance by asking that he put it to the board that perhaps it is time to relook at whether more needs to be done in the way of making sure that the ABC is a more properly regional organisation and less an organisation that is concentrated in Sydney.

PARA.TAB: I am very happy for my own statistics to be carefully assessed by the ABC board, and if in due course it wishes to make a response I would welcome that. But I think the ABC board now needs to reconsider, particularly because so much of its management is based in Sydney. Despite the best will in the world, because of the way head offices perform it is natural that, when choices are made on resources, staffing levels and where production facilities will be located, there often tends to be a bias towards the home town.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is what the honourable senator would have towards his home town.

—Fair enough. But what I would like is for the ABC board now to look very closely at just what its responsibilities are as a national broadcaster and to other capital cities, and whether there is substance, as I believe there is, in suggestions that the Australian Broadcasting Corporation is now becoming too much the Sydney broadcasting corporation. Perhaps the Minister could say whether he would be prepared to seek a response from the ABC board and seek a review of the particular issue of whether too many resources are concentrated in one capital city.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Transport and Communications)

TALK.START.PARA: —I will take those concerns directly to the chairman of the board, Mark Armstrong. I just make this point to Senator Kemp, and I am sure it is one he would acknowledge: the ABC does have an absolutely finite budget. It is, quite rightly, regularly scrutinised and often rigorously criticised in respect of that budget. Regionalisation is very important but there is a cost attached to it, and I am very conscious of that in respect of TV Asia in Darwin. The two sites that were being carefully considered for the location of TV Asia—I hate to reveal this to Senator Kemp—were Darwin and Melbourne. That was legitimately so, because Radio Australia is based in Melbourne and possibly it would have been cheaper to locate it in Melbourne.

PARA.TAB: In political terms—and I use that term in its broadest sense—it would have been very retrograde to have based the Asian service in Melbourne when it is trying to interact with the region. When the ABC carefully balanced the cost of locating staff to Darwin and the necessary travel and administrative arrangements, the final decision was to locate it in Darwin. I will raise these matters directly with the chairman of the board and Mr Hill. The only reason I mention it is that, as I am sure Senator Kemp would acknowledge, one thing that would obviously have to be considered in regionalising would be the administrative cost of setting up in another city, wherever that is, facilities which may already be provided in Sydney or somewhere else.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister for that comment. I hope that, with the logic he expressed, we are not going to see Radio Australia located in Darwin, too, but I am sure that was not his intention. Once a large range of facilities is located in a particular city, there will inevitably be pressure to locate more and more of the growth of an organisation in that city, so I welcome the constructive response the Minister made to my suggestion. I would like to see a proper analysis done by the board, which I think has a responsibility to all taxpayers who pay their 8c a day to the ABC, to make sure that there is not an undue concentration of activities in Sydney.

PARA.TAB: The final point I would like to raise goes back to the issue of where ABC TV should be headquartered. The Minister was forthcoming enough to indicate that some 240 jobs would be created in a reasonably short period by the establishment of ABC pay TV. I think one of the officers from the ABC indicated that there would be very substantial knock-on effects, and I have no reason to query this. I have three questions for the Minister. First, is any study available that can help quantify those knock-on effects—the multiplier effects and the other jobs which would come about through the establishment of ABC pay TV? I realise that the Minister may not have the material here, but I would be very interested to see that. Secondly, when would the Minister anticipate a final decision being made on the location of ABC pay TV?

Thirdly, prior to that decision being made by the board, will the board and its officers make sure they consult with all relevant people in Melbourne? I am sure they will do this in the Sydney area. I know, for example, that the Committee for Melbourne has a particular interest in this matter, and I have no doubt the Premier would also have a particular interest in this matter. I am sure Senator Carr, who is in the chamber, has a great interest in this matter as well. Would it be possible for the Minister to give me an assurance that before a decision is made there will be widespread consultation with relevant people in Victoria?

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Transport and Communications)

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a better suggestion for Senator Kemp, and this will be my coup de grace on him. The chairman of the board of the ABC comes from Melbourne. I do not think there would be any difficulty at all if Senator Kemp were to contact the chairman of the board of the ABC as a fellow Melburnian. I am sure Professor Armstrong would be delighted to speak to him personally about this matter, and I will ring him and suggest it. He could provide Senator Kemp directly with the information about the resolution of this issue. Senator Kemp can directly lobby him about his preferred site for the office, and Professor Armstrong can give Senator Kemp the detailed technical information he wants.

PARA.TAB: I advise the committee, as a courtesy, that I have to absent myself temporarily from the Committee because I have to go off and sign an air services agreement with the Prime Minister of Vietnam.

TALK.START.PARA: —Make sure you read it first.

—No, I think it would be bad protocol to do that. I am just expected to sign it. I have read it already and it is very satisfactory. My absence should be only a short one, and I will return to the chamber as soon as I have signed the agreement.

PARA.TAB: The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN (Senator Chapman)—We have covered the general issues on program 2, Broadcasting. We will move to subprogram 2.2, Australian Broadcasting Corporation, and subprogram 2.3, Special Broadcasting Service.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ferguson Sen A.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I nearly had some questions that I would have had to raise under unanswered questions, but once we started the hearing on Estimates Committee E last night some of the answers were delivered to my office. I am sorry that the Minister for Transport and Communications (Senator Collins) is not here because there are one or two questions that I would have liked to ask him specifically, but I think I can ask them in general terms. I need some clarification on some of the answers that were delivered to my office last night.

PARA.TAB: At the hearing, I provided a question on notice regarding the National Transmission Agency and the review at which it will be considered whether the NTA becomes a government business enterprise. As I said, I only received the answers last night, but now that I have had some time to consider them, I have one or two points that I wish to have clarified. In answer to my questions Nos 4 and 5 about the NTA earning revenue from the ABC, and whether the ABC's budget would be increased to cover transmission fees charged by the NTA, it is stated:

SPEECH.PARA: As part of its review of the NTA to commence later this year, the Government will consider not only whether to convert the NTA to a government business enterprise, but also whether funds should be transferred to the ABC and the SBS to pay for transmission services.

What I would really like to know is: does this mean that the NTA could be converted to a government business enterprise and charge the ABC and the SBS transmission fees, but that funds might not be transferred to the ABC and SBS?

TALK.START.PARA: —No, it does not. The funds would be transferred to the ABC and the SBS.
—Can I take it from the Senator's answer that we can be absolutely guaranteed that the ABC's appropriations will be increased to cover the total cost of transmission fees?
—We can only give a guarantee in so much as we do not know, at this stage, what the amount of money will be. We cannot give an absolute guarantee at this point in time.

—In response to that answer, a problem could arise, of course, if the ABC has to meet the cost of those transmission fees. Unless the Government is prepared to guarantee whatever the cost of those transmission fees will be over and above its existing budget, its budget could effectively be decreased if it is not fully reimbursed for any cost of transmission fees.

—The review has not started, so, given that the review has not started, it is not finished. Until the review has been completed, with some idea of what the costings are, it is very difficult to give the absolute guarantee that Senator Ferguson seeks.
—In the light of that answer, is it possible for Senator Sherry to tell me what funding is currently provided to the NTA for services to the ABC? Is it in the order of $70 million to $80 million?
—Senator Ferguson is correct. It is in the order of $80 million and it does not cover just the ABC; it also covers the SBS.

—In light of that response, let me say that, if the Government is not prepared to guarantee that these transmission fees would be appropriated to the ABC in addition to its current budget, it would make somewhat of a mockery of the Government's criticism of the coalition's policy prior to the election of cutting funds of $60 million to the ABC because, unless the Government can guarantee that those transmission fees will be appropriated and that the full cost of those transmission fees will be met by the Government, then in effect it is a backdoor way of cutting funds to the ABC. So there would need to be some sort of guarantee that any transmission costs would be met by the Government in the appropriations.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I just do not think our approach at the election in criticising Senator Ferguson's party and its policy is relevant to this issue.
—It is relevant if you cut their funds.

—It is, but we are not proposing to cut the moneys because the review has not started, as I have already said. One of the roles of the review, as I understand, is to identify exactly what these costs are. We cannot give any guarantees as to covering of costs if we do not even know what the costs are. Once the review has commenced, and when it is concluded and those costs are identified, the Government will have to determine, through policy, what those costs will be covered by. But it is premature now to seek assurances, given that we do not even know what the costs are.

—It may be premature to identify exact amounts, but surely it is not premature for the Government to give some guarantee that the transmissions costs, whatever they may be, which costs are going to be in addition to what the ABC currently spends if the NTA becomes a government business enterprise, are covered so that there would not effectively be any cut in the ABC's funding.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)
