TALK.START.PARA: —I really cannot add anything to what I have said. Senator Ferguson raises a valid concern. It will be considered as part of the review. It does remind me a little about the speculation involving the general development of the current Government's budget. People can speculate all they like about a range of options but, as I say, the review has not commenced; and when it finishes, we will have some idea what the costs will be and how we will deal with them.

—On a separate issue: during the hearing of Estimates Committee E I asked about a saving of $11 million in expenditure listed under the heading `Division 971—Capital works and services—broadcasting and television', relating to the provision and installation of radio and television transmitters and ancillary buildings, works and technical equipment for national broadcasting. I was informed during the hearing that this $11 million had originally been appropriated for a number of projects involving the provision of new transmitters and totally new facilities to distribute ABC radio and television programs. I would now like to further ask: how many transmitters will now not be provided this financial year and where in Australia were they to be located?

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, I can provide the honourable senator with some further details. The $11 million was primarily the result of deferrals in two major projects. Those two major projects were the refurbishment of a lower section of the Gore Hill tower in Sydney, for a deferral of $5.35 million, and the construction of a new transmission facility at Mount Wellington, Hobart, for a deferral of $4.5 million. To allow the refurbishment of Gore Hill to proceed, the NTA must arrange to relocate the transmission facilities for SBS TV to another site. The NTA has been negotiating a sharing agreement with the commercial owners of the Seven/Ten tower at Artarmon, Sydney, where it is intended to place this service.

PARA.TAB: The NTA has also been involved in complicated negotiations with the Hobart City Council regarding the approval to construct a new tower on Mount Wellington, at $4.5 million, to replace the existing tower, which has reached the end of its viable life. Due to the need to dedicate resources to establishing new activities that the NTA is now required to undertake, particularly the tendering of major projects, planning for several smaller projects has also been delayed, resulting in the need for deferred additional expenditure of $1.15 million. All of the funding for the projects deferred from 1992-93 will be spent on these projects in 1993-94.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before asking the next question, let me say that I totally endorse the remarks of Senator Kemp when it comes to the concentration of facilities and services and the jobs that are provided in regard to what he referred to as the Sydney broadcasting corporation. I emphasise that point when we consider some of the facilities that are provided to regional radio and television. Having been in many of those studios and having seen the conditions that some of the employees work under in rural and regional Australia, I have nothing but admiration for the job that they do. I note that some $5.4 million is to be spent in Sydney. If Senator Kemp were here, he would probably agree with me that, if that could be better spent elsewhere, we would be very pleased.
—At Port Pirie.
—The honourable senator would like that one at Mount Wellington.
—I am very happy about that.

—I will not argue about that one at all. The other question I should ask is about some other smaller decisions that have been deferred. Which radio and television networks besides those that have been mentioned are likely to be delayed because of the decision? For instance, does it mean that Radio National might not be extended to certain areas of Queensland or rural Australia?

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —We do not have the details of the breakdown of the $1.15 million as a result of the delay in that area. The department will provide the honourable senator with the breakdown. The example he gives at this point is just speculation. We will give him the precise details.
—Is it the first time that these particular projects that were mentioned before have been delayed?
—I am advised that it is not unusual for delay to occur in these sorts of projects. So it is not the first time it has occurred.

—If it is not the first time these projects have been delayed, were there any particular reasons why they could not go ahead this year? What particularly has changed since the Government requested the appropriation of the $11 million?

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am advised that the reason for the delay over the last year is that the NTA has only just been established as an organisation. The NTA previously had Telecom do the work for it. There was no process of competitive tendering. The reason for the delay is that the NTA has been established only in the last year and has now moved to the competitive tendering process. A lot more time has been involved in setting up that process rather than simply relying on Telecom to do the job.
—I ask the Parliamentary Secretary why the ABC was not made aware of how this saving of $11 million would impact on the transmission of its programs.

—I am advised that the ABC has been aware of the ongoing problems in the construction of these facilities. I am advised that there is a meeting today in order to discuss these matters. When the honourable senator refers to problems with broadcasting, I would have to say, firstly, that I am certainly not aware of any problems in the southern area of Tasmania. From first-hand knowledge I am certainly not aware that there have been any problems in that State as a result of this delay. We are not aware that there have been any problems with broadcasting in Sydney, either, as a result of the delays.

—I did not say that there had been any problems involved with broadcasting. The question I ask is why the ABC was not made aware. My office has been in contact with at least a couple of senior people in the ABC who have said that they were not aware of this saving of $11 million. The ABC forms 85 per cent of the NTA's client base. Surely it should have been made aware of decisions about this saving of $11 million; surely it should have been made aware of whether this would have any impact on any of its programs. I would have thought that, if I were selling a service to a client which was 85 per cent of my client base, I would at least be consulting with the consumer and putting it in a position of knowing exactly what was happening. I am just surprised that the ABC was not consulted or informed about this and that it had not been made aware immediately of the decision that there would be a saving of $11 million in this program.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am advised that the ABC has been informed about the construction work in these two major projects that have been delayed. In one sense, the money is not relevant. The important thing to the ABC is the construction or otherwise of the facilities, and it has been kept informed about the deferral of these two projects. The only other point I would make is that these are two projects; another 55 projects have come on line in the last year. So it is two out of 57, albeit major projects, when we look at the expenditure there.

—Can the NTA give a guarantee that these projects will go ahead next financial year and that other projects that are planned for 1993-94 will not be pushed back to 1994-95 as a result of this? In other words, is this delaying of expenditure to the next financial year just going to be a complete saving, or is there some guarantee that money that would have been expended next year will still be spent?

—I can give that undertaking. I refer the honourable senator to the last sentence of my first answer, where I stated that all of the funding for the projects deferred from 1992-93 will be spent on these projects in 1993-94, including the Gore Hill tower and the Mount Wellington tower.

—Finally, I want to make quite clear and put on the record the importance of the ability of the ABC to transmit and to broadcast to all Australians. I note Senator Kemp's comments earlier; we understand that the services that are provided to people in the more highly populated areas would be greater and have more variety than those provided to people who are receivers of those services in outback rural and regional Australia.

PARA.TAB: The service that the ABC provides to people in remote areas is sometimes the only form of communication, the only form of broadcasting and radio that people in those areas can receive. People rely on it entirely for their news; they rely on it entirely for many other information programs. Certainly, the ABC is held in very high regard in all of those areas, both for the quality of its service and, in most cases, for its ability to transmit news to people in those areas.

A cut in funding, particularly for transmission purposes, which would affect the ability of people to receive the services of the ABC would certainly be detrimental to those people. I would like to think that we could have some guarantee that the Government would continue to provide the services and to expand the services to those people who need it the most—people who have no other option and no other means of getting radio broadcasting or television.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I certainly share Senator Ferguson's concern about the ABC and the importance that it plays in rural and regional areas. I will certainly transmit those concerns to the Minister. I am sure that he will transmit his concerns to his own party when it reviews its policies in this area.

—I have some unanswered questions on subprogram 6.2 which dealt with salary levels corresponding to those of non-APS agencies. Could I be assured that I will get an answer to those questions as soon as possible?

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not sure whether I have been shown what Senator Ferguson has been provided with. Is that not in sufficient detail for his purposes? If he could perhaps indicate where it is insufficient, we can try to sort out with the department what additional information can be provided.

—I do not have it with me, unfortunately. I asked to be provided with a table which lists full-time positions and corresponding levels of salary in the department and the non-APS agencies. You are saying that that has been answered?

—I am informed that what you have requested over and above what has already been provided—just looking through, it is considerable data—is quite a massive task. The department will endeavour, within a reasonable time frame, to obtain the type of information that you are seeking. I understand that Senator Collins is on his way to the chamber. When he gets here, perhaps we can look in some detail at the salary levels.

—I take the opportunity of asking the Minister about Port Pirie. I have interjected a couple of times about the importance of regional radio and television in my own State. I am aware of the ABC's interests in Port Pirie, and I just take that as one example of decentralised initiatives within the ABC. Are you confident that adequate resources are available for regional broadcasting, and that the ABC is living up to its proper mandate to ensure that those who live in regional areas, remote from our capital cities, are receiving the very best from the ABC?
—Before I call Senator Sherry, I just mention that Senator Collins will be further delayed, so after this question it might be better if we deal with the next committee report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry Sen The Hon N.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —In answering that question, I share your concerns and I appreciate the spirit in which it was asked. It was endeavouring to resolve a delay of some sort. I am not sure what standard Port Pirie's facilities are but certainly, coming from a regional State, I think they are very important. I will take up your suggestion, Mr Chairman.

PARA.TAB: Motion (by Senator Sherry) agreed to:
That further consideration of Estimates Committee E, as it relates to subprogram 2.6 of the Department of Transport and Communications, be postponed.

SPEECH.PARA: REPORT OF ESTIMATES COMMITTEE F

PARA.TAB: Motion (by Senator Sherry) proposed:
That the report of Estimates Committee F, as it relates to the Appropriation Bill (No. 5) 1992-93, be adopted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Committee will now consider expenditure examined by Estimates Committee F, as it relates to the executive departments. The first department to be considered is the Attorney-General's Department.

—I put in a reservation on the questions I asked the Attorney-General's Department about the Law Enforcement Access Network, commonly known as LEAN. Because of the time of the evening the Minister was rather anxious to get the matter settled. I am not saying he was trying to rush matters through, but on looking at some of the answers I received I noted that the answers on that particular night were almost identical with the answers I received on 10 September last year. If the officers had been here, I was going to ask them how much progress had been made on the letting of tenders for this computer program. In the Estimates previous to last September's Estimates I asked questions about LEAN and about whether the privacy guidelines that were a matter of concern to the Privacy Commissioner were any further advanced.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOLKUS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Multicultural Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —Given the state we are in with the necessary officers not being here, I offer to take Senator Calvert's questions and write to him very early in the recess rather than have him go through the mechanical process of putting questions on notice. We will take on board the points he has just raised and respond to him, hopefully in the course of the next fortnight.
—Does the Minister want me to put on notice all the questions I have regarding LEAN?
—I think maybe a good way of doing it is for Senator Calvert to give them to me and have me take them up for him, but he could have them incorporated into the Hansard now.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Calvert Sen P.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —If you make a note of my concerns, that is fine. I also raise a privacy matter that is of concern to the general public and has been raised before. It is about the number of terminals involved. We have had conflicting evidence given to us over a period about whether there were going to be 2,000 or 10,000 computer terminals. The last figure I received was 10,500.

PARA.TAB: My last question is one I raised back in September. When I raised it this time I was told that we have a preferred tenderer, we have conducted very extensive contractual negotiations, and we are close to entering into a contract. I want to know whether the department is still using Admiral Computing, the advisers they contracted from the UK at a cost of over $200,000 for six weeks work. I want to know whether they are still being engaged.

My main concern is that when Senator Vanstone, Senator Hill and I were asking questions about it—I am just checking back through—it was more or less indicated to us in September that the whole thing was going to be satisfied and completed. Mr Reaburn said:

SPEECH.PARA: I cannot be precise as to when I anticipate a conclusion because it depends upon the process of our discussions.

Senator Vanstone said, `This year?', and Mr Reaburn said yes. I got the same answer this time, and I want to know why it has taken so long and what are the problems. They were the major concerns I had on that particular matter.

PARA.TAB: I had two questions on notice that were answered after the report was received and I wanted to ask some questions on those. It seems that we have not got any officers here. With your indulgence, Mr Chairman, could I read those questions into the Hansard? They concern the Iranian Embassy debacle. I note in the answer that was given to me that I had asked how much had been spent over the last 12 months on guarding the Iranian Embassy. I received the staggering information that the cost of guarding the Iranian Embassy was some $2,084,440 for less than one year. That equates to $40,000 a week and, having talked to some service personnel, it equates to at least two platoons of military personnel. I wonder whether I could get a breakdown of those costs because we have gone from the sublime to the ridiculous.

When we had the inquiry last year, I think Senator Richardson was asking some very pointed questions about the whole mess-up of the raid on the Iranian Embassy that almost ended up like the Keystone Cops. We had all those different agencies involved—the Australian Federal Police, ASIO, the Australian Protective Service, DFAT, and the Protective Security Coordination Centre. All of them knew what was going to happen, or they believed they did, but they did not tell each other. As a consequence, the whole thing went ahead, and we have the situation where this Government and the taxpayer ended up with a compensation bill of some $469,700, of which $187,200 was paid to the Iranian Government. That bill included $47,500 for damages to fixtures and fittings; payments to individuals from $55,000 down, totalling $282,500; and, quite incredibly, an amount of $US65,000 that was given to them because it was allegedly stolen during the raid.

Since then, of course, we have had the situation where 11 are going to a full trial. I would like to know whether the estimate of $1 million in legal aid still stands. As I said, coming on top of the more than $2 million that has been spent since in a classic case of shutting the gate after the horse has bolted, the whole fiasco has ended up costing the taxpayer of Australia $3,553,700. I would like to know whether there is any likelihood over the next 12 months of that amount for guarding the Iranian Embassy being reduced. Okay, we have got the people here now, have we?

TALK.START.PARA: —No, we haven't.
—So the Minister wants me to hurry up and finish.
—That's right.

—I have only been waiting four days to ask these questions. I do not know why I bothered coming in. Everybody else has been rabbiting on for weeks. This matter is of particular interest to me. I am concerned about what seems to me to be a waste of $3 1/2 million of taxpayers' money because of bungling by people who are paid a very good wage. The answer to the other question, which I received the other night, was that we have an obligation to protect foreign diplomats under the Vienna Conventions on Diplomatic and Consular Relations. I do not argue with that. It went on to say `particularly where protection agencies have information about possible attacks or where the assessment of risk is high'.

PARA.TAB: That is exactly what happened last year. There was information about possible attacks and there was an assessment of a high risk, yet nothing was done. I would like to know how much was spent last year on guarding the embassies prior to the attack. Now we have a situation where we are spending millions of dollars on guarding one particular embassy. That is of major concern to me, as is the answer I received regarding the cost of the War Crimes Prosecutions Support Unit, where we have spent $2,064,000 with no result. I would like to know how much in total has so far been spent on the War Crimes Prosecutions Support Unit. Is more money going to be spent on it in the future? If so, how much?

In the interests of my colleagues who will be making valedictory speeches later today, I will leave it at that. If the Minister could answer most of the questions I have raised, I would appreciate it.

TALK.START.PARA: —The situation is that, by leave, we went back to the Attorney-General's Department. We have finished the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, but as Senator Short wants to ask some questions on that area we might go back to that department by leave.

—Thank you very much, Mr Chairman. I have a range of questions that I want to put to the Minister. They are rather specific. In view of the time, I am quite agreeable to reading the questions into the Hansard. If the Minister would give me an undertaking, as was given to Senator Calvert in relation to Attorney-General's, to give some responses early in the recess, that would suit me. Senator Knowles has some questions that she would like to ask as well and she has kindly agreed to put the questions on my behalf because I have another pressing commitment. With your indulgence, Mr Chairman, we could do it that way.
—That is fine.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOLKUS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Multicultural Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —That process is acceptable to me. Obviously, some questions might take a bit longer than most to respond to. If I can anticipate those as Senator Knowles is asking them, I will try to do so, but we will try to get answers to Senator Short early in the recess.

—There are a number of questions, as Senator Short has said, and I would like to go through them in categories. The first ones are about the handling of the boat people. As the Minister would be aware, we have continued to express our concern that the Minister has ruled out any review of the Government's handling of the boat people currently being held in detention. Six hundred and eighty people have arrived in Australia by boat and there are some 222 people currently in detention, with 13 cases before the courts and 93 cases remaining to be processed by the department. Therefore, I ask the Minister: are there other groups of people awaiting decisions on whether they qualify for refugee status who are currently living in the Australian community—for example, the numbers of people who arrived here on visitor visas and who then applied for refugee status? What support does the Government provide to these sorts of people?

PARA.TAB: I ask the Minister also: what proportion are the refugees who have been visaed from the former Yugoslavia of the total refugee intake? What percentage are they of the total immigration intake? How much more money will the department allocate to the refugee humanitarian program this year? How many refugees have been settled in Australia from families in Bosnia? How much has the department allocated to administering this program to 30 June 1993? With regard also to refugees, from where has the department obtained its legal advice concerning the boat people? How much has that advice cost? What sort of advice has the department received from Attorney-General's and has Attorney-General's commented on the Burdekin comment about detaining the boat people?

I now move on to the Chinese students. It is concerning to us that the Government has still failed to make a decision concerning 26,000 people currently in Australia who are eligible to stay in Australia until June 1994 with a special category of temporary resident permit, as a result of Prime Minister Hawke's commitment in 1990. We are aware that, although the Minister claims that the Government does not need to make a decision about these people until next year, this issue is of ongoing importance and concern to the community. That is shown by the report in the Australian of 21 May this year of a Chinese student who had originally been granted one of the special permits but was trying to re-apply for refugee status following his return to Australia after a visit to China.

I put the question to the Minister: how many of the people in Australia with the special temporary S437 visa have exited Australia since being granted their visas? How many have returned to the PRC, either permanently or on holiday? How many have sought to return to Australia, in the same way as the student who was reported in the Australian of 21 May as having been back to China for three months and was now re-applying for refugee status?

There is a further area of concern. We referred earlier to a Japanese crime boss but the questions have not yet been responded to. Senator Bolkus told the Senate on 12 May 1993 that Mr Takumi entered Australia on a multiple visa which had been issued before he had a criminal record. Why has the Government allowed a senior crime boss—reportedly No. 2 in the Yakuza in Japan—seemingly free access to Australia? What sort of visa does Mr Takumi hold? Is it a tourist, visitor or business visa? Does Mr Takumi conduct business in Australia? If so, what sort of business? Why was the visa not cancelled when his activities and criminal background were first discovered?

There is a further question on grants-in-aid. Could the Minister provide a list of grants to community groups, including the amount to each group, its purpose and the date of approval of the funding. The savings of $244,000 are listed under voluntary agencies and community groups. Where have the savings been made? Have the savings affected the level and number of grants-in-aid to community organisations, and what was the $3.098 million budgeted to go as a grant to the Australian Red Cross Society for the asylum seeker assistance scheme? Why has it been possible to make a saving of this particular grant? The citizenship question has a number of other areas associated with it, so I ask: what proportion of permanent residents take out citizenship, and how many people who have been permanent residents for five years or more have not become citizens? How do Australia's requirements for eligibility for citizenship compare with other major OECD countries? I do not know whether the Minister wants to make a response to any of those questions at the moment.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is that all you have?
—I just want to go through and check whether I have any further questions here.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOLKUS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Multicultural Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —While Senator Knowles does that, in respect of all those questions we could probably come back with answers. In respect of the one on the Japanese person, I am taking a keen interest in pursuing that to ensure that we have sufficient and adequate quality evidence on which to base any decision that might be made in this matter. In respect to the PRC, having met with representatives of most parts of that community, the Parliament can be assured that that issue is getting ongoing attention. With any decisions that have to be made, we do have until the end of June 1994 to do so—though it would be helpful to make them before that date.

PARA.TAB: In respect of the question of detention, and while Senator Knowles is looking through the questions, I take this opportunity once again to state that we are talking about a regime which had support from both sides of the Parliament. I have not witnessed a policy shift from the other side on the issue of detention in circumstances such as the ones we are talking about. That support came at a time which was quite relevant in that legislation was before the Parliament towards the end of last year and that support was there then. I also ask people who enter into this debate to realise that not all of the time these people spent in detention has been spent awaiting government decision. In respect of one batch, there was a 17-month period during which government was waiting for an application for refugee status from some of the applicants. Also keep in mind that we have extended rights while some of these people have been in detention. I think Senator Knowles is now ready to proceed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Knowles Sen S.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have another couple of questions. Just how much money has the department so far allocated to legal assistance for the illegal entrants who are appealing the decisions of the department since November 1989? What are the exact costs to date associated with litigation outside the refugee process? How many illegal immigrants are being serviced by the particular administrative expenses associated with them? Just how many people are involved in the management and administration of the detainees—those who are in charge of the boat people?
—Does that include those who have to prepare answers to Senate questions on those issues? We will take them on board.
—That concludes the consideration of the estimates for Committee F. I put the question: That the report of Estimates Committee F be agreed to.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.PARA: REPORT OF ESTIMATES COMMITTEE E

PARA.TAB: Consideration resumed.

TALK.START.PARA: —The item from Estimates Committee E that was postponed was subprogram 2.6, communication selection team.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ALSTON
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to ask a question in relation to the role of Professor Pearce. As I understand it from the second Pearce report, Professor Pearce has been retained by the department for further ongoing inquiry work. Could the Minister enlighten the Senate and, if possible, table any terms of reference?

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Transport and Communications)

TALK.START.PARA: —The issue is not for further inquiry. I think he is being retained for a matter that Senator Alston will probably support. One thing I want to say about the Pearce report is that I am not a lawyer—I am not a failed law student, either—and I do not know why Senator Alston keeps on saying that. I had no presumptions ever to be a lawyer.
—Did you not do one year of law?

—I did, indeed. I did not fail. I did so, not from any desire to get a law degree, but because of the great interest I have in law. In fact, I enjoyed the introductory law unit that I did that year. I was going to say that, although I am not a lawyer, I do admire the way in which lawyers think. I think Professor Pearce has done a very forensic examination of the problem in the department. It was laid out in a very tough manner, as he said, by Mr Hutchinson, in the report dealing with the inconsistencies. The reason I refer to Professor Pearce's report is that he does make a recommendation that—he acknowledges that this is, to some extent, going beyond the terms of reference—some training is required in the department on these questions of law and, if you like, the precedence of law.
—A re-education process.
—Not an expression I would have used.
—A Vietnamese expression.

—I am pleased to say that I have just signed an air services agreement with the Vietnamese Government which effectively advances what is a growing aviation market between our two countries. Professor Pearce makes the recommendation that training is required. I think that is very supportable, in terms of the errors that have been disclosed by Mr Hutchinson's report, particularly dealing with these inconsistencies. Professor Pearce made the extremely illuminating statement that, and I think this is probably getting to the heart of the matter, departmental officers probably had a predisposition to consider the question of policy more important than these very technical legal matters—the legal niceties, if you like, of actually getting the process right.
—We don't think that, do we?

—No, I do not think that. It is for that reason that training was recommended. It is my understanding that Professor Pearce is being retained to assist in that training within the department. I could not think of anyone better qualified for the task. In addition to that, I received a letter—that is why I was delayed; I was looking for it—from the Secretary to the department relating to these issues. The matter that we are talking about now is referred to in paragraph 1. I would like to table that letter. Perhaps Senator Alston can be given a copy of it straight away.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ALSTON
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —What is the estimated total cost of the inquiries undertaken by Professor Pearce? Could a full breakdown be provided, including remuneration to, I presume, both Professor Pearce and Dr Swanton.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Transport and Communications)

TALK.START.PARA: —I will certainly provide Senator Alston with that advice. Dr Swanton is a senior officer of the department so there will not be any additional remuneration for him. Professor Pearce, as I understand it, will be paid for the work that he has done at the standard rate for this kind of work. I have not had any information about that. I will take that question on notice and provide Senator Alston with a reply as soon as I can.

—Has the department made any attempt to calculate the full cost of the series of problems relating to both tender processes? I include in that the opportunity cost of the time that officers have been required to spend on these matters when they might have been attending to other duties.

—I think that at this stage the answer is no, although that is a relevant question and can be addressed at some time in the future. I will try to get as good a guesstimate as possible of what that might be. There would also be the legal costs associated with the matter. I might say, though, that I was particularly interested to read the research paper produced by Sydney University. As regrettable as this entire matter has been—and it is extremely regrettable—and as important and necessary as it is to carry out the recommendations that have been made by Professor Pearce and, indeed, the action that has already been flagged by the secretary to the department, the problems fortunately are capable of resolution.

PARA.TAB: One may compare these matters with previous incidents canvassed in terms of departmental problems. The two spectacular ones were the Asia Dairy affair and the meat substitution scandal, which almost destroyed a billion-dollar-a-year export industry for Australia. The fortunate thing about these recent problems is that, in the first instance—that is, the satellite—they have been substantially corrected by legislation which passed through this Parliament and became law about two weeks ago, and, in the case of the MDS matters, they are properly before the Federal Court.

I conclude on that point by saying that there have been some assumptions made about the resolution of the MDS tender problems, in respect of government taking decisions on this. That is not what is happening at all. I advise honourable senators, as I have done previously, that the very first action that the Commonwealth took, that Cabinet decision having been made, was to place the matter immediately before the Federal Court, which is in every sense in charge of the matter. As I understand it, the situation now is that the court has determined that the tender process should remain open until 28 May but at that point be frozen while the legal arguments are being canvassed.

I might also tell Senator Alston that I have done what I previously told the Senate I would do; that is, I have asked the lawyers who are acting for the Commonwealth to explore with the legal representatives of Mr Stokes, in the normal way, whether the matter can be properly brought to a resolution which will safeguard the interests of the Government and the tenderers who are involved in the process.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ALSTON
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —Is it correct, as reported earlier in the week, that additional technical deficiencies have recently been identified? There was a report in the Australian Financial Review on Monday, I think, which suggested that counsel for the Commonwealth had advised Mr Stokes's solicitors that further technical deficiencies had come to light.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Transport and Communications)

TALK.START.PARA: —I will examine whether that is correct or not, but I have no difficulty in asserting that I am sure it is not. The proof of that is before the committee. I am still here alive but I think, quite honestly, that if I had been advised of that on Monday I probably would have had a terminal heart attack. I will organise now to get a copy of the newspaper article referred to but I think I can positively assert that, if that was the newspaper account, it is wrong. There are no further technical difficulties.

PARA.TAB: This is very comprehensively laid out in these two reports and also in the documentation that has been tabled in Parliament. They show all of the problems that have occurred and all of those matters are now before the Federal Court. I am told that the hearing is going to proceed expeditiously—both sides have asked for that—and I would expect the matter to be heard in the near future. To the best of my knowledge there are no further technical problems.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is it not the standard practice for the department to provide the Minister each day with a detailed written analysis of newspaper articles?
—That is what I am saying. I do not think the report is correct. Yes, I do get—
—Did you not get one in relation to this article?
—No. That is why I think it is wrong.
—You should have got a report saying it was wrong.

—This is all based on the assumption that what Senator Alston has told the committee is correct. I am sure that my staff are now watching the monitors and getting this information. I will say it again: I can positively assert—and the information is contained in here—that there are no further legal technical difficulties with the report. So far as Australian Financial Review articles are concerned, if I took the trouble to correct every mistake the Australian Financial Review has made, I would be doing nothing else except correcting the Australian Financial Review. From my perspective, I think the only times that Tom Burton would comply with the AJA code of ethics would be by accident. As I said the other day, the only conclusion I can draw from some of the Australian Financial Review reports has been that, when the Australian Journalists Association merged with Actors Equity, the code of ethics was amended to take consideration of that merger.

PARA.TAB: All I am saying—and I do not say this in a flippant manner—is that there have been a very large number of inaccuracies on this entire matter canvassed in the Australian Financial Review. For that reason, I am not altogether sure that one more would have been directly brought to my attention. I am sure that the article will arrive here momentarily. I think the substance is the important thing about this question, that is, there are no further technical difficulties with the process. I have just received the article in question. I must say that I cannot recall this particular column—there have been so many. I will just give it to the officers and ascertain whether they have any further advice.

The resolution the Commonwealth would like to bring about—and I have made this clear—is that the court would examine the legal argument and that the court would acknowledge that, even though the odds are very slim of the legal technicality being exploited in the way I have already canvassed in the Senate, now that it has been brought to the attention of the court it cannot be left to stand; and that the court would, in fact, issue new orders to allow the process to be restarted, with a new set of determinations, gazettal notices and information papers. That is the resolution we want to bring about. I am pleased in that regard. That is why I think a resolution is capable of being formed on this.

I was pleased therefore—and I told the Senate this—to see the public comments made by Mr Stokes, who, I think Senator Alston would agree, is probably the most aggrieved party. Certainly he is the party in the action. He has conceded publicly, having read the legal advice I provided him with—in other words, I have given him advance notice of the arguments we are going to run in court, which is not a normal procedure, as Senator Alston knows—that the earlier comments he made were made without reference to those articles. He has now conceded that he is satisfied that the Commonwealth's action in this matter has been, if you like, legitimate and was not for any ulterior purpose, and that there is a real legal problem that has to be addressed.

I would hope, from the Commonwealth's point of view, that the resolution to it would be that the court would agree with that and would issue new orders for a new process. To the best of my knowledge, there are no problems other than those laid out in these reports.

I have precise advice on this article now. The problem referred to in the Australian Financial Review article is the allocation problem additional to the technical determination problem in the notice. It is covered in the Hutchinson report and in the Gyles advice. The article referred to further problems. The further problems—and this has all been canvassed by the Senate—are not just the technical problems in the determination but the actual problems further down the track which would have occurred when the licences were being allocated. It is at that point that the, if you like, extreme case I canvassed in the Senate could have arisen.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister able to advise the Senate as to who was the first person to draft the notification?

—I cannot at this moment answer that question precisely. I have not had an opportunity to read the reports from cover to cover, but the entire process is meticulously laid out in these departmental reports, and I would agree with Professor Pearce that it is laid out in a way which is tough and glosses over nothing.

—In relation to the communications selection team, were any members advised of the possibility that prospective bidders for the satellite pay TV licences were able to, or intended to, make multiple bids?

—That question has been asked in the Senate estimates committee, and answered by Christine Goode. The advice that was given to the Senate estimates committee by Ms Goode was that people had advised the department that they would be putting in more than one bid.

—That report in the Financial Review seems to have been reasonably accurate, then. Does it follow from that that the department anticipated that from the outset, or that it was content to accept that when it became aware of the possibility?

—Nothing can be added to the answer already given in Senate Estimates, because it is the same question. To save going back for readers of the Hansard of the Committee of the Whole, I will read in that answer. Ms Goode says:

SPEECH.PARA: The newspaper references to what I was told are inaccurate. A number of people had said to me during February and March—after the court challenge to the Minister's January decision on the use of MDS—that the outcome of that court case, and therefore whether the direction would stand or not, might not be known by the time the satellite licence bids closed. They had said that they thought the outcome of that court case would affect the value of the satellite licences. Some people had said that they were contemplating putting in—and it was possible, they thought, to put in—two bids at different values.

Senator Tierney then asked what her reaction had been to that, and Ms Goode replied, `That is what I was told'. The reference is contained in the Hansard of Estimates Committee E of 11 May at page 111.

TALK.START.PARA: —Does it follow from that that that was the first time members of the department, particularly Ms Goode, became aware of the possibility that multiple bids could be lodged?
—The advice that I have received from the officer concerned was that that was the first time that she had had information that people were contemplating such a process.
—My question was whether the department had intended that from the outset.

—I think I would have known the answer to that just from reading the pile of papers, and Ms Goode has just confirmed it. The answer to the question is that that was not a matter contemplated by the officers of the department when this process was put together. In other words, the process was not deliberately designed to have that effect.
—Order! Normally at 12.45 p.m. I would report progress, but I understand that there is an agreement that we finish these estimates before I do that. Is that so?
—Mr Chairman, I am not aware of that personally but I indicate, on behalf of the Government, that I am perfectly happy to continue until the matter is concluded.
—Mr Chairman, I am not aware of an agreement either. I think, from our point of view, we would prefer that you report progress at this point.
—There being some confusion, I will report progress.

PARA.TAB: Progress reported.
The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Crichton-Browne)—Pursuant to order, I now call on matters of public interest.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: International Day of Action for Women's Health

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reynolds Sen The Hon M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to acknowledge that today a number of us are wearing Thursdays in Black badges, which is a concept that has been introduced by the World Council of Churches. It is the opportunity for women around the world to wear these black badges in solidarity with women in Argentina who march to demand where the missing are and Palestinian women who march to demand the end of occupation. Also, we are wearing black in solidarity with women around the world who are the victims of rape, violence against women and violence in war.

PARA.TAB: Tomorrow is the sixth International Day of Action for Women's Health. This year the campaign is for the prevention of maternal mortality and morbidity. The campaign is calling for action against illegal abortion, which is one of the most important causes of maternal mortality and morbidity. It is estimated, from the figures that we know about—there are probably many figures we do not know about because of the illegal nature of abortion in so many countries—that up to 200,000 women are dying of illegal abortions each year. So this year's theme, `Abortion: we shall no longer be silent about it!', is an important one for us to speak about in our own country, and certainly in solidarity with women around the world.

The International Day of Action for Women's Health began at the fifth International Women and Health Meeting in Costa Rica in May 1987. Tomorrow night, women around the world will light a candle for those women who have died from illegal abortions. This campaign is about abortion as a health issue and the right of all women to decide about their lives and bodies without unwanted intervention and harassment. It is about removing barriers, whether they be legal, social or economic, so that all women have access to the health care they are entitled to.

Just recently, I had the opportunity to debate this issue with a number of women attending a population and development conference in New York. It is an issue that is sensitive to individual views, individual cultures, individual religions, individual societies. It was very rewarding to be at a meeting of women from such diverse backgrounds and to find that we could unanimously agree that abortion is a health issue and should be regarded first and foremost as a health issue, an issue for women to consider in consultation with their doctors as a health issue.

At this meeting I was reminded of the range of opinions that could be accommodated by this expression of concern about maternal mortality and morbidity. Some of the statements that have been received for tomorrow's International Day of Action on Women's Health come from very diverse groups. I would like to read just a few of them. Catholics for a Free Choice state:

SPEECH.PARA: As Catholics we are pleased to add our name in support of the 1993 Call for Action which is focused on the problem of unsafe and illegal abortion. Polls show that Catholic people world-wide—from Italy to Poland to Mexico to the United States—understand the importance of and support a woman's right to choose abortion.
Regardless of particular religious views, it ultimately comes back to the individual. The International Women's Health Coalition states:

Each year, millions of women face unwanted pregnancy for a variety of reasons. The International Women's Health Coalition . . . works to insure that abortion services are made universally accessible for all women, and that laws and regulations that restrain these services are abolished. Women have a fundamental human right to make their own decisions about when and whether to bear children;
safe abortion is an essential means to exercise this right.
That is coupled with, of course, accessibility to safe contraception.ISIS International, Manila states:

We recognize that the issues of people's development, women's rights—reproductive rights in particular—and the environment are interrelated. It is within this framework that we have been discussing the issue of induced abortion. In the Philippines, our sisters have called on the public and private sectors to provide the full range of safe and effective contraceptive choices, including safe and legal abortions.
Finally, Women Living under Muslim Laws states:

Although we acknowledge, respect and learn from our mutual differences—for it is this variety which makes for the common wealth of humanity—we oppose the growing trend to use culture, religion, ethnicity, race, etc, against women in order to 1) `divide and rule' the globality of our demands as women, and 2) promote and justify anti-women policies.

PARA.TAB: In Muslim countries and communities reproductive rights have diverse interpretations: Muslim law may forbid contraception and abortion in one country, allow contraception and criminalize abortion in another . . .

SPEECH.PARA: All these countries claim that their policies reflect the true Islamic position.

PARA.TAB: Today, in speaking about abortion as a health issue, I cannot help giving a reminder to the Government of my State, where the Premier insists that abortion is still not on his agenda, that abortion is on the agenda of many people. The opinion polls that have been conducted in Queensland recently indicate that up to 70 per cent of Queenslanders believe that essentially abortion is an issue that should be debated and that certainly should not be regarded as a criminal activity. ALP policy indicates that the law should be amended so that all legal distinctions between termination of pregnancy and other medical procedures are abolished, by repealing sections 224, 225 and 226 of the Queensland Criminal Code.

We were very disappointed to find that, at the time of decriminalisation of homosexuality and decriminalisation of vasectomy in Queensland, abortion was not also decriminalised. I hope that we will continue in this place to debate these issues and to support the women's movement worldwide, which is working for greater recognition of women's reproductive rights.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today I rise to plead the case of Reg and Sylvia Faulkner, who are victims of a 20-year legal battle against the Commonwealth of Australia which has cost them their business, their home and their health in their struggle for justice.

PARA.TAB: Sylvia Faulkner should be an Australian success story—an Aussie icon. She was one of the very first women to succeed in the overwhelmingly male field of heavy engineering. In 1964, she set up her own engineering firm—at the behest of General Motors—to make motor parts. In 1968, she was the only woman finalist in the inaugural Prince Philip Prize for Australian Industrial Design. Her invention, the trisal clip, a reusable device that could connect heavy loads faster and more safely than conventional shackles, enabled the easy lifting of extremely heavy objects and had obvious wide application in industry.

The famous engineering firm of Vickers recognised the trisal clip's potential and went into partnership with Mrs Faulkner to manufacture and distribute the clip worldwide. Sylvia Faulkner's troubles began when the Australian Army, having made an initial order, procrastinated about taking the clip, allegedly because of an argument with the Army's engineer-in-chief over who should be chairman of the production company. The engineer-in-chief, incidentally, subsequently resigned after a worldwide police investigation into commercial deals. Sylvia Faulkner had invested $4.5 million of her family money gearing up for the development of the clip. However, the vital seed orders from the Australian Army never came, notwithstanding numerous letters and assurances that orders were forthcoming.

Sylvia Faulkner took legal action against the Commonwealth for breach of contract but was forced into bankruptcy because of repeated legal delays. It was a classic case of a defendant with deep pockets frustrating a plaintiff with only a case to argue. Again, we saw the resources of the Commonwealth pitted against an individual. It is never an equal struggle. In 1981 the now Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Evans, agreed with my colleague Mr Philip Ruddock that the delays were inexcusable and that the Faulkners' case was a classic example of poor administration. Indeed, so close was Senator Evans to the Faulkners that he agreed to sponsor them when they applied to become accredited international lobbyists.

Notwithstanding this, when the case finally came for trial in 1987, Senator Evans decided to stop legal aid in a decision with serious implications for natural justice. According to the Faulkners and their then legal representatives, in pre-trial negotiations the Commonwealth had suggested $850,000 as a possible settlement figure. The Solicitor-General was involved in this case, both as an adviser to the Commonwealth as the defendant and as arbiter of the Faulkners' case through the provision of legal aid. The Faulkners allege that the provision of confidential advice to the Solicitor-General for the purposes of obtaining continued legal aid may have influenced the Solicitor-General in his capacity as chief counsel for the Commonwealth.

After a discussion between the Faulkners' barrister and the Solicitor-General from which others were excluded, the Solicitor-General, in his capacity as arbiter of legal aid, then reversed an earlier commitment to cover all the Faulkners' legal costs, which meant that the Solicitor-General, in his capacity as Crown counsel, was almost guaranteed to win the case. The Faulkners' lawyer had advised that the case had a good chance of success provided overseas witnesses could be called. It was in the wake of this advice to the Solicitor-General that the grant of legal aid was amended to restrict the number of overseas witnesses who could be called.

My colleague Philip Ruddock has suggested that the Solicitor-General's potential conflict of interest, as both chief law officer of the Commonwealth and arbiter of legal aid, meant that this matter was not dealt with expeditiously. My colleague has suggested that, even though the Solicitor-General tried to put a `Chinese wall' between his twin roles, the coincidence between his learning of the nature of the Faulkners' case and his withdrawal of unconditional granting of legal aid raises at least the suspicion of abuse of power. The ACT President of the Council of Civil Liberties has taken up the case and states:

SPEECH.PARA: Early on, something went bad between Faulkner and the (Army) people . . . and after that, I think person after person on the side of the institutions did something silly or wrong or supported something wrong and the damage was overwhelming on the Faulkners.

PARA.TAB: Some very odd things have happened. Legal aid was restricted, the counsel confronted each other and told everyone else to leave. That's strange in itself. It's legitimately a matter for us to ask that individual rights and liberties are preserved from the point of view of the way the lawyers operated in this case.

SPEECH.PARA: I am not arguing today that the Faulkners' behaviour in this whole saga is utterly without blemish. I am not arguing that the rights and wrongs of this case are abundantly clear, but I am saying that the behaviour of the Solicitor-General raises very serious matters for concern.

PARA.TAB: If the Faulkners' very plausible allegation is correct, that the Solicitor-General used information obtained in one capacity improperly to influence him in another capacity, then the very integrity of our legal system is threatened. The ultimate rights and wrongs of this dispute are now shrouded in the mists of time, but it does seem that a settlement offer of close to $1 million was mentioned and it is clear that the Commonwealth withdrew that offer after its chief officer happened to learn the exact nature of the Faulkners' case and legal aid was curtailed to prevent them proving it.

Compared to the amount of money and time the Faulkners have lost in this pursuit, any settlement offer in the vicinity of the previous offer would seem to be little enough justice. There is so much money that governments waste, why not spend some on deserving people who have been put through living hell? In their own words now, they have got to the stage where they say, `Justice or we die'. I believe that the Government ought to renew the previous settlement offer to the Faulkners or, if that is inappropriate, consider the offer of a suitable ex-gratia payment in consideration of the pain and suffering they have experienced at the hands of government.

Government exists in order to do whatever is appropriate to secure a better life for its citizens. In particular, government exists to ensure that justice is done by one citizen to another. Everything that this Parliament does and every act of every government should be motivated by considerations of justice for individuals. Therefore, it is all the more important that the Government which demands justice of its citizens should do justice itself. Granting the Faulkners a measure of justice is certainly not going to set precedents for a host of hard luck claims. How many cases are there of the Commonwealth wearing two hats to frustrate longstanding litigation? It will merely demonstrate that the law of this land does not discriminate between the whale and the minnow.

In other words, the difficulty that is being presented here, that of obtaining information wearing one hat and the same person—an officer of the Government—using that information wearing another hat, is something that has brought about an injustice. I ask and recommend that the Government consider an ex-gratia payment around the sum previously offered to ensure that some justice is done at this late time.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to express concern about some comments made by the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Senator Bolkus) this morning during Matt Abraham's interview program on ABC radio. The comments about Mr Bernard Collaery follow a letter published in the Canberra Times by Mr Bernard Collaery headed, `Detention camps shame Australia'. In that letter Mr Collaery suggests that it is likely that the way in which we handle the detention of asylum seekers is in contravention of our obligations under international conventions. Senator Bolkus responded to this suggestion during the interview by saying that he would not go to Mr Bernard Collaery to run such a case.

PARA.TAB: I believe that that comment is not germane to the issue at hand. The Minister was not addressing the substance of it, he was casting aspersions on the legal professional skills of Mr Collaery. Bearing in mind that Mr Collaery is one of many human rights lawyers who are giving their time and energy free to take up cases of this nature, I believe that concern must be expressed that the Minister saw fit to use the occasion of this interview to reflect in this manner on Mr Collaery. It is likely to cause considerable damage to his professional standing.

At another point of the interview, Mr Bolkus saw fit to comment on some statement of Mr Collaery's by calling it a `mad loop' comment. I believe that is in the same category, Mr Acting Deputy President. I believe that it behoves us to deal with this issue, which is an extremely sensitive one, on the facts of the case and on the implications on international human rights and Australia's reputation and position.

TALK.START.PARA: —Criticism from Senator Bolkus would actually enhance his reputation.

—Yes, that may well be the case. Perhaps the Minister might like to add some comments about me, because I believe that we are running very close to being in contravention of our international human rights obligations by denying asylum seekers the opportunity to use natural justice and bias as defences in appeals against decisions about whether or not they can be classed as refugees—those being among the many that were withdrawn by legislation.

PARA.TAB: I believe that Australia's record on this issue is a shameful one, and that it means that people before Australian courts are not equal. It should make no difference whether the person before an Australian court is a citizen of Australia or an asylum seeker; but the fact is that this Parliament, at the behest of the Government, has passed legislation which makes these people less than equal before our courts. I believe that that is a contravention of basic human rights and that we should revisit this issue and examine very carefully Australia's standing in the international community. I believe we should be grateful to people such as Mr Bernard Collaery who raise issues like this, rather than denigrating them as the Minister has done.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Giles Sen P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —In case at some time in the future somebody should look through my contributions to the Parliament and wonder where I was between September and December 1992, and because the official report of the delegation to the United Nations will not be produced until I no longer have the opportunity of commenting on it, it seems sensible for me to use this opportunity to make a very brief report about that particular time, and about some other activities in which I was privileged to be involved earlier this year.

PARA.TAB: I am sure that the vast majority of people who take an intelligent interest in international affairs would be aware of the fact that senior officers of our Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade, experts on issues such as disarmament, chemical warfare, development, environment, aid and human rights, are brought in from the capitals of Europe and from Australia for particular agenda items. These officers are well known and highly regarded for their expertise and contribution to the development of international policy.

Our permanent mission to the United Nations in New York also consists of talented and hardworking officers under the able and effective leadership of Ambassador Richard Butler and his deputy, Richard Rowe. A highlight of United Nations General Assembly 47 in 1992 was the election of Richard Butler to chair the committee which has the duty of preparing for the 50th anniversary celebrations of the United Nations in 1995.

Although I knew that we have highly regarded officers and we have contributed significantly to many issues involved in international policy development, it was not until I was able to take part in some special sessions which were held last year that I realised that we are pre-eminent in a number of social policy issues. There were special sessions on people with disabilities at the end of the decade for people with disabilities; there was a special session on ageing, likewise at the end of the decade; and there was a special session on indigenous people at the beginning of the year for indigenous people. On each of those occasions, I was able to report to the General Assembly on behalf of Australia on measures that we had taken to fulfil, in the first two cases, the objectives of those two decades, and on the initiatives that we were in the course of taking in relation to indigenous people.

When I spoke with people from those many other countries who were contributing to those debates I realised that the policies we have developed over the last decade or so are seen to be models for much of the world, of high quality, and that we compare very well with other countries with which we normally identify. In many cases, the social achievements of Australia over the past decade are seen to be superior to those of most of the rest of the world. I did not just rely on my own colleagues to confirm that; there were members of other delegations coming to us for information, with compliments and requests for further information.

In the third committee, where I spent most of my time, we were also able to make excellent contributions to all the issues that were subsumed under the heading of human rights. On the occasion of the opening of the agenda item on the status of women, a prominent Australian constitutional lawyer, Dr Hilary Charlesworth, took part in a seminar and made an excellent contribution as a result of her analysis of international conventions, along the same lines as the analysis we have been applying to domestic law in Australia for some years, which is, in brief, that laws of this nature were developed principally by men from the thoroughly patriarchal establishments which have been running the world for a long time; that they have been interpreted by men; and that they have not lived up at all to the assumptions that might have been made somewhere along the way that they applied to all human beings. They did not explicitly or implicitly address the many breaches of human rights suffered by women.

Coming out of the discussion that was held at the UN on this matter and other matters involving human rights, agendas and resolutions were developed that will be the subject of the world conference on human rights to be held in Vienna within the next fortnight. I can report that the Australian delegation had a great deal to offer as a result of the expertise of our human rights specialists, particularly Dr Colin Willis and Dr Martin Sharp. The three months that I had in New York were, for me, busy and stimulating and affirming of the high regard in which Australia is held at the United Nations and of the talent of our officers. The opportunity to be part of that process in 1992 was certainly one of the highlights of my parliamentary career and one for which I am intensely grateful.

Early this year I was able to go to Paris at the time of the opening of the chemical weapons convention for signing. Parliamentarians for Global Action were conducting a symposium at the same time as the opening of the convention for signature, and about 30 members of parliaments from around the world made their way to Paris for that occasion. Our Minister for Foreign Affairs (Senator Gareth Evans), discovering that Senator Chamarette and I were in Paris for this symposium, invited us to be part of the Australian delegation at the UNESCO meeting where the official opening ceremony was held. Australia was among about 125 nations which signed the convention at that opening. We had the great good fortune and pleasure of hearing the people who spoke at the opening, such as the Secretary-General of the United Nations, Mr Boutros Ghali, Mr Mitterrand and other dignitaries, mentioning with considerable warmth the enormous effectiveness of Australian officers during the last few years when the chemical weapons convention was being finalised and opened for signature.

For many Australians, the first consciousness that they would have had of our role would have been in 1989 when the chemical weapons manufacturers were invited to Australia to take part in a discussion about how they might contribute to the process which had, at that time, been stalled for 20 or 21 years. The progress since then has been extremely encouraging, and it was enormously satisfying to see this convention, having come to the point where it was opened for signature, being approved by signature by a very large majority of the member nations of the UN.

When I returned from Paris after this unique experience, I received a phone call from the former Minister for Veterans' Affairs. My response was a perfectly natural one: `Oh, he is going to ask me to lay another wreath'. It actually was the case, but was a wreath laying with a considerable difference. The former Minister was unable to leave Australia during the election campaign, so it was an occasion where he was asking me to deputise for him at the laying of a wreath on the island of Bangka at the dedication of a memorial to the Australian Army nurses who died when they were escaping from Singapore in 1941. Minister Humphreys felt that I was a reasonably appropriate person to send in his place as I had long ago trained as a nurse. Also, I had been closely involved in the development of policy for veterans over the years—

TALK.START.PARA: —They should have sent me.

—I am sorry, Senator Newman; maybe she will have a chance some time. But in any case this was a three-day exercise as far as I was concerned, though many people who came to the actual memorial service in Bangka on 2 March were taking part in a longer pilgrimage which took them to a number of other war graves in the area—in Jakarta and Singapore, I believe. The delegation actually included seven of the nurses who had survived 3 1/2 years of internment by the Japanese on this island of Bangka which, incidentally, is just a little north of Sumatra and 160 miles south-east of Singapore.

PARA.TAB: I seek leave to have incorporated in Hansard the speech I made that night at the welcoming ceremony, not because of any great value that the speech has per se, but because I included in that quite lengthy references to the enormous privations that these women had suffered during the time that they had been interned by the Japanese under very, very harsh circumstances.
Leave granted.

SPEECH.PARA: Speech at the Welcoming Dinner on the Occasion of the Dedication of the Memorial to the Vyner-Brooke Nurses
BANGKA 1 March 1993

I'm here tonight to represent the Minister for Veterans' Affairs who sends his apologies for being unable to leave Australia during this election period, and who sincerely hopes that this occasion will be a memorable one for you all. I feel honoured and privileged to be given the opportunity of deputising for him.
Everyone here tonight is an honoured guest.
There are, however two groups of people for whom this is a particularly poignant occasion.
The seven Vyner-Brooke nurses who are able to be here come with memories of a terrible ordeal, but with the knowledge that their bravery is almost legendary.

Relatives of the deceased nurses, many of them not knowing for years what had happened to their sisters, daughters, aunts, will, we all hope, be able at long last to say farewell to their long lost and loved ones. We feel for you and greatly admire the commitment that has brought you all here to Bangka.

In trying to describe the calibre of the nurses of the Royal Australian Army Nursing Corps, I felt I could do no better than to repeat the words of Colonel AM Sage, CBC RAC who wrote the forward to the 1954 edition of Betty Jeffries remarkable book "White Coolies".
"They fought against anything that threatened to destroy life" she wrote.
"Theirs was a courage not stimulated by lust for battle, but born of women's natural instinct to tend the sick, the helpless, the suffering, the fearful".

"Despite terrible mental anguish and constant fear, they armed themselves with the weapons of good humour and resourcefulness, and an ability to overcome the greatest problems, and withal to keep morale at the highest possible level.
Professional and disciplined as they were, when commanded to evacuate and abandon their patients those sixty five nurses must have felt that nothing worse could happen to them.

The horrors of their ship being bombed and sunk; having assisted everyone else to leave, leaving the ship and struggling to stay afloat among oil and debris; losing sight of comrades, and being washed repeatedly towards and away from the shore; clambering exhausted and wounded through mangroves, thigh deep in mud; finally capture and reunion with only some of their numbers—what could then be worse?

The arrival of Vivian Bullwinkle bringing the miracle and joy of her survival, but the certain knowledge of so many sisters slain in cold blood must have brought home the greatest horror, of the constant and menacing threat to their lives as Prisoners of War with a deadly secret.
Betty Jeffries account of the following three and a half years should be read by all Australians.

Without a trace of melodrama or self-pity, she describes their systematic deprivation of all the basic and vital requirements which are acknowledged rights of prisoners of war—of clean adequate, food; of safe water, for much of the time; of decent shelter; of clothing, fuel, prophylactic drugs and medical attention, even at times of sleep.

Never, however, do these women, interned, and working with a community of four hundred women and children, lose their dignity, their professionalism, their wit, inventiveness or compassion, or their courage.

Despite the fact that all of the nurses contracted malaria, and there were frequent outbreaks of typhoid typhus and dengue, and despite their malnutrition and the physical exhaustion that inevitably resulted from this combination of factors, they made life tolerable. They cleaned filthy rice and improvised variations on their meagre rations in a myriad ingenious ways.
Their creativity knew no bounds.
One nun's habit plus a rusty needle plus a determined nurse was converted to five pairs of shorts.
Long before hippies and yuppies nibbled these delights, melon seeds were dried for nutritious but not very filling desserts.
When supplied with fish for the first time for twelve months, they dried the bones and crushed them to make a fair approximation of anchovy paste—and a much needed calcium supplement.
They made hats of straw mats, mattresses of rice sacks, and even shoes held together with the tacks salvaged from old furniture.

As if just existing were not a full-time job the nurses were forced to work as labourers by their captors, digging out sewerage channels, at a time when rain was the only source of washing water. They went on nursing the sick and helping with the babies. They nurtured each other, rehearsed for choral concerts, held classes for the teenage girls, created art and craft. Theirs was a wonderful example of human resilience and spirit amid the horrors and atrocities that were the appalling hall-marks of the Asian war.

We are all immensely privileged to be here on the eve of the ceremony which will dedicate the memorial to those nurses who did not return home, and which will renew in our hearts and minds the brave history of those nurses who survived.

Such wartime experience forged a link between the Australian people and the territory that is now Indonesia. Bonds of friendship, understanding and respect have grown over the years. Australia and Indonesia are closer today than at any other time.
Mr Deputy Governor the warm and colourful welcome that we received at the airport today and the presence of many local dignitaries was very much appreciated and we sincerely thank you.
The time and effort contributed by the people of Bangka has been fundamental to the success of this important and complicated excursion. Without the people of Bangka it couldn't have happened.

Following from Matron Statham's initiative and the willing and wholehearted support of the government of Indonesia and Australia we will tomorrow honour here in Bangka those fine servicewomen of the Vyner-Brooke.
Creation of the Memorial, arrangements for its Dedication and for the pilgrimage could not have been made possible without the support and cooperation of the:

PARA.TAB: Government of Indonesia
People and Industries of Bangka
Indonesian and Australian Veteran's Organisa tions
Defence and Police Forces of Indonesia
Australian Embassy in Jakarta
Australian Defence Force
Australian Department of Veterans' Affairs
Ansett Transport Industries

SPEECH.PARA: Many people have come to Bangka to be part of this Dedication. We welcome and salute them.

Bangka today is a place of great beauty and traditional Indonesian hospitality. I am delighted to be here representing the Australian Government. I am delighted to welcome the Australian group and the Indonesian hosts to this gathering.

Tomorrow will see an event of great significance to Australia's heritage and, I hope, to that of Indonesia, especially Bangka. It will be an occasion when we will honour the bravery of our Army Nurses of fifty one years ago, and the participation of the present-day Matron in Chief and her youthful colleagues will symbolise the handing down of those values that sustained those seven women and their colleagues through such difficult times.
Thank you all for being here.
PATRICIA GILES
SENATOR FOR WESTERN AUSTRALIA
5 March 1993

TALK.START.PARA: —Once again, it was an enormously satisfying experience, a very moving but not a maudlin occasion. The people who were there were, in many cases, having the opportunity for the first time of properly mourning their lost loved ones. The women who died, who drowned, who were assassinated or who subsequently died of disease did so without their relatives in Australia being aware of their fate. It was often years later before they knew. This was the occasion for these people to come to Bangka to mourn and to throw flowers into the sea in memory of their relatives. It was another occasion which has made my parliamentary career extremely rewarding. Once again, my thanks should go to a system that not only initiates and implements such measures but that also involves humble backbenchers, much to their pleasure and satisfaction.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was not going to speak about Bangka but I cannot resist adding a few words to what Senator Giles has said. There is a frontbencher here who would dearly have liked to have been associated with that ceremony on Bangka. I have long had an interest in the plight of those nurses. In February of last year I was in Singapore for the commemoration of the fall of Singapore. I met a number of nurses who had nursed in Singapore and a number of them had tried to get away at the fall of Singapore. Matron Bullwinkle has talked for a long time about the wish to have this memorial on Bangka.
