Until the recent policy changes were made, Australia was almost unique in that this did not happen here.

This provides the opportunities for terminal arrangements to be made that are quite different to the ones we have now in terms of an airline operating both international and domestic flights. That matter is currently being considered in terms of all our major terminals such as Sydney and Melbourne. Of course, we are now in the happy position in respect of the Brisbane terminal of being able to pre-plan for those arrangements.

The terminal is certainly due to be completed no later than 31 January 1996. It is well and truly on schedule. Major tenders will be announced in the next week or so for the steel fabrication for the building. We are currently discussing with the FAC the prospects of bringing forward the schedule from that date.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: World Heritage Listing of Nullarbor Plain

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories. Firstly, following the Minister's answer to question No. 2389 of 24 November 1992, what endeavours has the Keating Government made to obtain the agreement of the Court Government to nominate the Nullarbor Plain for World Heritage listing? Secondly, will consultations between the governments conclude in time to lodge the nomination at UNESCO headquarters before the deadline of 30 September 1993?

—I can inform Senator Chamarette that Mrs Kelly, the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories, has written to the Western Australian Minister for the environment, the Hon. Kevin Minson MLA, seeking clarification of the Court Government's position with regard to possible nomination of parts of the Nullarbor region to the World Heritage list. Mrs Kelly, in her letter to Mr Minson, has suggested consultation on the Nullarbor region between her department and officials from Western Australia. But it would appear that there may well be insufficient time to allow the nomination to proceed by 30 September 1993, although, naturally enough, that would depend upon what kind of cooperation is received from the Western Australian Government.

PARA.TAB: I should say that, in looking at World Heritage nominations from Queensland to Tasmania to Western Australia, there are always people who get very excited. Ignorance often reigns supreme. Breaking through ignorance, however, is a job that we can share and, with people like Senator Crichton-Browne, it takes a long time but we can get there if we keep trying.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister for Transport and Communications. I refer the Minister to the Bureau of Industry Economics report on international performance indicators with regard to the waterfront. I draw the Minister's attention to the fact that government and port authority charges at Australia's five major ports are $107.48 per tonne equivalent unit. By comparison, the port average for 10 major overseas ports was only $45.39, or some $62.09 less—that is, $6.2 million more on each 100,000 tonnes equivalent units of cargo from Australia. I ask the Minister: when is this Government going to become serious with regard to such outrageous government and port authority cost structures and address the fact that, despite all the hoo-ha about waterfront reform, our ports are just simply not internationally competitive?

—If we were in the happy position of running the ports around Australia, we would be able to do something directly about it. We are not. In fact, one of the interesting things about the proposals put to the Australian electorate and, I might add, comprehensively rejected by the coalition prior to the last election, was the startling proposal that the Federal Government would privatise the ports. As I said at the time, it would come as a hell of a shock to the State governments which actually own them that the Commonwealth Government was proposing to dispose of assets which, in fact, we do not own. At that time the Opposition cheerfully ignored—it was probably total ignorance—how the ports actually work.

PARA.TAB: Ports in Australia are State government responsibilities. The Bureau of Industry Economics reached different conclusions about different aspects of Australian port operations, and it is important to be clear about what it actually said. The bureau found that State government and port authority charges in Australia were substantially higher than those experienced for similar cargoes and ships overseas. The results clearly emphasise what I have been saying in this chamber for three years: we need to achieve more efficiencies in the port sector—that is, the State government responsibility—particularly now that significant reforms have been delivered so far as the waterfront and the stevedoring sector are concerned.

The Government will be discussing the scope for further port reform with the States following the release of the Industry Commission's final report into port authority activities at the end of this month. On the other hand, the bureau's report provides further confirmation that there have been major improvements in the operating efficiency of Australia's container ports in recent years. The bureau concluded that in some cases Australian productivity levels are approaching observed best practice in similar sized overseas ports. Of course, no-one in the coalition wants to highlight that. The bureau also concluded that the operating efficiency of Australian coal and wheat handling ports approaches, or is already at, world best practice. Stevedoring arrangements at wheat ports were a major focus of the waterfront industry reform program.

In conclusion, through the conference that ATAC has set up for consultation between the Federal Government and State transport Ministers the question of increased efficiency in Australian ports will be discussed between the Federal Government and the governments that are directly responsible for them, that is, the State governments. State governments are aware of the need to improve the ports under their control, and most States have addressed the problem. New South Wales has certainly made progress in that area, and the Queensland Government—just to name two States—commissioned a major review into the operation of all its ports which resulted immediately in it reorganising and replacing most of the existing port authority boards which had been a sinecure for retired National Party figures prior to that for about 20 years.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper.

—Earlier in Question Time Senator Bell asked me a question about dried vine fruit exports. I regret that I was unable to answer him then; I am now. Under the export equalisation arrangements for dried vine fruits, all exports are equalised in price. The Government is aware that some growers are now moving into organically grown grapes and that these dried fruits are able to command a premium on export markets. Because the export of high quality clean food products is regarded by the Government as a priority, the production of organically grown grapes is a welcome development. The horticultural task force, which the Government has established to develop export marketing strategies for the horticultural industries and which is being chaired by Senator Nick Sherry, has a dried vine fruit subcommittee. The question raised by Senator Bell is a matter, I am pleased to be able to tell him, that will be examined by that group as a matter of priority.

—On 13 May Senator Hill asked me whether the Government would table the advice it received from the Foreign Investment Review Board regarding the Fairfax matter. I said that I would seek the advice of the Treasurer in that respect. I have raised the question of tabling the FIRB advice with the Treasurer, who advised me that he considered it would be inappropriate to break with established principles governing advice provided to the Government by its officials—namely, that such advice should remain confidential. I will, therefore, not be tabling the FIRB advice with regard to this matter.

PARA.TAB: While I have noted Mr Black's comments that he would have no difficulties with the advice being made public, I should not need to point out to Senator Hill that Mr Black's preferences on this matter are not really decisive when it comes to the main consideration which is that it is the Government, not its officials, which takes the decisions and which is ultimately responsible and accountable to the Australian people. In matters relating to foreign investment policies, the Treasurer has been charged with exercising this responsibility. The Government's decision in the Fairfax case and the reasoning behind it have already been clearly articulated in the Treasurer's press release of 20 April and in subsequent public comments, including my original answer to Senator Hill's question.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Ferguson asked me a question recently concerning spare parts. The Assistant Treasurer has provided the following answer. The Government is aware of the position outlined in Senator Ferguson's question. Under the new sales tax legislation, parts used in the repair of machinery or other goods are regarded as being applied to the own use of the repairer. If they are drawn from a tax free stock, they are liable to sales tax at that time unless an exemption item applies.

PARA.TAB: Where farm machinery belonging to a farmer is being repaired or reconditioned, an exemption item applies to exempt the parts. However, where a dealer owns the machinery, the repair of that machinery does not attract exemption because the dealer is not an exempt person or an exempt user. The Government has the matter under review, but has not yet reached any final conclusion on the issue.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday in Question Time, Senator Herron referred to an answer that I had given in respect of the drug Zoladex. He went on to extend an allegation of gender bias in the listing of another drug, Rocaltrol, which is the brand name for the drug Calcitriol. He was wrong again. I seek to answer the points that he made.

PARA.TAB: The allegation of gender bias is absurd. It is all very well for Senator Herron to raise the issue of drugs that treat medical conditions that affect one sex, but the fact is that this does not reflect any sexual discrimination on the part of the Government. Further, I strongly object to the inference that the Australian Drug Evaluation Committee, the Pharmaceutical Benefits Advisory Committee and the Government seek to favour males or females or vice versa.

Drugs are recommended for listing on the pharmaceutical benefits scheme by the Pharmaceutical Benefits Advisory Committee. I have a list of the membership of these committees. It represents some of the who's who of Senator Herron's colleagues—people he would regard very highly. Drugs are recommended by them on the basis of the conditions for which they have marketing approval, not on the basis of the sex they treat. It is purely academic that a drug may be used for one sex.

TALK.START.PARA: —You have missed the point.
—Senator Herron has missed the point and he is going to get it now.

PARA.TAB: Calcitriol, as it was raised yesterday, is listed for a number of uses in the pharmaceutical benefits scheme, including `the treatment of post-menopausal osteoporosis'. The product was first listed in the scheme in 1981. The Australian Drug Evaluation Committee recommended an extension of its uses in November 1985 and approved general marketing to include the treatment of post-menopausal osteoporosis. This did not include prophylactic use—that is, use to prevent osteoporosis.

Calcitriol was approved for marketing for the treatment of established post-menopausal osteoporosis on 6 June 1986. An application to extend the pharmaceutical benefits scheme availability to include the treatment of osteoporosis was considered by the Pharmaceutical Benefits Advisory Committee in October 1986. The committee sought advice from two experts and the chairman of the endocrinology subcommittee of the Australian Drug Evaluation Committee, who did not support the drug's listing in the pharmaceutical benefits scheme for osteoporosis.

The application was rejected by the Pharmaceutical Benefits Advisory Committee in October 1987. The advisory committee rejected another application in February 1988 because of the lack of evidence for the need for the product in the pharmaceutical benefits scheme.

The company applied again in June 1991, supported by data including a New Zealand clinical study. Based on this information, the Pharmaceutical Benefits Advisory Committee recommended listing for the treatment of post-menopausal osteoporosis in accord with the marketing approval.

The fact is that data was supplied to support the treatment of osteoporosis in post-menopausal women. No data was supplied to support the use of the drug for osteoporosis in males nor for its use as a preventive treatment for either males or females. If the manufacturer can supply data indicating that the drug is cost-effective in males, the expert committees to which I have referred will reconsider extending the uses of the drug. But to attempt to suggest bias in processing drug applications in the listing of the pharmaceutical benefits scheme just is not right.

Senator Herron also raised the matter of Zoladex, which I dealt with yesterday. All I can say about that is the fact that only men have prostate problems does not mean that the drug should not have been put on the bottom of the pile for listing so that the Government does not get accused of gender bias.

It is legitimate to raise the issue of the marketing of a particular drug or its listing, but to sensationalise the issue of gender bias in a press release, as Senator Herron did, is ridiculous. He referred to the use of Zoladex for endometriosis. ADEC will consider an application to extend the marketing approval of Zoladex to cover this condition at its June 1993 meeting. The fact is that ADEC cannot approve a drug for a particular medical indication without data to support it. The crux of this argument is: no data, no approval. There obviously could never be approval.

The fact that the Government has never rejected one recommendation from that expert body suggests that we take seriously its recommendations. We accept them every time; we have not changed one. Therefore, to accuse that body of any kind of gender bias is over the top, even for Senator Herron.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to inform the Senate of the untimely death on 24 May 1993 of Mr Jim Monro, former senior officer of the Office of Parliamentary Counsel, better known to a large number of senators over the past 15 years as one of the Senate's consultant legislative drafters. On behalf of all senators, I extend sympathy to his family.

PARA.TAB: Honourable senators—Hear, hear!

QWN.TITLE: ADDITIONAL RESPONSES TO QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday, Senator Knowles asked a number of questions about alleged tampering with documents related to disciplinary action against the former Ambassador to Chile, Mr Malcolm Dan. I undertook to seek further advice from the department in order to refresh my recollection, among other things, as to what had happened and to provide any additional comment to the Senate before it rises today.

PARA.TAB: I stated yesterday that the allegation that there had been tampering with documents would have to be tested in an appropriate way, in the first instance by internal investigation. I have been reminded that an internal investigation was in fact conducted promptly within my department following the inquiry officer's receipt of a letter from Mr Dan in this connection dated 7 April 1993. I was in fact advised of that by the department on 30 April. I had forgotten that earlier exchange when I responded yesterday.

That investigation found that there was no evidence of any tampering with documents in the possession of the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade. It was therefore neither necessary nor appropriate for my department to request action by the Australian Federal Police. There was, however, evidence that a document in the possession of OPG, the overseas property group, had been altered. My department therefore referred the matter to the Department of Administrative Services, which has the responsibility for the OPG, for attention and appropriate action. I understand that those investigations are continuing.

The effect of my department's finding was that there was no impediment to its inquiry into the seven charges against Mr Dan, which I referred to yesterday, proceeding. Evidence that a version of the document held elsewhere had been altered did not affect my own department's inquiry process. I have not myself seen the actual documents. I have no requirement to do so, consistent with the approach that I outlined in my initial response to Senator Knowles's questions yesterday. My office referred Mr Dan's letter to me on this matter of 13 April to the department for direct reply. A further letter from Mr Dan to me has similarly been referred to my department.

As I stated yesterday, had the department found evidence of tampering with the documentation connected to the disciplinary action it is taking against Mr Dan, it would have referred that matter automatically to the AFP in accordance with a memorandum of understanding between the department and the AFP and I would have been advised of that action.

I am informed that the department has sent a reply to Mr Dan's letter to me of 13 April and that a reply to the more recent letter is being prepared. The inquiry officer had already replied to Mr Dan's letter to him, informing Mr Dan of the results of the department's investigation. I am advised that the letter from Mr Dan's solicitor of 11 March 1993 did not refer to the tampering issue.

What all that boils down to is that my department has, therefore, promptly taken all the appropriate steps in response to Mr Dan's raising of this matter. I reiterate that it is not appropriate for me as Minister to intervene in the detailed scrutiny of all the matters raised by either side in this or any other disciplinary action, for that matter, taken by my department pursuant to the disciplinary provisions of the Public Service Act. The department proceeds strictly in accordance with the Act on the basis of legal advice and keeps me informed of significant developments. That procedure is being adhered to in respect of the department's disciplinary action against Mr Dan.

I think it would be inappropriate now—as it is likely to be in the future—for me to comment in any more detail on this case, given that this inquiry is in process and given that action is being taken, as I said, by another department in response to my department's referral to it of the tampering issue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Herron Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the further answer given by the Minister for Health (Senator Richardson, in response to a question without notice asked by Senator Herron on 25 May 1993, relating to subsidies under the pharmaceutical benefits scheme for goods approved by the Therapeutic Goods Administration.

SPEECH.PARA: I admire Senator Richardson's defence of his department. Senator Richardson pumps himself up in excess energy. I had never seen him so energised as when I asked him a question on a medical matter. I can only regard this as a reflection of his reaction to me. I appreciate his attitude for that. I seem to get under his skin. Perhaps he needs a dermatological consultation or something of that nature. I might be seriously concerned if this gets more and more each time. I am pleased that we are rising until August or he might suffer further medical consequences.

PARA.TAB: I accept that the Australian Drug Evaluation Committee is a legitimate and properly constituted body comprised of eminent members of the profession, just as I do the Pharmaceutical Benefits Advisory Committee. In fact, the chairman of one of those bodies is a close personal friend of mine, and I do not think there would be any more eminent person to chair that body. Senator Richardson has totally missed the point. It is all very well to go on and on about the eminence of these bodies and their attitudes, on a scientific basis, to the allowance of these drugs onto the pharmaceutical benefits scheme, but the facts of the matter still stand. If one is a premenopausal woman with breast cancer then Zoladex is not available today. He told us yesterday, and I accept it, that it is in the process thereof and that as of 1 August that will be so.

The fact of the matter is, from the point of view of the Rocaltrol trials, that if one is a male with a compression fracture of the vertebra, one has to pay up to $100 for that drug. The only way for somebody to be covered would be if that person was a postmenopausal male. That may be an allegation made about some members on the other side of the chamber, but it is not a scientific fact as yet. The facts are that today, if one is a postmenopausal female with a crushed fracture of the vertebra, that drug is available to that woman under the pharmaceutical benefits scheme; but if one is a male over the age of—shall we say—50, that drug is not available to that person under the same scheme.

The other interesting aspect—this is not going to be like Blue Hills—is that I have been contacted today by the retail pharmacy association, and there are many more anomalies which I will be pleased to instruct Senator Richardson on when the Senate resumes in August. By then I should have a comprehensive list which will be supplied to me by the pharmacy profession.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Health (Senator Richardson), in response to a question without notice asked by Senator Newman this day, relating to Medicare.

SPEECH.PARA: My question related to whether the Minister for Health could rule out any further rises to the Medicare levy following the one due on 1 July this year when it will go from 1.25 per cent to 1.4 per cent. Anyone watching Senator Richardson would have thought that he was a bit like a cat dancing on a hot tin roof. I said a cat, but I do not know whether a cat has fingers to cross behind its back while it dances. He was really in a bit of a quandary as to how to avoid the question and not give a pledge to not increase the Medicare levy during the life of this Parliament. The situation is that, unless something `turns up', the Minister really is on a hot tin roof. He will not give that pledge on the Medicare levy because he knows that, inevitably, the levy will have to rise again. One presumes that it cannot wait until the next election; it will have to be done before then.

PARA.TAB: The Minister knows that he cannot implement the co-payments which were outlawed a year or so ago because there is no Caucus support for them. That is why they were wiped out when Mr Keating became the Prime Minister. Similarly, the Minister knows that he will not get sufficient support in the party room for the introduction of tax incentives for private health insurance for individuals. But he desperately needs some more money; the health system is going broke.

He says that he will do better at catching instances of fraud and overservicing. But the Government has been pretty ineffectual in this area already. So far in 1991-92 it has recovered $1 million from Medicare fraud and $55,000 from chasing overservicing. So the Government does not have a crash-hot record when it needs hundreds of millions of dollars.

Mr Deputy President, you will recall that the former Minister for Health, Brian Howe, said on the 29 August 1991 that if the co-payments were overruled, a Medicare levy of 1.53 per cent would be needed with further increases in the future. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: We would require a lift in the Medicare levy from 1.25% of income to 1.53% and because this would not stem the growth in service use, further increases in the levy would be required in later years.
So we can see why Senator Richardson was not prepared to give a pledge today. He has his fingers crossed hoping that something will turn up, but goodness knows what it will be.

PARA.TAB: He also tells us that he will keep all the election promises in relation to health. I ask again: where will the money come from? He has already put the emergency dental health scheme on hold. That is down the track now. He has acknowledged today that his Government's promise to buy back beds in private hospitals for public patients will not work. I told him that during the estimates committee hearings. He claimed that he would get private hospitals to agree to the scheme, but now he acknowledges that that will be very hard.

He has been on the public record saying that 100,000 people on waiting lists for elective surgery is not a crisis. Today he claims that he will spend every cent he can to reduce waiting times and lists in public hospitals. Apparently, he is now prepared to acknowledge the seriousness of those awful statistics. Those statistics are not just numbers; they are people in pain, suffering in queues.

He claims that he will increase health research. How will he do it all? The fact is: there is not enough money in the health system in this country to meet the existing commitments let alone fulfil those hollow election promises. More money has to be injected into the system, and the only options are to introduce co-payments, increase the Medicare levy, introduce tax incentives for private health insurance, claw back any fraud, cut services and ration health care. That is why Senator Richardson is dancing on a hot tin roof. He does not have many options and he has to come clean in the end. He cannot prevaricate much longer. Where will the money come from?
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by Senator Evans, in response to a question without notice asked by Senator Lewis this day, relating to the economy.

SPEECH.PARA: The Australian Labor Party sent Victoria broke—not a bad effort. Victoria was a small, viable State which had a lot of industry and where transport was not a great cost, yet the once great Australian Labor Party managed to bankrupt Victoria.

PARA.TAB: The Government did that while appearing, for most of its term of government, to be quite reasonable. The public were actually lulled into thinking that Mr Cain was a very nice and reasonable Premier, until ultimately the full enormity of what the Australian Labor Party had done to Victoria fell upon the people of Victoria. They were appalled and determined that they would throw out the Labor Party at the next election, and that is what they did.

The problem stems from a lack of control over the Government's own expenditure. The Government squeezed the State dry; it looked for every avenue of revenue it could get; it taxed the people of Victoria; it used the institutions of Victoria, such as the State Bank, to raise revenue; and it imposed taxes and raised revenue. The Government then wasted the revenue because it failed to control its own expenditure, in particular on its own staff. The Government kept increasing the number of State employees to overcome problems that it believed existed in various areas, and the result was bankruptcy for Victoria.

The Federal Government is now in the process of doing exactly the same thing, because it has all the money. Every opportunity the Federal Government has it creams off the revenue of this country. It is failing to exercise genuine control over its own expenditure, and that is the problem.

What has happened is that this country is already bankrupt. However, as the Treasurer, Mr Dawkins, said yesterday, Australia is not bankrupt because the Government has the right to raise additional revenue. This year the Government will make the decision to borrow another $16 billion, or more, to add to our national debt, but it says to the Australian people, `Do not worry, we are not bankrupt because at some stage in the future we can increase taxes to pay off the debt so that the country is not bankrupt'. That is what the Government is saying to us.

The Australian Labor Party always forgets that if people have no money and no incentive and if there are no desires in the community then they give up hope. Once the Australian people give up hope they stop working overtime, business people stop bothering to increase the size of their businesses and withdraw into their shells. They try to cope with the possibility of bankruptcy, they try to just survive, they refuse to employ more people, unemployment increases enormously, the burden of the social welfare bill gets bigger and the country is then in desperate trouble.

What is happening now is that every person on the magnificent sum of more than $50,000 a year—which is thought to be very generous and sounds like a great amount of money—is being taxed enormously. Once all the taxes on that sum have been paid there is not much left. Not only are those people paying income tax at the rate of 48.5c in the dollar, but they are also paying a Medicare levy of 1.25 per cent, which is about to be increased to 1.4 per cent. In addition, they are required to pay 5 per cent of their income to some life assurance company for superannuation benefits that they have no control over and one of these days—when they are old enough—that life assurance company may give them their money back. One day they might get the money back.

Those people are taking home about 44 per cent of their earnings and they have lost their incentive. This Government has no plan in any way to overcome that problem. Therefore, there is no money available for venture capital and the nation's small businesses are contracting. Those that have the opportunity are going overseas. The nation is in diabolical trouble and this Government is talking about a republic or anything else that might divert the attention of the people and this Parliament from the problems of the nation. I say to this Government that it has no long-term economic policy which, as far as I can see, will enable this country to recover from its present problems.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Faulkner), in response to a question without notice asked by Senator West this day, relating to a review of the system for awarding Australian honours.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tierney Sen J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Family Services (Senator Crowley), in response to a question without notice asked by Senator Reynolds this day, relating to the employment of women in higher education institutions.

SPEECH.PARA: This answer by Senator Crowley, which was another dorothy dixer, was an attempt to cover up the appalling spectacle that we saw last week when Senator Crowley obviously did not know what she was talking about in relation to affirmative action and the number of women employed in senior positions in universities. Having claimed last week that the figures had actually risen—when, as was quite correctly pointed out by Senator Knowles, the number of women in senior positions in universities had dropped from 13 to 10, a drop of 30 per cent—Senator Crowley today attempted to correct that.

I listened very carefully to the answer given by Senator Crowley today. As someone who has conducted professional research in universities and has some knowledge of statistics, I was curious to know how that drop of 30 per cent could suddenly turn out to be an increase. The only explanation that Senator Crowley gave for this was that one university had submitted incorrect figures. I take it that she meant that figures were reported on the wrong line, because she did talk about 15 vice-chancellors in one university.

So I believe that Senator Crowley was speaking nonsense. I want to look at those figures more closely. I place on record in the Senate today that Senator Crowley should table those figures. Unfortunately, as it is the last day of Parliament, we will not have a chance to look at them or debate them today. After she has tabled the figures, Senator Crowley can be assured that I will look at them over the winter break. When we come back in August, we will see yet again that Senator Crowley does not know what she is talking about in relation to affirmative action for women. She has shown that time and time again in this chamber during this session with regard to other matters that are within her brief.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services (Senator McMullan), in response to a question without notice asked by Senator Maguire this day, relating to funding for the production of films.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator McMullan let his normally high standards slip a little in his response to Senator Maguire's question, particularly when dealing with an allegation that the Opposition was going to cut $20 million out of total funding to film in Australia. I draw the Senate's attention to the reality. During the election campaign, the arts policy of the coalition showed that a coalition government would be committed to creating an environment in which a creative, highly professional, efficient and competitive Australian film industry would prosper.

PARA.TAB: The revival of the Australian film industry, which was generated by support measures under the Gorton, McMahon and Fraser governments, all coalition governments, and which created an international awareness of the quality and style of Australian film and of Australia itself, cannot be guaranteed to continue without a sound financing base. This is the problem that the Government now faces. The failure of the present Government's film financing strategy underlines the need for policy reform. Senator McMullan should get off his backside and start doing something positive, instead of misrepresenting the past.

These are the facts. According to the latest Budget papers, the Hawke-Keating Government had intended to cut support for the Film Finance Corporation in half, from last year's $68 million, which itself was a reduction of $5 million from the Forward Estimates, to only $35 million in the current financial year. It was doing this `in recognition of the Government's expectation that the corporation should increase private sector contributions and its revenues'. The abject failure of this policy is evident from this year's ad hoc emergency injection of another $34 million into support for the film industry in 1992-93 by this Government, restoring its overall Budget allocation to $84.8 million, as against the original projected $50.8 million, in order to save the Film Finance Corporation from a funding disaster.

This crisis emerged because of the withdrawal of private sector investment support for Australian films, with the volume of funds subscribed under 10BA tax incentives under this Government falling from $55 million in 1991 to only $21.2 million in 1991-92, with further falls indicated in the current financial year. This disaster in Australian film investment under this Government is not simply the result of Mr Keating's engineered recession; it is largely attributable to the inflexible and unrealistic basis on which private sector investment is expected to be made.

At a time when outstanding film successes such as Strictly Ballroom have generated widespread national interest in Australian films, it is incredible that no ready investment medium is available for ordinary Australians, other than major investors, to invest in individual Australian filmmaking ventures. That is a direct consequence of this Government's policies. Whereas the Government wanted to cut funding in half for the Australian film industry, the coalition wanted to improve the arrangements under which private investors could make up this difference.

In taking positive measures to restore private sector investment, the coalition's policy sought to achieve the objective that the present Government has unsuccessfully sought of being able to significantly reduce direct government funding without diminishing in any way the total funds available to the industry. That is why I am so irritated by Senator McMullan's claim. He did not go on to admit, firstly, that we had other ways of funding the film industry which would have increased its total funding and, secondly, that his own Government intended to cut film funding by just about the same amount as we proposed. Our policy said:

SPEECH.PARA: To tide the film industry over its transition to a less subsidy-dependent position, the Coalition will limit the reduction in direct government funding of the FFC from this year's $61.9 million to $48 million in its first three years in office . . .

That is comparable to the Government's own projected cut to $50 million by 1995-96; but, as this was to have been backed by far greater incentives from private sector investment, overall funding for the film industry would have improved considerably under a Hewson government. What a shame Senator McMullan did not tell the whole story. I hope that in his role as Minister for the Arts—and I look forward to his being a successful Minister for the Arts—he is a little more careful in dealing with the truth.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! That last statement is quite out of order. I ask the honourable senator to withdraw it.
—I withdraw it, Mr Deputy President.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bell Sen R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Senator Evans), in response to a question without notice asked by Senator Bell this day, relating to dried vine fruits.

SPEECH.PARA: After getting this answer, with a little difficulty, honourable senators were able to see that this issue is indicative of the problems that occur when bureaucracies are allowed to overwhelm enterprises. The enterprises in question here are ones which are attractive, growing and in great demand internationally; that is, the production of the very sort of primary product which is getting so much attention from the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, Mr Simon Crean.

PARA.TAB: I was pleased that we were told in Senator Evans's answer from the Minister that a subcommittee will treat as a matter of priority the matter of gaining access to exports markets for organic produce. It is called `organic produce', but what that means is that it is produce which has been made in the primary industry without exposure to pesticides or artificial chemicals of any nature.

The fact that a subcommittee is treating this as a priority is recognition of the international trend to seek this sort of produce. It is a trend that was recognised by Australia's Rural Industry Research and Development Corporation which reported in May 1990 on the market for Australian produced organic food. The Senate should be interested to know that on page 62 of that report we are told that opinions expressed during the survey conducted by this group and corroborated by overseas experience suggest that the specialist organic retail market can currently bear premiums—that is price premiums—on organic products of up to 35 per cent over what it calls conventional products. The report further goes on to say that, as the market increases in size and a larger number of less committed consumers start buying organic produce, it is expected that those premiums that can currently be obtained will diminish. But at this stage, in the early part of the development of this particular market, considerable premiums are possible.

This is important because at the threshold of achieving those premiums are many members of Australia's dried vine fruits marketing organisations. While it may seem that it is not particularly important how many organic sultanas or currants are sold overseas, we should be aware that the organic market in the United Kingdom is estimated as being worth over $200 million; and, in Japan and the United States, markets of similar or even superior size are becoming available. I think it is important that we recognise this. It is one thing for this particular subcommittee to see this as a priority, but to actually achieve an expansion into this market area is even more important.

At the moment, this very day, some of Australia's dried fruit producers have a product which is in high demand internationally. But the problem is that that product is not able to make its way on to the export markets because of the equalisation arrangements which exist at the moment in our dried fruit industries. The effect of that is that, if a producer manages to find a market—and I must say that these markets are actually coming to Australia; buyers are actually coming here trying to find the very clean, green product Minister Crean is talking about—on the introduction of the producer to the potential buyer, we find that the producer is unable to get any of the premium for himself or herself but in fact that that premium returns, under the equalisation provisions, to the equalisation fund.

I suggest that it would perhaps be more appropriate to introduce categories of product in this market to recognise the premium that is paid for special categories of product. For example, certified organic products are different from the other dried fruits that are on the market. If they were recognised as such, a considerable international market could become established and our producers could take advantage of it. I am very pleased that this is a matter of priority. I hope it is treated in that way and that we will get a very quick resolution of this problem.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Veterans' Affairs and Minister for Defence Science and Personnel)

TALK.START.PARA: —I table the explanatory memorandum relating to the Bills and move:

PARA.TAB: That this Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The speech read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: Mr President, this Bill amends the Development Allowance Authority Act 1992 (the Principal Act).
The purpose of the Bill is to amend the Principal Act to extend the development allowance to projects in the motor vehicle industry and the printing production aspect of projects in the print media.
These amendments re-open the application period for projects in the motor vehicle industry and the print media that were previously excluded from the development allowance.
Thus the amendments allow proponents to apply for the development allowance for projects in the motor vehicle industry and the printing production aspect of projects in the print media.
The amendments reflect commitments made during the election campaign.

While extending the eligibility of the development allowance to such projects, these amendments also ensure that projects relating to these two industries must meet competitiveness tests in relation to work practices and input pricing, which under the Principal Act could otherwise be waived where the project sponsor is able to show that, prior to 1 January 1993, there was substantial commitment to completion of the project. That is, these amendments would provide that, irrespective of whether there was substantial commitment to completion before 1 January 1993, to be eligible for the development allowance projects in the motor vehicle industry and the printing production aspect of projects in the print media would have to meet the competitiveness tests.

All other criteria in the Principal Act, including the $50 million threshold would need to be met by projects in the motor vehicle industry and the printing production aspect of projects in the print media industry, in order to be eligible for the development allowance.
I now turn to a more detailed discussion of these amendments.

This Bill defines additional projects now eligible for the development allowance. In particular, projects in the motor vehicle industry and the printing production aspects of projects in the print media are defined and the Principal Act's basic eligibility test modified so these projects are now eligible.

The Bill adopts a wide definition of the motor vehicle industry to include the manufacture of vehicles and components. The Bill also defines printing production to include the printing unit and ancillary facilities.

This Bill amends the Principal Act to re-open the application period for projects in the motor vehicle industry and the printing production aspects of projects in the print media until either 30 September 1993 or until 28 days after this Act receives the Royal Assent, which ever is the later. This will ensure the affected businesses have sufficient time to lodge their applications.

Finally, as noted earlier, this Bill amends the Principal Act to specify that in order to be eligible for the development allowance, projects in the motor vehicle industry and the printing production aspects of projects in the print media must meet the competitiveness tests in relation to work practices and input pricing, irrespective of whether there was substantial commitment to completion before 1 January 1993.
Mr President, I present the Explanatory Memorandum which contains more detailed explanations of the provisions of the Bill.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.

Motion (by Senator Bourne) agreed to:

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bourne Sen V.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1)That a select committee, to be known as the Select Committee on Matters Arising from Pay Television Tendering Processes, be appointed to inquire into and report upon the following matters:

(a)the extent to which the Minister for Transport and Communications discharged his ministerial responsibilities in relation to satellite and MDS tender processes, having particular regard to the appropriate contemporary definition of ministerial responsibility, and including any different responsibility which might attach to the role of a Minister during the caretaker period of an election; and

(b)the adequacy of action taken by the Minister and the Department of Transport and Communications to rectify any problems identified in the reports by Professor Dennis Pearce tabled in the Senate on 19 May 1993 and 26 May 1993 respectively, including but not limited to the following matters:

PARA.TAB: (i)tendering arrangements for price-based licensing allocations;
(ii)understanding of administrative and commercial law;
(iii)proper management of documents, files and records; and
(iv)public service accountability.

SPEECH.PARA: (2) (a)That the inquiry into the matters described in paragraph (1)(a) shall commence forthwith for report to the Senate by 2 September 1993.

TAB.TAB: (b)That the inquiry into the matters described in paragraph (1)(b) shall commence on receipt of reports by the Minister for Transport and Communications and the Secretary of the Department of Transport and Communications on those matters, or on 6 September, whichever is the earlier, for report to the Senate by 25 November 1993.

SPEECH.PARA: (3)That the committee consist of six Senators, as follows:

PARA.TAB: (a)three nominated by the Leader of the Government in the Senate;
(b)two nominated by the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate; and
(c)one nominated by the Leader of the Australian Democrats.

SPEECH.PARA: (4)That the committee may proceed to the despatch of business notwithstanding that all members have not been duly nominated and appointed and notwithstanding any vacancy.
(5) (a)That the chairman of the committee be appointed by and from the members of the committee;

PARA.TAB: (b)That the deputy-chairman of the committee be appointed by and from the members of the committee immediately after the appointment of the chair;
(c)That the deputy-chairman act as chairman when there is no chairman or the chairman is not present at a meeting; and
(d)That in the event of the votes on any question before the committee being equally divided, the chairman, or the deputy-chairman when acting as chairman, have a casting vote.

SPEECH.PARA: (6)That a Senator who is not a member of the committee may participate in its public sessions and question witnesses, unless the committee orders otherwise, but shall not vote.
(7)That the quorum of the committee be three members.

(8)That the committee and any subcommittee have power to send for and examine persons and documents, to move from place to place, to sit in public or in private, notwithstanding any prorogation of the Parliament or dissolution of the House of Representatives.

(9)That the committee have power to appoint subcommittees consisting of three or more of its members, and to refer to any such subcommittee any of the matters which the committee is empowered to consider, and that the quorum of a subcommittee be a majority of the Senators appointed to the subcommittee.

(10)That the committee be provided with all necessary staff, facilities and resources and be empowered to appoint persons with specialist knowledge for the purposes of the committee, with the approval of the President.
(11)That the committee be empowered to print from day to day such documents and evidence as may be ordered by it, and a daily Hansard be published of such proceedings as take place in public.

(12)That the committee may report from time to time its proceedings and evidence taken and any interim conclusions and recommendations arising from its inquiry, and may make regular reports on the progress of its proceedings.

I have negotiated these terms of reference with the Government and the Opposition and I believe that they are acceptable to both sides. This motion would establish a Senate select committee to inquire into matters arising from the pay TV tendering mess of the past few months. The Democrats have said all along that any Senate inquiry should deal with matters which had not been adequately processed by the two Pearce reports. The Pearce reports are thorough, well-considered and consistent with the mountains of documents tabled in the Senate. I believe that there are about 4,000 pages. We have read them all.

PARA.TAB: The Democrats are satisfied that Professor Pearce has identified the problems, and there are many. They include: a lack of understanding of the law and its importance in policy development; an absence of clear guidelines for price-based licence allocation tenders; poor document handling; and sub-standard file management. Sections of the department and the Minister's office have a great deal of work to do to rectify those problems and implement public service accountability requirements.

There is no point in the coalition's proposed inquiry, which it brought up last week, because we believe that it would go over the ground covered so adequately by Professor Pearce. We are very pleased that the coalition has agreed to the terms of reference we have now put forward. However, there is every point to an inquiry into questions which Professor Pearce was not required to answer, and in ensuring that thorough corrective action is taken by the Minister and his department. We need to ensure that, as far as possible, there is no recurrence in this department, or in any other, of this mess. In other words, we are not interested in re-inventing Professor Pearce's wheel. The problems have been identified; we now want to look at the solutions.

The Opposition has highlighted the fact that Professor Pearce was not asked to comment on the doctrine of ministerial responsibility in the handling of pay TV licence tenders. It is quite clear that there is no agreed contemporary definition of ministerial responsibility. There is no agreement on where the line should be drawn between the responsibility of Ministers, their advisers and the senior officers of their departments.

The first phase of our proposed two-stage inquiry would seek to define ministerial responsibility, and suggest where the lines of responsibility should be drawn. The first report should be tabled in the Senate by September this year. The second phase of the inquiry would start in September at the latest, and would examine the corrective action taken by the Minister and his department in response to the problems identified by Professor Pearce. This three-month delay is designed to give the Minister and his departmental head time to put solutions in place and report to Parliament on what they have done. The second phase would start once those reports were received, which could overlap with the first phase.

To ensure that the second stage cannot be stalled, we have set a deadline of 6 September, after which the inquiry would proceed regardless. The Democrats' proposal for an inquiry is practical and sensible. It provides for continuing parliamentary scrutiny of ministerial and public service performance, without needlessly going over old ground. I commend this motion to the Senate.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ALSTON
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —This motion to establish the Select Committee on Matters Arising from Pay Television Tendering Processes is now before the Senate because there is a general recognition, both in the community and in the Parliament, that the events of recent weeks have been quite unsatisfactory in terms of establishing norms of responsibility and in terms of identifying the extent to which the processes of one department, in particular, are satisfactory. We have said consistently that the only way to really attack these matters is not to have an internal inquiry. Professor Pearce, brought in as an outsider with limited terms of reference, has certainly made a contribution. But it has been clear all along that we needed to go that extra step.

PARA.TAB: I am delighted that, with the Australian Democrats, we have been able to agree on a form of words that, I think, will address all of those concerns. Without in any way wanting to get into the business of deciding who thought of what first, suffice it to say that we have, for some weeks, maintained that there was a need for a Senate committee. I am delighted that others now accept the desirability of that approach.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Transport and Communications)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased, on behalf of the Government, to support this motion. I have not had a chance to check, but I will check whether this is the very first time that a committee has actually been established to try to define, in the contemporary Australian scene, the definition of what ministerial responsibility should be under our Westminster system. Interesting research papers have been published on it, and it will be interesting to see what input—
—I've won my bet!
—I owe Senator Ray a dollar. I bet Senator Ray a dollar that I would not go for more than a minute.
—Money for jam!

—It was, actually. He should have taken the $100 offer I made and then I would have shut up. It will be interesting to see some of the submissions received by the Select Committee on Matters Arising from Pay Television Tendering Processes from members of parliament, both Federal and State who will, no doubt, want to have their 5c worth. I certainly look forward to the deliberations of the committee.

PARA.TAB: I conclude by talking about the important part of the reference so far as I am concerned—the second part of the reference. I have tabled papers in this Parliament from the Secretary to my department that indicate what action has already been taken. I tabled another one today with respect to the second Pearce report. I and the department will be extremely busy between now and when Parliament sits again in redressing the problems and in reporting back to Parliament. I gave an undertaking prior to this motion being moved that I would do that and, most importantly, ensure that the organisations that will formally handle the tender processes of the department—principally the Australian Broadcasting Authority, representatives of whom I spoke to some weeks ago, and the Spectrum Management Agency—will have full access to the voluminous material that has been produced. I look forward to the deliberations of the committee and its final report to the Senate.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: SOCIAL SECURITY AMENDMENT BILL 1993VETERANS' AFFAIRS LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1993

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Consideration of House of Representatives Message

PARA.TAB: Messages received from the House of Representatives acquainting the Senate that it had disagreed to the amendment made by the Senate to the Bills, for the reasons shown in an annexed schedule.
Ordered that consideration of the messages in Committee of the Whole proceed forthwith.

EMPHASIS.TAB: Reasons of the House of Representatives for disagreeing to the amendment of the Senate to the Social Security Amendment Bill 1993—

PROCTEXT.PARA: (1)It excludes shares and other listed securities from the definition of investment product in the Social Security Act and thereby prevents the equitable assessment of the ongoing gains made on shares and other investments listed on the Stock Exchange compared with indirect investments in shares through equity trusts.

(2)The amendment will reduce the equity of the social security income test. The assessment of ongoing capital gains on shares ensures that equity of the social security social security system is enhanced. Pensioners with the same means and the same financial resources available to them should have the same amount of income assessed for social security purposes. People who invest in shares should not be treated more beneficially than those who invest in equity trusts or other managed investments, and they should not be treated more beneficially than those pensioners who invest in income generating investments such as bank accounts.

(3)The amendment would result in the expenditure of approximately $60 million within the Social Security portfolio in a full year and a further $20 million for a full year within the Veterans' Affairs portfolio on a group of clients with substantial financial resources.

(4)There is no reason why shares should be excluded and given privileged treatment. It is a principle of the social security income test that ongoing gains are treated as income for all investments that can be readily realised and utilised by pensioners for their support. Only those investments which are not readily realisable, such as real estate and shares held in private companies, are currently exempt. Listed shares can be sold in small or large bundles at any time allowing gains on listed shares to be readily utilised by a pensioner.

EMPHASIS.TAB: Reasons of the House of Representatives for disagreeing to the amendment of the Senate to the Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment Bill 1993—

PROCTEXT.PARA: (1)It excludes shares and other listed securities from the definition of investment product in the Veterans' Entitlements Act and thereby prevents the equitable assessment of the ongoing gains made on shares and other investments listed on the Stock Exchange compared with indirect investments in shares through equity trusts.

(2)The amendment will reduce the equity of the service pension income test. The assessment of ongoing capital gains on shares ensures that equity of the service pension income test is enhanced. Pensioners with the same means and the same financial resources available to them should have the same amount of income assessed for service pension purposes. People who invest in shares should not be treated more beneficially than those who invest in equity trusts or other managed investments, and they should not be treated more beneficially than those pensioners who invest in income generating investments such as bank accounts.
(3)The amendment would result in the expenditure of approximately $20 million in a full year on a group of clients who generally have substantial financial resources.

(4)There is no reason why shares should be excluded and given privileged treatment. It is a principle of the income test that ongoing gains are treated as income for all investments that can be readily realised and utilised by pensioners for their support. Only those investments which are not readily realisable, such as real estate and shares held in private companies should be exempt. Listed shares can be sold in small or large bundles at any time allowing gains on listed shares to be readily utilised by a pensioner.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Defence)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the committee does not insist upon its amendments to which the House of Representatives has disagreed.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not propose to canvass all the arguments—that has well and truly been done. I have spied an amendment standing in the name of the Opposition which is to be moved at an appropriate time. That amendment proposes to refer certain matters to the Standing Committee on Community Affairs for inquiry and report by 18 August 1993. The Government does not propose to support this amendment. However, in view of the exigencies of the numbers of this place, we will accept defeat with grace.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —In December 1992 the Government brought legislation into this place that, in part, proposed that pensioners who invested in shares would, from September 1993, have unrealised capital gains treated as income for the purposes of assessing their pension. The Opposition expressed its concern about this at the time. From the moment we discussed the legislation, we said that we thought it was inequitable and that it had problems, and that in government we would review it. We are not in a position to review it so we have done the next best thing we could in opposition. In conjunction with the Democrats, we addressed the issue because we felt that there was sufficient concern in the community. Also, we had made a commitment to pensioners, in particular, that we would attempt to do something if we were in government.

PARA.TAB: When speaking to that legislation, I said that I doubted the validity of the principle underlying the Government's proposal. We were effectively prevented from opposing the amendments that went through in 1992 because they were attached to other benefits. We had the prospect of a gun being held at our heads—that if we opposed the amendments relating to unrealised capital gains for pensioners, some of the other benefits would not flow. That is why we did not oppose that amendment at the time. As I said, we made a commitment to review it and we have done that in conjunction with the Democrats.

We attempted to raise this as an issue and give the Government an opportunity to address the problems by putting a private member's Bill before this House and the House of Representatives. The private member's Bill that was introduced into this place was supported by the Democrats. The week before last a social security Bill came before us and the Democrats and the Opposition took the opportunity to put pressure on the Government to address the issue yet again. Our private member's Bill still stands. However, we took the opportunity to use our private member's Bill as the basis for an amendment to social security legislation that was before the Senate. That amendment was passed in this House and the legislation was sent to the lower house. But the Government has yet again seen fit to return that amendment to this chamber. In doing so, it is denying pensioners—many of whom have small amounts of money that they have saved—the opportunity of having some sort of financial predicability.

We are again in a situation where the Bill now before us contains other benefits. Those benefits would be jeopardised if we oppose the motion that the Minister for Defence (Senator Robert Ray) has moved. We are clear about what will happen if we oppose the motion. Mr Keating told us that in no uncertain terms yesterday. In fact, Mr Keating knows so little about what goes on in this chamber that he was wrong. But he did not have the good grace to go back into the House of Representatives chamber and admit that he was wrong. I do not expect that he reads the speeches that are made by Senator Lees and me but I would have thought that his advisers might have read them or at least understood what we do up in this place.

We have supported amendments which are beneficial to people on the unemployment benefit. We have supported amendments that assist pensioners. If honourable senators go through my speech they will see that I said things such as `We welcome this initiative' and `We support this initiative'. They will see that the Democrats welcomed and supported the initiatives. What does Mr Keating say? He went through each of those initiatives and said that we opposed and rejected every item of benefit. He does not understand what we did. Not only does he not understand but also, when speaking in the other place, he misrepresented what we did.

The Democrats and the Opposition should be equally amused, confused and annoyed by what the Prime Minister did. There was an attempt in the House of Representatives yesterday afternoon to censure the Prime Minister because he had misrepresented what went on in this place. We agreed with all the amendments. All we did was add our amendment, which asked the Government to address the issue again. Never did we oppose those amendments.

What did Mr Keating call us? He called us irresponsible, stupid people—villains. I looked up what `villain' means; it means a person guilty or capable of great wickedness, and a scoundrel. Well, I actually call Mr Keating a villain—and I suppose I am allowed to do so as he did it yesterday; he is a scoundrel—because yesterday he misrepresented what went on in this chamber. Therefore, he is not in a position to call us irresponsible, stupid people who are villains.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise on a point of order, Mr Temporary Chairman. I draw Senator Patterson's attention to the matter that is under consideration here.
—That's what Keating was talking about.
—Whether he was drawn to order in the other place, I am not sure. I was just trying to get us onto the main subject matter here.

PARA.TAB: The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN (Senator Chapman)—Senator Patterson, the term that you have used is not parliamentary.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Temporary Chairman, I will quote what Mr Keating said—it is relevant because he was talking about this very Bill. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . those opposite are into revenge, obfuscation and just being villains. They are irresponsible, stupid people.

I am not going to call Mr Keating those things. I will say that people can make their own judgment about the fact that he has not understood what went on here. If people do not understand what goes on here, they are stupid; and if they misrepresent what goes on here, they are villains and they are irresponsible. People can draw their own conclusions from that. That is what Mr Keating did and he failed to go back into the chamber.

PARA.TAB: We are not villains, we are not stupid and we are not irresponsible. We are concerned about pensioners. People have come to our offices and expressed concern. In fact, I have received many letters—I think Senator Bell has received a huge number of letters—from people expressing concern about the fact that this measure will mean that there will be no predicability in their financial lives.

Yesterday in the other place the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Social Security (Mr Sciacca) said that a similar situation applies to people who have managed investments. But people who have managed investments have a more predictable income. So too do people who have shares in friendly societies. But the income of people who have investments in listed securities is less predictable and therefore we are likely to see greater fluctuations in their pensions as a result of this measure.

In order to address this issue and in order to give people an opportunity to present their case to the Government—it does not seem that they have been able to do this—the Democrats and the Opposition have decided to accept the Government's motion. But we refuse to accept that this issue should not be looked at further. One mechanism that the Senate has available to it—because we have the numbers—is to ask a standing committee to look at this issue in detail. We have prepared an amendment which will enable this to happen. I move:
At end of motion, add: "but that the following matters be referred to the Standing Committee on Community Affairs for inquiry and report by 18 August 1993:

SPEECH.PARA: All aspects of the proposed treatment of unrealised capital gains and losses on listed securities as income under the Social Security Act 1991 and the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986; and in particular:

PARA.TAB: (a)whether the Government's costings for this measure are valid;
(b)whether the proposed method of calculating unrealised capital gains and losses is fair and equitable;
(c)the effect that the implementation of this measure is likely to have on national savings and investment decisions made by pensioners and veterans;
(d)whether this measure will result in a more or less equitable treatment of the various types of pensioner and veterans' investments under the relevant incomes and assets tests; and
(e)the wider implications of creating the precedent of deeming unrealised capital gains and losses on listed securities as income.".

SPEECH.PARA: They are the issues that concern pensioners, and they are the issues that we want the committee to address. We hope that when that committee comes forward with its report, the Government will re-examine its position on this and attempt to ensure that the income and assets test for pensioners is as fair and equitable as possible.

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats are determined to exhaust all the parliamentary processes available to us. As Senator Patterson has outlined, this issue has been running since December last year. The Democrats have been, and continue to be, opposed to what we see as a most unfair measure. It impacts not only on pensioners but also on the share market, the value of Australian shares and whether Australians will be encouraged to own shares. I will not re-run that issue, but simply explain where we are now. We are not prepared to let it die.

PARA.TAB: Effectively, in supporting Senator Patterson's amendment, we have temporarily taken it off a vehicle that is passing us and we are more than prepared to put it on the next vehicle that comes our way. We do believe it needs to be looked at very closely. I realise there has already been some discussion in committee on this matter, but not to these specific points. By referring this matter to a committee, we will give pensioners a specific place to direct their letters, comments and experiences rather than risk the whole lot of mail ending up in a bin somewhere.

The groups that have been coming to us and writing to us—the hundreds of people from Tasmania alone who have written to Senator Bell—will now be able to address their anger and make comments and formal representation to the Senate committee on this issue. The issue is very much alive, and we are not prepared to walk away from it. There is still a lot to be done in the use of the parliamentary process to make sure that the Government really is made accountable. One hidden issue is exactly how far we will go on this principle that the Government has decided upon. Will taxpayers who hold shares end up paying more tax if those shares go up in value? This will certainly not be the last time that we deal with this issue in this place. I look forward to the committee hearings as we proceed towards August.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before the amendment is put, it is important to recognise what has gone on here. I, like my colleagues, do not want to rehearse the argument that has been well run in the media. It has been put without any substantial contradiction by the Government or its representatives, or anybody who agrees with the Government—although I have not found anyone who does. The argument that has been rehearsed by the media in that way has been well presented and has not been successfully countered by any representations from the Government.

PARA.TAB: There is no factual basis for this move against pensioner shareholders. I suggest that the best thing the Government could do would be to pay particular attention to the submissions that come before this committee which Senator Patterson has proposed.

I suppose the coalition has been convinced that the Government will not accept these amendments as part of the social security legislation. As Senator Patterson outlined earlier in her speech, the Government ran a very snotty little blackmail session yesterday, which disgusted those who heard it and which should continue to disgust anybody who reads the transcript of it in the future. The contribution by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) was foul in the extreme in the way that it purported to give to people who are concerned with pensioners motives which they do not have, motives which I reject and motives which I think the Prime Minister was stretching the depths of a gutter brain to find. The people concerned should not be insulted by ever having to read it. But there it is in black and white—just what the Prime Minister said. Senator Patterson was right to bring those disgusting phrases into this place.

The concern Senator Lees just passed by us is one that is shared by a number of people. If the principle is continued of redefining the English language to such an extent that capital gains is determined as income, where will it end? In the previous argument, we mentioned that it could well apply to other capital investments such as land, the family home, artwork, antiques et cetera. But the principle could equally apply to PAYE taxpayers who have capital gains and who are anticipating the right payment of capital gains tax when they redeem their capital investments.

Following the principle that is being established here, PAYE taxpayers would be assessed annually for the increase in value of their capital portfolio. There might be some justification for doing that if all taxpayers had their share portfolios, land, family home, artworks, French clocks et cetera, valued each year and had to pay tax on them. We might then see some sort of equity, which is supposed to be the motivation for this Government's move in this area but which, of course, it is not. It is not equity; it is a complete misunderstanding of the way the world works and the way people plan for their future. It is most inequitable in its delivery.

The committee will also be able, without a great deal of difficulty—I reckon it will take it about five minutes—to demonstrate the lack of factual basis for the calculation of potential savings for the Government. Another five minutes is probably all that will be required to demonstrate to the committee that it will cost the Government as much to administer this nefarious scheme as it might save. It will take perhaps another five minutes to demonstrate that Australia will not be well served at all and that Australian investment will suffer. After that, we will be able to get down to the real issue of how fair it is and how it should be dismissed entirely. Consequently, I certainly support Senator Patterson's amendment.

Personally, I am not convinced that the Government would have withdrawn the original legislation, because the social security legislation onto which this amendment was originally tacked was necessary. It was blackmail and a bluff, and that is illustrated by the sheer invective that the Prime Minister came out with; that was the usual song and dance routine that we have seen from the Prime Minister, and it had about as much substance as any of the others. I think the Government would have eventually backed away. I do not accept the bluff at all. However, faced with the reality that this Bill will be supported, I look forward to the committee being able to demonstrate to the Government the fallacy of its original intentions.
Amendment agreed to.
Motion, as amended, agreed to.
Resolution reported; report adopted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —When I first came to this place 15 years ago, when the passions of 1975 were still very much alight, I said in my maiden speech that my views about the Senate were so well known that I feared I would have to walk the corridors like a medieval leper armed with a little hand bell calling out before me, `Unclean! Unclean!'. I have to say 15 years later, despite the exalted position in which I now find myself, that my attitudes to the Senate as an institution have not significantly mellowed.

PARA.TAB: What I have long been conscious of and what I have enjoyed in this place is the extraordinarily diverse cast of characters who make it up, with an unbelievable range of backgrounds, skills and personalities. In a sense, all human life passes through this place, along with one or two other species from time to time. We learn a lot about each other's follies and foibles, and our attractive points as well, in the inordinate amount of time we spend here together and it is an occasion of genuine sadness to see people leaving, even some of those whose demise on occasions one may have been fervently praying for.

The longest serving of our departing senators, and a person whom I personally will be very genuinely sad to see go, is Peter Durack, who came here many years ago in the early 1970s. Peter is a man who in his own quiet way I once would have referred to as sleepy, but that was before I became a statesman. Peter is a man of genuinely Liberal reformist instincts. Peter is a thoroughly decent human being. I gave him a terrible time when he was Attorney-General and he did his best to reciprocate in the years that followed when he shadowed me through various portfolios. But I think we came genuinely—I do not know whether today has been a counter-example of that—to respect each other's commitment to good government and good policy and to form one of those funny kinds of friendships that are possible across party lines in this place. Peter has had a very honourable career and I wish him and Isabel a long and happy retirement together.

I cannot pretend that I formed quite the same cross-party political bond with Shirley Walters. A Liberal reformist she ain't. An indefatigable, noisy, wearying campaigner for every tory value I deeply deplore she is.
