We have moreover said some absolutely terrible things to each other over the years in the rough and tumble of the Senate chamber. But all that said, I have never suspected or seen any actual malice about Shirley. She has believed fiercely in a series of particular political objectives, she has been as tough as nails in this place in pursuing those objectives, but she has always been thoroughly charming and pleasant personally and impossible to hold a grudge against.

TALK.START.PARA: —Watch out for that lightning!

—She has been one of the really colourful personalities in this place—and I am not going to respond except to allow that interjection into the record. She has been one of the really colourful personalities in this place and we are going to remember her for a long time to come. I did not think I would ever hear myself saying it in this place, but we are going to miss you.

PARA.TAB: Florence Bjelke-Petersen is cast in an altogether gentler mode, even if her political causes have been, if anything, over the years even more unmentionable. From the day Flo came here in 1981, she has unquestionably been a personality in her own right, someone whose genuine warmth and good humour makes her rather irritatingly someone that is absolutely impossible to be irritated with. It is just a pity that John Button is not here to wave her goodbye. The two of them have been fluttering eyelashes at each other across the chamber for as long as I can remember.

Austin Lewis has been here in one capacity or another since 1976, rising to become, of course as he did between 1989 and 1990, No. 3 in the Liberal Party. I think I can say, again notwithstanding today's exchange, without any dissimulation or any gilding of lilies, that Austin Lewis is one of the most liked parliamentarians in this building. His honesty and his frankness have got him into a lot of political trouble from time to time. He has not had quite that same kind of teflon coating that seems to have enabled others, maybe equally deserving, to avoid that kind of fate, but those qualities have never lost him any friends in this place. Even Paul Lyneham was heard on one occasion to describe him as an `immensely likeable, easygoing sort of chap'. There are not many of us around this place who have had that accolade from Mr Lyneham.

There are two other non-Labor senators leaving as well. Janet Powell, who came in as a Democrat in 1986 and who leaves us now as an Independent, I think won a great deal of respect and admiration for the way in which she has withstood, with apparently infinite good cheer, the buffeting of what has been, on any analysis, a pretty tumultuous political career. She said when she became the Leader of the Democrats, `You'd have to have rocks in your head to be a political leader'. I think we can all understand that sentiment, even if it was not only the Australian Democrats that she was talking about. One monument that Janet can be very proud of is the tobacco advertising prohibition Bill, which is one of the very few private member's Bills ever to make it to the statute books in the history of this country.

Karin Sowada has been here the shortest time of all the departees, but she has certainly made her presence felt in a variety of ways during that period. It may cheer her up to know that, while it is pretty much par for the course for all Australian Democrats to reduce government Ministers and senators to wailing and gnashing of teeth from time to time, Karin Sowada has single-handedly, over the last two years, caused more distress to the Government than nearly all her colleagues put together. I think that might make her feel better. She will now be able to put all that practice in digging holes for the Government back into a professional context as she resumes her career as an archaeologist. I know all of us in the chamber will wish Karin Sowada well.

Then, of course, it comes to departing colleagues from one's own side of the chamber. I suppose it does not follow as an absolute matter of logical necessity that one is sadder to see them go than one's opponents. Nonetheless, for most of us that is a very reasonable assumption. It is with very real regret and nostalgia that we wave goodbye today to Terry Aulich, Graham Maguire, Pat Giles, Peter Walsh and, although it is a little distance from his actual departure, John Button.

Might I say in parenthesis that I know there has been some media speculation that this might also be Michael Tate's last day in the Senate. All I can say in that respect, like the character in The House of Cards television series is, `You may well say that. I couldn't possibly comment'. If that were conceivably to come to pass, Michael would just have to settle for us saying nice things behind his back; although that is always a much more risky proposition than having it said to one's face, as we all know.

Terry Aulich, who came in here in 1984 after six years in State politics, during which time he held eight different ministries—which, in itself, suggests a certain lack of staying power—has had a career which has been graphically described by Senator Ray at a recent function we had for our retiring members as:

SPEECH.PARA: Footballer, boxer, teacher, union official, poet, State Minister, party apparatchik, Senator, novelist—

and—here I am bowdlerising a little—bulldust artist. Terry's political career has also included residence at one time or another in all three factions of the Australian Labor Party. The chamber will recall that even Billy Hughes took the view that you had to draw the line somewhere but Terry has not shared that view. All this has now caught up with him. He is going off to pursue yet another career. Whether that career will be focused on writing books or pulping them remains to be seen. But, whatever career it is, we wish him well. Terry has been a lively and engaging colleague. There was never a dull moment with him around.

PARA.TAB: Graham Maguire, senator for South Australia since 1983, is another colleague who has in a sense been cut off in his prime as a result essentially of preselection problems. While this is an occupational hazard about which we all have to be philosophical, it is certainly a matter of regret for his colleagues and, I would have thought, in the case of Graham, everyone in this chamber who has worked with him.

Graham Maguire is the quintessential good, straight, honest, hardworking guy—nothing remotely flashy about him—but utterly dedicated to his political principles and enormously professionally capable in the exercise of all his senatorial roles. There is not a malicious bone in his body. I have particularly appreciated, as have many others including people overseas in the foreign relations business, the quite groundbreaking work that has been done by the Senate Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade under Graham Maguire's chairmanship; in particular, the major reports for which he and his committee have been responsible on India and Latin America.

Pat Giles is someone else at the less flashy end of the politicians spectrum but someone who is equally liked and admired for her personal qualities and her huge efforts over the years on women's issues, human rights issues, and peace and disarmament issues. I do not think Pat was ever fully convinced that, on women's issues, I was quite the SNAG that I claim to be—for the benefit of the Country Party that is a sensitive new age guy—but she certainly did her best to educate us all. I remember one famous occasion during the course of one of her gynaecological contributions—a subject on which over the years only Michael Tate has been more forthcoming when he was representing the Minister for Health in this place—Pat referred to `cytological changes in the cervix' which Hansard duly recorded as `psychological changes in the cervix', thereafter, of course, entrenching allusions to the moody interior of the chamber. Pat is a lovely lady and I hope that we will continue to see a lot of her in one or other of the numerous activist roles that I hope and believe she will continue to play.

Peter Walsh has already assumed a legendary status in his own parliamentary lifetime, and I fear he may be about to write another chapter of that legend this afternoon. No-one can claim not to have been warned from the outset about Peter Walsh. The wheat farmer from Doodlakine started his parliamentary career in the acerbic style which continued thereafter when he said in his maiden speech:

Predictably I have a particular interest in rural issues and a special interest in agriculture . . . I think I can justly claim to possess all the attributes so much admired by our agricultural fundamentalists except, hopefully, the intellectual atrophy of which the Country Party is both a product and a cause.

SPEECH.PARA: What Peter Walsh has contributed to this place and to the government of this country over the time that he has been in the Senate is not just his sometimes quite outrageous iconoclasm, but an enormous personal intelligence and integrity; an enormous intensity of focus on the main economic game; and, I have to say, an enormous sense of social justice in the finest traditions of democratic socialism.

PARA.TAB: I can remember rather amusing Peter once at a function for the Labor Party in Fremantle and enraging the party faithful to whom I spoke by saying that historically speaking the ALP was racist before it was socialist. Peter has never been one of those people to confuse the romance with the reality. He has been someone who has given real modern content to that democratic socialist tradition of which we in the Labor Party are still so proud.

John Button came into the Senate at the same time as Peter Walsh—the 1974 double dissolution. Their careers in a sense ran a parallel course thereafter. But it is hard to think of two more unalike characters. Whereas Peter Walsh has looked for most of his life like, as I described him once, an unmade bed, John Button is a model of sartorial dapperness; whereas Peter Walsh has made a career out of being a curmudgeon, albeit of the heart of gold variety, I think it would be fair to say that John Button has been the first person since Shirley Temple to build a whole career out of whimsy; and whereas Peter Walsh's inclination was always to crash into the water and swim against just about any tide that was going, John Button notoriously was always the man who dodged the raindrops—and that was not just a sizeist remark by whoever it was who first made it.

Different as his style may have been, there is no doubt that during his time in this place John Button was an extraordinarily successful and effective politician. He was a senator for 19 years; Leader of the Labor Party in the Senate for 12 years; and industry Minister for 10 years during a period of most fundamental and far-reaching industry change and reform in this country's history. John won an extraordinary degree of confidence and respect from industry which was earned by the constant attention he gave to what people were saying about the real world. He won it through his extremely effective style of communication, combined with a capacity at the same time to prompt people into embracing new horizons, not least in our own region. This particular style made him a unique character in the history of this place and I know he will be missed not just by his own side but by the whole chamber.

Mr President, in addition to our departing colleagues there is one other unhappily more permanent passing that should be acknowledged with sadness; that is, as you mentioned earlier today, the passing yesterday of Jim Monro the former Second Parliamentary Counsel who, for more than 15 years, put his legislative drafting skills at the service of senators on all sides of the chambers in providing them with amendments in private senators' Bills. I knew Jim Monro very well myself, having given him apoplexy back in 1973 when, as a consultant to Lionel Murphy, I worked with him in the drafting of what proved to be an ill-fated legislative bill of rights. Jim was absolutely unequivocal in his distaste for what he obviously regarded as a heap of trendy nonsense but, like a true soldier, he soldiered on, and I think he was sneakingly rather proud of the result. I am sure all senators will join with me in expressing our thanks to him for what he contributed and, at the same time, our very great sympathy to his widow.

Mr President, at the conclusion of this session I would like to thank you for once again the grace, the good humour and the firmness with which you have guided our deliberations—not always easy ones—in this chamber. We are looking forward to seeing you back next session. I want to acknowledge the work of the Clerk of the Senate, Harry Evans, and all the staff of the Department of the Senate for providing a very wide range of services which enable this chamber, our committees and offices to run efficiently. I hope all senators will have a good break and come back here relaxed, refreshed and ready to do battle in what will be unquestionably a pretty trying three years ahead.

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —If I might start where Senator Evans finished and join with him, both personally and on behalf of my colleagues, to thank the officers of the Senate and all of the staff. I will not mention all the separate officers and departments by name but I thank them for their fantastic support.

PARA.TAB: I particularly reflect upon that awful period leading up to Christmas last year when intolerable burdens were placed upon officials in this place. Now is probably not the time to have a go at the Government's management of its program, even though it was largely the mismanagement of that program that got the Senate into that state. It was a matter of sadness for those of us on this side that we were not even given the opportunity before the Government moved the gag in the early hours of the last morning to say thank you to the Clerks and all the staff in this place for the help that they gave us during that difficult period. We do recognise that, even if at times we do not seem to appreciate you, Mr President. I appreciate the opportunity to be able to put that on the record now.

I also want to refer to the sad news that you, Mr President, brought to us of the death of Mr Monro. On behalf of the coalition senators, I record our condolences to his family. Although I did not know him personally, I do know of the great help that he gave to Opposition senators who were mainly in the business of drafting private members' Bills and the like, and we very much appreciated his help and expertise.

This is principally the occasion on which we say a few pleasant words about our colleagues who are departing and to give them an opportunity to say about us what they really want to say on this final occasion. I might take the reverse order and just mention the senators on the other side who are retiring and whom we wish to recognise for their contribution to the Parliament, and some of them to government, and to wish them well in their retirement.

Regrettably, Senator Button is not here today, but we must recognise him for what, I guess, could be referred to as an enormous contribution to Australian parliamentary life and to government. He served here for 19 years. He was a shadow Minister for two years, industry Minister for 10 years, Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate for three years, then Leader of the Opposition in the Senate the next three years, Leader of the Government in the Senate for 10 years and so one could go on. He certainly left his mark in that regard.

I guess what impressed me most about Senator Button was that fine balance of a good sense of humour plus his intellectual capacity. The blend of that often helped to make this place more interesting. I recognised and appreciated that. I also appreciated the clear dedication that he put to his work in industry. We did not always agree with the policy he implemented but it was interesting to note the number of constituents who came to us in the course of having seen the Minister first and who commented on the fact that Senator Button, no matter how busy, was always prepared to listen and hear their cases and give fair judgment on their cases. That might be a lesson to Senator Evans in the years ahead. Constituents are important and it is worth listening to their arguments. I wish Senator Button well in his retirement. He is somebody who will be missed in this place and, according to some, has already been missed in this place.

Senator Walsh, of course, is a great character in here—a fine political mind, as Senator Evans has said. He brought to this place a good political instinct which, I believe, is something to be respected. He has lots of courage and has always been prepared to say what he believed no matter what the consequences. That is something that we appreciated also. We look forward to what he will say later in this debate and we wish him well in his retirement from this place.

I have served with Senator Giles on a number of committees. I have always admired her dedication to her causes which were never forgotten. She was always in there fighting for the issues that she believed to be of great importance and often neglected, particularly women's issues. I heard her the other day when I went to an Amnesty International lunch. She was first on her feet to demand of the speaker what Amnesty was doing about one particular important women's human rights issue. I think there are many Australians who should be appreciative of her contribution to the Senate during her period here.

Senator Maguire should not be going, I have to say. The fact that you are is an indictment upon the Labor Party. It would probably be improper of me to say more than that as he will no doubt seek preselection and come back either here or at the other end in due course. We noted that practically through the whole of the last parliament when somebody needed to be called on at short notice to respond to an MPI in the economic area, so often it was Senator Maguire. We recognised his skills in that area. I particularly want to record what I think was important and that was the role that he played in the Senate foreign affairs committee, his chairmanship of that committee and some of its very significant reports in recent years that I think have, in themselves, made a contribution to improving Australia's international relations.
I do not know Senator Aulich as well, but he has also brought a sense of humour to this place on occasions during Question Time. Terry, I wish you well.

I probably know Senator Tate better than any of them through long associations on constitutional and legal committees. I presume that you are going, senator. I do concede that The Hague will enable you to continue your legal interests with the International Court of Justice and the association with Rome that I understand will be linked with it. This will enable you to present Australia's view to that high authority in a way that is in our best interests. We wish you well in Europe, Michael, and we hope that you will always have a bed for colleagues who might be passing through. That is one of the requirements of ex-parliamentarians who get these jobs. I just thought I might let you know that in advance.

I do not think Senator Powell was all that well treated by her colleagues either. I had quite a lot to do with Senator Powell when she was Leader of the Australian Democrats. I found that I could always be confident of what she said to me. We developed a good relationship during that short period of time. I have always respected her dedication to her causes and I wish her well in her retirement.
I do not want to say a lot about Senator Sowada because I suspect she might be back soon also. If you praise senators retiring at this time you often hear it back on a later occasion.

TALK.START.PARA: —Better come back as a Liberal, though.

—She has shown a bit of courage and, I have to say, good judgment on occasion. I was reflecting on those times that she voted with us, Senator Macdonald, on very important issues of freedom of information and the like. She may not have been here long, but she has shown both courage and ability. If she is to come back, so be it. Senator Macdonald has given you an invitation and you might like to enter into some negotiations. If you decide not to seek to come back, we wish you well.

PARA.TAB: That leads me now to my colleagues. There are four of my colleagues who are retiring and who, I think I can fairly say, have made an enormous contribution to both parliament and politics in this country. Senator Durack has had 22 years in politics, Senator Walters 18 years, Senator Lewis 17 years and, although Senator Bjelke-Petersen has been in politics all her life, she has been with us in this place for 12 years. That is some 69 years in total of contributions to Australian political life that will end today. It really makes this quite a significant day in our political history.

Senator Durack retires with an immensely impressive record. When one looks at his background, one finds that he was a Rhodes scholar in 1949, he had three years in the Western Australia Parliament, was a Fraser Government Minister for repatriation, the Attorney-General for six years, Deputy Leader of the Government in the Senate for five years, Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate from 1983 to 1987, and then again from 1990-92. As I have said, that sketches a parliamentary career that is both long and incredibly impressive.

No doubt others will refer to his period as Attorney-General, and I endorse what Senator Evans said. I think of this time as a period of reform. I think of the administrative law reform that he brought into effect by setting up the AAT. I think of the Human Rights Commission that he established and his early work in relation to a freedom of information Bill. I was reminded that even before being a Minister he did a lot of groundwork in relation to the Family Law Act as Chairman of the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs. So one could go on. He was very much a reformist from the day he got here and throughout his period as Attorney-General. We owe a great debt to Senator Durack for his contributions.

From a personal point of view what struck me about Senator Durack is the dignity with which he has always carried on the business of politics, his skills and his judgment, which has always been impeccable. If one wants advice, not only would one always get it from Senator Durack but one could be confident of that advice because it would be sound and sensible. I guess it could be summed up in the word `professionalism'. He is a highly professional parliamentarian, someone who can retire proud of his contributions and someone who retires highly respected within the community. Peter we today recognise, with appreciation, all you have done for Australia and wish you well in your retirement.
Opposition senators—Hear, hear!

TALK.START.PARA: —The second of my colleagues I wanted to mention was Senator Flo, who was a legend before she got here. But nevertheless she has made her mark as an individual in this place. I remember her speeches on the family and on roads, and roads and on the family, and on roads and the family. She is a Queenslander from the beginning to the end. I think her last question today was a Queensland question, and I have no doubt that her first question in this place was a Queensland question also.

PARA.TAB: She has represented her State with great determination and she has sought to advance the interests of Queenslanders. She has stood by her values constantly. She is somebody who we all respect. We are not sure exactly what she is going to do in her retirement, but I understand—

TALK.START.PARA: —Someone has to run the farm.

—I am told that Joh is into worm growing at the moment, so she might help in that industry. I gather her new book entitled Classic Country Cooking about traditional Australian fare is about to be launched. I doubt that there is anyone in this place—certainly not on this side and I suspect not many on the other side—who has not sold her pumpkin scone recipe at fundraisers, both for charitable and political purposes. Florence, we respect your family values that you have stood by and without fear continually promoted as important within Australian life. You have been a credit to this place and we will miss you.

PARA.TAB: The third of my colleagues I wanted to mention was Senator Lewis. Senator Lewis is one of those examples in politics where he has been a bit unlucky with his time. It is unfortunate, we think, that we have been in Opposition for the last 10 years or so. If that had not been the case and Senator Lewis was retiring now, we would have been talking about Senator Lewis having been a government Minister for a long period. He served for over five years in the Opposition shadow Ministry. He served in a number of different shadow portfolios, such as communications and industry and he was Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate for three years. Austin can retire being proud of his contribution in this place.

Again from a personal point of view, apart from Austin being a genuinely good type of person, it is his fighting characteristics that I will remember. Some of his speeches when he took on Senator Button on industry policy I will remember for a long time. We heard again today in his final question in this place a deep concern about the future of Australia, the future for those who are unemployed and the future of the young people of Australia. I think it would have been in Australia's best interests if he had had the opportunity to be industry Minister for some years and contributed to an economy that would have been much more sound than it is today. Austin, we thank you for your contributions and wish you well also.

I did not deliberately leave Senator Walters to last. It is just the way that it worked out. I told my colleagues the other night, and I may as well share it with the whole chamber, that just as a matter of interest I asked Hansard whether it would get out the number of Senator Walters's recorded interjections. I have to say to you that, in the last two years alone, the sum is in excess of 580.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is that all?

—That is not including today's and yesterday's. When I came in this morning and looked at the red and saw that Senator Walters was there on an item of business relating to human rights and equal opportunities, I thought she snuck it in on me again. I could not believe that she had agreed to have it adjourned until after she had retired.

PARA.TAB: We remember Senator Walters for her dogged determination. She is a fighter in anyone's language. I do not know that I have ever come across anyone with quite the application and determination that Shirley Walters has, and they are good qualities in politics. She has also come here holding strong values and she has been prepared to fight for those values each and every day of her parliamentary life. I guess most of us will particularly remember that in relation to the X-rated video issue. She was concerned about affronts to the dignity of women, she was going to fight to improve the dignity of women in that regard and she has fought constantly towards achieving that goal. Shirley Walters, everyone in this place will remember you. I think everyone will remember you fondly; certainly those of us on this side will. We will also remember you for your contribution to the Parliament and the way in which you so doggedly fought for your beliefs. We wish you well in your retirement.
Honourable senators—Hear, hear!

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to join Senator Evans and Senator Hill in wishing our retiring senators all the best. It is a sad day for many of them as they leave this place for the last time and walk out the door full of memories—some good and some bad. But I am sure that when they walk out the door tonight and catch their planes it will be with regret and a lot of memories of people whom they have met here. We are all here to advance good government in Australia, whether we sit on this side or the other side.

PARA.TAB: I am going to speak about Senator Tate today. I was not going to, because I was not aware that he was leaving, so it will have to be straight off the cuff. When Senator Tate was the consumer affairs Minister, he was accused in Country Life of forming some sort of conspiracy with the National Party in the Senate when we were debating country of origin labelling and a number of other issues. He earned a lot of respect in country Australia for his stand. I remember one day when we had the great Aussie breakfast outside Parliament House. He walked out and said, `I'm not going over there. That's a National Party rally'. I said, `You'll be right. Just go in there, don't show them you're frightened and they won't hurt you'. We will miss you, Michael. I think you will do a great job in whatever position you fill.

Senator Powell, Senator Aulich and Senator Giles have all made their marks here. Senator Powell made her mark as Leader of the Australian Democrats. While she was leader, she represented the things that she believed were in the interests of her constituency and she did it well. She has always had very strong views on industrial relations, some a little too far away from where we are. Nevertheless, they were the views which got her elected and she represented them well.

When Senator Aulich came into the Parliament in the old House, he was my next door neighbour. We got to know each other and we shared a few jokes and a few laughs together. We will miss him too. As Senator Evans and Senator Hill said, he has a terrific sense of humour and he brightens up the place.

Senator Giles has always been known for pushing her pet interest. She was a strong proponent of women's interests. I was very glad that she gave us some support on the competition policy when it was critical for small business throughout Australia, and I thank her for that.

Senator Maguire is another Labor senator who is retiring. He entered the Senate at the same time as I did—in 1983. He is best known for his defence of government economic policies on MPIs. He was sent in as nightwatchman to defend almost the indefensible, but he did it with great economic skill. In our early years in Parliament he used to target me about Queensland's economy. Graham, I hope that you will find a career path that will give you satisfaction and more time with your young family, whom I know you miss sadly. If you do choose to come back, I wish you all the best in that path too.
My old colleague Senator Walsh is not here, and that is sad because I have known Senator—
Honourable senators—Yes, he is.

TALK.START.PARA: —There he is. He has changed position from the far right and moved into the centre. I have known Senator Walsh since I was six, when my grandmother shared a neighbouring fence with his farm. After 10 years of being parliamentary adversaries, I am prepared to forgive him for wiring me up to the spark plug lead on his father's tractor. I know my grandmother gave him a thump in the ear for doing it. Walshie, we wish you all the best. After all the nasty things that you have said about the Country Party, I hope you do not think too badly of us.

PARA.TAB: Senator Sowada leaves us today too. We have known her for only a short while. I will miss her and the bright, happy character which she shows around the place. She represents the right wing of the Democrats—there always has to be a right, a left and a centre in anything—and Senator Sowada has shown good judgment in supporting the coalition on a number of occasions.

Senator Durack is retiring. He is the father of the House as he leaves. I think that honour now goes across to Senator Harradine. As father of the House, he has given this side of politics wise counsel and good guidance in the party room and in the Parliament, particularly at Question Time. He has put in 22 years in both State and Federal parliaments of Australia. He has done a great job for Australia and his State. We also wish him and his wife well in retirement. He must be getting very sick and tired of taking that four-hour plane trip over and back—

TALK.START.PARA: —And the rest!

—`And the rest!', the Western Australians say. Senator Shirley Walters is also retiring. We will sincerely miss our Shirl and her 581 interjections—she scored another one today. I think that Senator Evans, Senator Collins and even Senator Button, if he were here today, would say that they will miss the exchanges that they have had with Senator Walters. She was a great representative of the State of Tasmania, both in the Parliament and in the party room. We never forgot that there was a little island off the bottom of the coast of Australia, and it was called Tasmania and it was important.

PARA.TAB: Honourable senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —It was called Tasmania and it was part of Australia. She represented Tasmania aggressively. She has always been one to make the hard ground up the middle in the Senate.

PARA.TAB: Senator Austin Lewis was placed next to me when I arrived in the Senate. We sat together for my first term in Parliament. He taught me; he was my minder in fact. I have enjoyed Austin's friendship over the past 10 years. He plans to retire to Queensland and become a constituent of mine.

TALK.START.PARA: —Shows good sense.
—Yes, Senator Bjelke-Petersen, it shows absolute good sense. I look forward to continuing my friendship with you in the future, Austin.

PARA.TAB: Finally, I would like to turn to my friend and colleague Senator Bjelke-Petersen. This is a special day for the National Party. Sir Joh started his parliamentary career in 1947. From 1947 until today there has been a Bjelke-Petersen in the Queensland or Commonwealth parliaments—nearly 47 years. Senator Bjelke-Petersen was involved in politics long before she entered the Senate. She was involved as the wife of the Premier. I am told that she received her first political invitation on her honeymoon, which was to open the Murgon State School fete. Florence is known in Kingaroy as the deputy member for Barambah because she represented her husband at countless functions and because she listened to his constituents and reported their concerns to him and action was always taken.

Sir Joh was commissioned Premier in 1968. During his time as Premier, Queensland experienced unprecedented economic growth. His was not a government that always made the easy decisions. As Premier, he made controversial decisions which I think were, in the end, in the best interests of Queensland. It was a State that was lifted to an economic powerhouse under his leadership. In 1977 he removed the State death duties, lifting a significant burden on the farm sector—a decision that forced every other State government to follow suit. Sir Joh's Government pioneered the development of the State's mining industry and it held taxes down. He did a great job for Queensland.

Florence stood beside Sir Joh during his time as Premier, despite the controversy and all the other pressures that were mounted on their lives. For many years, through controversial issues, Senator Bjelke-Petersen stood shoulder to shoulder with the Premier, offering him advice, running the farm and providing a good Christian home for Joh and the family. During those years, Florence would tour rural Queensland talking to different women's groups and rural people. She would take their views back to the Premier and then the Government would act on them. She was a most effective advocate for rural Australia because she went out there and listened to people, and when she came back all was fixed.

In 1980, at an age when most people look forward to retirement and looking after their grandchildren, Florence was called to run for the Senate. Many people, including many commentators and even some people in the National Party, thought that she would not be able to make the grade. Over the last 12 years she has proved them all wrong. She has made contributions on many Bills, asked many direct questions—as we heard today—and entered vigorously into debate. She has served as Acting Deputy President and, apart from an altercation with Senator Evans when he threatened to report her to the President, she has done it with style and decorum. She has also served for the last three months as Whip. Irrespective of what she has done in the Senate, she has earned the respect of every person in this chamber and in this Parliament. I have seen Labor senators come down here with absolute aggression towards the National Party and within a month Senator Bjelke-Petersen has had them eating out of her hand.

The highest accolade that anyone can give to retiring senators is to say that they have represented their State well, and she has done that. Many times during her parliamentary career she has stood up for Queensland primary producers, whether the debate concerned wheat, wool or sugar. When primary industry needed her support, it could rely on her coming through.

During her period as a senator, she travelled to the Torres Strait Islands. If they were having any particular problems, she was up there. I can recall one night when they had some problems and invited her up to Darnley Island, just off the Murray Islands. They had a feast, with traditional singing and dancing, and Florence was made ma ma—I think that was the term—or grandmother of the islands.

Whether we are talking about the Torres Strait, western Queensland, the Gold Coast, the north coast or Brisbane, she has earned the respect of the people in those places. She has strongly supported family values. She believes fervently, as we do in the National Party, that the family is the basic tradition of Australia. Throughout Australia she has supported that, and throughout Queensland and Australia she is known for those values. The last three years have not been easy for Florence, but down here she has carried her burden well. I think she has earned the sympathy and the respect of all the people in this chamber.

Today, Florence, is a sad day for the National Party. You have always been our exocet when it comes to campaigning. If we were contesting a marginal seat, the cry would go up, `Get Florence. Put her in', and she would campaign. She would tirelessly walk shopping centres, she would knock on doors, she would visit people and she would have morning tea after morning tea. Many a person in the National Party certainly owes his or her seat to Senator Bjelke-Petersen. If the truth were known, I suppose I would be one of those people.

Florence, I thank you on behalf of all the National Party members in Queensland—the 30,000 people who do pay to join the National Party—I thank you on behalf of all Queenslanders, and I thank you on behalf of all the people in Australia for the job that you have done and the values that you have espoused on behalf of the National Party.

TALK.START.PARA: —I believe that Senator Kernot is at a meeting. If she wishes to speak later, I will include her. At this stage I think the best thing to do is to call on the retiring senators in order of their length of service.
—What about Senator Harradine?
—It's their day; let them go first and I might say a couple of words later.

—I suppose it is appropriate for me, as the father of the Senate, although I hate that title—some people think I am really the grandfather, which is even worse—to commence the response by the retiring senators to the very warm and friendly speeches that have been made by the party leaders on the occasion of the acknowledgment of our retirement from the Senate. I have to keep telling people that I still have another month or more as a senator, as we all have.

PARA.TAB: I feel very pleased with the kind remarks that have been made, particularly by the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Gareth Evans). We have had a vigorous rivalry in this chamber over the 15 years that he has been here. I do not suppose that life was all that much easier for a Minister in the Fraser Government before Senator Evans got here, but he helped to warm things up a bit.

I think the way people see us is a bit out of perspective. Senator Evans has referred to the Costigan debates, during which he certainly gave me a hard time. I always felt that I was pretty good in giving back a hard time to him. In retrospect I can say that I rather enjoyed those debates. But there was much more to our debates over the years when I was Attorney-General than the Costigan debates. On many occasions, most of the debates, although vigorous, were positive and productive debates about important pieces of reform which in almost every case ultimately got through the Parliament—perhaps more to my liking than to his liking. Nevertheless, he and his colleagues made notable contributions to them.

I turn to the more vigorous debating that Senator Evans mentioned. Although Senator Tate is not here at the moment, I add for the record that he always made pretty effective contributions. Many times I listened more carefully to what he was saying than I did to Senator Evans. It did get a bit notorious that I was in an embattled state with Senator Tate and Senator Evans. At about that time, one member of my staff discovered a very new and very successful Western Australian wine known as Evans and Tate. He bought a few bottles of this wine and suggested that I present at least one of them to each of Senator Evans and Senator Tate. The wine has gone from strength to strength since then; I will leave it for others to judge the careers of Senator Evans and Senator Tate.

I particularly thank my leader Senator Hill for his warm valedictory speech to me. Senator Hill and I, in the twilight of my political career you might say, were very closely involved together in my resurrection as Deputy Leader of the Opposition for the two years 1990 to 1992. Although we naturally had quite a deal to do with each other over the years as colleagues, nevertheless we worked very closely and, I hope, very effectively during that period. I enjoyed those two years during which we worked together here in this chamber and that period was one of the highlights of my political career. I think during that period the Opposition worked together as a team better than it had ever done in its previous years either in government or in opposition—except perhaps during the Whitlam years when it was very difficult not to work as a team because of all the free kicks we were getting almost every day. I also thank Senator Boswell for his kind remarks and wishes.

In response to a speech made on a valedictory I think it is appropriate to thank a number of people other than those who proposed it. In particular of course, I would like to thank my wife, Isabel, and my two children, Anne and Philip, and their families for the great support I have had over the years. I came into politics much against the wishes of my family, including my parents, I might say, who thought politics was really beneath one's dignity. I do not accuse Isabel of thinking that; I think Isabel just thought that it was a pretty silly, stupid thing to do and that it would cause a lot of unnecessary inconvenience in our family life—which it has done. Therefore, I do thank her for her forbearance and I am delighted she is here in the gallery this afternoon.

My two children I do not think have suffered at all from this trauma of their father in politics, even though I came into politics when they were teenagers. I think from their point of view they benefited very much from their father not being around during those years, and I probably benefited from not having to deal with them during that difficult period of their lives. But Isabel of course had to carry that extra burden. I have always been delighted with the great interest that my children have taken and still take in political life. Although it is unlikely perhaps that either of them will go into an active political career, I know they will still remain active in their interests and perhaps activities outside parliament in political affairs.

Another group of people I would like to thank very much are my personal staff for their assistance over all the years I have been both a Senator and a Minister. I have been very lucky indeed with the quality of staff I have had working for me, and they have been an enormous support. I would like particularly to mention my two `personal assistants'—as I would refer to them rather than `personal secretaries'—and the personal assistance they gave me. I refer to Jan Keogh and in recent years Kathryn Carr. They have served me extremely well, and I am very grateful for their loyalty over all these years and through the difficult times that they have sometimes had.

I would also like to express my great regard for the staff of the Senate and their help; in particular, the series of Senate clerks over the years. I will not mention them all but I must mention our present Clerk, Harry Evans, and Deputy Clerk, Anne Lynch, and thank them for the help they have been to me. I would also like to add specifically Rob Alison as another person who has been of great help, but all the Senate staff in one form or another have been of invaluable assistance.

I also wish to mention the support staff there are in the Senate, and I will not mention them all. The attendants are perhaps the most obvious. I am pleased to see still a number of old faces amongst the attendants. When we came up here to the new House we seemed to be seeing new faces all the time, but was delighted that the attendant who brought me a glass of water before I rose to speak this afternoon is an old face and an old friend. So I do thank all the attendant staff we have.

Another group of people who have been of great help have been the drivers. I have had two drivers over the years personally assigned to me. In particular there was David Hoddell who drove me almost all the time I was a Minister and also for some of the period when we were in Opposition; and Rick Boyland who was my driver when I was resurrected, as I said, between 1990 and 1992. Both gave unstinting service and loyalty in that role. It is a very important role they perform for us when we are carrying these responsibilities.

I do not wish to spend a great deal of time going over my life in politics. I do not think this is a suitable occasion. It is certainly not one on which to publish a political will and testament. You will be pleased to know that I am not going to do that tonight, although I am thinking of doing one before 30 June and have to give some more thought to that. Perhaps I will also have to have regard to the law of defamation which I could escape if I published it tonight. But I think it would be unwise to use your forbearance tonight in speaking of very controversial matters.

People have asked me over the years what it was that attracted me to politics, why I ever became a politician and so on. The answer is that I really do not know. I have been interested in politics ever since I was in senior class at school—not just my leaving class. I suppose it was perhaps the study of history which fascinated me and political history and economic history which perhaps got me interested. But of course my attraction to a particular political cause, namely that of the Liberal Party, was clearly due to my great admiration for Sir Robert Menzies. The foundation of the Liberal Party in 1944 came at an impressionable time for me when I was just a first year university student. I had my first taste of political life in helping to form the university Liberal club at UWA in the middle of 1945. My interest in politics from that time onwards has never flagged and I do not think it ever will, even when I leave here. Although I do not plan to be active in a political sphere at all after my retirement, I will continue to remain closely interested in political affairs and what is going on, even in this place.

I have felt during my political career that there are some fundamental reasons why I had become a Liberal in the first place, why I was attracted to the Liberal Party. It was essentially for two reasons: firstly, that I have always had a very sceptical view of what governments can achieve. I guess that is why I never bought socialism as an undergraduate, which was a fairly natural and attractive proposition, but I have always had that scepticism. Even as a Minister when I believe we were too active in trying to fix up everything in life by public action, public decisions, nevertheless, I feel more proud in many ways of some of the decisions I did not take, refused to take, as a Minister than those I did.

The other major motivation I have had in political life has been to try to expand and improve the rights of individuals, and that was the belief that was very much behind my role as Attorney-General. I do not propose to speak for very long about my career before coming into the Federal Parliament and into this Senate. Life in the State Parliament of Western Australia for three years was well and truly long enough and I was pleased when the electors decided to make me a oncer. For the following three years I had a more agreeable time as State President of the Liberal Party. I enjoyed that period very much, although it was a rather demanding one when I was also trying to make a living at the Western Australian bar.

It was when I came into this chamber 22 years ago that I first really found my feet, so to speak, and what I felt my appropriate role. I realise that the selectors in one form or another in the Western Australian Liberal Party were quite right in selecting me for the Senate because I do believe that this is where I was able to make a greater contribution than if I had gone into the other place.

I came into the Senate at a most important time for this chamber because in 1971 it was just starting to get moving on the new committee system. There had been some committees before that, but the new committee system had just begun when I came into the Senate. I believe this has been the most outstanding achievement for parliamentary reform and reinvigoration, not only in Australia but in other parliamentary systems. It was no doubt modelled on the American committee system and the vigour that that contributed to democratic life in the United States. It was a great reform for our parliamentary institution and it has gone from strength to strength.

I commend the estimates committees and the work they have done. I know it is very irksome for Ministers, but those of you who have enjoyed the benefit of asking questions of Ministers and pressing Ministers will realise that what is good for the goose is good for the gander. It is most important that the Public Service has that pressure put on it to respond—and it has responded handsomely to that challenge and is much better for it.

The other area of committee work which must be developed further and which is vitally important for the future is the system of sending Bills for scrutiny before the so-called Friday committees. I think such committees must be expanded from just sitting on Fridays only. Maybe some Bills can be dealt with in a day but others need much greater time. All those in the electorate interested in what we are doing, all those who in many cases have a major personal interest in what we are doing with legislation should have that opportunity—indeed, an even greater opportunity than they have now. That again is a major plus for the Senate.

We lost government in 1983 and the ensuing 10 years have been long, hard, frustrating and disappointing. They have not, however, all been negative. Certainly senators on this side of the chamber are all heartily sick of being in opposition, and I hope we will not be in opposition for very much longer. However, the work which has been done over the years in the development of our policies, under successive leaders with a great team effort on the part of so many on this side of the chamber, has been most important. When we come into government those efforts will be most important in making a good, sound government for the betterment of Australia.

When we were in opposition between 1972 and 1975, we were just so overwhelmed with the daily free kicks we were getting and the use that we were able to make of them in both chambers that our time was largely taken up with tactical matters from day to day. We certainly did not devote sufficient time to policy development, to updating and developing policy to meet the challenges of the day, but that has not been the case in the last 10 years. I emphasise that something very positive has come out of what seems to have been a very frustrating period.

I am going into retirement without regret. I was not terribly happy about the circumstances that led to my decision not to contest the last election. As I said, I will have something to say about that in other forums on other occasions. I had hoped—and expected—that we would win the last election. I would have liked to have had a crack at another short time in government; I certainly have no desire to spend any further time in opposition. I feel very happy to pass the torch to my colleagues. They are now well trained and well disciplined—unfortunately—in the role of opposition, but they are well suited to continuing to fight the good fight. I trust that at the next election they will be back in government.

I am very proud to have been a politician for 28 years. I do not believe that this role deserves the disparagement of so many people. It is a career and a professional life of great importance—probably the greatest. In a democratic country, it is the greatest and most important profession that anyone could take up. The work we do is in most cases selfless in the sense that we are always thinking of the best policies for Australia. We differ on these policies very widely, but there is enormous common ground in both chambers about the right policy to pursue. We concentrate on those areas where differences lie.

As long as we as Australians can make the most use of our parliamentary democracy and our democratic life generally, I have no doubt that Australia will get out of its present problems and return to the prosperity it had known for so many past decades. I have the greatest belief in Australia and Australians. I do not have any doubts about what it is to be an Australian. We have very clear identities and clear basic philosophies about how life should be conducted, how we should be governed, and how we should be defended. It is with a great feeling of satisfaction that I leave political life with this very firm and hopeful belief about the future of Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tuesday of last week was the 19th anniversary of my election to the Senate. Fifteen others were elected for the first time at that same time and I am the only one left. Among members of the present Parliament, only Senator Durack and seven members of the House of Representatives have been here for longer than I. In that time I have made a few enemies as well as many friends on my own side and, somewhat surprisingly, I have made some friends on the other side. In the mid-1980s I decided that this would be my last term, although I then anticipated that the term would end in June 1994. The unexpected double dissolution of 1987 brought that forward. But this is the time for me to leave.

PARA.TAB: I shall of course miss being involved in parliamentary politics. I still care about policy and issues, the Labor Party and Australia but I am too old and/or too tired to apply myself properly to constituency or parliamentary duties. The pinnacle of my personal political ambition was reached during the five years I was Minister for Finance. The most satisfying and significant period of my life was the period I spent working with that excellent department.

I came into the Senate with strong and long held beliefs about a fair society, and the importance of economic efficiency in achieving one, civil liberty, conscription, capital punishment and a belief that I could make an important contribution to agricultural policy, an area in which the Labor Party had long been ignorant and confused. The Country Party, which I despised, was in that respect worse. Its ignorance was compounded by a propensity to protect its electoral base as an end in itself. Its policies were not beneficial to either the nation or most of the farmers it purported to represent.

Over the last 15 years or so, and with the partial exception of the sugar industry, all that has changed considerably. The old system of treating the welfare needs of a minority of farmers with costly and inevitably ineffective across-the-board budget and consumer subsidies has almost disappeared from both sides of politics. Even the National Party has now followed mostly the lead that Labor gave. The first significant Labor politician to take a serious interest in sensible agricultural policy was Bill Hayden at the 1971 Federal conference. I would like to believe that I played an important role in the late 1970s and 1980s.

All, of course, is not well in Australian agriculture today but it would be worse had the shibboleths of the earlier period not been swept aside. We—that is, the Labor Government—made a serious error of omission in the late 1980s, allowing wool industry agro-politicians to use the Commonwealth's taxing and fiscal guarantee powers to accumulate the stockpile. There are early but ominous signs that a similar coalition will again misuse taxing power in cargo cultist pursuit of value adding.

In 1974 I genuinely had no ministerial ambitions. I believed the then Ministers, and possibly even their opposition shadows, were more experienced, astute and competent than I could ever hope to be. It took the simple country boy I then was more than a year to realise that that was not so—that most of them were flawed in one way or another and some of them were flawed in many ways.

The adjustment from wheat farmer to politician, aggravated by the speed with which the 1974 double dissolution caused it to happen, was not easy. Indeed, I remember in late 1974 reading Toffler's Future Shock while also experiencing it. I seriously contemplated giving politics away. That was turned around sharply by the Opposition perpetrated events of 1975.

The 1972-75 Labor Government was not a particularly good one. In its last months, largely because of Hayden's appointment as Treasurer, it was better than it had been but there is no serious doubt that it would have been removed from office in the proper way and at the proper time. It, of course, would have been removed from office at the end of 1975 in the proper way and at the proper time had the opportunistic Opposition not forced the premature 1974 election.

But in 1975 the Opposition just could not wait. No lie was too big, no tactic was too sleazy, no risk, including the risk of civil disorder, was too great if it facilitated the return of what it regarded as its birthright. As they had done a decade earlier with conscription and Vietnam, the coalition parties kindled fire in the belly and put steel in the spine.

Of the three principal villains of 1975, Kerr was driven into exile, Fraser blubbed and resigned ultimately, but neither the role played by Garfield Barwick in 1975 nor his assorted other villainies have been adequately dealt with. Some are barely known or remembered by the current generation of politicians, journalists and, I understand, even younger lawyers. This should be rectified lest it be repeated.

Following the 1974 election, the eligibility of the Victorian Country Party senator, James Webster, to sit in the Senate was challenged under section 44(v) of the Constitution. This section disqualifies anyone who:

SPEECH.PARA: Has any direct or indirect pecuniary interest in any agreement with the Public Service of the Commonwealth otherwise than as a member and in common with the other members of an incorporated company consisting of more than twenty-five persons.

Jim Webster was a director of and principal shareholder in J.J. Webster and Co. Pty Ltd, a timber company. It had fewer than 25 shareholders and several contracts to supply, among other things, telephone poles to the old Postmaster-General's Department. The facts were not in dispute.

PARA.TAB: Barwick anointed himself to sit solely as a court of disputed returns to determine the challenge. He found that Webster was eligible because no evidence had been produced to suggest that Webster had used his position as a senator to secure the contracts. That was indeed so but it had nothing to do with the charge—the fact that the contracts existed. I do not believe now, and I did not believe then, that Webster had acted improperly but he was unambiguously disqualified by the Constitution's black letter law, as Phil Cleary was nearly 20 years later.

Barwick's judgment was so shonky and so redolent of political prejudice that one Liberal senator said at the time that it had almost destroyed his faith in justice. Another said that if Webster was not caught by section 44(v), nobody could be.

The same propensity to pre-emptively interpret law in accordance with his own preferences and prejudices was displayed by Barwick in his advisory opinion to Kerr the next year. Some of the defects in that opinion were drawn out when he appeared before the National Press Club on 10 June 1976. The transcript of the unexpectedly penetrating questions and the answers to them was published in the Financial Review the next day and exposed effectively Barwick's inconsistencies and contradictions on this issue.

In a series of bizarre judgments in the 1970s, in which, to their discredit, a majority of High Court judges concurred, Barwick set about the serious business of emasculating the Income Tax Assessment Act and laying the foundation for the notorious bottom-of-the-harbour tax evasion schemes.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise on a point of order, Mr Deputy President. I am very reluctant to raise a point of order in a valedictory speech; I do not think there has ever been an occasion when the issue of defamatory statements in a valedictory speech has arisen.
—That is not disorderly. He is not a member of the Parliament.

—I will ask the Deputy President to rule, rather than Senator Collins. I raise the issue as to how far Senator Walsh is going to be allowed to go in defaming Australians on the occasion of a speech in which we were hoping to hear him reflect upon his parliamentary career and his contributions to Australia rather than bucket Australians under the privilege of Parliament.

—Mr Deputy President, there is no point of order, and I think you are acutely aware of that. It is open to Senator Walsh to talk about anything that moves him or has moved him in the course of his parliamentary career, on this, his last occasion in speaking in this place. He has made clear the context in which he is correcting the record as he sees it. Questions of relevance would not even begin to arise in the context of a valedictory speech. He is entitled to exercise the free speech that this place allows its members. I suggest that he be allowed to get on with it without any more spurious points of order.

—Mr Deputy President, on the point of order: Sir Garfield Barwick is a distinguished Australian. He made a great contribution to Australia. If he were still a member of this Parliament, Senator Walsh would be ruled out of order. Mr Deputy President, are you going to sit there and allow a distinguished Australian to be slandered under parliamentary privilege in the way that is occurring?
—If you don't get a pint of blood you can't go to sleep in your coffin at night—filled with earth from the North Shore!
—Order, Senator Collins!
—Mr Deputy President, I raise a point of order. I know that the Minister for tap dancing has had a rough week, but would you mind asking him to withdraw.

—Order on both sides of the chamber! Before I make a ruling on the point of order, I point out that the Senate at one stage adopted a series of resolutions in relation to parliamentary privilege. Resolution No. 9 probably has some effect in relation to the matter which was raised, but it does not have the effect of a standing order; it is there for the guidance of honourable senators. There is no standing order which would uphold the point of order raised by the Leader of the Opposition. Therefore, I call Senator Walsh.

—I am not doing this lightly. I believe that there are historical facts that ought to be put on the record. I am sorry that Senator Hill or some of his colleagues might be offended by it. The High Court judgments of the 1970s laid the foundations for the notorious bottom-of-the-harbour tax evasion schemes. Those who deplore the extreme length of the present Act should remember that it is a legacy of those Barwick judgments. Once commonsense and clear intention had been suspended by a High Court dedicated to finding pseudo-legal excuses for tax evasion, every conceivable matter of detail and process had to be closed off by black letter law. It is pretty cheeky for former High Court judges who supported Barwick in the 1970s to be sanctimonious now about the extreme length of the taxation Act.

PARA.TAB: Barwick's commitment to eroding the Commonwealth tax base was not mirrored by his attitude to spending public money—at least not when expenditure was directed towards his indulgence and self-aggrandisement. He is personally credited with adding some $15 million, in 1970s dollars, to the cost of the High Court building. His plans to spend a few million more to establish Lanyon Homestead as the chief justice's palace were ultimately thwarted by Malcolm Fraser.

His personal aversion to paying tax was `outed' by the Mundroola affair. Mundroola was a family company set up, like most such family companies, to minimise tax by splitting income without surrendering control. In 1980, it was revealed by a search of the corporate affairs records that no company return had been lodged with the New South Wales CAC since 1974. The return listed Sir Garfield Barwick as director, and at that time—at least until 1981—he occupied a company house.

The tax law was quite clear: if he had paid rent to the company, that must be recorded in the company tax return as income; if he did not, he, as a company director, must include imputed rent as income in his personal tax return. These facts provoked considerable—

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I raise a point of order. I put to you that what is being said is clearly offensive—I do not think anyone could argue about that—in terms of standing order 193(3) and that `judicial officers' should be interpreted to include a former judicial officer. Therefore, what is being said on this occasion under privilege by Senator Walsh is not only sad and a reflection on him but also clearly out of order under that provision.

—Order! In the time that I have been in the chamber I have never known a former judicial officer to have the protection that a current judicial officer has. I do not think this is the time to start doing so.

—As Senator Evans, among others, will remember, the facts provoked considerable debate in the Parliament and considerable speculation about the contents of one or both tax returns. The ATO, as it now is, was prohibited by section 16 from making either available. But that prohibition did not apply to the taxpayer. Anyway, after the debate had raged for some time, Barwick's letter of resignation from the Mundroola board fortuitously appeared—dated 1974.

PARA.TAB: When Labor was elected in 1983, my firm belief was that we would be in office for at least two terms, partly because the coalition had been thoroughly discredited and partly because, unlike in 1972 and 1974, the coalition had accepted the legitimacy of Labor's victory. I believe that the most important subsequent election was in 1987. The coalition was then still committed to reversing the just and necessary reforms to the tax system and to the Budget outlays which had been pursued in the mid to late 1980s.

The 1987 victory confounded the pre-existing conventional wisdom that a government which actually practised fiscal responsibility, closed tax loopholes, desisted—mostly—from pork-barrelling and cut perks to the affluent could not survive an election. After 1987, I believed that Australia's political culture had been permanently changed. Now I am not so sure.

Labor inherited a sick economy in 1983. For the rest of the 1980s, progress was made in reducing unemployment, fostering economic growth and, to a lesser extent, reducing inflation. For the first time ever, the Commonwealth Budget was in surplus. Although outlays as a proportion of GDP came down by nearly six percentage points, the needs of the poor, of the lowest quintile, were more effectively addressed than ever before.

Contrary to the chattering class mantra, it was, at least until 1989, a very proper Labor Government in the traditional sense. But productivity growth was poor and nominal wage increases too high. Partly because of that, partly because of an inadequate level of private saving and partly because of the inflation and tax related asset price boom of the late 1980s, the current account deficit was not brought under control.

Ultimately, that brought the Government's economic strategy undone, and the policy response to the 1989 current account deficit blow-out—interest rates of 20 per cent plus—ushered in the present recession. The current account deficit is not under control now and, on present indications, is not likely to be in the near future, even if the economy continues to wallow in the trough of sluggish growth and high or slowly rising unemployment.

There is a small but very noisy group which says that many things are more important than economic growth. Almost inevitably, these people display the following attributes: they have jobs—usually well paid; they are either on the public tit or have secure jobs in the semi-public sector; they are vociferous demanders of more government services and handouts to their own pet causes; and they are opponents of higher taxes, or at least higher taxes on themselves and their cronies.

Their stars often appear on television. One recently asserted that, if we do not have enough money for all the worthy causes, then we just have to find it. `Oh for a magic pudding'. Another participated in a recent Lateline discussion on Australia's destiny and place in the world. Geoffrey Blainey observed that, unless we fairly quickly overcame our economic problems, Australia was destined for mediocrity and insignificance. The reply was, `I could not disagree with that more'. Obviously, to such people long-term economic decline is not regarded as a problem.

The million or so Australians who do not have a job, and who, a bit of churning aside, have no chance of getting one unless growth is high, disagree. But who cares about them? Certainly not those in comfortable public sector sinecures.

Those who disagree so violently with the proposal that economic growth matters to the future of Australia might reflect on how many banana republics or countries in long-term decline are important, respected or influential in the world.

For some of that group, the unemployment issue is evaded by claiming that economic growth is not a prerequisite to more jobs. All we need, according to them, is `green' jobs. While that is technically feasible, the advocates are too ignorant to understand—or too dishonest to acknowledge—that the quid pro quo for these green jobs is a big fall in real wages—something which they would oppose more vehemently than most, at least if it applied to themselves.

Each of the three Australian recessions in the last 18 years has lifted unemployment to a higher plateau with a commensurate increase in long-term unemployment. This has also happened in most other countries, but our difficulties are compounded, and our chance of real recovery diminished, by our chronic current account deficit. That the Governor-General's speech paid so little attention to those problems is disappointing; that it pandered so much to sectional interest and pressure groups, which will aggravate them, I find alarming.

I fear that Ben Chifley's Labor Party, to which I made a personal commitment more than 40 years ago, has lost its way—and mouthing Chifley rhetoric is a poor substitute for sharing his beliefs, especially his belief that economic growth, or development as he would have called it, has a paramount role in improving the life of ordinary Australians.

Does anyone believe that Ben Chifley would have closed down mines and banned exploration in a sequence of highly prospective mineral provinces, not for any serious environmental reason but to appease the secular religious sanctimony of Balmain basketweavers? Would Chifley have allowed the long-footed potoroo, or whatever fad was in vogue with the chattering classes, to take priority over a million unemployed?

Those who stultify growth always ensure that others bear the cost. This is profoundly unfair. Moreover, and perhaps even worse, we are entitled to question whether liberal democracy, which I trust we all cherish, can survive long-term economic decline and falling incomes.

Periodically, most recently earlier this month, journalists have labelled me as an old-fashioned Labor man—left wing on income distribution, right wing on social issues. I do not mind being called old fashioned, but I dispute the description of being right wing on social issues. On social issues I am generally a libertarian, which is why I am contemptuous of bourgeois left authoritarian social engineers who have much more in common with the Calvinistic right than they do with left liberalism. They are the people who have not read or have not understood, or who have rejected, John Stuart Mill's On Liberty.

Over the years I have made many friends among journalists, but I believe most political journalists have failed to discharge their fundamental responsibility to the public: to accurately report facts and rigorously analyse conclusions. There is, particularly in Canberra, an alarmingly short and shallow knowledge of political and economic history. All journalists should follow the lead of their independent colleagues: wean themselves from government or other drips and from the implicit obligation to run the government line. Above all, they should apply themselves much more to the substance of issues and much less to the theatre or entertainment of politics.

I want to thank the other speakers for the kind things they have said. There may be fewer kind things said in the future, over the next hour or two. I also want to thank my family for the support they have given me. At least two of my children, like Senator Durack's parents, were not at all happy when I became a politician—nor for that matter were my parents, particularly as by that stage they thought I was going in on the wrong side. I want to thank my party for giving me a parliamentary career and all of the people who have worked for me, for other politicians or for the Labor Party per se who have played a major role in helping me to fulfil that career.

Finally, I want to thank the parliamentary staff: the transport office, car drivers, dining room staff, the cooks and cleaners, the attendants, the parliamentary library staff, the Senate clerical staff and, last but not least, the Hansard people, who have indulged me over so many years.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I feel it such a pity that I have to follow Senator Walsh because I believe the atmosphere in this chamber had been so pleasant. It is not a surprise that I disagree with Senator Walsh over the events of 1975, but I do not intend to get into the debate with the bitterness that Senator Walsh has just displayed in this chamber. Of course, it is rather typical of him: he briefed the media to be here to hear what he was going to say because he was going to dump on people. Such self-aggrandisement and selfishness I think is to be regretted.

PARA.TAB: The atmosphere, as I say, had been very pleasant. Senator Evans must now wonder why he ever took on the leadership, having been left with such dreadful jobs as saying he is going to miss me! We did have a nice atmosphere, as I say, and I will try to get the Senate back to that atmosphere.

Gareth, there is just one thing I would like to remind you of. Perhaps the most hilarious direction I ever remember reading about was your direction to the pilot of the F111 flying over the south-west of Tasmania. We all remember it well: `Try to be inconspicuous'. Gareth, an F111 does not fly over the south-west of Tasmania too often—I think he would have had to be flying backwards to attract more attention.

Senator Hill, you have been very generous to all of us in your speech and I thank you very much for all you have said. And you too, Bozzie, although I will have to give you a little lesson on where Tasmania is, by the sound of it. I thought I had done that before.

I would like to acknowledge the members of the House of Representatives, both down on the floor and in the gallery, who have come to hear us. I am very grateful that they have bothered to come over from the other place to listen to our valedictories and I certainly welcome them.

Most of my colleagues—I think probably from both sides of the chamber—know that I have thoroughly enjoyed my time in the Senate. It is not hard to know that I do enjoy this place. I do love the Senate, and I will have to leave it in other hands. I am going to have withdrawal symptoms. I guess I will be listening in, interjecting back home in the kitchen and I will be telling you all what you should have been saying. I do not doubt it. I might even give you a phone call to tell you what I should have said if I had been there. I am just delighted to have been given the opportunity to represent the people of my State and I hope I have not let them down or failed to live up to their expectations.

One moment that I treasure—I am sure Senator Crowley will remember this—arose one night on the adjournment. It was not long after Senator Newman came into the Senate. Senator Grimes was giving her a particularly hard time on the likelihood of her being able to get a pension when she left this place. I had my turn and I was really getting stuck into Don Grimes. He told me that my behaviour was the result of my having had a very good dinner and that I was drunk. Being a teetotaller, I took grave exception to that and asked him to withdraw. He got up and withdrew—and then started hiccupping all the way through my speech.

I finally told him that he was a disgrace to Her Majesty's Government. He did not do a thing about it, and I wondered why. But who did? Rosemary did. Rosemary stood up and would not allow such disgraceful language to be used against Senator Grimes. She took a point of order and demanded a withdrawal. I can remember very clearly Don Grimes saying, `No, Rosemary, sit down'. I did not know why he was being so anxious, nor did Rosemary, but he did. I was asked to withdraw and I refused.
