I was really worked up at this stage.

Senator Chaney came up to me and said, `Withdraw; I won't support you'. I said, `You do what you like, I am not withdrawing'. A few of my other colleagues had gathered around and stood behind me and Senator Chaney changed his mind and decided that he had better get there too. So I decided that I was not going to withdraw. I was finally named, the vote was taken and guess what happened? It was late; the Labor Whip had gone home; and so had all the other Labor senators. To this day, I do not believe that the Labor Party understands that Standing Orders are there to protect the Government. They should have been here. If they had, they would have thrown me out. As it was, it was only the second time in the history of the Senate that someone had been named and not thrown out.

TALK.START.PARA: —It made the newspapers.
—No, I do not think it did because it was so late, but it is an occasion that I certainly remember.

PARA.TAB: I thanked my colleagues the other night for their tolerance in putting up with me for so long. Mr President, I would like to thank you for your tolerance in the way in which you have handled my many interjections. I have really tried not to. When Margaret Guilfoyle was here, I can remember my husband saying to me, `Why don't you behave like Margaret Guilfoyle?'. I tried and for three hours I did not interject, but I found that it was quite impossible. My interjections would be out before I really knew that they were about to be delivered. I believe that you have shown great forbearance with me and I thank you for that.

Regarding the inspiration for me entering politics, I did know why I came in, Peter. Peter said that he was not quite sure. I had a driving force and that driving force was Whitlam. My gosh, I used to listen to the wireless, like we all did during the war time—those of us who can remember the war.

TALK.START.PARA: —The word `wireless' is a real give-away. Which war?

—I can assure Senator Collins that the country was as concerned with Gough's era as it was at the time of the Coral Sea battles. I decided that someone had to get rid of Gough and do something about it. So I stood and to my great surprise I was selected. We knew that something had to be done at that time because great changes were occurring very quickly and very radically and people were frightened.

PARA.TAB: I decided that I really loved my country and that I was going to do something about it. That sounds a bit over the top, but I must explain that I was brought up in a fiercely patriotic home. My father was a great monarchist, but he absolutely and fiercely loved Australia. My sisters and I—there were three girls and he used to call us his quarter of a dozen unassorted—were brought up on a diet of C.J. Dennis. My father had one poem—it was his poem actually—that I cannot help but remember. All of us knew it off by heart because he recited it so often. I know what you are going to think when I recite it to you, but just let me get over it when I do. The poem goes like this:

SPEECH.PARA: To this great big land I've given
all the love that courses through me.
That her hand has rocked my cradle
thrills my heart with every beat.
Australia, aye Australia,
Oh, the word is music to me
and the traitor who'd deny her
would I spurn beneath my feet.
Comes the thought that should a traitor stretch a tainted hand to destroy her,
Should I see her flag of silver stars a tattered thing and torn,
Should I see her torn and bleeding `neath the shod heel of destroyer,
Her crimson wounds a byword and her name a thing of scorn,
There would lift the living bayonets in the strong arms of my brothers
And the voice that cried for nationhood through all the years of pain,
In the hearts of Aussie fathers and little Aussie mothers
Would be hot as hissing lava streams to thrill the world again.

All I knew was that it was Dad's poem. Honourable senators know how we can go to the library and, if they cannot tell us who an author was, we can send to the National Library. When I came to this place I did both those things and I was told that there was no evidence of this poem. The National Library said, `I can assure you that it has never been published'. As a young child—and Dad died before I had even thought of asking him whether he had anything to do with composing it—I had always thought of it as Dad's poem. We all learnt it; we all knew it off by heart. I do believe that he had written it—at least, the National Library believes he did—because he was a great poet. Every Christmas we used to have quite a bit of doggerel with our presents. Any new boyfriend we got sure got in the doggerel. He was very good at that.

PARA.TAB: It was typical of that era, because that generation knew what it meant to be Australian. That generation had no identity crisis at all. People of that generation were not subservient to anyone. They were not subservient to the Brits, nor would they be tempted to be subservient to our Asian neighbours. Indeed, that was a fiercely patriotic generation. I know there was a lot wrong in those times and things have moved on, but I do believe that we could learn a great deal from them. We would all be far too embarrassed these days to get up and recite a poem like that.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not me.

—The majority would be, Bob. I just wonder why we are. We do not teach our children those sorts of poems any more but I believe they could learn a lot from them. As I leave the Senate, I am worried about the changes you are going to try to bring in. I hope you are not going to ruin all those aspects of Australia that I hold so dear, Gareth.

PARA.TAB: Mr President, there are so many people to thank. I would like to start with my husband, who had never boiled an egg before I came up here. One of my witty campaigners sent him a cookbook, Cooking for one—500 recipes. He has not even opened it. I leave him a meal for Monday night; he goes to one daughter Tuesday night; a son Wednesday night; back to the first daughter Thursday night; and I am home Friday and, as soon as I walk in, he says, `What's for dinner?'. He has been absolutely terrific. I do not know how he has put up with it. When I am asked by many people, `What on earth are you going to do, Shirl?', he says, `Cook for me'. I think there will be a fair bit of that.

I cannot thank enough my four children who have supported me through thick and thin. I hope that my parliamentary life has not made life too difficult for them. I know that I have missed out a lot on my grandmother role.

I would also like to thank my Whips. Marg, you have been really fantastic, and you, Sue. They are the two former Whips, and John has now taken over. They look after us. You lot over there should be very jealous. We have scones, cream and jam for morning tea and when we do not have scones, cream and jam, we have fruit cake or sticky buns—all cooked by our Whips and John is learning the recipes. We never miss a birthday; we never miss any sort of celebration. They have been celebrating all week because we are going.

I would also like to thank my Tasmanian colleagues. We have been a very happy bunch in Tassie—Paul, Brian, Jocelyn, and John. We have really been a very happy bunch. We have gone round the State in a bus touring together, telling Paul at the last minute which way to turn. I do thank my colleagues for their friendship through all the years I have been there.

I would like to thank the Clerks. I would really like to extend to you, Harry, and the rest of the Clerks all the thanks I can for your forbearance with me for all the numerous times that I have come to see you on sometimes very stupid little issues, and you always treat them as though they are the gravest in the whole wide world. You have really looked after me so well. I do thank you very much. It does not seem to matter at what stage we are at. You can turn up and say, `Quick! I want a draft of an amendment'. `When do you want it?'. `I need it straightaway—five minutes'. They are never impolite. They are as polite as can be and they always do their best to accommodate us.

I would like to thank my staff—I have one here at the moment. I would like to thank Sandra. She has not been with me as long as some. One of the others has been with me from the beginning, can you imagine? I do not know how she has put up with that. I cannot believe the work my staff did during the last election and the number of hours they put in. I know it applies to the staff of everyone else, but my staff were quite magnificent over that last election. I do thank them very much for all they have done, all their loyalty and for all the dreadful things I have asked them to do.

I would like to thank Hansard. It is amazing. You know, you think you are speaking pretty good English, but when you get your Hansard back—you remember the old way we used to get it? Words were crossed out all the way through and all put into correct English. I thought my English was all right till I came to this place, but Hansard taught me so much.

I would like to thank the Library, particularly stats. I would ring them up and say, `I need this statistic immediately'. `When do you want it?'. `Well, I wanted it half an hour ago, so can you please hurry?', and they always did. I do not know why the Library staff put up with us with the way we treat them, but they are very good.

I would like to thank the people on the switchboard. The switch put up with my husband ringing. They know him, and know him well. They will tell him where I am. I get messages on my beeper, `How do you cook such and such? How many minutes do I give it in the hi-fi?'. He always calls the microwave the `hi-fi'. I get all these sorts of things in the middle of a committee. The switch is so good to him; it is quite incredible.

We have staff in the dining room who I think are just tremendous. They put up with us arriving late. Sometimes nobody is there; they have prepared the lot and two people turn up. The next night they have the whole dining room full. How they are meant to imagine when we intend to go up there and when we intend to go out, I do not know. They are always so polite and so pleasant. I really do think the dining room staff are quite magnificent, and I would like to thank them very much.

I would like to thank the attendants. The attendants rush around. I am always gesturing over there to show them what I want. They seem to understand. You know, we all indicate when we want a drink of water, and we get waited on hand and foot. I am going to miss that. When I go home, I will be doing all the waiting on, I can assure you.

I would like to thank the drivers. I know there has been a lot of controversy over the drivers lately, whether we should be using taxis or drivers or what our actual entitlements are. But I think one of my greatest luxuries is Com drivers. I would just like to say to you that in the early hours of the morning I value having a Com driver to take me home. I do not feel like getting into a taxi. I feel like having a Com driver to take me home. I feel that for my security I need a Com driver. I know one night at 3 a.m. when we were on Estimates our secretary came up and said, `All the Com drivers have gone. We are ordering a taxi. How long do you think you will be?'. I said, `I do not want a taxi. I want a Com driver'.

I lived for a while out at Macarthur. Macarthur is a good way out; you go through a fair bit of bush. I am not too much of a sook, but I just feel that women senators should have a Com driver to take them home. I was told that the Black Rod had said, `No Com drivers'. I am sorry, Black Rod. The secretary said to me, `Senator, I'll come home with you in the taxi'. I said, `Really, I'll be fine'. I suppose I was trying to make a point. I do believe that particularly the female senators need the security going home late at night, and the Com drivers are fantastic. They always wait till I get inside. I have lived in a couple of places that have been a bit dicey. I have gone round the back of the house. That sounds a bit wrong. You know, it is a bit dark. They will wait till you are in. They give you all the assurance under the sun that they are there for your security. I really do appreciate the 18 years that they have looked after me so well.

I must admit that I am disappointed we did not win. I was going to be back for three months to set up that committee system again as it should be set up, and I am disappointed that I have not been able to do that. But there are a lot of us over here and, when we win, that committee system will be set up correctly once more. I do approve very much of sending Bills to the committee system. I think that is working remarkably well, despite the fight that we had to set it up. I think there are quite a number of senators on the Government benches who still do not like that system, but I think it will work. Senator Harradine and I had a great disappointment on our video stuff, but we are doing great work on the community standards.

TALK.START.PARA: —Don't talk about it!

—We will get you eventually, I am sure of it. Mr President, thank you again for your tolerance. I do thank all my colleagues on this side of the chamber for their tolerance. I thank the Democrats and even the Government senators. You have been tolerant most of the time.
—We will miss you, Shirley.
—I know you are going to miss me like a hole in the head, but thank you very much.

—Because of the time, I do not think it is fair to ask Senator Lewis to start his speech now. I am sure the Senate will not mind if I tell a small story about Senator Walters, because she did make reference to the record number of interjections that she has made here and my tolerance. I think last year she and I attended a meeting of the Commonwealth Parliamentary Association conference in a country where there had not been a change of government for 17 years. The Government that had been in for 17 years lost power just before the conference with the result that a new Prime Minister came in to find out that his first task was to Chair this conference. So the conference duly opened with pomp and ceremony. The new Prime Minister was explaining how the rules of debate would take place and a very familiar voice yelled out, `Point of order, Mr President!'. I must say, I jumped to attention. But just to make matters worse, and Senator Walters knows this, the point of order was correct, and we enjoyed a very good conference.

—I note the difference in the number of people in the chamber now as compared with 6.30, when it was packed! I had intended to make a very brief valedictory speech, but I regret to tell the Senate that Senator Walsh, with his comments about 1975, has provoked me to expand on my speech a little.

PARA.TAB: The years of the Second World War had a very deep influence on me, as they did on Senator Walters. I think I was about seven when the war started and 12 when it finished. Children of such tender years certainly are deeply influenced by their perception of the events of the day. I was a dedicated patriot who knew many of the servicemen who were killed or came home wounded. I mostly heard them telling their families the funny stories about what had happened, not talking about the sad things and the pain they had suffered.

I was determined to be a pilot. My great ambition in life was to be a fighter pilot. I ultimately achieved that ambition. I was a fighter pilot in 21 Squadron of the Citizens Air Force, and I was very proud of that. Like Senator Walsh, Mr Chifley was a hero of mine and I saw the light on the hill that Mr Chifley talked about.

I was an only child in a Labor family. I was born and bred in Richmond and we were all Labor people in Richmond. The Liberal Party was for people who lived in Toorak. The wealthy people supported the Liberal Party and we all supported the Labor Party, except for one uncle of mine who was a foreman in a steel factory. I could not understand that, because he was really the only genuine labourer that I knew. My father was quite a wealthy merchant. I remember Uncle Cec was the only genuine labourer that I knew and he was a great supporter of the Liberal Party. I asked him on a number of occasions why, and on each occasion he said that he would never forget what the Labor Party did to us in the 1930s.

That did not mean anything to me at the time. However, I subsequently came to understand what he was talking about. I was far too young to appreciate Sir Robert Menzies and, unfortunately, I was too young to do what my colleague Senator Durack did and that was be associated with the Liberal Party when I got to university. As I said, my father was a dedicated member of the Australian Labor Party and he sought and held office in the local branch. He ran the local branch, was a councillor for the city of Richmond and on three occasions was mayor.

In the 1950s, when I was at Melbourne University, the Labor Party split. It was unbelievable what was going on. While I was flying and doing things like that at weekends, it seemed that all the other university students could talk about was politics and people stabbing other people in the back. It did not matter which side of politics they were on, they were always talking about being stabbed in the back. So I proceeded to opt out of politics and in 1956 I even opted out of the city of Melbourne and got a job at Warrnambool, 300 kilometres away.

By the 1960s, there was a fellow named Sir Henry Bolte who was governing Victoria and governing it very well on most occasions. From time to time I used to get very angry about some of the things he said and did. I remember being very angry about capital punishment, which I think is totally wrong. The state should not be entitled to take anyone's life in the same way as no-one else should be entitled to take anyone's life.

The Liberal Party was doing quite well but there were a number of things it was doing that were not quite right. I used to talk to one of the local members down there, a fellow by the name of Sir Ronald Mack, who subsequently became the Speaker of the Upper House of the Victorian Parliament. He was then the Minister for Health. He said to me, `Why don't you join the Liberal Party and then you will be able to push the changes that you want and make it a better party'.

In the 1960s I came to see that there was some merit in that course and I adopted it. My father was absolutely staggered. He could not believe that his son had become a member of the Liberal Party and he dared not tell any of his friends about it. Like any young lawyer in a country town who takes an active interest in the community, I suddenly found myself rising through the party ranks and becoming the branch president. I had previously been the branch secretary and the organiser for the campaigns for the electorates of Warrnambool, the member being Ian Smith, and Wannon, the member being a fellow named Malcolm Fraser. I ran their campaigns.

In 1972 my father was absolutely delighted with the result of the election. I was surprised that it was such a strong result in favour of the Labor Party. I remember going to my opposite number Gerry Hand, who was running the Labor Party campaign in Warrnambool, congratulating him and wishing him well for the term of government.

By 1975 it was unbelievable what had happened to this nation. My father said to me, `I knew they were crook down here, but I did not understand that it went right through the Labor Party to the top in Canberra'. I say to Senator Walsh that that was the attitude of many people around Australia. They could not believe that the Labor Party was crook. Crooked was what they meant. They did not just mean that Labor was governing badly, but that there was an element of crookedness which really worried them.

Senator Walsh said, and this is part of the shibboleth of the Labor Party, that if Fraser had only waited the Liberals would have won office legitimately in due course. That is nonsense. Has he forgotten that Mr Whitlam was about to call a half Senate election and has he not seen the Labor Party's ability to manipulate the media? We have seen it in the last three elections. Dare he forget what Mr Wran did for the media with regard to Lotto. Let there be no doubt that once the Labor Party sets itself up to remain in office it will pull any trick, it will tell any lie—the bigger the lie the better—and it will manipulate its sycophants in the gallery in order to remain there. Those sycophants have been to university and have no practical knowledge of what goes on in real life. They leave university with some sort of degree and join the cynical force of the press gallery and then think they know all that there is to know about it. They do not understand the manipulations and devious arrangements that go on underneath. I feel as angry about what the Labor Party has done to this country as Senator Walsh feels about what Sir Garfield Barwick may have done to this country.

Like my colleague Senator Shirley Walters, I am concerned about the future of this nation at present. I think it is desperate. I think the fact that the Prime Minister, today simply cancelled Question Time in the House of Representatives is an indication that our democratic institutions are falling apart under the Labor Party. Democracy is something which is very precious and hard to get and it must be held onto. I am very concerned about what the Government is doing. We know that Senator Evans came into this place with the objective of getting rid of the Senate. He has never said that he has since changed his mind, so one must presume that he continues to want the abolition of the Senate. Where would we be, so far as democracy is concerned in Australia, without the Senate?

The other place has become simply a place of manipulation of numbers and no debate. In fact, whatever debate takes place takes place in the Caucus and in the Caucus committees. Most of that, from what I can gather, takes place as a result of various factions within the party making up their minds what they can do, so that `If you have this, I will have that'; `You take this trip and I will take that trip'; `You get onto this committee and we will get onto that committee'; or `You become the chairman of this and we will become the chairman of that'. That is not what government is all about. It is certainly not what parliamentary democracy is all about. Without the Senate at present there would be no parliamentary democracy.

I will move away from my reaction to Senator Walsh's remarks; I will move on to what I hope are more pleasant subjects. In 1976 I surprised myself, and certainly my wife, by winning the position to replace the late Senator Ivor Greenwood, who I might say was a very powerful and able senator. My wife said she had married a solicitor, not a politician. I can only say to her that I regret that I did not perhaps stay a solicitor. If I had stayed a solicitor I have no doubt that I would by now be a millionaire, as the owner of a woollen mill. However, that little business venture, which with hindsight would have been extremely successful, fell by the bye and in December of 1976 I became a senator for the State of Victoria.

On that day, 7 December, I was sworn in. Up until then my life had been my own. If I wanted to have a haircut, I simply said to my secretary, `Put me out between 3.30 and 4.00; I am going for a haircut', and I went out for a haircut. On 7 December 1976 I was sworn into the Senate in the presence of my wife and family. At about 20 past four I said to them, `We will have to get you out to the airport now because the plane goes at five. I will just get a car and take you out'. I was walking around to the side of the old place with my wife and family to get a Senate car to go out to the airport when these bells started to ring, and for the first time I realised that I had no right to walk out of the building. For the first time in my life, as far as I could recall, I was bound by rules which required me to be in this place all the time and to answer these bells.

I might say to Labor senators—this might even surprise Democrat senators—that when we were in government and I was on the back bench, as far as I was concerned that meant that I asked the Ministers the toughest questions I could think of. I really do not understand how the Labor Party backbenchers can continually ask dorothy dixers; it is beyond me. I used to think of the most difficult questions. I would have lunch with Margaret Guilfoyle and I would not warn her what I was going to ask her. I would come into the Parliament, get the first question and go whack, straight at Margaret Guilfoyle with an extraordinarily difficult question. Margaret would say to me, `Why do you do that?'. I would say, `Isn't that our role? Our role is to keep the Ministers on the ball, to keep them going, to keep them up-front. This is a difficult question. The public are entitled to know the answer to it'. I remember that I used to get very cross. I see a stranger—get out of the place!; my local member, too.

I just do not know what has happened to Question Time. In those days, as a backbencher on the government side, I got a question every day. If I was quick I could get a second question. By leaping up at the end of the day I would get two questions every day, and the toughest questions I could think of. I do not know what government members do over there now. They have a few dorothy dixers handed around—

TALK.START.PARA: —I was here then; I remember. So does Margaret.

—I know that Senator Ray will say that I was pretty tough as the chairman of an estimates committee. But Senator Ray, I only showed you the way. You people learned very well. We would not keep people here till 6 o'clock in the morning to make sure they were exhausted. We used to let the Senate get up and the estimates would go on for weeks.

PARA.TAB: One of the things I am very proud of is the fact that I came forward with the idea of financial impact statements. I came forward with the idea that every time the Government introduced a Bill it would put down a financial impact statement. I did not just mean the cost to revenue; what I meant was what the cost to the community would be. The reason I did that was that I was so angry over metrication and what metrication had cost this nation. The change across from pounds, shillings and pence to dollars and cents had gone so well and had been so successful that people just took metrication and said, `Oh, it will be all right'.

Well, it cost the nation hundreds of millions of dollars. For what? To find out that, instead of living 163 miles from Melbourne, I lived 300 kilometres from Melbourne. What difference does it make? I still will never be able to work out what air pressure I am supposed to have in the tyres of the car, and I do not know anyone who can. And for what? We have spent hundreds of millions of dollars on this. People used to say to me, `It is so that scientists will be able to work in metric numbers'. That is rubbish. We used to be able to buy 25 feet of 8mm film and no-one ever got upset about that or did not understand what you were buying when you asked for movie film. What difference does it make if you now buy two metres or four metres of it, instead of 25 or 50 feet? It is an absolutely ridiculous waste of money.
I was so angry about that that I got this idea of financial impact statements. I used to drive Margaret Guilfoyle mad. She was the Minister for Finance.

TALK.START.PARA: —It's absolutely true, I know you did.

—Rod Kemp will know because he was working for Margaret at the time. I used to drive her mad by saying, `We must have financial impact statements'. I hate to say it, but in 1983, when Mr Dawkins became the Minister for Finance, the idea of financial impact statements was one of the first things that he adopted. I congratulate the Labor Party for it, although the Labor Party has not really carried it out to the full extent in that every Bill has a financial impact statement but only in regard to the cost to the Treasury, not the cost to the nation. It is really the cost to the nation that bothers me. I might say to the Democrats that since then I have from time to time mooted the idea that what ought to be produced in addition to a financial impact statement is an environmental impact statement, detailing the cost to the environment of legislation which is introduced.
—Don't give them ideas!

—No. As I said, today I found that the Prime Minister simply wiped the Question Time of the House of Representatives. I really could not believe that this Government could treat this institution so cavalierly. I have mentioned how precious is democracy—we have to be very cautious; it is so easy lose—and I note that Senator Walsh in his speech earlier this evening also mentioned the possibility of the loss of democracy. But he was looking at it from the point of view of finance—that if the economy of the nation gets to such a stage that there is no other way out then we may very well not be able to continue with our parliamentary democracy in the way that we have.

PARA.TAB: I would like to express a few thanks. It has been an honour and a privilege to be a senator. For that I thank the Liberal Party. Without the Liberal Party I would never have been a senator. Senator Harradine is one of the few senators I know who has the ability to do it without the substance of a major political party behind him.

TALK.START.PARA: —He has a system.

—Yes, he has a system; he probably has his own political party—he is very good at it. I thank the party for that opportunity. I certainly thank my wife for all that she has had to put up with because of my taking on this role. I think the thing that we really did not understand was that Warrnambool is a hell of a long way away from Canberra. I know that it is bad for the people from Western Australia—and I have great sympathy for them—but, believe me, it is just as bad at Warrnambool. I actually live at Port Fairy, which is a 3 1/2-hour drive from there.

PARA.TAB: At one stage, when I was deputy leader, I actually had a vacant house in Port Fairy, a vacant house in Melbourne and a vacant house up here. They were the three houses that my wife and I used to ship ourselves between as we were required in various places. My children—Amanda, Phillip, Matthew and Anthony—have been extraordinarily supportive. I am staggered that they have become so conservative. In particular, my son Phillip has a very good political nose, but he is so conservative—he just hates the Labor Party.

I went away on a trip overseas with Mr Arch Bevis, the honourable member for Brisbane. My wife and I agreed that he is so like our son it is unbelievable. But he hates the Liberal Party! It really is quite extraordinary: they would think alike; they would have the same sorts of families; they would do practically everything alike. He is just the spitting image of our son in everything that he says and does, yet he hates the Liberal Party and my son hates the Labor Party. It really is quite remarkable.

I turn to my staff. I really have had some marvellous staff. In particular, I had a secretary whom I brought across with me from my legal practice and who was with me for 14 years, Joan Bosch. The year after I came here, I employed a fellow named Jim Hume. He was with me for 13 years and then he had to retire because of age. I brought him back for the last three months to help me clean up the office. I also mention two fellows, John Robertson and Gerry Wheeler, who helped me when I was the deputy leader. They did a brilliant job.

I must say to the Labor Party: you have not done very well by John Robertson. I might be doing the wrong thing by him by mentioning his name here tonight, but when he went back to the Public Service you did not leave him at the position that he should have been at, you put him down below that position, and you have not promoted him in the way that he should have been promoted. I think he has finally started to receive some recognition of his brilliance. He is a brilliant and unbiased adviser. I do not think he was a supporter of the Liberal Party; I think he joined me simply as an adviser. I add that I am quite certain that my secretary of 14 years, Joan Bosch, was certainly not a supporter of the Liberal Party. I had many other secretaries and other staff who did very well for me. I had a marvellous driver by the name of Lance Morton during the years that I was deputy leader. I have retained contact with him and his family.

I also wish to thank the Senate staff; in particular, Harry Evans, Anne Lynch, Peter O'Keeffe and the Black Rod, Rob Alison. There are many others at that level who are marvellous in the support they give us. I support everything that has been said by others tonight. They are brilliant. But it is not just them, it is the other staff as well: the attendants and the people around the chamber who provide us with service while we are in the chamber, and all the other staff. The committee secretariats are brilliant. I must say that I really did enjoy my term of service on the Senate regulations and ordinances committee—a marvellous committee. When we get into government, we will make the scrutiny of bills committee as important as the Senate regulations and ordinances committee. How it is that members of the Labor Party just allow that committee to slip by is beyond me. But it will be as important as the Senate regulations and ordinances committee when the Liberal and National parties ultimately get to government.

There are other people—in particular, a number of my friends—who have been very supportive of me. I have made friends on both sides of the chamber. I would have even called Senator Peter Walsh a friend of mine, although that might surprise many. I have noticed that when you go away on trips it is easier to make friends with people in the other chamber than with those in this chamber because you are not involved in the close day-to-day clash. In particular, I thank my Liberal Party colleagues; my Whips, Margaret, and Sue, and now John; and my leaders. I have had some brilliant leaders. Reg Withers was a marvellous leader. Sir John Carrick was another good leader. Fred Chaney and Rob Hill have been up to the standard. We have been very well led. My only regret is that we are not in government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bjelke-Petersen Sen F.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise this evening to make my final contribution to the debates in this chamber. In doing so, I must admit to a certain degree of sadness at the closing of this chapter of my life which has brought me 12 1/4 very full years of representing the wonderful people of Queensland.

PARA.TAB: I want to thank the Leader of the Opposition here in the Senate, Senator Rob Hill, for the kind words he said about me this evening. I also want to thank him for the nice things he said about me the other night at the dinner. He told everybody how I campaigned so well. I think back to one of the very first occasions that I was asked by the Liberal Party in Victoria to come and have a dinner. Neil Brown, who was the member, said to me, `Florence, would you please write out your pumpkin scone recipe and I will get it framed and we will auction it'. It was probably the first time that I had done this. He got it framed with the most beautiful red for the Senate around it, and they auctioned it. I bet you will all be staggered when I tell you that they raised $1,000 for the Liberal Party that night. I must say that that is one of the best efforts that I have had.

I have had George Negus pay $430 for my recipe at a fair in Brisbane. He told me about it once when he was interviewing me. I did not like to say to him, `If you had written to me, George, and asked me, I would have done one for nothing for you'. I must say, too, that prophets probably have no honour in their own country, because the smallest amount I have heard about for my recipe was at a fete held in Kingaroy. I got $25 on that occasion.

It has been wonderful to work with my Liberal Party colleagues here in the Senate. As I look around tonight, I realise that I have made many friends. I thank you all for the friendship that you have given to me while I have been here.

I thank the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Gareth Evans) for his kind words and I also thank my friend and leader Senator Ron Boswell. I really felt very humble when he said all those nice things about me. He could probably tell you a few things that I have done from time to time that he has not agreed with, but I guess that is just the way it is. I believe that I have made friends across party lines, too. I can see Barney Cooney over there. He always says nice things to me—whether he says them with his tongue in his cheek or not, I am not too sure, but he has always been very kind.

TALK.START.PARA: —He's a lawyer!

—Being a lawyer might have something to do with it—I do not know. Really, it has been nice. Senator Harradine and I have been together in the parliamentary Christian fellowship and in our pro-life group. I tremendously admire Senator Harradine's stand on these very important issues for this nation.

PARA.TAB: It was in 1981 that my term as a senator for Queensland began, although it would be fair to say that I have been actively involved in politics all my married life. As a matter of fact, before I got married to Joh—before he found me in the Main Roads Department when he came on a deputation on one occasion—I had actually been a Liberal in Brisbane. That is why I get on so well with you all, of course.

But I saw the light and I became a National Party member. Well, in fact I became a Country Party member because we were the Country Party in those days. I am sure that all senators here would acknowledge the tremendous support and hard work of their spouses without whom, I believe, a politician's lot would be untenable. We have heard various senators here this evening saying that. I believe it is almost a case of `Buy one, get one free', and that is exactly what it is. So it is with me, because I married a backbencher in the Queensland Parliament and basically knew what I was letting myself in for.

I still remember going to New Zealand on my honeymoon and I got this letter asking me if I would go and open a fete in Murgon. It was only a small thing, but I nearly died of fright because I had always been careful never to be a president or a vice president in case I had to make a speech. I did all the secretarial work of all the organisations I was in. I looked at this letter and said to Joh with fear and trembling, `What will I do? They want me to open a fete'. `Oh' said Joh, `You go'—and there was method in his madness because I have never stopped going from that day until now, I might say.

Joh, of course, later became a Minister in the Queensland Parliament and then the Premier. So by the time I was elected to the Senate I had experienced many, many years of being the one you got for free. Somebody once asked me what the difference was between being a Premier's wife and a senator. I said, `Well, I get paid now for what I used to do for nothing'. But I did find out that, from being a premier's wife whom everybody treated with great respect and were always glad to see, when you came to the Senate you were certainly very humble. But that had nothing to do with it at all. You were just an ordinary backbench senator. Well, I suppose it sort of put me in my place fairly well.

Nevertheless, for a number of years I was still the Premier's wife and a senator. When I got all the invitations that I did as a senator, I still had to work and used to have to ask the Whips for leave and I was always saying I could not do this and I could not do that. However, when I was no longer the Premier's wife I found that the invitation list got very much smaller. So I decided that the reason I got all those invitations was not because I was such a wonderful senator; it was because I was the wife of the Premier.

I have always indeed, friends, considered it a great honour and privilege to have been elected by the people of Queensland to represent them in this place. I have constantly travelled our State talking with people from all walks of life, keeping my ear to the ground and doing the best I could always to represent what I believe are their interests here in Canberra.

Federal Parliament is a virtual melting-pot of people and personalities, ideas and ideals, philosophies and theories, goals and agendas, occupations and experiences, with the occasional ego thrown in for good measure. As I look back on 12 years of being part of this bubbling cauldron, I hope that I have contributed in a constructive and positive way.

I refer to the experiences of a person committed to the wellbeing of the family; a supporter of private enterprise and initiative; a champion of the rural communities, which I believe has been very important; and also, judging from what I heard in the Senate today, a champion of road builders everywhere. Of course, as I look back on the 13 years I had in the Main Roads Department when I typed estimates for many numbers of years—and I was in Main Roads during the war years where we used to have to work terribly late at night doing all these estimates for the jobs that the Americans wanted built—I remember how eventually I became the secretary to the Main Roads Commissioner. I then think to myself `Well, I was very fortunate that I got to the top of my tree in the job that I was doing'.

I have certainly also been an advocate of lower taxes. I have tried, during the hundreds and hundreds of speeches I have given and in the questions I have asked and the representations I have made, to keep these issues firmly on the Government's agenda.I recall that when I made my maiden speech in the Senate on 6 May 1981, I spoke of the need then for a single rate of tax. I still believe that if my suggestion had been adopted, Australia would be in a better financial position today. Certainly, according to the Auditor-General, when you think that Australia has more than $125 billion in debts and only $57 billion available in liquid assets to meet those debts, well, there is no doubt that a single rate of tax would have been better than what we have now. I think our children and our grandchildren certainly want us to do better than we have been doing recently.

I spoke all around Australia at that time about overhauling our nefarious taxation system that we had in those early days. You could say that my advocacy fell on deaf ears—although there was one occasion when I thought I had at last made them see reason. I was sitting in my room one day, I got a knock on the door and a letter was delivered to me. The letter asked me if I would go and have a cup of tea with John Howard, who was Treasurer at the time, as he would like to discuss with me my single rate of tax—I think we called it the `flat tax' at that time. So off I went, knocked on the door and his secretary came out and said, `What I can do for you?'. I thought it was rather funny and said, `Well, look, I've got a letter here asking me to come and have a cup of tea with John Howard'. She said, `Oh, just a minute', and rushed and got John Howard.

When John Howard came to the door, he looked at me and said, `What can I do for you, Florence?'. I said, `But look, John, I've got a letter here asking me to come and discuss with you my proposed single rate of tax'. He laughed and said, `Do you know what day it is today? It is the first of April'. So I fell rather flat on my face. I thought, `Well, that's a fine ending to this story'. But, never mind, he took me in, gave me a cup of tea, and let us say we talked about all sorts of things except the single rate of tax. But I am nothing if not persistent for I still believe that if our tax system were simplified vis-a-vis a single rate of taxation, Australia would be in a better financial position today.

As I have just mentioned, I came to the Senate when the Liberal-National Party coalition was in power. I made an early name for myself as a renegade when I crossed the floor to vote against the Government over the `necessities of life' tax issue. Needless to say, I was sent to Coventry where I had plenty of time to contemplate the ramifications of my actions. I do not regret crossing the floor over this issue, for I believe it helped me to communicate to the people of Queensland that I was prepared to go in and do battle for them if I truly believed that what I was doing was right. And I know that there were a number of others on my side of parliament, even down to the right there, who at different times have crossed the floor for things they thought were right. I look at Dr Herron here who crossed the floor about tobacco issues and things like that. However, I did learn that if you want people to keep on talking to you, it is best to signal your intentions beforehand.

Regrettably for us, we became the opposition in 1983, and so for 10 years now I have served as an Opposition senator. During that time I have been a Temporary Chairman of Committees, a job which I have enjoyed. I want to thank the Deputy President, who is in the chair this evening, for the nice letter he wrote me thanking me for the work that I had done. I always enjoyed it. Now and again I got into a few spots of hot water here and there. I recall that the Leader of the Government once disputed a ruling and wrote to the President. I had said to him, `Well, if you don't agree, you can write to the President'—so he did. But I did not actually get hauled over the coals; that was all right.

During this present session I have become the National Party Whip in the Senate, which gave me a change of occupation and helped me to realise the tremendous amount of work that the Whips do to keep this place operating successfully; though even with good Whips, it is still hard to keep the program going as we plan it at the Whips meetings in the mornings. I do want to pay tribute here to my friends Margaret and Sue. During the times when Senator Brownhill was over at the United Nations working very hard, I relieved him for a while and had the great pleasure of getting to know both Margaret and Sue very well.

I must say that John Panizza, the present Deputy Whip, is the most obliging person when it comes to doing a little bit of duty in the Whips chair for me. I would like to thank him very much for how he has helped me. I think he knows that I am trying to pack up upstairs and do all the things you have to do when you finish here in the Senate.

I have served since 1981 on several committees, including standing committees on social welfare and national resources; the legislative and general purpose committee; select committees on social welfare and private hospitals and nursing homes; Senate Estimates Committees C, B and D; and the Joint Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence—I must admit that was only for a very short time in my very early days. The work which is done in the committee system is very important to the overall effectiveness of this place. I know that many senators give a great deal of their time to this function of the Senate. Apart from its obvious import, I have also found the committees to be a very good means of communicating with fellow senators and members across party lines. I personally think this is very desirable and I have made many friends from all parties during my committee work.

One of the most fascinating aspects of life in politics is the recognition factor, and I guess I have had my share of this. I would like to think it is not just because of my much publicised culinary expertise that I have been recognised here, there and everywhere. I recall one particularly funny incident when I was overseas, in Chester, England. I had gone to church; we were coming out of church and we shook hands with the Minister who said, `Where do you come from?'. I said, `I come from Australia'. He said, `The couple who have just gone come from Australia too'. Just at that particular time they looked around, and the wife came over to me and she stared at me; she kept on staring at me. She said, `Oh, you do look like Flo'. I said, `Well, I am Flo'. `Oh', she said, `Do you mind if I give you a kiss?'. I said, `Oh, no'. Better still, the husband came up and gave me one too, so that was extra nice. But it was funny—a year or two later I went to a National Party meeting in Orange and who should be there but the said lady and her husband, so I guess that was perhaps a part of the attraction.

Well, the recognition factor can also work the other way. I recall being in Norway on one occasion where I met a lass who came up to speak to me, my sister and a friend, and we all exchanged our names. I told her that my name was Florence and I came from Queensland. She looked at me with horror in her face and she said, `Florence—that is a handicap of a name in Queensland, isn't it?'. I was really taken aback and my friend Claire said, `Oh, that is the Florence that you are talking to'. So, I suppose it is lucky that I have a good sense of humour and that that never worried me. In fact, it has made a jolly good story which I tell at some of my meetings around the countryside.

I believe that the Senate is an essential part of the balance of power, built into the Constitution to protect against unbridled power wielded by the majority view expressed in the House of Representatives. I know there is a certain section in politics which would like to see the Senate abolished—and that, I believe, is the Labor Party. Also, in Mr Whitlam's time, they were talking about abolishing the States. I know this, because Joh went over to England with all the other premiers of the States of Australia—Labor Party people and I think Sir Rupert Hamer and also Robert Askin. They all went together to see Sir Alec Douglas-Home who was the Minister in charge of overseas countries. They said that they did not want to have the States abolished, nor did they want to become a republic. Whatever Alec Douglas-Home said, they came back and nothing more was said. But the next time Joh came down for a premiers conference, he met Mr Whitlam who said, `Joh, you might have won the first round, but let me tell you that I am going to be the first president of the republic'. Joh, I think, said much what you said, Senator O'Chee.

Queensland's Mr Goss, for one, feels the Senate is just a talkfest and not really a States house at all. I recently said on television that I believe one of the most important parts of the Senate's work is as a house of review and much time is spent in this place trying to improve legislation passed by the House of Representatives, I might say to my House of Representatives friends over there—although I do admit that our work is often thwarted because of the Democrats' tendency to side with the Labor Party. However, I believe the Senate is a very important part of our system of government, and I strongly support the maintenance of such a system.

I thank the National Party in Queensland for giving me the opportunity of standing for the Senate and I thank the people of Queensland for supporting me so well over the past 12 years. In the 1987 double dissolution election, I was chosen to lead the National Party team and we returned four senators on that occasion. Regrettably, when I leave, Queensland will be represented by only two National Party senators, but I know that they will continue to represent Queensland and the National Party well. Senator Ron Boswell has been a great fighter for Queensland in the area of small business and rural matters and, no doubt, will continue with this good work. Senator O'Chee, who calls me his grandmother, is the youngest senator in this place; he is a very able speaker and debater. The National Party can be proud of his work, and I look forward to watching his progress after I leave.

One thing that I do regret is the fact that I will not be replaced by the woman who held the No. 2 position on our Senate ticket, De-Anne Kelly, from Queensland. There has been much talk of late about the need for more female representation in the national capital, and this was an opportunity for the people of Queensland to elect an extremely capable woman to the Senate. De-Anne is an electrical engineer, a mother and a farmer, and would have made a valuable contribution to the workings of the Senate. It is regrettable, to say the least, that she failed to achieve the necessary quota to ensure her election.

I have had some excellent colleagues in the National Party, both in the Senate and in the House of Representatives. I am very pleased indeed to see our National Party leader, Tim Fischer, here this evening with a number of my National Party colleagues and Liberal Party colleagues also from that place. I am thankful for having made so many friends down here across party lines. I also want to thank our party Whips for the lovely function held earlier in the week when you all said farewell and gave us that lovely pewter tankard for the occasion. I thank all my staff who have worked hard over the years with me on behalf of the people of Queensland.

At the moment, one of my staff—who is about to have a baby—has been approached by people from the CJC worrying about this jury problem up in Queensland. I really begin to wonder just where that CJC inquiry into the jury is going. I cannot quite see why everybody is getting worried about the fact that there was one National Party person on the jury. They do not talk at all about the three Labor people who were on the jury. I cannot understand that. Another thing I cannot understand is—and Senator Hill, as a lawyer, would know—why did the prosecution not challenge the selection of Luke Shaw? If it had challenged his selection, he would not have even been on the jury. I believe that it is really getting over the odds and costing Queensland millions of dollars. It seems so very unnecessary to me.

I would also like to thank the staff of the Senate, including the clerks—my good friends Harry Evans, Anne Lynch and all their offsiders—who helped me to count divisions when I was doing the Whip's job to bring out the right numbers. I thank the transport officers and all the car drivers for their help and assistance. I particularly thank my dear husband, Joh, and my children and grandchildren who have supported me so well in my career as a senator. They were all grown up and married before I came into this place, so I did not have to worry about small children.I have on my desk here in Canberra a plaque which reads `A woman's place is in the house and in the Senate'. Perhaps that is appropriate for my work and for the work of all our women senators.

I want to wish all my colleagues who are retiring all the very best in their future lives. People have asked me what I am going to do when I retire. I say that there is a community in Kingaroy that I will get involved with again, as I was before I came to the Senate and perhaps before I had to do quite so much for Joh as the Premier's wife. My six grandchildren are there and I think I might be doing a little child minding. Then, of course, I might be able to work on the other cookery book that I am supposed to be writing. I have not done too badly out of the pumpkin scone tag.
I would like to quote an article which appeared in the Woman's Weekly last year and which I feel sums things up pretty well. It said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . and after four decades in conservative politics, the 71 year old woman, who turned pumpkin scone baking into a political statement, is flying the feminist flag high and hard. But in her hands it is still more like an apron.

I have never considered myself to be a feminist but I certainly have used my God-given talents for hard work, caring about people, standing up for what I believe to be right and making the most of the opportunities which come my way—yes, even for cooking—to the best of my ability and for the betterment of all Queenslanders. For 12 years now I have enjoyed being the paid servant of the people of Queensland; I shall now go back to being the one you get for free.
Honourable senators—Hear, hear!

TALK.START.PARA: —It is fitting that I should follow Senator Bjelke-Petersen this evening as I came into the Senate a short time after she did. Perhaps this is the time to confess that I have nursed a simmering resentment over all those years. Flo's pumpkin scones were hogging the headlines while I was hiding the fact that I was the champion sponge cake maker of Bassendean for very many years. What was the point of mentioning it? But now is the time when all can be told.

PARA.TAB: My principal purpose in speaking this evening is to acknowledge as comprehensively as possible my gratitude to those who preselected me, those who elected me to represent Western Australia in the Senate and those who individually and collectively have helped to make my 12 years as a senator rewarding and, I hope, effective.

On many occasions—in fact, most of the time—the support and encouragement that I have received has been beyond the call of duty, good-natured and generous. Those closest to me—my daughters and their daughters, and my invaluable staff, who are also my very good friends—have shown warmth, wisdom and good nature whenever it was needed and have been unfailingly generous with their skills, energy and understanding. Their lives, as well as mine, have been enriched by this experience, partly as a result of their association by proxy through me with this great institution, and certainly as a result of the achievements of Labor governments over the last decades. Their opportunities and the opportunities of the younger generations of women to participate fully in Australian society are greatly enhanced.

From the day I arrived I was conscious of being cared for in a way that I had never before experienced, and I have never taken this for granted. Perhaps it has not really struck the males who come to Federal Parliament, but I realised that over the years the institution of the parliamentary system had been designed to provide a comprehensive network of support for totally helpless males bereft of their normal support systems. I was shocked on the first occasion when somebody found something for me that I did not even know I had lost.

The move to this building has correctly, I believe, encouraged a higher level of self-sufficiency for the work force generally and at the same time provided the conditions in which our work could be more effective. I was very conscious of the extremely poor working conditions for everybody in the old Parliament House, particularly those who provided the excellent support system under extremely difficult conditions.

I wish to thank the people I have known for many years—attendants, catering staff, reproduction staff, the owners of those soothing tones on the switchboard, drivers here and in other cities, the transport staff, committee secretaries, Hansard and library staff, and Senate clerks and officers. Many of them have become dear friends, as have many senators from all parties and their staffs. One even knows and has affection for some of the people on the other side of the building—less predicably on the other side of the Senate. Some of the increasingly heavy load of committee work in which I have been involved has been enlightening, and some of it exhausting and frustrating to the point of making one grind one's teeth. Much of it rewarding and undeniably worth while.

I think it will be a little easier in a few months or a year or so to be clearer about this, but at this stage it seems to me that my work on the Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances and the Standing Committee of Privileges looms largest in my recent memories. Perhaps it has a lot to do with the fact that I chaired each of those committees for some time, despite the technical nature of the former and the unrelenting workload of the latter. Of course, the cooperation of the committee members and the excellence of staff helped make the work on those two committees absolutely memorable.
I believe that one of my greatest achievements in this place may have been teaching ex-Senator Stone, when we were on the regulations and ordinances Committee, to say `his' or `hers' as appropriate.

TALK.START.PARA: —That's a miracle.

—Yes, it was a miracle. Despite our concerns—so aptly raised again this evening by Senator Bjelke-Petersen—that only 13 per cent of Federal parliamentarians are women and the rate of gain has slowed down distressingly recently, this new building is actually distinguished by an ever increasing number of women in pretty well every category of employment. Clerks, security officers, attendants and even drivers were very few and far between until relatively recently.

PARA.TAB: I have remarked on occasions that women were conducting proceedings in the Senate—the Acting Deputy President was a woman, both clerks were women, both Hansard reporters were women, women were on the front benches on both sides of the chamber, the Black Rod was a woman and all the attendants one could see were women. We were actually running the place perfectly well. This excited no comment whatsoever. There is no doubt that we could run the country if given half a chance.

This demonstrates in microcosm the immensely increased nationwide opportunities open to women and the increasingly good example of equal employment opportunity being established within this institution. There are many fine feminists in this building and they are not all women. Such developments are probably in the long run of more lasting importance than today's actual number of women in the Senate and the House of Representatives. I have just been handed a note which says that more than 50 per cent of the Department of the Senate's staff are women.

The few women who have the honour of being elected to this place have a duty and a challenge to ensure that other Australian women of all ages and backgrounds are made aware of the fact that a career in politics can be civilised and rewarding; that it provides a unique opportunity to influence people and events, and to serve one's country and its people; and that it can be constructive, rewarding and even fun.

There are aspects of this life that I can relinquish with relief, and I do not think I need to detail them. I have worked with Ministers—some SNAGS, as referred to by Senator Evans, and some definitely not—most of whom I greatly admire and whose leadership has resulted in excellent initiatives which have placed Australia at the forefront of civil rights reform and social legislation. I have worked with dedicated and intellectually impressive ministerial staff and departmental officers with pleasure and mutual enlightenment. I have worked with non-governmental organisations from every group involved with social and human rights issues, and I have been greatly enriched as a result. I have represented Australia in Commonwealth, United Nations and other non-governmental forums.

To my good friends in the Senate system—they know who they are—my sincere thanks; I will never forget you. To my party colleagues and the people of Western Australia, you have given me a gift beyond price: the opportunity of being part of the social and human rights policy development in the 1970s, of participating in and implementing those policies in the 1980s and of being in a position to tell the world about it at UNGA 47. I am leaving the Senate but not by any stretch of imagination am I leaving politics.
Opposition senators—Hear, hear!

TALK.START.PARA: —In this valedictory I would like firstly to thank all of those who have assisted me in this place over the years, from colleagues through to staff and the Clerks. I have certainly made many friends in the 10 years that I have been here, among staff and my colleagues in particular. I say at the beginning how I valued the speeches made by the party leaders earlier this afternoon when they canvassed a number of points about all of us who are leaving this place. I have learnt a great deal since I have been here. I trust that I have contributed—I certainly have tried to contribute—at all times while I have been here.

PARA.TAB: While I am not a sentimental person, I would like give special thanks to my family for the many sacrifices that they have made over the years with me being here in Canberra and not at home. I also thank my parents for their great help, particularly as volunteer workers in my office over the many years that I have been a member of the Senate. I give particular thanks to my very loyal, dedicated and professional staff who are second to none, particularly Kath Couper, my personal secretary, who has been with me almost from day one as a member of this place; and Cassandra Gelade, one of my research officers who is here today.

I also thank my staff in Adelaide, Andrew Blue and Paul Dunstan. I see one of my former staffers in the gallery. A number of them went on to bigger and better things after getting the rigorous training in my office that was required of anybody who contributed to The Canberra Reports—one of my publications—over many years. They went on to the Premier's office, House of Representatives seats or wherever. They now have much bigger and better careers than they had prior to those wonderful opportunities.

While I was here I tried to focus on the economy and taxation. I tried at all times to help lift the standard of debate on the themes of the economy and public finance throughout the years. I trust that I have had some impact in the time that I have been here. I am well aware that many in the chamber tonight would not agree with very much of the content that I have put forward a lot of the time, but they were certainly aware that I believed in what I was doing and that I was trying to set standards for myself and keep the debate on the economy at a high level. I hope that I have had some impact in doing that.

Part of that participation occurred during the period of tax reform in 1985, which was an important time for Australia. I was pleased to be a small part of it as a member of this place by supporting the reforms month after month. One of the great reforms that this Government has brought in in the time that I have been privileged to serve here is the introduction of the capital gains tax. Of all the things that I wanted to see before I came to Canberra, one was a capital gains tax. It was just so unfair and unjust that many people in this nation derived their wealth and economic wellbeing from increases in asset values while the rest of the community paid tax regularly on its income. It was a tremendous unfairness in the Australian community. I know I am in good company. I will not name names across the chamber tonight, but I know one illustrious Opposition senator made a maiden speech on this very same subject and made that point.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why do you always pick on me?

—We both went to the same university, so maybe we were brainwashed at the same time about these things. That was a long overdue reform. The introduction of the capital gains tax helped drag Australia's tax system into the 20th century. We basically had a 19th century tax system until the mid 1980s. The capital gains tax was certainly a very important element in bringing fairness and equity to our tax system.

PARA.TAB: It is fair to say that when I came here the Australian economy was basically a quarry and a farm. Our export proceeds essentially came from rural products, either in mining or from growing crops and exporting them. They are very important industries now—they always will be—but we have seen over that 10-year period a diversification of the Australian economy towards value adding in the manufacturing sector. A now very large and growing area of our export proceeds is generated by manufactured products and, most importantly, by elaborately transformed manufactured products.

I was also pleased to be here at the time when perhaps the most major revisions of the Commonwealth Electoral Act occurred—the period 1983-84. The Act dates from 1918. Perhaps the most major changes since that time occurred at a very privileged time for me in the early 1980s. I was pleased to be a very small part of that process of bringing in major reforms to voting procedures in Australia. One of them was to ensure that more Australians could cast valid votes. We had the situation prior to those reforms where, in some parts of Australia, one-fifth of all voters voted informally because they simply could not get past a ballot paper with 78 or 74 names on it. That was one of the many reforms that came in during that period.

I was also very pleased to have a small role in helping give more recognition to women in public life in Australia. In fact, I put forward a proposal in 1984 that more House of Representatives seats in Australia be named after women of achievement—prominent Australian women. I did a lot of research—my staff helped—on that subject. It is always very easy to make a proposal about doing something; we not only made a proposal but also did the hard work and suggested who the seats might be named after. I am very proud to say that most of the names put forward by me were adopted by the Australian Electoral Commission. So many members of the House of Representatives today represent seats with names that I proposed which commemorate and mark the enormous achievement of women in the Australian community.

When I came here in the early 1980s, the six-year Senate turn prescribed under the Constitution was largely theoretical. With one exception, very few people had actually served a six-year term in this place. The only person at that time who served a full six-year term, which was the one laid down by the Constitution of Australia, was the former President of the Senate, Senator Douglas McClelland. He had the distinction in the late 1960s and early 1970s of having served a six-year term. The rest of us during the 1980s found that we were serving one and a half-year terms, three-year terms or whatever. It is something to note now that half of the 72 senators in this place who come from the States will have served a six-year term on 30 June. So that is quite a change from the past.

In passing, I refer to one of the ironies of politics as it has affected me. There are many ironies in politics, but one has affected me particularly. As a result of the 1987 double dissolution, I had the misfortune of being the last person to get a six-year term. Senator Robert Hill, who is on the other side of the chamber, was the one who missed out on getting that six-year term and was the first person to get a three-year term. Had events turned out otherwise, I would have been facing re-election in 1990, not 1993, and I will leave you to work out the implications of that proposal.

Looking over that particular time, I remember listening to a very impassioned speech by Senator Jim Short, who was the frontbencher in the Opposition who had carriage of electoral matters at the time. He made a very moving speech about how we should work out who would get a short term, a three-year term, and who would get a six-year term in this place. He made a very interesting speech saying that we should in fact use the proposal set down in section 282 of the Commonwealth Electoral Act; that is, that after a double dissolution one could look at the votes for the 12 elected persons and assume that it had been a half-Senate election, and the six who would have been elected in the half-Senate election would get the long term.

It is a matter of history now that we on the government side of this place decided to stick with the traditional method of working out who got the six-year terms and who got the three-year terms. I very consistently supported that position over the time, but that is one of the unresolved items of business perhaps facing this place in the future; that is, whether we will ever actually determine that we will use that section 282 to determine who gets a long term and who gets a short term or whether we will stick with the traditional method which is basically that senators get the six-year terms according to the order in which they are elected.

One of the things that has struck me about being in this place over the last decade is one of the limitations on debate and on ideas on this place; that is, the number of times—it must be thousands of times I could have counted up over this period—that honourable senators, in making a comparison in a speech or in framing a question, have been able to compare Australia only with the United Kingdom or the US. I think this is one of the big limitations that we have to face up to in this country.

In recent years, of course, it was fashionable to make comparisons with New Zealand for certain reasons. Sometimes Canada got a guernsey in these international comparisons. But we really do have this very serious problem in Australia, which has been reflected time and time again in this place, that honourable senators on all sides of the chamber—those on the frontbench and the backbench—do not seem to be able to talk in any great depth about what has been happening in the non-English speaking countries of the world.

We do live in a very conservative country and I think that this limitation that is imposed by our inability to speak other languages—of course I am generalising; I am a bad offender too as I do not have the ability to speak other languages—is an enormous inhibitor to the flow of ideas in this country.

Very few people can talk about economic reforms that are occurring in, say, the non-English speaking countries in Europe. Very few people know about these sorts of things, such as some of the very imaginative things that are done in running economies, in dealing with employment and in a whole range of policies. Time and time again we hear what has been happening in the UK or the US, or sometimes in New Zealand. I think we really have to deal with this. It is an important issue that has to be looked at in terms of language education in Australia.

Over 10 years I have published a number of newsletters. I called them The Canberra Report. They dealt with a range of issues, as you know, Mr Deputy President, as you yourself received them time and time again. The very catholic selection of issues—with a small `c', I might emphasise—

TALK.START.PARA: —It should be the big one.

—Senator Cooney asked for the big one. There was a classic which I think Senator Boswell got very close to referring to this afternoon. It was the one that had that tantalising title `Inside Queensland's faltering economy'. It was published in 1985. It was one that I did a lot of work on to examine whether Queensland really had the dynamic economy that the National Party was saying it had. It looked at the competence of the then Queensland Government to run the Queensland economy. That was a bit of a landmark. It seemed to get quoted everywhere in parliaments around Australia. I think I was a bit of a bete noire in Queensland for a while, but it certainly did put some of the problems of Queensland's economic situation on the map. It pointed to the lack of diversification in that economy and its narrow base. Of course, things have changed over the last five years or so with diversification into tourism and so on in a very big way, but that was one of the ones I particularly remember.

PARA.TAB: Another of those newsletters I particularly remember is the one published in November 1990. So it is now 2 1/2 years ago that I was able to publish my first research report on the implications of the goods and services tax in Australia. I looked at that in great detail. I believe that I did expose a number of the problems with that tax at that time and certainly helped expose the arguments in support of it over the next 2 1/2 years. I think it had some small impact in getting the ALP to think about what the implications of the GST were, were an election to be held some time in the future.

I have had the privilege of serving as a committee chair for six years. It has been a very interesting time. A number of people in the chamber have served with me and I have certainly valued their contributions to my committee work. I must say that I have been helped enormously by having an extremely high calibre secretariat. I would like to particularly thank the committee secretary, Ms Ilze Svenne, who has been a tower of strength to all of us on the committee on all sides of the chamber and has helped us turn out some extremely good reports, particularly in recent times. There was one on Australia's role in UN peacekeeping and one that I think was referred to by Senator Hill today on Latin America. I think we also had the same sort of support from our secretariat staff before her time and were able to turn out a landmark report on Australia's relationship with India which has led to a number of the recommendations being adopted by the Australian Government.

That is basically what I propose to say tonight. I have enjoyed my time here. I have enjoyed the 10 years that I have had in the Australian Senate. It has been an enormous honour for me and an enormous opportunity. I have never sat in opposition in this place and that is, I suppose, something to be remembered. I do know what opposition is like. I served on the staff of an opposition leader prior to coming here. I know it is a very hungry, very difficult and very lean time, but I can certainly say that in the Federal Parliament I have never had to serve in opposition.
I will be working hard in the future. I will not be winding back my activities. I will certainly be working hard to see Labor returned for yet another term in Canberra.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Aulich Sen The Hon T.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is a very strange place. I came to my place tonight after dinner and I found this book sitting there. It is called Stalin: the shaping of the Soviet Union. It says, `Best wishes, Terry. You could learn a lot. Senator Shirley Walters'. I do not understand it. After all these years, a closet leftie has been over there, interjecting more than 500 times in the last year or so. Suddenly I know she has converted to the sort of thing we have been saying for years. I will put that book aside, Shirley, and I will remember it as something that has been very important—the only conversion I have ever had since I have been in this place!

PARA.TAB: Today we are hearing 11 senators make their final speeches. Some of them will leave of their own accord and some will be dragged kicking and screaming into a new life. In fact, the rumour has it that some have already barricaded themselves in the old Parliament House and they are still down there like Japanese soldiers after the war, wondering whether someone will find them sooner or later.

As some of you know, I went to the old Parliament House a couple of years ago with a former senator. He sat in the seats there and he said, `I do not care about this new Parliament House, but the sad fact was that I left from the old Parliament House where there is a sense of tradition, a sense of history, and I feel very sad about it'. Nevertheless, when you put the building aside, there is still something in this place that is important to all of us.
