Sooner or later everyone leaves this place. Most of you feel that you are invincible and will be here for as long as Peter Durack. Even Peter would regret sometimes that he stayed so long. But it is a wonderful history for someone to come into this place and see every change of political complexion, both within his own party and between parties, and to be able to say, `I have seen it all and I have been part of those changes'.

In my own case, I have had some 15 1/2 years in politics at a State and Federal level. I had about a year and a half as a State secretary and, as those of you who have been State secretaries would know, just to hold that position for that time is worth about 15 years in politics.

TALK.START.PARA: —Except in New South Wales, where it is 30.

—In New South Wales it is 30, as Senator Faulkner says. For me, of course, time ran out. There were no more factions for me to join. There are only three in the Labor Party. If they had made a broad Centre Left, maybe I could have saved myself and picked up a few votes from this new emerging faction. In Tasmania at that stage there were only 11 factions and I could not get the numbers from any of them to get up. That is the way it is. You accept the—I will not say the decision or the judgment of the people—but of the people who count in that 200-member assembly.

PARA.TAB: As Senator Harradine knows, the Labor Party can be pretty tough. It wins elections because it is tough. It kicks its own out at the drop of a hat. It renews itself. It kills Prime Ministers from time to time, if it feels it is necessary to get re-elected by doing that. That is why we are on this side and you are on that side. That does not necessarily make us a better party but it does mean, in terms of understanding the way the mechanics of politics work, that we are probably a little better at it than you. I will get on to this question of idealism and the mechanics of politics in a few minutes.

When I look back on the time I came here in 1984 things were slightly different from now. The value of people leaving Parliament from time to time is the opportunity it gives for them to reflect a little on what we are doing here. Every day we go through the same routines; we are bogged down by the workloads that we seem to take on like Calvinist operators—the more work we have, the better we are and the happier we feel—and we do not have a chance to think about what we are actually doing. Occasions like this give us a chance—as Peter Walsh showed us tonight—to think about where we are going and what we are doing; and to ask is this particular institution evolving and, more particularly, is it relevant to what goes on out there in the big community? I want to get on to that in a few minutes.

When I came here in 1984 I still, after six years as a Minister in a State government and a year and a half as a State secretary, had ideals, enthusiasm and a lot more hair than I have now. Those of you who know me very well, can work out what is left after this nine years or so that I have been in the Senate.

The first thing that strikes me when I look at that particular period is how naive we were then compared with now. Nobody knew about economics then. They were the days before we all pretended that we were economists. If we fell over a Laffer curve, we would not have recognised it in a fit. In fact, we had just been introduced to the J-curve. We did not know what a comparable factor endowment was. To tell the truth—come on, be honest—very few of you know even now what any of those are. I think that the most exciting Senate committee hearing that we could have would be to call the Prime Minister in and ask him what was the J-curve; what was it intended to do; and what happened to it? It has just disappeared into the ether. Nevertheless, I must say that all of you were very impressed at the time, even Senator Short, who had been in Treasury, and pretended to know.

The simple fact is that all of us have talked about economics. We have been dominated by the imperatives of economics in this House. My good friend Senator Maguire has talked about economics. He has made a very strong contribution in that area. There are people like Senator Walsh, who pursued economic logic and pushed fiscal probity as far as he could, and was recognised as being an important person in that particular area. Most of us in this place, let us face it, are not economists, yet, on the whole, we have been convinced that we ought to be economists and that we ought to talk the language of other people outside this place.

The bottom line is simply that we are politicians. We do not like the term. `Politicians' has been a dirty word out there because it is associated with, say, American politicians of 1910, where you went into Parliament, got yourself half a railway, made a fortune and retired. That is not really what it is all about. The word `politician' comes from the Greek word `polis', which means people together living in a community and it means that you represent that community. The simple fact is that we do not represent the economists. We do not represent that small group who went off to Harvard, Sydney University or the ANU and learnt the language; we represent the community out there.

I do not represent the whole community. I represent a small section of it—the sort of people who knew me, loved me, hated me but who said, `All right, I will vote for the bloke', and they did. There are people within the party who did that and people in the public who did that. There are the Brian Harradine people, the Graham Maguire people, the Barney Cooney people and the John Watson people—they are all out there waiting to be represented by various people in this place. There are the David MacGibbon people—

TALK.START.PARA: —There are a lot of them.

—Yes, there are and they are interested in defence. They have a particular issue that they are interested in; their life centres around that particular thing or that, intellectually, is what they are all about; and they go to him.

PARA.TAB: There are people like Dame Margaret—which is what I call Margaret Reid in private. She is a wonderful member for Canberra. She gets elected in a city which basically votes Labor. How the hell she does it year after year and election after election, I do not know, but she does it. She works hard. She is assiduous and an incredibly good Whip in this place. I have heard her talk to various people on the other side. They know where they are or where they should be. I have seen Margaret hunt them like an exocet around the place and she gets them. If she does not get them there is a quorum called, we all come here and they are there doing the right thing.

There is Shirley Walters. I have disagreed with Shirley on many things. I have heard Shirley tell the unemployed that they ought to get their hair cut and go out and get a job. I have said, `This is shocking; this is disgusting' with my Labor friends. Then I thought, it is not a bad idea. If you go for a job interview, you ought to cut your hair, you ought to be well mannered and you ought to dress up to get that job. You may have been right but at the time, Shirley, you were totally wrong, you were a typical fascist under Fraser who was telling people to go and do the right thing and then they might be employed, ignoring the fact that unemployment was a big thing and was always going to be a big thing in the Australian community.

John Tierney is another typical example. He knows his area, is terribly interested in education and gets around all the universities and colleges. He is the sort of bloke who actually makes a contribution, represents people in this place and is prepared to do deals with me to get commonsense and logic up. Of course I admire him for that. We have very few divided votes on the committee. I could keep on going around this place. The fact is that you are a representative sample of the community. All of you represent certain sections and certain viewpoints.

My own committee—the Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training—is a terribly important committee. It did not have much to do with economics. We talked about what it cost to provide a service to the community in a way that the community would understand. We were not ashamed of the fact that we did not understand Laffer curves or J-curves and the rest of it. We aimed at a particular audience. We said certain things ought to be done and we worked it through. I must say that in about six years I cannot remember a divided vote on that committee. People like Senator Bell, Senator Sowada, Senator Calvert, Senator Teague and others were very important parts of that process. We worked our way through and we finally got what we thought ought to be done.

I remember the report we did on youth unemployment, which I think is the biggest problem facing this country; in other words, the lost generation. As politicians we have flunked it. We have got a big zero out of 10 for what we have done with this generation aged between 15- and 25-years.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Labor Party did that, not us.

—No, all of us in this place. We have not actually thought this through as much as we should have. When we sat on that committee, when we went and looked at all those groups around Australia and when we wrote that report, the one thing I got out of it was a determination from every member on that committee to do the right thing—that is, to work through intellectually all the options and what the solutions might be.

PARA.TAB: I am very grateful because during the preparation of that report there were members of the Liberal Party who went back to their shadow Ministers and said, `There are certain things in Fightback that we are going to have to pull out, that we can't accept and push on that committee'. They did it, and I know there were some problems within their party in doing that. Similarly, there were people in our party on that committee who said, `Look, we'll come to a compromise. We think that the kids of Australia deserve better than just party politics to solve this problem'.

To me that was a very encouraging sign because it was a committee report that was coming up to an election. We all could have taken sides and kicked the hell out of each other, but we worked towards what we thought were the only available options at that time. I know that, in many ways, that will have an effect but because we were not partisan the public servants, the bureaucrats, have gone back and looked at that report and said that there are some options there that we could use and the Minister will get that report and their response on his desk in a couple of months, and I think they will affect what the Government will do.

It is the sort of thing that I think is never covered by the press in this place because, if a committee is unanimous in its views, if we give and take a little to get to logical conclusions, it is not news. What is news is whether I drive a Saab 900 and make some money from a novel. That is what I read in the paper yesterday coming back from Sydney. That is news because it is something different. It is news that the Prime Minister has a piggery or if someone does something different. In other words, it is the unusual that tends to get promoted in this place, not the normal working arrangements that we have.

I will just go back to one point that I think is very important. I will give you a bit of a lecture here for five minutes on what I think you ought to do. I will be out of this place; I have had 15 years and it is time for me to go. But the one thing that I think this Parliament has to do is to ensure that the balance between the bureaucracy, the media and the Parliament is at least sustained—that one is not over the other. I must say that in the eight or nine years I have been here the one thing I have noted is that the bureaucracy is on top at the moment. In terms of balance, it has the greater power not because it is unseemly, devious or whatever but because we have created an environment in which we have put the weight on the scales of the bureaucracy.

Let us go back to one of the most important changes that happened in this Parliament and that most of us missed—the ball went whizzing in a wide curve, straight through to the keeper and we missed it. They were the changes in 1987 when David Block was asked to report to the Government about the way government departments ought to be restructured. The super ministries were created in 1987, when we reduced the ministries from 28 to 19, when we said that all these major departments that clearly had a Minister who was responsible and who you could drag into this place or into the House of Representatives were to be amalgamated. Just exactly who was the Minister responsible for various sections was not quite clear.

That was the first step. It was a major change. It created super ministries. It gave power to the bureaucracy, which was something that had not been done before in quite an overt way. The funny thing about that was that when the Prime Minister, Bob Hawke, was asked a question about this he said that it was:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the most far-reaching reshaping of the Federal machinery of government and of public administration in our history.

He did not say at the time that no bureaucrat need live in poverty by 1992, but what he said, taking aside the hyperbole, is a very important point. That decision was made by the Prime Minister in an administrative fiat with no discussion in Cabinet—no Cabinet decision—and it went straight through this Parliament with very little being said.

PARA.TAB: The results are now starting to show. I am sure the Minister for Transport and Communications, Senator Bob Collins, has no objection to my saying that one of his biggest problems in a number of areas that he has had to deal with recently has been trying to work out who the hell did what. Was it his bureaucrats, the Minister under him, the Minister assisting him, the Minister in the House of Representatives or the other Minister in the Senate? The simple fact is: we, as a parliament, whether we blame Bob Collins or not, have a lot to take account of. The fact is we let that through. We let that major change in government structures through with very little comment here. In other words, we talked in estimates committee hearings about this and that, where the dollar went here and where the dollar went there, but we really let the biggest change in the history of public administration this century through to the keeper.

So that was the first thing I noticed, and that relates to one other thing that I want to finish on tonight—that is, the question of the isolation of this Parliament from the general community. If you are going to ask yourself one question as politicians, at the end of the day you have to ask yourself this: is this Parliament relevant to the community it serves? All of you know that the membership of political parties in this country has declined over the last decade—declined immeasurably. In the Labor Party in some cases in some States membership is literally a tenth of what it was 10 years ago. The Liberal Party membership has gone down. The Labor Party membership has gone down. Independents find it difficult to get people to work for them. Only the National Party has kept up its membership. I am not sure of the reason for that. Maybe it is because the members of the National Party are the only socialists left in the Parliament—you know, the agrarian socialists. Maybe it is because they make being a member of the National Party a social event.

TALK.START.PARA: —We just serve the people—very simple.

—They serve the people and they do very nicely by them. But the simple fact is that all of us have experienced the problem, with the exception of the National Party, of a declining membership around Australia. That means that the sorts of people we are picking to go into parliament and the sorts of people who are choosing the ones to go into parliament are based on a far narrower base than, say, 10 years ago. That, in itself, is a problem.

PARA.TAB: Once you get to Canberra, following the creation of the super ministries, you also have a new bureaucratic arrangement, which I think most of us are having great difficulty in understanding. For example, if you went out into the street and said, `What's DOPIE? What's DITAC? What's DOTAC? What's DFAT? What's DEET?'. The average intelligent person in the street would say, `What the hell are you talking about?'. Yet these are the departments that affect people's lives right round this country. These are the super departments that have been created that affect business, little battlers, ordinary people, everyone in the Australian community, yet the Australian community would be almost unaware of the existence of these super departments and of the way they operate. Even for skilled lobbyists, the difficulty is to get into this place to find out how it works and how you affect the decisions.

I think the biggest question that this Parliament has to ask itself, and every individual member of the Parliament has to ask himself or herself, is: are we relevant and are we accessible to the community? Do they understand the processes that we follow here? I do not care whether they understand when the Black Rod moves in and puts the mace there when the Senate is not sitting or sitting or when the President comes in at a certain time. That is basically irrelevant. What is more relevant is whether people know how to get to us and how to influence the process and whether they understand the process. If we start talking like economists or bureaucrats, we are in trouble, because at the end of the day we are politicians.

That is our role. It is not something that is demeaning. Let the press tell you that if they like, but being a politician means being a person of the people. That does not mean shaking hands with some bewildered pensioner in front of a camera during an election campaign where someone says, `Do you want to meet Bob Hawke?' and suddenly there is a golden handshake and the poor old pensioner has had his hand grasped and the camera is on him and suddenly Bob Hawke has gone off with an entourage of 20 people.

TALK.START.PARA: —The silly old bugger.

—Or whatever he calls them. The simple fact is, that is not access; that is public relations. Access is whether people understand the system and whether they can come to you and you can then get something done. Anyway, that is the end of the lecture, but I think you can understand what I am getting at. It is a question all of you need to ask.
—You still don't know what the J-curve is, Terry.

—I am not going to tell you what the J-curve is. I never understood what the J-curve was. Is there anyone in the place who knows? Senator Short is not here, so I presume we will still all be in ignorance.
—Johnny Watson would know.
—Yes, he would.

—Maybe Senator Watson would. I must say that Senator Watson has been one of the most valuable members of this Senate since I have been here. I intended to mention Senator Watson later because he has spent time on our education committee where he was a very great contributor.

PARA.TAB: One of things I have noticed is that when someone like Senator Watson does his homework, goes through all the issues, objectively looks at what affects people in the community—whether they are accountants or people who are paying taxes—and comes back to this Parliament with views about how the legislation should be changed, he gets listened to. I must say that I have never seen anyone affect government legislation individually more than Senator Watson has because the suggestions and the amendments he has made get taken on trust. Someone like Minister McMullan listens to what he has to say, the advisers listen to what he has to say and on the whole they trust him. They do not find that in two weeks' time he has dudded them because he has given them smart advice which was intended to give his party an advantage. They take his views on trust. Over and over again in this Parliament I have many people perplexed by the complexity of the sort of situations that they are faced with, particularly in relation to tax legislation, and Senator Watson has been able to help us through the situation. That has been a very valuable contribution and I pay tribute to him for that.

I pay tribute to my staff—Charles, Carol, Scott and Jane. I particularly pay tribute to Scott Davies who ran an incredibly good campaign in Bass. He helped win the seat of Bass from a person who was a very good shadow Minister, one of the best shadow Ministers the Liberal Party had. I have to pay tribute to my staff for that, but I am sorry in a way that a good member like Warwick Smith lost his seat. However, that is politics and that is the way it goes. We would not be in government if some good members on the other side had not lost their seats or had failed to get seats that they should have won.

In relation to the committee itself, I would like to thank John Tierney, Paul Calvert, Karin Sowada, Winston Crane, Olive Zakharov and previous members John Watson, Kay Patterson and Robert Bell for the contributions they made. It was very important to me and this Parliament that they were able to work with me and the secretary, Brenton Holmes, and members of the secretariat. What we did was very important in many ways. For example, a couple of the reports we have produced are already set on the university curriculum. Some of them are in their fourth reprint and many of them are used as vade mecums for the bureaucracy. People look at what we have done and they say, `Let's have a talk about this with the Minister'. They actually use it to go through particular issues. They use it as advice. I think that is another aspect of the Senate that has in many cases been overlooked.

It is time to go because it has been 15 1/2 years or more. I have to say that I like old Bolsheviks. I like people who say, `The system is fine; it is working well. Party discipline is okay. We are in government' or `it looks like we are running a tight shadow Ministry'. But at the end of the day you need a few Bolsheviks around the place. You need people like Peter Walsh who says, `The Prime Minister is an old jellyback because he has reneged on his promises'. You need people like Michael Baume who says, `Come on John it is not good enough. You forgot the arts'—and the Liberals did. You need people like Brian Harradine who say, `The Labor Party at this stage is going through a difficult period'—I am just putting it tactfully for you, Brian—`I am getting out'. You need people like Bruce Childs who pushes a particular line which you have to respect. You need people like Jim McKiernan who has nationalistic views about Ireland and our place in the sun, but Australia first.

TALK.START.PARA: —And terrible ties.

—And terrible ties and braces. You need people who have got character in this place. You need the Wilson Tuckeys and the John Howards who say, `Okay, we are moving towards a republic, everyone seems to be going towards a republic but why should we have it?'.

PARA.TAB: I am a republican and I will always be a republican. I think that is the way to go, but I respect other people who say, `Hang on a second, let us think about this. Why should everyone run like the Gadarene swine over the cliff together'. Let us all be individuals in this place because we represent all sorts of people. I love Senator Kemp. I love the way he gets up—

TALK.START.PARA: —Couldn't have explained it better.

—Do not be embarrassed Senator Kemp. I love the way he gets up in this place and says, `I am sorry to upset you, Mr President', and he gives the President hell in the most polite way. He does it very nicely, but he sure makes the President think about it. He does it politely and he is a nuisance but he gets through. At the end of the day you are a mixture of different groups of individuals. My final message is: stay that way.

—Mr Deputy President, it is a pleasure to see you in the chair at this late hour. I was actually inclined to think that it really was not necessary for me to make a speech as I leave the Senate because one of the features of my time in this place has been the extent to which various aspects of my life, both personal and political, have been made an open book. I thought I could go home early. It probably will not surprise anybody when I say that not all the chapters have actually been written. I do not know whether I will follow in the footsteps of other former politicians in writing a book, especially other former Democrat leaders such as Chipp, Haines and Macklin, who have all produced their books. I do not know whether John has started his yet.

PARA.TAB: If I did write a book it might reveal certain so far unpublished facts. There certainly would be at least one chapter devoted to the inevitability of Cheryl Kernot's rise to the Democrat leadership. It would begin with the crucial initiation in her home State of Queensland of the petition to oust me from this position in the early months of 1991. It will be no doubt of interest to senators who are staying in this place—and looking at list of those who are speaking tonight it seems that there are hardly any of you staying—that the incoming Democrat Senator elect for Queensland, the Reverend John Woodley, officiated over that exercise as State President at the time.

As a party worker, and later as a senior party official, in the nine years before I came here for the Australian Democrats I was close to the operations of the Democrat Senate party room. I was even closer after I came here. It was always clear to me that operating the stressful and highly responsible role of balancing power within a small group of people—all with fair sized egos that we must have to come here as politicians in the first place—and working in a hot house atmosphere would be a very difficult task. This was only able to be successful because of the existence of trust and mutual support. The replacement of that approach with politics of Machiavelli, McCarthy and even a touch of Bob Roberts, who has not made it to Canberra yet, have seen me, others and tens of thousands of voters leave the Democrats. I leave the Senate as an Independent.

I was fascinated by Senator Maguire's analysis of the differences that might have occurred had different decisions been made in this place after the 1987 election. While he was speaking I worked out that had a different decision been made, I would not have been up for re-election in 1993. In fact, I would have been re-elected in 1990 and Senator Spindler would not even be here.

I welcome the opportunity that this speech gives me to say how much I have enjoyed, over the last 10 months, working with Senator Chamarette of the Western Australian Greens. I have seen in that period the continuation of the work that I have always done in this place and before I came here. The firm, principled policy position of the Greens and other groups, with whom I worked in the recent election campaign, reflects very much the deeply held convictions and priorities that landed me here in the first place.

As well as that Senator Chamarette is a politician whose style I admire and whose influence on the work of the Senate and the Parliament is, and I am sure will continue to be, a very positive one. I wish her and her new colleague Senator Margetts well in the challenge that lies ahead for them. I am comforted and encouraged by the knowledge that they will be here carrying on the work which I would have wanted to do had the election result been rather different for me.

I want to make a few more remarks about political style. It really worries me that the nature of politics, as it is practised by the most prominent politicians, although not necessarily the majority of politicians, is such that the average Australian is turned off, repulsed, even scornful of politics, politicians, and most disturbingly of the political and parliamentary process upon which our democracy depends.

It has been my goal, throughout my political life, and particularly during my time in this place, to make a positive contribution to breaking down that stereotype. It has been really important to me that the game should not be played for its own sake, that I should not be seduced by the trappings of office or the exercise of power and influence, that I stay in touch with real life and real people and their real feelings and challenges, and that I truly serve those in need particularly those in need of a political voice.

In spite of that public perception—and I think it is a view that is distorted, because the public only gets part of the picture via the media—there are a great many politicians who actually spend the vast bulk of their time in this place working outside that stereotype. They are the people whom I admire and respect in politics. I like to call them `the quiet achievers'. Some are not always all that quiet all the time, of course, but their achievements are considerable. Some of those achievements and some of those people have already been mentioned. They are not the people you see featuring nightly on the network news or on the 7.30 Report or on the big-time talkback radio. They are not there slanging at the other side during Question Time or in the heated debates of little consequence. They are the ones who are there doing the hard slog of the heavily responsible work in committees, both party committees and parliamentary committees. They sometimes make the most worthwhile and best researched speeches in matters of public importance and urgency motions. Here I think of Graham Maguire, of John Coates and others. They go on in this fashion year after year, serving their party and the Parliament and the public well, with loyalty and with substance.

They are the ones who often band together to shift the party heavies—and sometimes that is literally the party heavies—from an unacceptable policy position. They are the ones who rescue the committee system—and they do it regularly—from partisanship. They enhance the political process, the Parliament and the democracy.

I particularly value my time on committees in this place because, as I have said, that is where you see so many of these people. It has been a particular pleasure to serve on the Scrutiny of Bills Committee—some critical comments were made about the Scrutiny of Bills Committee a minute ago; I did not agree with those—on the Legal and Constitutional Affairs Committee, on the transport and whatever else it was committee, which has now been merged, and, right up until noon today, on the Privileges Committee. It is there that I have met these quiet achievers and worked with them—the Pat Gileses, the Barney Cooneys, the Bruce Childses, the John Coateses, and the Peter Duracks—quieter these years than in earlier years. I have not worked on committees with John Watson or with Margaret Reid, but those are the sorts of people, as I said, that I respect.

I am not suggesting that nobody on the front bench of either party has those sorts of qualities—of course they do—but I think it is true to say that, where those qualities do exist, they are not given emphasis or they are ignored or they are even discouraged, particularly by the media. I always remember how John Hewson vowed, when he took the leadership of the Liberal Party in May 1990, that he would not get down into the gutter, that he would raise the tone of the House of Representatives. Within two weeks he clearly had been discharged; certainly you could see it in the media. I can imagine his advisers telling him that this was no good; he had to mix it with Bob Hawke. I felt that was a shame.

I think that people on the front bench and those on the cross benches who bear the heavy responsibilities that they do should never lose sight of this further and crucial area of responsibility. They are the face of politics. They ultimately decide whether it is an ugly face, a face that causes people outside here to turn away, or whether it is a strong, responsible and trustworthy face, a face that draws more good people towards it.

This speech marks the end of seven years of parliamentary work, and of course I have some regrets about the end of this particular stage of my life. But overwhelmingly when I look back I feel a great satisfaction and some pride in what I have been able to use this platform to achieve during those years. I would like to mention just a few highlights. They are in some kind of chronological order to the extent that I can get it right. I think I had been here two weeks when the new disability services legislation came before the Senate. I was able to succeed in amending that legislation with the Opposition to include the psychiatrically disabled, who had been excluded from the new disability administration that was being put in place. There were a lot of other successful amendments that I have been involved in, but this does remain the highlight for me, perhaps because it was a significant first.

The second thing I would like to mention is the establishment, at my instigation, of the Senate Select Committee on Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals and their alternatives. I would acknowledge, in particular, the patience of the then Minister for Primary Industry, John Kerin, who stood by his commitment to give Government support for the committee's establishment, even in the face of almost a year of bitter resistance and hours and hours of debate in the Senate. It is worth noting, I think, that now in 1993 we have moved a long way on the question of organic agriculture to the extent of official government clean green policy.

Thirdly, I would mention my own role in opposing the Gulf War, a position which I believe has been strongly vindicated since. In particular, I was pleased to provide the catalyst for the recall of both houses of parliament in January 1991 to debate the Australian involvement in that war. I hope that this might have set a precedent and that no future government will consider sending troops overseas without such a debate.

I am particularly proud of having been able to break a 13-year log-jam, following the Fraser Government's legislation in 1976, banning electronic advertising of tobacco products. Senator Evans has already mentioned my successful private member's Bill passed in 1989 implementing a print ban on tobacco products. This has been followed up only three years later. If I did not have an abhorrence of mixed metaphors I would say that the log-jam was broken and the snowball rolled down the hill, but I am not sure that that would work. However, it has only taken three years for the rest of the promotion and advertising of tobacco products to be cut off by a government which was spurred into action by that breakthrough which was made possible by the years of persistent work against the odds, and against a tremendous lobby, by a wide range of community and health organisations who followed up in this more receptive political climate and finally achieved their goal.

I would like to acknowledge, too, the role of people in both parties who urged their leadership to support the first measure in 1989 and who then made that political climate there for last year's legislation, particularly Peter Baume, Peter Staples and others. I think the three of us have been found to be too left for all of our respective parties, when you think about it. The whole community benefits from these moves, particularly generations of young people still to come.

A recent achievement, if you like, to which my name is not attached in any way but which is an excellent example of the work of quiet achievers, is the removal of the ban on homosexuals serving in the ADF. This ban was opposed by many enlightened people within the Government party. I was really pleased to have the opportunity to use tactics on the floor of this chamber to strengthen their position against an unacceptable policy position. They used that increased muscle to establish their committee and eventually won the day. That was a great step forward in human rights in this country and a very important move in the individual human lives of many women and men.

I thank all of the people who have made our time in this place bearable, possible and even enjoyable. I share Senator Giles's experience of suddenly feeling that life was easy when I got here, that people did things for you. Since I had come out of the kitchen sink into the Senate, I suppose it was very easy to feel that way. I thank all of those people around this place who have done that.

It is interesting that Senator Giles is the only other senator—and, Pat, we really do think along parallel lines—to have mentioned the improvement brought about by the move from the old Parliament House. The improvement in working conditions for our parliamentary staff alone would have made it worth while. All of those in this place who work such long hours so successfully on our behalf, and on behalf of our democracy, deserve our thanks and deserve this place.

I thank the Black Rod and the Senate staff, the attendants and the Comcar drivers—I say, `Hear, hear!' to Shirley Walters in this respect—here and in other cities. I thank the cooks and the cleaners, one of whom chided me last week when I put a sticker on the door saying `toilet rolls needed'. The next morning the toilet rolls had been delivered. The sticker was still on the door but it had `please' written underneath my message. I felt about that big—and so I should have.

The Clerks are absolutely essential, particularly for those of us in a minority position. We need their advice to ensure not only that we do not make idiots of ourselves but also that we are able to achieve and advance our objectives. Harry Evans and Anne Lynch in particular, and the other clerks, really have my undying gratitude.

I thank the Hansard staff, who are always able to turn us into lucid human beings, and the PLOs. When Senator Chamarette leaves, she will have some good PLO stories. I will not tell them, Christabel; I will leave them for you. I thank the committee secretariats. It is all very well to say that it is good to work on committees with people across party lines, but the people who work in the committee secretariats are indispensable to that process. I particularly mention the Parliamentary Education Office. This marvellous and very valuable institution is growing, and I wish it well in the future.

Of course, I thank the President and the Deputy President. The President will remember that I, along with all other senators who fill a casual vacancy, had my own private briefing. He told me all the right things to do. When I first came in here I did all the wrong things—I asked a long question and I gave a long notice of motion—and he sat there and took it. I thank him for the early call yesterday for my last question in this place.

I also want to include in my thanks many of the people in the press gallery, not only for the job that they do, and do well, but also—and this is a personal thanks, as it is to many of the other staff and workers around this place—for the great measure of personal support that I have felt from them at some particularly difficult times for me in this place and again now that I am leaving.

Obviously, we cannot thank enough those people who work on our personal staff. The dedication to the job in the case of my staff has been extraordinary. I had dinner tonight with the three people who started with me and one other who joined me later. This week I have been joined by all of my staff. It has been a wonderful experience to have not only the professional support and the professional expertise but also the personal loyalty and the love of a group of people who are my best friends. It should never be forgotten that while we all cheer each other up as we go off into the wild blue yonder, and people ask us what we are going to do, those people are out of a job as well. Nobody thinks of them. There are five of us in my office writing out job applications, not just one.

I thank the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Gareth Evans), the Leader of the Opposition (Senator Hill) and the Leader of the National Party of Australia (Senator Boswell) for their kind words this evening. I wish them well as they forge ahead in their difficult roles in the new Senate. I think they will need those good wishes.

I offer my best wishes to other retiring senators. Although the AAP the other day pointed out that some of us were retiring senators and three of us were actually ousted, Senator Durack was nice enough the other night to say, `There are many ways of being ousted'. That did cheer me up, Peter.

I hope that all the other retiring senators feel as I do: keen to get on with the next, hopefully exciting, phase of their lives, even if it is terribly relaxing for those who want it to be. I assure the Senate that I feel absolutely no need for psychological help in making the transition to the next stage of my life. I hope it will be a productive new decade for me. I am sure that I will find new ways to be a nuisance to both Government and Opposition and, most importantly, to continue to be an activist on behalf of issues and people in the community which have always meant such a lot to me and which got me into politics and parliament in the first place.

I was asked today, `Was it all worth it?'. I answered, `Of course'. My family and my loved ones may well not agree. I do ask us all, and anybody out there who might be listening, to bear a thought for the innocent victims of political viciousness. When my family and loved ones have to put up with me on a daily basis from now on, they may well join with those who take the view that I ought to consider coming back here. That is not a consideration that is uppermost in my mind at the moment.

However, I leave this place with the same sense of excitement and anticipation for the future as I remember feeling when I left Nhill high school in 1959 to go into the great world of university. Thank you very much for all of the consideration, the help, the support and the challenge that all of you have given me in the time that I have been here.
Debate interrupted.

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —Pursuant to contingent notice of motion standing in the name of the Leader of the Government in the Senate, I move:

PARA.TAB: That standing order 64 be suspended to allow new business to be commenced after the question for the adjournment of the Senate is first put this day.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Debate resumed.

TALK.START.PARA: —It has been a bumpy night for a lot of us. I am in the position of following 10 other speakers. I feel very humbled because those speakers have spoken very eruditely about their time here. They have all had many years of very distinguished service. I leave the Senate having served only 22 months, and I am very conscious of those who have contributed much more over many more years.

PARA.TAB: If one had asked me before the election what I was going to say in my valedictory speech, I would have laughed because, like Senator Powell, and I guess many members in the House of Representatives, I had expected to be elected. I had every expectation of spending another six years here pursuing the issues and causes dear to my heart. But such are the vicissitudes of politics. In the words of another senator, `The people have spoken'—much to my disappointment. But I must accept that result without bitterness and rancour, while examining the post-30 June scenario as a new phase in my life.

I shall miss the Senate—there is no question about that. Contributing to the national debate on important issues such as youth unemployment, education, training and science has truly been a rare honour. To serve the people of New South Wales has been a privilege, and for that I thank God. It is possible to help people in a very real way here, either corporately or individually, and that has been a tremendous revelation. Being part of the balance of power has been challenging intellectually and a real test of political skill—a test that I have relished and thrived on.

I shall miss the cut and thrust of this chamber and the enjoyment of watching personalities play out their differences on the national stage. There are, as you would be aware, some firm friends and arch foes across party lines—although I think sometimes those animosities are more imagined than real. For example, Senator Walters versus Senator Collins. They have had some notable clashes certainly in the 18 months that I have been here. Senator Spindler and Senator Kemp—that goes without saying. We have all watched the exchanges between those two senators over a range of issues and I have certainly found their conversations in this chamber most entertaining. Of course, Senator Bishop and Senator Evans—and maybe quite a lot of other people as well—have likewise been very entertaining.

On first entering the Senate it did not take me long to realise that politicians were one of the most vilified groups in the community—and with good reason. Who in their right mind would work from 10 a.m. until 2 a.m. the next morning, a whole day in one go, without any overtime payment? Who would put up with phone calls from journalists, party members and assorted hacks at almost any hour of the day? We do. And what worker would willingly and ritually depart one's home for a whole week, 22 weeks of the year, leaving behind spouse and children only to be abused in this place and eat substandard food in the canteen downstairs? I tell you what, it defies all logic. We must be absolutely mad, and what is more, we enjoy it. That is the great paradox of this situation. It is no wonder the public shake their collective head in wonder.

One of the lasting impressions I will have of this place will come as a surprise to most members of the public. The adversarial nature of Question Time means that we give the public an impression of really hating each other's guts. But I was pleasantly surprised when I first came here to find that it is possible to form friendships across party lines and how important this element of the Senate is in the way this place runs. I have to say, I have really enjoyed getting to know people from a whole range of parties—and they know who they are—through committees, through the Parliamentary Christian Fellowship and through other social occasions.

I would also say that I have learnt a great deal by watching the style of senators in this place: the way that people use the procedures to achieve their goals, the way people speak, the way they manage to interject at the right time—and I guess, Senator Walters, you will go down in history in some respects as the doyen of interjecting. I have to say that I have learned a great deal from your tenacity and your capacity to get up and speak on virtually any subject at any time when called on. I think that is something for which you will be fondly remembered.

I will also leave this place in the knowledge that my time here was very short but, although my time here was short, I managed, I think, to put some runs on the board in relation to a few issues. I think I would regard the youth unemployment inquiry of the Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training as perhaps my most important work. For perhaps the first time the young people of Australia—and not just a select group invited by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating)—actually had an opportunity to put their views on the record about the challenges facing young Australians. Wanted: Our Future, the committee report, is a very important document, and I shall be sorry not to have the opportunity to debate the Government's response to that committee report in the Budget sitting.

Despite the intrigues of pay television, the foolishness of the tax cuts and the time wasted over procedural motions in this place, we must not lose sight of the many thousands of Australians facing long term unemployment; many of them are young Australians. These people are looking to us, the Parliament and its decision-makers, to put aside self-interested political points-scoring and devise real solutions to this most pressing of social problems. For we must recognise the trauma created by unemployment: the family breakdown; the hardship and the emotional stress of financial difficulty; the loss of self-esteem, particularly for men, and the social problems arising from it. While unemployment rises, State and Federal governments will continue to plug the dyke with bandaid measures to help people pick up the fragments of their shattered lives.

I found the Senate committees to be one of the most rewarding aspects of parliamentary work. Working on the Senate employment committee has been one of the most encouraging and positive experiences of my time here, and I guess that is reflected in many of the comments made by other senators. Each member of that committee brought to the work a sense of dedication and enthusiasm which enhanced the quality of each report.

I would like to pay tribute to the chairman of that committee, Terry Aulich. I have never worked with a chairman inside or outside of politics who has such a capacity to forge consensus between opposing views. His understanding of the issues, combined with a sensitivity for the politics of compromise, meant that even the most controversial matters were handled amicably and with good humour by the committee. Mr Deputy President, I would hope that this could be the norm for all committees in future. I wish Senator Aulich all the very best for his future, and I thank other committee members for their friendship and hard work, in addition, of course, to the secretariat led by Brenton Holmes.

Certainly I will remember with great fondness many of the public hearings that we had and the working relationships with people like Winston Crane and John Tierney, whose knowledge and understanding of education issues never ceased to amaze me; Olive Zakharov and Paul Calvert, of course, whose sense of humour was always a source of great amusement to me; and many others on that committee who contributed so much.

It is a truism almost that hardly a major decision is made in this place without some input from a parliamentary committee of some description. This Senate has enormous powers and nowhere is this more evident than in the committee system it has established for itself. I would hope that as time passes senators here would perhaps push the envelope of parliamentary reform a little further.

For example, the avalanche of delegated legislation by way of regulation is an issue that I believe requires urgent attention. The widening of regulatory powers in Bills has proliferated as the bureaucracy has sought to avoid scrutiny and exercised much more control over public policy. I think here I would echo the comments of Senator Aulich in relation to the bureaucracy, and it is time that we pulled them back and held them to account and made them much more accountable for what they bring into this place.

As a result of various disallowance motions that I have moved, it has become plainly obvious that the Senate needs to examine ways of more effectively dealing with regulations. The disallowance mechanism is a heavy handed and crude method of dealing with delegated legislation. The purposes of review and scrutiny would be better served by creating a procedure to amend regulations in the same way that we deal with Bills. I understand that Senator Harradine is developing a private member's Bill to address this very issue, and I hope that my colleagues and colleagues in the Opposition will give this Bill their due consideration because this is a very important issue.

Many people have asked me what I plan to do after 30 June, and the answer is very easy because, rather than watching Government Ministers dig holes for themselves, I shall return to the desert sands of Egypt and the great tells of Jordan to dig holes of my own. For, quite literally, on 1 July my research will suddenly reappear and I shall resume my former life as an archaeologist as suddenly as I became a senator. Yes, friends, I will once again have the pleasure of experiencing education at the coal face of the Dawkins reforms—the inadequate library and research facilities, the shrinking funding for the humanities and the academic politics which accompany a large university. Those of you who have come from an institution will know that academics play it as hard and as fast as we do here.

TALK.START.PARA: —Harder.
—Maybe even harder, Senator Tierney.
—A great training ground for politics.

—A great training ground for politics. I have a sneaking suspicion I might get drafted to the university Senate at some stage. The hardship of leaving this place is balanced by the privilege of returning to study the ancient past. The hot desert sands of Egypt still hold many treasures, as we have seen from recent reports in the newspapers. Despite the excitement of this place, nothing can quite match the thrill of discovery and the challenging task of piecing together the history of a long forgotten culture.

PARA.TAB: My own research will examine the pottery of ancient Egypt from the late pre-dynastic to the end of the third dynasty in an attempt to more clearly define the chronological relationships of this period. In addition, I hope to answer something more of the foreign relations between Egypt and its neighbours in the late fourth and early third millennium. I will be Senator Calvert's worst nightmare: an academic completing research on a topic incomprehensible to his waste watch committee. I will look forward to Senator Calvert's contributions on the Australian Research Council annual report in the Budget session, as I have watched with interest over the last 18 months.

One of the pleasures about leaving the Senate is that I will rediscover my marriage. Shirley, I have to tell you that I could not boil an egg when I came here and I still cannot. So, now that I am leaving, perhaps I will finally learn how to do that. I am sure my husband is waiting at home, just waiting to teach me how to cook; for the first time in 31 years, I might actually learn something. Many of you would know that I had been married for only some six weeks before being thrust headlong into this place, so the opportunity to spend meaningful time with my husband, Armon Hicks, is something I look forward to with great enthusiasm. Indeed, I would like to place on the record my thanks for his unrelenting support over the last 22 months as we worked through the trials and tribulations of parliamentary life. I really do not know what I would have done without him.

Of course, there are others to thank. My parents were always ready with dinner after a week in Canberra whenever we were too tired, frazzled or too sick to cook for ourselves—or for Armon to cook for ourselves. Our friends patiently kept in touch with us during long absences in Canberra. Officials of the Parliament, the Black Rod's office, Bruce and Kearen in the transport office, the committee secretariats, the catering staff, Hansard, the Senate attendants and the drivers were all always obliging and helpful. I would like to add my support to the Comcar drivers here as I, like many other women in this place, greatly value the security that we feel when we are travelling home at 4 o'clock in the morning. I really do think that any proposal to abolish Comcar would be strenuously opposed, not only by Comcar drivers but by every woman senator and member in this Parliament.

Special mention must be made of those people without whom a Democrat senator could not survive—Harry Evans, Anne Lynch and Cleaver Elliott. My special thanks to them for all the help, assistance and advice they have offered me in the past 22 months. Their kind attention when I first arrived in this place made the transition to political life much more comprehensible and much less terrifying. Of course, there are the Democrats' staff and members without whom I could have achieved nothing. Fundamentally, I thank my party for giving me the opportunity to serve my country in this very special way. My staff—Pam, Jaqui, Aldis, Jeff and Natasha—kept the ship afloat and helped to ensure that, in a short time, we achieved a great deal. To them I owe a deep debt of gratitude, along with my State and Federal parliamentary colleagues.

The next three years will not be easy for the Democrats but I am sure that, under the leadership of Senator Kernot, the party will restore its electoral fortunes and continue as a vital force in Australian political life. To those other senators leaving, you have my warmest regards and my best wishes for the future.

So there we have it, colleagues. My time here has been brief, and perhaps I will return. But my father always told me that it was better to live short and live like a lion than live long and live like a sheep. Whilst I do not agree with that sentiment as applied to life as a whole, it does sum up my time here as a senator. I have absolutely no regrets. I thank you all and I wish you well.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kernot Sen C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator KERNOT
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I do apologise to all of those who are leaving that I was not able to speak earlier. I will not detain the Senate unnecessarily, but I think the contributions of all these distinguished Australians who are leaving this Parliament deserve to be recorded. I begin with Senator Peter Durack, a most courteous gentleman who first made himself known to me when I was in the airport lounge in Melbourne before I had even set foot in this Parliament. I was astonished that he knew who I was and came up and introduced himself to me and wished me well. He was the very first person from either party to do that, and I remember it with great gratitude. Peter Durack was a member of State Parliament when I was only 16—
—You have aged, Cheryl.

—That is right, and we know why. That was when my State Liberal member was suggesting to me that I think about some sort of career in politics. After being defeated at the State level, Senator Durack entered this chamber in 1971, after being elected in 1970. This gives him the honour of being father of the Senate, soon to be taken over by Senator Brian Harradine.

PARA.TAB: It is difficult to refer to such a career in a few short words. He has held four portfolios, including the senior position of Attorney-General for almost six years. He has legendary committee experience; he has represented Australia and this Senate on numerous occasions. This, of course, does not mention his brilliant academic career which won him a Rhodes scholarship. His knowledge of the Senate is renowned and his contribution to this place has made it a richer place.

Senator John Button is not with us tonight; he is my favourite resident garden gnome—the perpetrator of the lethal fairies at the bottom of the garden label, he of the infamous pen and postcard. Let me add to the list—of which Senator Bishops's is well known—another letter written to me. Here is the original letter; it is written in black texta on a piece of ordinary writing pad, liberally sprinkled with spelling mistakes, the words not even straight on the line. It says:

SPEECH.PARA: Dear Cheryl Kernot,

PARA.TAB: I am a pensioner and short sited.

I congratulate you on becoming leader of the democats. I think you are a good person, and when I listen to parliment on the wireless I can understand you. . . . Therefour I was pleased you won and I wish you well. Don't let those Labor's or Liberal's pull the wool over your eyes; not that Liberals could fool anyone.
My best wishes for the future. Look after the Senior Cits.
Sorry I have no proper paper, John Button.

SPEECH.PARA: And it is John Button, because this is the envelope with his name crossed out in black pen. I looked at it three times and decided it is definitely John Button.

TALK.START.PARA: —He never could spell.

—I do not know that. I am really indebted to my staff member Chris Fry for his assistance with the remarks I am to make about Senator Peter Walsh. Peter Walsh played, and continues to play, politics very hard. Indeed, on some occasions he obviously played it far too hard. After the events of late 1975, he maintained the rage more than most and for longer than most. As the leader of the party which has suffered more than its share of Walsh bile over the years, I can honestly say that, while on many occasions I disagreed with him, often vehemently, I also acknowledge that there was often substance behind the head kicking—well, I might acknowledge it in the case of head kicking the Opposition.

PARA.TAB: Like it or not, politics often involves opportunism and, unfortunately, stunts often generate headlines more easily than matters of substance. Also, the pursuit of power tends to become dominant over principle. None of these things could ever be laid at the feet of Peter Walsh. Few people in this place willingly sacrifice ministries. Fewer people still sacrifice senior Cabinet posts. Peter Walsh did so—apparently, with a deal of satisfaction. This gives us an insight into Peter's enigmatic nature.

He started in the Left and later helped found the grouping that became the Centre Left. But, ironically, he has been labelled as a member of the extreme Right because of his relishing the task of cutting public spending. I have differing views from many of those held by Peter in this area, but we have to acknowledge that he is driven by the principle of equity. He has no shortage of courage in pursuing what he regards as equitable, even if it involves criticising his own party. The income tax debate of recent times is a prime case in point.

I do not really like the crusade he has engaged in in his pursuit of organised crime in this country. To use his words, he has personally, he believes, exposed the hairy-legged mafia, the ethnic mafia and the green mafia, not to mention some groupings of his own New South Wales colleagues. One would have thought that he might have championed a larger budget for the National Crime Authority. However, I am advised he did not.

While I think he has been particularly unfair and savage against some high profile women, he and his wife, Rose, have raised a family of four daughters. Anyone involved in an achievement such as raising and debating adult daughters cannot be all bad and cannot have learnt nothing from the experience.

Apart from his ministerial reputation, Peter Walsh also has an unmatched social reputation in this Parliament. He is a gregarious, generous host who avoids any semblance of pomposity or unnecessary formality. Party lines are irrelevant and all hatchets are buried as long as one can stand watching endless repeats of the West Coast Eagles. Indeed, his generosity has left more than one member of my staff, to my annoyance, with tired eyes and a sore head the next day. He has retained his larrikinism to this day. In short, Peter is an iconoclast in the Australian bush tradition and this Parliament is losing one of the sharpest thinkers it possesses. The faint praise I have personally received from him—that I am not bad for a Democrat—could well be the ultimate accolade.
Debate interrupted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 10.30 p.m., under sessional order I put the question:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate do now adjourn.
Question resolved in the negative.

TALKER.NAME: Senator KERNOT
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to say a few words about Shirley Walters. Shirley, you are wrong in saying that you will be missed like a hole in the head. You will genuinely be missed from this chamber. You will also be genuinely missed from the many committees on which you have served because of your enormous energy, your tremendous enthusiasm and your unparalleled ability to speak on anything for any length at any time—the later the hour the better. You said you will get them yet on community standards. I think you will because I can hear your voice now on the talkback radio networks of Australia tenaciously and regularly. I believe you when you say you will get them and I hope you believe me when I say that we know you will never give up. Thank you for your hospitality and generosity towards me when my house was burnt down and for the many pleasant little conversations that we have had as members of the committee together.

PARA.TAB: I do not know Senator Austin Lewis very well but I am told that he has done particularly outstanding work on the Standing Committee of Privileges. I am sure we all remember the delightful notice of motion on the occasion of the birth of his grandchild. There is one thing for which I will have a constant reminder and that is that he shares my birthday of 5 December, with just a few years difference in between.

Senator Flo is a most charming and gracious Queensland woman, the fourth woman to be elected to represent the people of Queensland since Federation. She is a very moderate and fair Acting Deputy President. I think one of the most charming and civilised combinations in this chamber has been Florence in the chair and Anne Lynch at the table. What a team! Never in my wildest dreams, as I said rude things to the National Party Cabinet Ministers on television in Queensland in the 1970s, did I imagine that 20 years later in this place you would cross the floor and sit on those benches with me to vote for one of my sugar amendments. It is amazing and instructive what history does to our lives.

I have always appreciated your inquiries about my family, particularly my daughter, and your graciousness to her when she is here in Canberra with me. I most of all admire your stamina. When young Bill has been missing from this chamber, you have been here. At 3 a.m. when you come out of your little doorway and I hear it close, I know that I have to come straight after you. I admire your stamina and I do not know whether I will be able to match it when I reach your age. I certainly do not expect to be here.

I turn to Senator Pat Giles. There are a lot of Western Australians leaving the Senate tonight. Pat has served her State since 1980. I understand that she worked in health before entering this chamber and has continued working on social justice. She has given long service to the areas of social welfare and community services in the Senate committees. She has an incredible record of working for women, and many others have pointed to this this evening. Time does not even allow me to scratch the surface. She has led Australian delegations to international conferences for women and she has an incredible range of friends and acquaintances from all around the world. I understand that in one respect she is quite a high flier in that she is a long term friend of the first woman in space, Valentina Tereshkova, who was also a member of the former USSR's Supreme Soviet. I would be proud if I could leave this Senate with such an impressive record on the achievement for women.

Senator Graham Maguire is described by others as one of the quiet achievers. In fact, he is a neighbour of mine. We share the same block of units and he has been extremely helpful to me in the most practical of ways, for example, when dealing with the body corporate. We even managed to organise to share Comcars and save the taxpayer money from time to time, Senator Hill will be pleased to know. I think that we have probably underestimated Senator Maguire's contribution to the economic debate in this chamber.

TALK.START.PARA: —So did the Labor Party.
—In some respects some of us have underestimated his contribution. I wish him well.

PARA.TAB: Senator Terry Aulich may well be used to valedictory speeches. I say that because he has been a representative at the local, State and Federal level. He may well be the only current senator with such a record.

TALK.START.PARA: —No.

—No? He has extensive ministerial experience in a variety of portfolios and extensive committee experience in the Senate. Senator Evans referred to Senator Aulich's long association with the Labor Party but he has also had a long association with the Democrats. Terry Aulich and Robert Bell were at the Poymeena Hostel High School together. Terry has worked as a teacher and I think you would have to say he is a bit of a greenie. I am also informed that he is a pretty fair boxer and quite a charmer.

PARA.TAB: His committee brought down a landmark report on the scourge of our age—unemployment—and provided many practical suggestions. I hope that these will be successfully implemented as soon as possible. We are all called on to write a lot as parliamentarians: we write speeches, letters and articles. Some of us even write and co-write books. We all know how true and accurate all of our works are, even if our opponents disagree. But Terry is the only senator I know who readily admits that his best work is fiction.

On behalf of the Australian Democrats, I would like to acknowledge Janet Powell's past contribution to the party as a Democrat senator. A high spot in her contribution is the stand she took on behalf of the Democrats on the Gulf War. It was a brave stand, a stand she articulated strongly and a stand which has been justified by the events. We also acknowledge Janet's great achievement in becoming the first woman member of either House of this Parliament to have a private member's Bill passed by both chambers and written into law. The Bill to which I am referring banned print advertising of tobacco products. The benefits to the community of this measure will continue well beyond the senatorial careers of all present senators. We wish Janet well in the future in her productive new decade and hope that she finds a new and satisfying focus.

I turn to Senator Karin Sowada. As Karin pointed out to us, she came into the Senate under the most difficult of circumstances from a wide-ranging and successful background with the Democrats in New South Wales. Like many Democrats, she has done everything from being a candidate to being campaign manager and elected senator. Karin had only been married six weeks, as she said, and what a way to start a marriage! It is absolutely no honeymoon.

TALK.START.PARA: —Flo knows all about that.

—Yes, Senator Flo does know. But we do know that Karin and her husband are still married and that they will be grateful for the time that they will now have to spend together. Karin has done some excellent work for the Democrats while in this chamber. I cannot tell you what a relief it was to have somebody fill a casual vacancy who was not only competent and intelligent but with the bonus of being young and female as well. You all know that under casual vacancies anything is possible. Karin will not mind me saying that she hates the late nights, and from one so young! Karin will enjoy many sleep-ins from now on and we will all be incredibly envious. But as the doors close and open for Karin, in many respects we know that she has the world at her feet—in fact, so much of the fabric of past worlds beneath her feet and beneath her trowel. We know that she will return when she chooses to.

PARA.TAB: I understand that people have made implied valedictories for Senator Michael Tate, so I will add a few comments. Except for his reputation with Comcar drivers, Senator Michael Tate deserves to be treated by this Senate and his party with the dignity and honour which he has accorded to this chamber. I have enjoyed his logic and passion. I hope that he does not end up in the High Court, although Australia might be the better for that.

To all of you leaving us this evening, on behalf of the Australian Democrats, I wish you continuing health and productiveness in whatever way you choose to continue to contribute to Australia's future.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I understand that it would suit the convenience of the Senate to transact remaining business now and then return to the valedictories, if required. There being no objection, it is so ordered.
