TALK.START.PARA: —I present the Government's response to the report of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade on Australia's efforts to promote and protect human rights. I seek leave to have the document and a tabling statement incorporated in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The documents read as follows—

PARA.EMPHASIS: THE GOVERNMENT'S RESPONSE TO THE REPORT OF THE JOINT COMMITTEE ON FOREIGN

SPEECH.PARA: AFFAIRS, DEFENCE AND TRADE, "AUSTRALIA'S EFFORTS TO PROMOTE AND PROTECT HUMAN RIGHTS"
Senator the Hon Gareth Evans QC, Minister for Foreign Affairs
The Senate, 27 May 1993
I am pleased to table the Government's response to the Report of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade, "Australia's Efforts to Promote and Protect Human Rights".

The Human Rights Sub-Committee of the JCFADT tabled its Report on 8 December 1992. The Report was the first from the JCFADT dealing with human rights. I would like to take this opportunity to congratulate the Committee and members of the Human Rights Sub-Committee, particularly the then Chairman, Senator Chris Schacht, on the Report.

The Report was comprehensive in scope and made a series of recommendations relating to the Australian Government's human rights policy. The Report stated that the Government's record was "laudable" and that most witnesses and most submissions approved of and appreciated the work of the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade in this area.

One specific area in which the report criticises my portfolio's handling of human rights policy is in relation to Indonesia and East Timor. The Report stated that the 12 November Dili massacre and its outcome "deserved much stronger condemnation" from the Australian Government. The Report also stated that it was important that the Australian Government should be consistent in its reaction to human rights outrages of this kind.

As I stated at the time, I do not believe that the Australian Government took a softer line on the Dili massacre than was warranted. This Government has a strong record of unswerving commitment to human rights. We have also adopted as far as possible the same approach to all cases of alleged human rights abuse wherever they may occur. In the case of East Timor, I said in this same place as recently as Monday, and I repeat it now: my hope and the Australian Government's hope has consistently been that Indonesian authorities will be able to achieve long term reconciliation in East Timor, through such strategies as a major reduction in the military presence, a major economic development strategy, further recognition of East Timor's distinctive cultural identity and possibly some greater degree of autonomy.

The JCFADT's recommendations covered a range of other country's situations. The Report deals with Australian policy towards Bougainville, Sri Lanka, Burma, Vietnam, the Philippines, China, Tibet, Syrian Jews, Sudan, Guatemala and Salman Rushdie. Most of these recommendations do not run greatly counter to existing policy and the Government has agreed either wholly or in part with most of the Committee's recommendations.

The Committee's report was critical of the alleged failure of successive Australian Governments fully to ratify the human rights instruments to which Australia is a Party. Specifically, the Committee recommended that the Government act without delay to accept further optional complaint mechanisms provided for under the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights, the Convention on All Forms of Racial Discrimination and the Convention Against Torture and Other Cruel, Inhuman, or Degrading Treatment or Punishment.
Action in this regard has been taken since the Committee's Report was issued and this is detailed in the Government's responses.
Australia lodged declarations with the United Nations on 28 January 1993, accepting the optional complaint procedures under:
Article 14 of the International Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Racial Discrimination (CERD), which provides for individual complaints of violations of the CERD;
Article 41 of the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights (ICCPR) which provides for State Party complaints of violations of the ICCPR; and

Articles 21 and 22 of the Convention Against Torture and Other Cruel Inhuman or Degrading Treatment or Punishment (CAT), which provides the State Party and individual complaints respectively of violations of the CAT.

The Committee's Report was also critical of the problems and delays associated with the consultative process with the States. One of the major themes of the Report is the belief that States' rights in the consultative process must no longer impede the ratification of outstanding articles in relevant international human rights treaties.

The JCFADT's recommendations also cover human rights training, the use of Official Development Assistance for the promotion of human rights, military exports and the development of regional human rights forum. The Government has agreed either wholly or in part with all of these recommendations.

The Government does not agree with two recommendations which specifically relate to an increase in resources in my Department for the handling of human rights and the reinstatement of annual human rights reports from diplomatic posts.

I believe resources currently dedicated to human rights in the Department and posts are adequate. The Department already devotes substantial resources to the advancement of our human rights policy and is able to satisfactorily meet the demands placed on it. The Human Rights Section is adequately staffed and is supported by the Human Rights and Social Unit within DFAT's Legal Office. Human rights policy is also dealt with extensively in the geographic Divisions within the Department.
Any increases in resources and activity in this area, although I regard it as a very high priority for the Department's work, would have to be at the expense of other high priority issues.

Annual human rights reports from posts would only duplicate detailed work done by other agencies to which the Government has access. The Government is able to rely on usually accurate and timely information on country situations from such diverse sources as the US State Department's annual publication "Country Reports on Human Rights Practices" and reports from organisations such as Amnesty International and Asia Watch.

In addition, many diplomatic posts are already heavily engaged in responding to requests from Canberra for information on individual cases forwarded to the Department from the Parliamentary Amnesty International Group, and other non-government organisations and members of the public. Posts also regularly report on aspects of human rights practice in most countries either when specifically tasked or in more general reporting.

The Australian Government will continue to record a high priority to the promotion and protection of human rights internationally. This position is based on the belief that the universal observance of the rights and principles contained in the Universal Declaration of Human Rights and other major international human rights instruments, would result in a more just international order, from which the security and prosperity of all nations and individuals would benefit.
The JCFADT's Report, and the Government's response to it, reflect the leading role the Government has taken on international human rights issues.
In conclusion, let me once again congratulate JCFADT on their report.

PARA.EMPHASIS: THE AUSTRALIAN GOVERNMENT RESPONSE TO THE JOINT COMMITTEE ON FOREIGN AFFAIRS, DEFENCE AND TRADE REPORT:

SPEECH.PARA: "REVIEW OF AUSTRALIA'S EFFORTS TO PROMOTE AND PROTECT HUMAN RIGHTS
Recommendation 1 The Committee recommends that the Australian Government introduced legislation to Parliament to implement the Genocide Convention.
Agree

As stated in the Submission by the Attorney-General's Department to the Committee, dated 9 June 1992 proposes are being prepared for consideration by the Government on specific legislation to create a Commonwealth crime of genocide. The Genocide Convention Act 1949 gave approval for Australia to sign the Genocide Convention and notified its extension to Australia's external territories. Article V of the Convention provides that:

"The Contracting Parties undertaking to act, in accordance with their respective Constitutions, the necessary legislation to give effect to the provisions of the present Convention, and, in particular, to provide effective penalties for persons guilty of genocide or any of the other acts enumerated in Article III".

Article III states that genocide, conspiracy to commit genocide, direct and public incitement to commit genocide, an attempt to commit genocide and complicity in genocide are acts that shall be punishable.

In meeting this undertaking, Australia has relied on the view that the obligation to legislate does not require the creation of a specific offensive genocide, but maybe satisfied by the provisions of State and Territory criminal laws. This view apparently accords with the practice of most other State Parties to the Convention and provides no basis for criticism from other countries that Australia is in breach of the Convention. A United Nations survey in 1978 found that most States regarded their constitution or "ordinary" laws as sufficient to prevent and punish genocide (see Study of the Question of the Prevention and Punishment of the Crime of Genocide, E/CN.4/Sub.2/416, 4 July 1978, at para 551).

However, in 1969 and 1987 the United Kingdom and the United States passed legislation dealing specifically with genocide. The Inter-Parliamentary Union, and its 86th Conference in Santiago in 1991, passed a resolution calling on all sovereign States to enact the necessary legislation for the implementation of the Convention. The Gibbs Committee, in its final report on the Review of Commonwealth Criminal Law, was of the view that Australian law as regards the Convention was unsatisfactory and recommended that legislation be enacted along the lines of the United Kingdom act "to implement fully Australia's obligations under the Convention".
In the light of these developments, the Government will soon be considering the options for specific legislation creating a Commonwealth crime of genocide.
Recommendation 2 The Committee recommends that the declaration regarding Article 4(a) of the Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Racial Discrimination should be withdrawn forthwith.
Agree in part.

Before Australia can remove its reservation to Article 4(a), legislation is needed to create a criminal offence of incitement to racial hatred, either nationally or in all jurisdictions. The Commonwealth proposed to create an offence of incitement to racial hatred in the Racial Discrimination Legislation Amendment Bill 1992. That Bill was introduced into Federal Parliament on 16 December and left to lie on the table for public consultations to occur. The Bill was the subject of a major round of consultations during January and February including public meetings in each capital city and in Townsville, Alice Springs and Launceston. The legislation received a mixed response. A report on the consultations is presently being prepared for the attention of the Attorney-General.

Recommendation 3 The Committee recommends that the Australian Government should act without delay to accept further optional complaint mechanisms provided for under the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights, the Convention on All Forms of Racial Discrimination and the Convention Against Torture and other Cruel Inhuman or Degrading Treatment or Punishment.
Agree
Australia lodged declarations with the United Nations on 28 January 1993, accepting the option complaint procedures under:

PARA.TAB: Article 14 of the International Convention on the Elimination of all Forms of Racial Discrimination (CERD), which provides for individual complaints of violations of the CERD;
Article 41 of the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights (ICCPR), which provides for State Party complaints of violations of the ICCPR; and

Articles 21 and 22 of the Convention Against Torture and Other Cruel Inhuman or Degrading Treatment or Punishment (CAT), which provide for State Party and individual complaints respectively and violations of the CAT.

SPEECH.PARA: Recommendation 4 The Committee recommends that the Government review the International Labour Organisation (ILO) Conventions 135, 141, 151 and 169 with a view to ratifying them without delay.
Agree for ILO Conventions 135, 141 and 151; Convention 169 under consideration.
In May 1990 Cabinet established an interdepartmental Task Force to review 74 (later increased to 75) International Labour Organisation (ILO) Conventions which Australia has not ratified.
The four Conventions cited either Joint Committee and Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade were amongst those considered by the Task Force. The position in respect of each Convention is as follows:
C135, Workers' Representatives, 1971.
This Convention was ratified by Australia on 26 February 1993.
C141, Rural Workers' Organisations, 1975.
Western Australia (1992), the Australian Capital Territory (1992), Victoria (1992) and South Australia (1992) have formally agreed to ratification of the Convention.

There appears to be full compliance in all jurisdictions, and all jurisdictions apart from the Northern Territory have intimated that they should be in a position to agree to ratification in the near future. The Northern Territory indicated that they probably would not be prepared to agree to ratification until the CAI complaint to the ILO's Committee on Freedom of Association relating to the 10,000 member requirement had been resolved. This matter has now been resolved and the Government has announced that it will amend the Industrial Relations Act 1988 to remove the requirement for an organisation of workers to have 10,000 members to be eligible for registration under the Act. This should remove any impediments that the Northern Territory has to ratification of the Convention. The Government hopes to be in a position to ratify C141 in the reasonably near future.
C151, Labour Relations (Public Service), 1978

Queensland (1982), South Australia (1987), Tasmania (1981), Victoria (1992), Western Australia (1992), the Northern Territory (1987) and the Australian Capital Territory (1992) have agreed to the ratification of the Convention.

New South Wales law and practice appears to be in compliance. However, concerns about ratification have been expressed by the New South Wales Government on the basis that they might wish to adopt certain policy initiatives which might move New South Wales out of compliance. In November 1992 clarification was sought from NSW Government but no response has been received. The Government hopes to be in a position to ratify C151 in the reasonably near future.
C169, Indigenous and Tribal Peoples, 1989
No State or Territory has agreed at this stage to the ratification of the Convention.

A draft law and practice report has been prepared in consultation with Commonwealth, State and Territory authorities outlining in detail the degree of compliance by Australia and the Convention. In addition, the views of non-governmental organisations and Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander communities are being sought concerning possible ratification of the Convention. A decision as to whether Australia will ratify the Convention is expected to be made during 1993.
Recommendation 5 The Committee recommends that:

the annual report from the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade should include a current list of UN Human Rights Treaties, including the reservations that still apply and those that have been removed in the preceding 12 months; and

the Committee's role should include scrutiny of Australia's treaties and treaty based machinery by the conduct of regular and formal reviews, which will be incorporated in the Committee's annual report to Parliament.
Agree.

The Department of Foreign Affairs will provide in its annual report a current list of Human Rights Treaties to which Australia is a party including information on any reservations that might apply and on those that the Government may have removed.
Recommendation 6 The Committee recommends that:

Arrangements be made to facilitate the participation of non-government organisations in further consultations prior to the preparation of Australia's reports under international human rights instruments;

The Australian Government's reports and the UN Committee's response to them should be presented to the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade as part of the annual report when they occur in that year; and
These reports should be tabled in Parliament to facilitate public scrutiny of both the reports and the UN response to them.
Agree.

The Government agrees that the involvement of non-government organisations and the wider community in the preparation of Australia's reports under international human rights instruments can assist in improving the quality of the reports and the effectiveness of the reporting system.
The responsibility for preparing these reports is divided between Commonwealth Departments and practices with regard to consultation vary. Substantial consultation already occurs.

The Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade is responsible for the preparation of the reports under the International Covenant on Economic, Social and Cultural Rights and the Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Racial Discrimination. The Department liaised extensively with the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission (ATSIC) in the preparation of the most recent CERD report (Ninth Periodic Report). The Department will institute more formal consultation with NGO's on the preparation of future ICSCR and CERD reports.

The Attorney-General's Department is responsible for the preparation of reports under the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights, the Convention Against Torture and Other Cruel, Inhuman or Degrading Forms of Punishment and the Convention on the Rights of the Child. The Attorney-General's Department intends to call for submissions from peak human rights organisations in relation to Australia's third report under the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights and is considering the possibility of circulating the draft report to such organisations for comment. In relation to Australia's first report under the Convention on the Rights of the Child, the States and Territories were asked to consult relevant non-government organisations in their jurisdictions while preparing their input to the report. Due to resource restraints only some of the States and Territories were able to do so.

The Office of the Status of Women (OSW) is responsible for the preparation of the report under the Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination Against Women (CEDAW). NGO's are consulted as a matter of course in the preparation of Australia's CEDAW Report. During preparation of Australia's second periodic report, OSW and the National Women's Consultative Council (NWCC) convened, in June 1991, a day-long meeting with a wide range of NGOs and representatives of Commonwealth Departments to discuss aspects of Australia's implementation of the Convention and to allow NGOs to express their views and areas of concern. These were incorporated in the preparation of the final report.

The Government supports the recommendation to present reports to the Joint Committee and to table reports to Parliament and would have no objection to their publication in the Parliamentary Papers series. It would also be valuable to make them more widely available by distributing them to interested agencies and libraries and making them generally available in government bookshops. More extensive publication would, of course, depend on the availability of resources.

Recommendation 7 The Committee recommends that the Government reinstate the annual human rights reports from Australian diplomatic posts and urges the Government to make provision in resources and training to officers of the Department to enable them to carry out this task.
Not accept.

The Government does not believe it would be useful to devote the substantial resources necessary to reinstate the annual human rights reports from Australia's diplomatic posts. Posts regularly report on aspects of human rights practice in host countries either when specifically tasked or in more general reporting. Human rights is a high priority subject for reporting and assessment from posts. Annual human rights reports from posts can only duplicate detailed reviews done by other agencies to which the Government has access, particularly such diverse sources as the US State Department's annual publication "Country Reports on Human Rights Practices" and reports from organisations such as Amnesty International and Asia Watch.

Many Australian diplomatic posts are also already heavily engaged in responding to requests from Canberra for information on individual cases forwarded to the Department from the Parliamentary Amnesty International group, other non-government organisations and members of the public.
Recommendation 8 The Committee recommends that the Government upgrade the resources formally allocated to Human Rights for the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade.
Not accept.

The Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade devotes substantial resources to the advancement of Australia's human rights policy and is able to satisfactorily meet the various demands faced on it. The Human Rights section of the Department of Foreign Affairs comprises a Director (Senior Officer Grade B), three Executive officers (Senior Officer Grade C Level), and three other officers. This is one of the largest sections in the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade. In addition the Human Rights and Social Unit in the Department's legal office comprises three officers who are also engaged to varying degrees on international legal aspects of the Government's human rights policy.

Human rights policy is also dealt with extensively in Geographic Divisions within the Department. Officers responsible for bilateral relations in a particular State may spend substantial time on human rights issues depending on the degree of concern the Government has with human rights practices in that State.
Recommendation 9 The Committee recommends that, in relation to Australia's Human Rights Treaty obligations:
The Government conduct a review of interdepartmental cooperation;
The Departments develop strategies for greater coordination of the implementation and monitoring of international human rights treaties; and
Resources be allocated for more effective community consultation and education.
Agree in part.
The Government will institute a review of interdepartmental cooperation aimed at furthering strategies for greater cooperation in the implementation and monitoring of human rights treaties.

In the writing of reports for the UN treaty bodies, the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade has established an interdepartmental committee to look at better coordination of report writing across the portfolios. Interdepartmental cooperation in report writing under the international treaties is essential as the reports prepared by the different Departments have significant areas of overlap. One option which is under consideration by the Attorney-General's Department is the establishment of a central reporting unit to further rationalise the production of reports. Such a unit would help ensure that reports are timely, of a high quality and that issues are presented to the international community in a consistent way.

It should be noted that on human rights issues generally, the broad function of consulting with community groups is being performed by the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission (HREOC). The Commission has a statutory function to promote the understanding, acceptance and public discussion of human rights in Australia.
The JCFADT's Report, and the Government's response to it reflect the leading role the Government has taken on international human rights issues.
In conclusion let me once again congratulate the JCFADT on their report.

Recommendation 10 While the Committee acknowledges that the Department of Defence is rather advanced than other departments in the matter of human rights training, nevertheless, it recommends that the Department review its human rights training with a view to upgrading and expanding it at the non-commissioned officer level and within defence cooperation programs.
Agree.

The Department of Defence will review the current training provided as recommended, with a view to examining possible enhancements of the training program detailed in the Defence response to the Committee's Question on Notice no.6 of 14 May 1992.

Recommendation 11 The Committee notes the intention of the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade to institute a comprehensive course on human rights for its senior officers and looks forward to future reports from the Department on the progress of the application of these courses.

The Committee further recommends that other departments affected by obligations under international treaties on human rights offer suitable and comprehensive training to officers likely to have to deal with such matters.
Agree.

The Department is currently completing a Human Rights Manual, which will form the basis for a comprehensive course on human rights. The course will consist of 2-3 days of seminars and workshops and will be conducted by officers from DFAT and AIDAB with a background in human rights, academic experts and representatives from non-government organisations. It will be specifically targeted at DFAT officers, including those proceeding on posting overseas, officers in Canberra who handle human rights as part of their responsibilities and other officers on the basis of interest, as well as AIDAB officers to enable them to better factor human rights considerations into the aid program. The course would also be available for other Departments/Agencies with particular interests in the issues.

The Attorney-General's Department already provides a small number of training courses on human rights issues, for example to the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs. The Attorney-General's Department welcomes the opportunity to cooperate with the proposed course.

The Australian Federal Police (AFP) does not have courses specifically designed to cover international human rights treaties although it does have a number of current training courses which include components covering cross-cultural communications exercises and awareness of human rights (recruit training courses are an example). The AFP would be invited to attend human rights training courses provided by DFAT.

The Prime Minister has recently announced that the Government will fund a gender awareness programme to be made available to members of the Australian judiciary. The program is being developed by the Australian Institute of Judicial Administration which has established a committee chaired by Justice Deidre O'Connor.

Most judges and judicial officers work for State and Territory Courts. The Attorney-General's Department is acting as a catalyst in developing pilot programs to encourage a more comprehensive understanding of Aboriginal culture among people who work in all Australian courts. This programme is in response to the Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody, Recommendation 96, and is being conducted in consultation with the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission and the Australian Institute of Judicial Administration.

Recommendation 12 The Committee recommends that the Australian International Development Assistance Bureau (AIDAB) explore ways to include in their programs aid projects which extend or improve human rights practice in the recipient country.
Agree.

AIDAB is exploring ways of including in aid programs projects which extend or improve human rights practice in recipient countries. In the Ministerial Policy Paper and Third Annual Report to Parliament on Australia's Overseas Development Cooperation Program (November 1992), the Government noted that AIDAB was:
cataloguing activities where it is already promoting human rights and good governance;
in consultation with DFAT, designing a human rights training course for staff from both organisations; and

assisting in the production of an Australian Government Human Rights Manual which sets out the international legal context and guidelines on the kinds of programs which could assist specific human rights objectives (see reference in Comment on Recommendation 12 to DFAT's Human Rights Manual).

Increasing attention is being given to the human rights implications of proposed new projects and to specific human rights oriented activities in the aid program. The issues of human rights and good governance are also being given much greater attention in a variety of international fora. In particular, the Development Assistance Committee (DAC) of the OECD is undertaking work to identify the types of assistance, representations and other actions which can be used to try to improve the observance of human rights. AIDAB is monitoring this work closely to identify suitable approaches which could be applied in the aid program.

Recommendation 13 The Committee recommends that the Human Rights Fund be classified as Official Development Assistance (ODA) and that significant funds from the ODA budget be made available to projects in support of the development of human rights, especially to countries in this region.
Agree in part.

To be classified as ODA an activity must, among other things, have the promotion of the economic development and welfare of scheduled developing countries as its main objective. The Human Rights Fund administered by the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade is directed towards promoting and protecting human rights observance and does not always fit neatly into this category. The Department will advise AIDAB of the expenditure under this Fund so that individual activities which do meet the criteria for ODA are reported as such.

As stated in the response to recommendation 12, AIDAB is actively investigating several avenues for increasing its efforts to support the development of human rights, particularly in the countries of our immediate region.
Recommendation 14 The Committee recommends that a direct connection be established between military exports and human rights violations so that:
guarantees are sought from recipient countries that any military equipment they receive will not be used against their own civilian populations;
where possible, training in the international standards of human rights is provided as part of defence cooperation training; and
it is made clear to the recipient country that military exports will be cut where persistent and flagrant abuses of human rights occur.
Response
Agree in part.

Schedule 13 of the Customs (Prohibited Exports) Regulations, Section Two requires applications to export defence and defence-related goods to be considered in terms of Australia's stated policy not to permit the export of military or related goods to governments that seriously violate their citizens' rights unless there is no reasonable risk that the goods might be used against those citizens.

The Government does not seek guarantees from recipient countries that any military equipment they receive will not be used against their own civilian population. Rather, the Government makes its own assessment, based on a number of criteria:
the use to which the goods are likely to be put is an essential factor in any decision to allow an export to a destination about which there are human rights concerns;
information on likely use is required from the applicant for any export, and valid end-use certificates are required by the Department of Defence before a permit or licence is issued; and
military exports would not be permitted to countries where persistent and flagrant abuses of human rights occur.

The Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade has pursued a strategy of encouraging human rights training in countries where there are human rights concerns. In particular the Department has funded a series of seminars equipping Philippines military and police trainers with skills and knowledge to teach human rights principles. Similar training has been included in courses offered under the Defence Cooperation Program with the PNG Defence Forces.

Recommendation 15 The Committee recommends that the Government examine the possibility of developing a regional human nights forum, with a view to drafting a human rights charter appropriate to this region.
Agree.
Comment

Australia has welcomed recent developments in a number of regional countries towards establishing national human rights institutions. We are currently examining ways of providing assistance in the establishment and operation of human rights machinery to several countries which have requested it, through our own national institution, the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission.
Where they exist, regional arrangements complement both United Nations machinery and national institutions. They also offer valuable opportunities for sharing national experience.
However, although Europe, the Americas and Africa have regional human rights mechanisms, there is no such body in the Asia-Pacific region.

Recent developments internationally towards the establishment of national institutions, and growing cooperation among those institutions, may foreshadow the establishment of a regional or sub-regional human rights body. We were encouraged by the concluding remarks made by Chairman Wiryono (Director-General for Political Affairs, Indonesian Foreign Ministry—DEPLU) to the Second Asia-Pacific Workshop on Human Rights, convened in Jakarta in January 1993 under the auspices of the United Nations and the Indonesian Government, and attended by thirty government delegations representing almost every nation in the Asian region. The Chairman's concluding remarks endorsed a step by step strategy to establish machinery for the promotion and protection of human rights in the region.

The forthcoming World Conference on Human Rights, to be held in Vienna 14-25 June, provides an opportunity to explore practical ideas for promoting and strengthening national institutions, and submitting recommendations regarding the role of national and regional organisations in the promotion and protection of human rights. The regional preparatory meeting for Asia, held in Bangkok 29 March—2 April, adopted the "Bangkok Declaration", which, inter alia, "reiterated the need to explore the possibilities of establishing regional arrangements for the promotion and protection of human rights in Asia".

PARA.EMPHASIS: Indonesia The Committee urges the Australian Government to support actively a new UN initiative to begin consultations with all the parties to the conflicts in East Timor, Irian Jaya and Aceh with a view to negotiating a settlement' and to draw to the attention of the Indonesian Government the gross injustice of the application of the Anti-Subversion Law to those involved in peaceful protest.

SPEECH.PARA: Agree in part.
There is no evidence of effective interest at the UN General Assembly in raising the conflicts in Aceh, Irian Jaya and East Timor
Aceh has never been under consideration by the UN,
Irian Jaya has, since the UN's acceptance of the 1969 Act of Free Choice, not been listed on the UN Agenda;

as far as East Timor is concerned, there has been no UN Security Council action on the matter since Indonesia's incorporation of East Timor in 1976 and no General Assembly resolution on the subject since 1982. The failure by Portugal and its supporters to introduce a General Assembly resolution since that date then suggests that international opposition to Indonesia's integration of East Timor has fallen to the level where any such resolution today would fail. The Australian Government supports the efforts of the UN Secretary-General to assist Indonesia and Portugal to reconcile their differences over East Timor, through talks under his auspices. The Government believes it is for these parties to determine the terms of and parties to the talks.

The Australian Government actively encourages the Indonesian Government to improve human rights observance in these three provinces, and to undertake development activities which benefit those peoples and which take account of their cultural sensitivities.

The Australian Government has repeatedly raised with the Indonesian Government its concerns over the application of the Anti-Subversion Law, conveying its belief that persons should not be punished for engaging in non-violent political activity. Most recently, Senator Evans raised these concerns with Indonesia's Foreign Minister Alatas, during his visit to Jakarta in November 1992.

Bougainville The Committee urges the Australian Government to encourage Papua New Guinea to make an urgent and full investigation of all the claims of human rights abuses on Bougainville. Furthermore, the Committee reiterates the recommendations made on this issue in the December 1991 Report of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade, Australia's Relations with Papua New Guinea.
Agree in part.

While Australia enjoys a very close relationship with Papua New Guinea, the Australian Government has made it clear that this does not exempt Papua New Guinea from Australia's universal human rights policy. Accordingly, the Government has taken every opportunity to raise, at the highest level, allegations of human rights abuse in Papua New Guinea, including on Bougainville. Where these allegations have been specific in time and place and able to be checked, Australian Ministers have drawn them to the attention of the PNG Government, asking that they be investigated and that those involved be disciplined. The Australian Government was encouraged by the previous PNG Government's announcement that it intended to establish a coronial inquiry into death on Bougainville and by the Wingti Government's acceptance of a proposal for a European Community/Africa, Caribbean and Pacific Joint Assembly (EC/ACP) fact-finding mission to visit the Province.

With regard to the recommendations on Bougainville made by the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade in its December 1991 report, "Australia's Relations with Papua New Guinea", the Australian Government maintains its position that Bougainville is an internal problem for the PNG Government. lt can only be solved through a political settlement reached by Papua New Guineans themselves.

The Australian Government has recognised the importance of keeping open channels of humanitarian assistance to Bougainville. The Australian Government has urged the PNG Government to do all it can to restore services on Bougainville, including by improving access for NGOs and the Red Cross. Since May 1991, and in addition to our assistance to Papua New Guinea through budget support, the Australian Government has provided $620,000 in humanitarian aid to Bougainville. This has included drugs, gardening tools, shelter material and transport assistance. The Australian Government is willing to examine sympathetically further requests to help meet the needs of Bougainvilleans, including aid to rehabilitate areas of the Province where conditions have stabilised.

The equipment and material provided by Australia to Papua New Guinea under the Defence Cooperation Program is to help the PNG Defence Force (PNGDF) carry out its nation-wide tasks, rather than for any specific situation, such as Bougainville. Apart from the provision of the Iroquois helicopters, for which conditions of use were agreed between the two Governments, it is up to Papua New Guinea, as an independent and sovereign country, to decide where and how its defence assets are deployed to carry out national security functions. Papua New Guinea understands that Australia expects the equipment we have supplied to be used in a way which is consistent with the purposes for which it was given.

In the case of the Iroquois helicopters used in operations on Bougainville, clear conditions of use apply. These provide for the helicopters to be used for troop transportation, for patrolling and surveillance activities, and for medical evacuation purposes, and allow for defensive fire from the helicopters for self-protection. We have sought, and received, assurances from the PNG Government that these conditions are being adhered to.

Australia and Papua New Guinea continue to explore ways in which Australian aid can be used to enhance the protection of human rights in Papua New Guinea. For example, components designed to strengthen PNGDF soldiers' awareness of humanitarian law and to provide guidance concerning the proper treatment of civilians during military operations have been included in military training programs funded under the Defence Cooperation program.

Sri Lanka The Committee suggests that the Government consider the recommendations made by the Canadian Human Rights Mission to Sri Lanka. In particular, the Committee urges the Australian Government to join with the Canadian government to seek action from the multinational agencies of the UN and/or the Commonwealth in the form of an international observer team to aid in the establishment of negotiations, to monitor the situation in the northern provinces of Sri Lanka, to supervise the distribution of humanitarian aid, and to verify a complete arms embargo to Sri Lanka.
Agree in part.
The Australian High Commission in Colombo has maintained a high-level dialogue with the Sri Lankan Government on its human rights performance. Sri Lanka has addressed the issue of

human rights abuses and reduced human rights violations. It continues to cooperate with international human rights organisations such as the ICRC, the UNHCR and Amnesty International. The Australian High Commission in Colombo continues to monitor closely the human rights situation and is tasked to draw to the attention of the Sri Lankan Government areas of continuing concern.
While the recent assassinations of the President and the Opposition Leader threaten a renewal of the cycle of violence, the new President has stated a continuing commitment to human rights reforms.

Human rights abuses in Sri Lanka are not the sole responsibility of any one party to the conflict. We condemn the massacres of civilians and other atrocities by all groups, in particular, the Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam (LTTE). We deplore the LTTE's continued failure to accommodate human rights scrutiny.

There is no doubt that sustained pressure by the international community has been an important factor in the improved performance of the Sri Lankan Government on human rights. Australia coordinates its action on human rights in Sri Lanka with that of other concerned governments, including Canada. The Australian Government has continued to stress that Australia stands ready to assist in any worthwhile peace initiative, including in approaching the Commonwealth about a possible good offices role. The Australian initiative has been noted by the Sri Lankan Government and remains on the table.

On the recommendation that the international observer team monitor the situation in the northern provinces of Sri Lanka and supervise the distribution of humanitarian aid, a number of independent international organisations such as the International Committee of the Red Cross and the United Nations High Commission for Refugees consistently maintain an effective presence in the north and east of Sri Lanka. These organisations have served a valuable role in monitoring the conflict in northern and eastern Sri Lanka, as well as being responsible for the distribution of aid in these areas.
There is no Security Council resolution imposing a complete arms embargo on Sri Lanka. The Security Council is most unlikely to impose such an embargo.

Bilaterally, however, Australia is already taking action in this regard. As noted above, in relation to other countries, the Australian Government has strict guidelines regulating the export of defence related goods; in the case of Sri Lanka, defence-related exports are considered on a case by case basis and are not approved if there is any risk that they will be used in human rights violations.

The Committee accepts the proposition that unilateral action on sanctions is ineffective. However, it believes that greater efforts in the multilateral agencies are called for. There are a range of possibilities for Australian action that could include:

sponsoring a resolution in the United Nations General Assembly to have Burma's seat declared vacant on the grounds that the regime is an illegal one both under Burmese and international law and does not have a mandate of the people;
calling for Burma's Least Developed Country (LDC) Status to be withdrawn on the grounds that the regime has spent billions on arms and little on improving the lot of its people;
asking the United Nations General Assembly to instruct the United Nations Development Program and all allied UN agencies immediately to cease all operations in Burma;
calling for a United Nations trade and arms embargo against Burma;

seeking assurances from UNHCR and all countries of First Asylum that no further refoulement of Burmese refugees will take place and that adequate care be accorded Burmese refugees and displaced persons until they can return to Burma safely;
establishing a special Burmese refugee program under the special humanitarian program; and
closing the Austrade office in Rangoon until power is handed to the democratically elected government.
Agree in part.
Comment

Australian Government policy is to recognise States, not governments. This policy has been in place since January 1988 and is consistent with the practice of other major western countries. Australia recognises the State of Burma, and thus supports its right to a seat at the United Nations. This does not in any way imply Australian Government approval of the policies of the Burmese State Law and Order Restoration Council (SLORC) regime or the manner by which it acquired and has retained power.

Least Developed Country (LDC) status is granted by the United Nations on the basis of whether a country meets a reasonable balance of economic criteria as specified by the United Nations, notably a GDP of US$423 per capita or less in 1989 prices and a share of manufacturing in GDP of 10 per cent or less. Burma meets these and other economic criteria for LDC status: GDP per capita has remained at approximately US$200 for the last several years, and manufacturing accounted for 9 per cent of GDP in 1990/91.

There is no precedent for the withdrawal by the UN of a country's LDC status on political or human rights grounds, or for reasons of government policies on military expenditure. It is highly unlikely that a proposal to withdraw Burma's LDC status would succeed in the United Nations. It would be opposed by most, if not all, developing countries, particularly because of the precedent which withdrawal of LDC status would set.

Since 1988, the Australian Government has banned the provision of bilateral development assistance to Burma. The Australian Government has not sought to stop UN assistance to Burma but has supported moves to re-direct UN assistance, specifically that provided by the UN Development Program (UNDP), away from longer-term development objectives in favour of support for humanitarian activities which are designed to help the Burmese people at the "grass roots" level.

Most UN assistance to Burma is now directed toward humanitarian, rather than long-term development objectives. UN expenditure in Burma over the three year period 1993-95 is expected to be US$49.98 million (compared with US$73.4 million for 1988 alone). Of that amount, approximately 71 per cent or US$35.5 million is to be expended by UNDP and UNICEF whose programs are predominantly humanitarian in character.

Almost all of UNDP's infrastructure projects have been stopped or significantly curtailed since the decision by the 39th UNDP Governing Council in May 1992 (supported by Australia) that UNDP funds assigned to Burma be de-committed, and that the released funds be used to implement projects likely to have greater impact at the "grass roots" level, particularly in respect of minority groups, indigenous peoples and the poor. Consequently the bulk of UNDP's US$20.5 million allocation for 1993-95 has been earmarked for poverty alleviation activities, HIV/AIDS projects, primary health care and community-level education.
The US$15 million allocated to Burma by UNICEF for 1993-95 is to be disbursed on child health care (particularly immunisation) programs and other small scale, village-based projects.

The UN Drug Control Program (UNDCP) has a projected expenditure in Burma of US$6.9 million for 1993-95 for narcotics supply-demand reduction, law enforcement and regional programs (14 per cent of total UN expenditure in Burma). Given that most of the illegal drugs which reach Australia originate in South East Asia's "Golden Triangle" area which includes parts of Burma, the Australian Government supports the work being undertaken by UNDCP in Burma and neighbouring regional countries to reduce the production of and trafficking in illegal narcotics. UNDCP is taking a rigorous approach to working with the Burmese Government on narcotics control. No UNDCP funds are provided to the Burmese Government and firm conditions regarding the provision of assistance have been established.

The remaining 15 per cent of UN funds for the period 1993-95 (or US$7.4 million) is to be disbursed by a range of UN specialised agencies, many of which are in the process of winding down their involvement in infrastructure projects.

Australia has implemented a unilateral embargo on trade with Burma in defence related goods. We have also urged other countries known to export arms to Burma, particularly China, to discontinue such exports. The Burmese Government's recent announcements concerning political change and releases of political prisoners have forestalled international pressure for UN trade and arms embargoes. There is currently no prospect of such proposals gaining enough support to be effective. Burma's major trading partners in the region, particularly China, are unlikely to support such measures.

Australia supported UNHCR in its efforts to gain access to Burmese refugee camps in Bangladesh, and continues to support the establishment of a UNHCR presence in Burma to monitor the repatriation process. UNHCR has advised the Government that it is currently satisfied with the extent of its access to Burmese refugee camps in Bangladesh. While there were reports of some involuntary repatriations of Burmese refugees from Bangladesh in late 1991, UNHCR has indicated that subsequent repatriations from Bangladesh have been made on a voluntary basis.

The Australian Government has on a number of occasions sought and obtained assurances from the Thai Government that there will be no forcible deportations from Thailand of Burmese political dissidents. In fact, although most Burmese students and dissidents in Thailand are technically illegal entrants, there have been no recent incidents of forcible return of Burmese students and dissidents, or of people from ethnic minorities in Burma seeking refuge along the border with Thailand. The Government of Thailand has sought to respond to international concern by establishing a safe area for Burmese students, but very few students have entered the area to date. The Australian Embassy in Bangkok is in regular contact with the Thai Government and UNHCR regarding the situation of Burmese groups and individuals in Thailand.

The establishment of a Special Assistance Category (SAC) for Burma was approved in August 1992. The SAC allows for the entry of up to 250 Burmese into Australia as permanent residents during the 1992/93 program year. The SAC will remain open at least until the 250 places are filled. In order to qualify applicants must be Burmese citizens who are resident in Burma and who have been subject to "substantial discrimination" in their home country. The Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs is currently drafting an additional regulation expanding the SAC to allow for the entry of 50 Burmese from Thailand.

In addition, the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs agreed in November 1992 to the drafting of a regulation to allow for the entry into Australia of up to 10 displaced Burmese students living in Thailand. The 10 Burmese students will be selected for study in Australia under an AIDAB-funded scholarship program. The Australian Embassy in Bangkok has received approximately 250 applications for #he scholarships, and it is expected that the successful students will commence their studies in June 1993.

The Austrade Office in Rangoon does not actively promote Australian trade with Burma but responds to enquiries from Australian companies. Closure of the Austrade office, which is staffed by two locally engaged Burmese, would be a logical step if implemented in the context of internationally coordinated trade sanctions. However, as a symbolic gesture, independent of such wider measures, closure of the office would have little or no impact on the SLORC.

Vietnam. The Committee would hope, in the course of Australia's efforts to aid the reintegration of Vietnam into the regional and broader international community and especially into the international financial institutions such as the World Bank and the IMF, that the Australian Government will encourage the Government of Vietnam to comply with its international obligations under the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights to which it is a party. In particular, that the Australian Government should raise with the Vietnamese Government the cases of those detainees, religious and political, who are prisoners of conscience.
Agree.
The Government engages the Vietnamese authorities on human rights issues in a number of ways and at several levels.

Firstly, it has become standard practice for Australian Ministers visiting Hanoi to raise human rights concerns—general and specific—at senior levels of the Vietnamese Government. Senator Evans also invariably raises our concerns, and specific detainee cases, at any of his meetings with his Vietnamese counterpart.

Concerns about specific cases are normally first raised at officials level, with the emphasis being on detainees with family or other connections to Australia, the rationale being that this provides the Government with a useful locus standi. The Government's practice of raising individual cases in this way has played an important, and in at least one case, a critical, part in securing the release of detainees.

Government representations about individual cases are not restricted, however, to cases with an Australian nexus. In their respective meetings with the Vietnamese Foreign Minister in Manila and Hanoi in 1992, Senator Evans and Mr Kerin handed over lists of individual human rights cases of concern that included Buddhist monks and political detainees without any direct connection to Australia.
The Government will continue to take full advantage of its maturing relationship with the Government of Vietnam to urge respect for internationally accepted human rights norms in Vietnam.

Philippines The submission [from the Philippines Christian Support Group] calls upon the Australian Government to condemn these abuses and in particular to link Australian aid to groups which support human rights, to cease arms sales to the Philippines and to investigate exploitative practices by Australians in the Philippines. The submission noted two possible areas of exploitation: the exploitation of labour through low wages and poor conditions and the exploitation of women and children in the sex trade. The Committee urges the Australian Government to examine these recommendations.
Agree in part.

Since 1986 the Philippines Government has taken a number of concrete steps towards better protecting human rights in the Philippines. This includes establishing the Philippines Commission on Human Rights (a separate Constitutional body) and continuing dialogue between the Philippines Government and non-governmental organisations interested in human rights issues. The 1987 Constitution contains substantial guarantees of fundamental civil and political rights, and laws passed in June 1991 mean that all cases involving human rights violations by military personnel are now prosecuted in civilian courts. These developments have contributed to a declining trend in human rights violations in the Philippines with the number of new violations reported by the Philippines Commission on Human Rights (CHR) falling from 1,795 cases in 1988 to 1,142 cases in 1991, a 36 per cent decline.

The Australian Government has made clear that it has looked to the Administration of President Fidel Ramos to sustain the gains made by the Aquino Administration in the area of human rights. In this regard it is encouraging that President Ramos has pursued broad policies of national reconciliation, including legalising the Communist Party of the Philippines, concluding a cease-fire agreement with the ultra-rightists and steps towards the commencement of dialogue with Muslim separatist groups. The process of national reconciliation has made headway in generally reducing the intensity of the insurgency. However the military—both the Armed Forces of the Philippines (AFP) and the Philippine National Police (PNP)—continue to prosecute counter-insurgency operations in various parts of the country, including in Mindanao against Muslim rebels, and the several insurgent groups remain active. To help stem the continuing, but declining, incidence of human rights violations the Australian Government has funded human rights courses for Philippine military and police trainers. To complement the training program, the Australian Government funded the International Committee of the Red Cross to supply human rights texts to Philippine military and police schools, individual units and military and police trainers.

Despite the downward trend in human rights violations in the Philippines, elements of the security forces continue to commit human rights abuses (albeit fewer) in the course of the counter-insurgency, as do insurgent forces. Principal human rights abuse by government forces against individuals include extrajudicial killings (324 cases in 1992), arbitrary arrest (142 cases), disappearances (29 cases) and torture (10 cases). Only a very small proportion of suspects in human rights abuses are punished. Since 1986 the Philippines Commission on Human Rights recorded 7,789 military and police personnel as suspects in human rights cases (949 in 1992), yet only 53 military and police personnel have been convicted of human rights abuses between 1986 and mid-1992.

Australia is a strong supporter of the United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child, and seeks to convey this view to foreign governments. Australia ratified the Convention on 17 December 1991. The Philippines acceded to the Convention on 26 January 1990. Articles 19 and 34 of the Convention expressly provide that States Parties undertake to protect children from all forms of sexual exploitation and abuse, including through the adoption of appropriate domestic and international measures.

The Australian Government takes very seriously the issue of child sexual exploitation and paedophile activities. The Australian Federal Police (AFP) is presently monitoring the nature and extent of paedophile activity overseas and AFP liaison officers in Manila are working together with local law enforcement agencies. The Attorney-General's Department is examining possible legislative options to tighten controls over paedophile activity by Australian nationals overseas.

Australia and the Philippines are both active members of the International Labour Organisation, the paramount concern of which is social justice and the promotion and protection of the human rights and fundamental concerns of labour.

The Philippine Labour Code regulates labour practices, including prescribing specific employment conditions for women, a minimum employment age of fifteen, and minimum wages. Enforcement of these regulations is the responsibility of the Department of Labour and Employment. The right to organise and bargain collectively is guaranteed in the Constitution and there are over 5,000 independent trade unions.

While the Australian Government has no jurisdiction to investigate labour practices in the Philippines, the Government will draw the attention of the Philippines Government to cases of labour practice violation where specific information is available.

China The witnesses [from the Welfare Committee for Chinese Students] urged the Australian Government, and this Committee endorses their request, to investigate these allegations and to raise the issues with the relevant government department in China and to draw the matters to the attention of the international community.
Agree.

The second Australian Human Rights Delegation investigated these allegations and raised these issues with the relevant Chinese authorities in November 1992. That report will be tabled in the Parliament during the current session. The wide distribution of the delegation's report will draw to the attention of the international community Australia's concerns about the human rights situation in China. The Government will pursue this further when, as is hoped, a reciprocal delegation visits Australia this year.
The Government continues to make representations to the Chinese authorities where evidence exists of serious violations of human rights.
Tibet This Committee believes that the Australian Government should continue to press the Chinese Government:

to respect the human rights of the Tibetan people, particularly those rights set out in the Universal Declaration of Human Rights which China has signed and the International Convention for the Elimination of Racial Discrimination and the International Convention Against Torture and Other Cruel, Inhuman or Degrading Treatment or Punishment to which China is a party; and
to enter into earnest negotiations, without preconditions, with the Dalai Lama and his representatives with a view to reducing the tension in Tibet.
Agree.

The Minister for Foreign Affairs and senior officers of the Embassy have made our concerns on human rights violations in Tibet known to the Chinese on a number of occasions. The Government remains most concerned about the repression of religious freedom, cultural identity and freedom of expression in Tibet. At the 48th Session of the UN Commission on Human Rights (CHR48) in 1992 Australia co-sponsored a draft resolution which expressed continuing concern over the human rights situation in China, specifically including Tibet.

The Government continues to believe there would be considerable value in representatives of the PRC Government and the Dalai Lama meeting, without excessively restrictive preconditions, to discuss the situation in Tibet, with a view to resolving the tensions there. The Government has put this view to the Chinese authorities.

Both the Prime Minister and Senator Evans met the Dalai Lama when he visited in May 1992. The Government has also agreed to the establishment of a Tibet Information Office staffed by a representative from Dharamsala. The Government also hopes to receive a delegation from Tibet this year.
The Government is also concerned about reports of environmental damage occurring in Tibet, including the disposal of nuclear waste.
Syrian Jews The Committee urges the Australian Government to continue to make representations on behalf of the Syrian Jews.
Agree.

Australia welcomed Syria's lifting, in April last year, of discriminatory restrictions on travel abroad by Syrian Jews. We had for many years been concerned that the Syrian Jewish community was subject to significant human rights restrictions, particularly a ban on whole families emigrating. Prior to the easing of restrictions, the Australian Government made direct representations to the Syrian Government through our Embassy in Damascus on the circumstances of members of the Jewish community. These issues were also raised at Ministerial level in 1984 and 1988, and by Senator Evans during his visit to Syria last year.

In October last year, the Government became concerned at reports that the issue of exit visas to Syrian Jews had ceased. Our Embassy in Damascus made enquiries about the cessation and was informed that the non-issue of exit visas was the result of administrative delays and did not reflect a change in the Syrian Government's policy about the emigration of Syrian Jews.

Australia is of course not accepting the reported explanation of the Syrian Government as the end of the matter, and, through our Damascus Embassy, we are keeping a close watch on the situation. Our Embassy recently reported that a small number of exit visas are being issued, which would confirm the Syrian Government's explanation of a slow-down rather than a cessation. Should further evidence arise that the delays are continuing, the Government will consider making further representations to the Syrian Government to urge that any Syrian Jew who has been denied an exit visa be issued with one without further delay.

Salman Rushdie It seems to the Committee that Salman Rushdie deserves the same international outcry and international pressure to be brought to bear on the regime that has imposed the death sentence on him as was devoted to the other hostages in the Middle East. Representation might be made to the UN and to the British Government to encourage it to work to obtain Rushdie's release.
Agree in part.

Senator Evans raised the Rushdie case with the Iranian Foreign Minister Dr Velayati and with other senior Iranians during his visit to Tehran in May 1992, and again on 11 May 1993 during a visit to Australia by the Deputy Foreign Minister of Iran, Mr Sarmardi. Senator Evans made clear our belief that the Rushdie fatwa will remain a serious obstacle to closer relations with Iran—a point which the US, EC and Canada have been emphasising with increasing strength in recent months.

Australia co-sponsored the Resolution on Iran adopted on 10 March 1993 at the Commission on Human Rights in Geneva (CHR49). The Resolution expressed grave concern at "continuing threats to the life of a citizen of another state", which, in multilateral terms, constituted an unmistakable condemnation of the fatwa against Rushdie. Western Governments may now seek to include references to this matter, either explicit or implicit, in future Resolutions in the General Assembly and possibly in other UN bodies. Australia would support efforts in this direction.

Sudan The Committee believes that the situation in the Sudan is an issue which must be raised again in the General Assembly and recommends that course to the Australian Government. Australia signed the anti-slavery conventions as the first of the international conventions it signed in 1926. In view of this, the Committee recommends that the Australian Government take extra measures in the United Nations to draw to the attention of the international community the revival of slavery as a result of the civil war.
Agree.

Australia co-sponsored a strong resolution on the Sudan at CHR49. The resolution called on all parties to cooperate in order to ensure full respect for human rights in the Sudan, and provided for the appointment of a Special Rapporteur who will investigate and report to the United Nations General Assembly (UNGA) at its forty-eighth session and to the Commission on Human Rights at its fiftieth session on the human rights situation in the Sudan. Earlier, Australia had supported successful action to move debate on the human rights situation in the Sudan from the closed to the open sessions of the Commission. This has had the effect of giving greater exposure to the human rights and humanitarian crisis in the Sudan and places further international pressure on the government of Sudan to improve its human rights record.
The Government will continue to strongly pursue this matter in the UNGA and at CHR50.
Guatemala This Committee urges the Australian Government to support further action in the United Nations which would seek an improvement in the human rights record in Guatemala.
Agree.

The Australian Government is deeply concerned by continuing abuses of human rights in Guatemala, and the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade regularly makes representations to the Guatemalan Government on behalf of victims of abuse. Grounds on which representations are made include detention, extrajudicial execution, death threats and disappearance.

In January 1993 Guatemala's Ombudsman for Human Rights delivered his report to Congress, which was largely funded by our Direct Assistance Program (DAP). DAP funds were also committed to a human rights seminar in Guatemala, organised by the Commission for Human Rights in Guatemala and the Council of Ethnic Communities. In view of the continuing seriousness of the human rights situation in Guatemala we supported a consensus resolution at CHR49 that proposed moving consideration of this country to Item 12 (Country Situations) from Item 19 (Advisory Services in the field of human rights), a move which allows for greater UN scrutiny of the human rights situation in Guatemala.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the 42nd report of the Committee of Privileges, entitled Possible adverse treatment of a witness before the corporations and securities committee, together with the transcript of evidence and a volume of documents received since the public hearings.

SPEECH.PARA: On 12 October 1992 the following matters were referred to the committee on the motion of Senator Spindler:
Having regard to the report of the Joint Committee on Corporations and Securities entitled Privilege—Mr James Gaffey, presented to the Senate on 14 September 1992:

TAB.TAB: (a)the circumstances of the laying of charges under the Public Service Act against Mr Gaffey, an officer of the Australian Securities Commission;
(b)whether any penalty or injury was inflicted on Mr Gaffey in consequence of his giving evidence to the Joint Committee on Corporations and Securities; and
(c)whether any contempt of Parliament was committed in respect of those matters.

SPEECH.PARA: As has become customary with the matters coming before the committee, the inquiry has been lengthy and detailed, encompassing the examination of a vast array of documents and a consideration of a plethora of submissions from both the person affected by the actions of the Australian Securities Commission and the Australian Securities Commission itself.

PARA.TAB: The committee conducted two public hearings and 24 private meetings to make findings which are the subject of a notice of motion I shall give shortly. One of the findings is that a contempt of the Senate has been committed. The reasons for all the findings are, of course, explained in detail in the report but I seek leave to incorporate the findings in Hansard immediately, to indicate the committee's views on the matters referred.
Leave granted.
The findings read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: 3.7The committee of Privileges finds as follows:

TAB.TAB: (a)That the Australian Securities Commission, as the body responsible for the actions of the two officers directly involved, and these officers, Mr Ronald Claude Trevethan, Regional Commissioner, and Ms Margot Diana Waters, Regional General Counsel, Victorian Regional Office, have taken action which constituted a contempt, in that the laying of charge F against Mr James Matthew Gaffey for having given evidence in a private capacity before the Parliamentary Joint Committee on Corporations and Securities which was "at variance to submissions made by the representatives of the Chairman of the Australian Securities Commission" could deter other witnesses from appearing before other committees. (paragraph 2.34)

(b)That the Australian Securities Commission, as the body responsible for the actions of the two officers directly involved in laying charge F, and these officers, Mr Ronald Claude Trevethan, Regional Commissioner, and Ms Margot Diana Waters, Regional General Counsel, Victorian Regional Office, intended to and did lay a charge against Mr James Matthew Gaffey for having given evidence in a private capacity before the Parliamentary Joint Committee on Corporations and Securities which was "at variance to submissions made by the representatives of the Chairman of the Australian Securities Commission"; and that the charge had the effect of penalising Mr Gaffey for having given evidence in a private capacity to that committee. (paragraph 2.35)

(c)That a contempt has been committed by the Australian Securities Commission, as the body responsible for the actions of the two officers in laying charge F, and these officers, Mr Ronald Claude Trevethan, Regional Commissioner, and Ms Margot Diana Waters, Regional General Counsel, Victorian Regional Office, in laying charge F. (paragraph 2.36)

TAB.EMPHASIS: 2.In respect of Charges A to E—

TAB.TAB: (a)That neither the Australian Securities Commission, as the body responsible for the actions of the two officers directly involved in the laying of these charges, nor these officers, Mr Ronald Claude Trevethan, Regional Commissioner, and Ms Margot Diana Waters, Regional General Counsel, Victorian Regional Office, laid charges A to E with the intention of penalising Mr James Matthew Gaffey on account of his giving evidence in a private capacity before the Parliamentary Joint Committee on Corporations and Securities which was "at variance to submissions made by the representatives of the Chairman of the Australian Securities Commission". Nor did the laying of these charges have such an effect. (paragraph 2.60)
(b)That, on the evidence, no contempt was involved in the laying of charges A to E. (paragraph 2.60)

TALK.START.PARA: —I mention that Senator Cooney has dissented from one element of the committee's findings.

PARA.TAB: The committee has also made a number of recommendations and observations which derive from its concerns about the protection of witnesses before parliamentary committees and the relationship of senior public servants and statutory officers with the Parliament. The committee points out in this regard that the present report is but the latest in a series of reports on matters referred as a result of the appearance before committees of witnesses who are public servants, whether they have appeared in a public or in a private capacity. The committee has therefore taken this opportunity to recommend to the Senate that a resolution be passed on this question. This forms one of the three recommendations, which I now seek the leave of the Senate to incorporate in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The recommendations read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: 3.8The committee recommends as follows:

PARA.TAB: 1.That the Senate endorse the findings in paragraph 3.7.

2.That, particularly in the light of the apologies offered to the Committee of Privileges and Mr James Gaffey by Mr Tony Hartnell, when Chairman of the Australian Securities Commission, Mr Alan Cameron, the current Chairman of the Australian Securities Commission, and by Mr Ronald Claude Trevethan, Regional Commissioner, and Ms Margot Diana Waters, Regional General Counsel, Victorian Regional Office, Australian Securities Commission, no penalty should be imposed by the Senate in respect of the identified contempts. (paragraph 2.62)
3.That the Senate resolve as follows:

TAB.TAB: That the Senate is of the opinion that all heads of departments and other agencies, statutory office holders and Senior Executive Service officers should be required, as part of their duties, to undertake study of the principles governing the operation of Parliament, and the accountability of their departments, agencies and authorities to the Houses of Parliament and their committees, with particular reference to the rights and responsibilities of, and protection afforded to, witnesses before parliamentary committees.
(Paragraph 3.6)

TALK.START.PARA: —Because of the effect of the findings, I am required under the privilege resolutions of the Senate to give notice of the action which the committee recommends that the Senate take in relation to this matter. Accordingly, I give notice that, on the next day of sitting that is not less than 7 days after the day on which this notice is given, the following motion will be moved on behalf of the Committee of Privileges:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate:
(a)endorse the findings of the Committee contained in paragraph 3.7 of the Report, as recommended in paragraph 3.8; and
(b)adopt the recommendations contained in paragraphs 3.8(2) and (3) of the Report.

SPEECH.PARA: I crave the indulgence of the Senate for just one more minute. The presentation of the 42nd report of the Committee of Privileges is my own swan song. It is a particularly appropriate one in view of the fact that the first report—the 11th—after I became the chair of the committee was presented at the very end of our last sitting in the provisional Parliament House. That is five years and 32 references ago.

PARA.TAB: Earlier this evening I paid tribute in general terms to my Senate colleagues and officers. I must take this last opportunity to emphasise the sterling service of Anne Lynch, the Deputy Clerk, whose skills have been invaluable to the committee members—themselves gifted and hard working, as the unremitting stream of references threaten to engulf us all. I venture to suggest that Anne's wisdom and efficiency, and that of the people who keep the paper flowing, have kept us relatively sane.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to take this opportunity of thanking Senator Pat Giles for her work as chairman of this committee and the way in which she has served the Senate, indeed all of Australia, at the cutting edge of protecting the civil rights of Australians, as well as the rights and privileges of senators in the good conduct of the Parliament. I am sure I speak on behalf of all members of the committee when I wish her well, as we did at a farewell dinner earlier this week, and, as I say, thank her and the other retiring members, Senator Lewis, Senator Durack and Senator Powell, who have served very capably on the committee. I join them in this statement of thanks, especially to Senator Giles, the Chairman.
