SPEECH.PARA: I wish to refer to the report from the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce that is mentioned in the report. The report refers to several significant amendments that were made to the customs tariffs in relation to the automotive industry, and in particular to the decision to impose a $12,000 duty on used cars.

PARA.TAB: This measure is in stark contrast to the current policy on tariffs. This is very clearly set out in the recently released independent parliamentary inquiry into tariffs and industry development report which received evidence from a number of car manufacturers including Mitsubishi and the Ford motor company. That report states very clearly that industries should be given the opportunity to be protected and developed and to increase their international competitiveness.

TALK.START.PARA: —Under standing order 168(2), I move:

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —It may well be that honourable senators are unclear on the significance of the issue upon which we are voting. We have had one concern with this matter, and this is a rather shrewd technique used by Senator Spindler and Senator Coulter late at night on the last night to seek to get this through without proper consideration.

PARA.TAB: Senator Spindler is seeking to table a large document that he has had prepared which he has entitled `Independent parliamentary inquiry into tariffs and industry development, final report, April 1993'. Our concern is that that title is misleading. Our concern is that people will be confused and believe that that is actually a report of a parliamentary inquiry not a report of an inquiry that an independent or one of a group of senators has undertaken for their own party political purposes and dressed up in terms of a parliamentary inquiry.

It is our concern that people will be confused by that title and that is the reason why we will vote against the tabling. If the report had been referred to as Senator Spindler's inquiry into the subject or the Australian Democrats inquiry into it, then we may well have had a different point of view. As it stands, we believe it is misleading and, therefore, we will not be able to vote in favour of this resolution.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have sought advice from the Clerk of the Senate on my view that the word `parliamentary' in this context is purely a descriptive term that denotes that the inquiry was carried out by parliamentarians, and the advice has confirmed my view. On all occasions when evidence was being taken or submissions sought, I informed the people interested in the inquiry that it did not originate from a resolution of the Senate and therefore no privilege was available.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Defence)

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that Senator Spindler approached the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Gareth Evans). He indicated that we would support the tabling of this document. We now face on this side the vexing question of whether we should give credence to the document beyond that which it should achieve. If the Government decided to oppose the tabling of this document, we would be breaking our word and we do not break our word.

PARA.TAB: Let me put on the record that this document is simply the views of a group of people; it is not the view of this Parliament and probably not the view of the majority of people in this Parliament. If by granting leave to table this document it is ever used as a device to get hundreds or even thousands of copies of the document printed and circulated free, then the Government would never give permission again. I ask Senator Spindler, if he is given leave by the Opposition, to give the Government the assurance that this is not a device to circulate the document.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I am happy to give that assurance to the Government. Whatever copies of the report are being printed are being done out of the Democrats' printing allowance.

—I rise to make a very brief remark on the proposed tabling of this document, although it may have been covered by my colleagues. I do not wish to deny Senator Spindler the opportunity to have an inquiry on any issue that is of particular interest to him. What I object to is the title of this document, which is `independent inquiry'. I believe the word `independent' is entirely misleading. I think it is a pity that Senator Spindler indulged in stunt politics on this occasion. It is a Democrat inquiry, not an independent inquiry. I think it is a pity that Senator Coulter and Senator Kernot agreed to the use of this title because I believe it is extremely misleading.

PARA.TAB: The reason I say that is that during the break after the election I heard an ABC news report on this document and the news bulletin was introduced with phraseology along the lines that this was an independent Senate inquiry chaired by Senator Spindler. It was no such thing. It is quite understandable that the ABC would have made such a mistake because of the way this document was marketed.

I think it would be a great pity if the Senate gave any standing to this document. If Senator Spindler had given it a title which was fair and honest, I would have no objection. But he did not do that. He indulged in stunt politics and is now asking us to give this document a special standing which, in my view, it does not deserve.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am extremely disappointed that the Democrats have set out to deliberately mislead the people of Australia regarding the status of this document. I am equally shocked that the Clerks have apparently given advice that the description `parliamentary inquiry' can be given to a document which is not an inquiry conducted by way of the usually Senate committee processes with which we are all familiar and with which the Democrats are very familiar.

PARA.TAB: I believe this gives undue weight to the report. I find it quite incredible that the words `parliamentary inquiry' can be attached to what is—

TALK.START.PARA: —`Independent', too.

—It may have some independent elements, I do not know. But it is not a parliamentary inquiry. I would ask Senator Spindler to save us a lot of embarrassment by agreeing to retitle the document. I am going to find it very hard to support the tabling of this document.

—I do not like to make statements from the chair but I think I must on this occasion because the Clerk has indicated to me that the advice was not quite as understood by Senator Tate. I believe the Clerk has asked whether Senator Spindler's advice could be incorporated in Hansard. Are you willing to do this, Senator Spindler?

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator Spindler

TALK.START.PARA: —I am willing to seek leave to incorporate the advice I have received.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The document read as follows—

INTERJECT.PARA: Office of the Clerk of the Senate
You have asked for advice on the point which was made in debate in the Senate on 25 May 1993 that your report and inquiry into tariffs should not have been described by the adjective "parliamentary".
The term "parliamentary" has no official or established meaning and its use is not covered by any rule of the Senate. It is used to refer to anything associated with Parliament.

I note your statements that you took steps to ensure that the public was aware that the inquiry was not established by the Senate and that its activities were not covered by parliamentary privilege. Given that you took those steps, I do not think that you could reasonably be accused of misrepresenting proceedings in the Senate within the terms of Privilege Resolution No. 6, paragraph (7).
The question of whether you should describe your inquiry as "parliamentary", therefore, is a matter of political debate and not one on which any procedural or legal opinion can be given.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not referring to any advice in the primary sense that the Clerk may have given; I am referring to the fact that Senator Spindler told the Senate a matter of moments ago that the Clerk had said that the title was in order and quite correct.
—I understand from the Clerk that that was not quite the advice that was given. That is why I asked Senator Spindler if he would mind incorporating the advice.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I spoke on this matter the other night when Senator Spindler sought leave to table the document. I said that I did not challenge his integrity or his attitude to the question of tariffs in conducting the inquiry and in preparing a report. I do not agree with much of it, but the bulk of it clearly sets out to follow the terms of reference that he set himself. But that is not the point of what we are discussing. I cannot find one word in this document that indicates that it is a report of an Australian Democrat committee. In that respect it differs markedly from a normal parliamentary report. Any parliamentary report that I have seen in the time that I have been a member of this chamber also indicates who were the people on the committee and lists their parties and affiliations. Nowhere does this document set out who were the members of the committee conducting the inquiry.

PARA.TAB: I turn to the matter of whether or not the Clerk said it was all right. I accept what the Clerk said, but I do not agree that the title on the front of the document, `Independent Parliamentary Inquiry into Tariffs and Industry Development', conveys to a person just looking at the document what the Clerk was talking about. Unfortunately, the Clerk here in the chamber cannot speak for himself, so I shall refer to the letter. On the face of it, to any person outside this building and to a number in it, that would be taken to mean that it is an independent parliamentary inquiry.

I accept that it is an Australian Democrat inquiry, and I am not suggesting that there is any bias in it at all; that is for the reader to determine. There is in the document a copy of a tabling statement of Senator Spindler's dated 22 April 1993, and the fourth paragraph says:

SPEECH.PARA: In the event the Clerk of the Senate confirmed that an individual Senator could initiate and run an independent Parliamentary inquiry. I am grateful for the support from industry associations. . .
Turning to page 1, paragraph 1.3, the report says, under the heading `Basis for establishment of Independent Parliamentary Inquiry':

Following the rejection of his proposed Senate Select Committee on Tariffs, Senator Spindler obtained advice from the Clerk of the Senate that it would be "well within the scope of your duties as a member of the Senate" for Senator Spindler to use his parliamentary facilities to conduct an inquiry into tariffs.

I would think that no senator could dispute that statement that he was, as a member of the Senate, entitled to use his facilities—his office, his paper allowance, his everything—to conduct an inquiry. But it is not the same as saying it is a parliamentary inquiry.

PARA.TAB: Acting on this advice, Senator Spindler announced his intention of conducting an independent parliamentary inquiry into the issue. I think one could challenge the `independent' because it clearly is an Australian Democrat inquiry. And why should they not conduct an inquiry? But they should call it an Australian Democrat inquiry, not an independent parliamentary inquiry.

Now we come to the correspondence with the Clerk. There is a letter dated 26 May from Senator Spindler to the Clerk and there is a letter of the same date from the Clerk to Senator Spindler. Senator Spindler says to the Clerk:

SPEECH.PARA: I refer to proceedings in the Chamber during the adjournment debate last night when the Coalition refused leave for me to formally table the Final Report of the Independent Parliamentary Inquiry into Tariffs and Industry Development.

The reason given was the use of the term `Parliamentary' on the grounds that the Inquiry was not established by a resolution of the Senate and as a result, hearings did not attract parliamentary privilege.
That was one of the things mentioned. He continued:

While I have accepted this restriction and have at all times informed witnesses that they are not enjoying parliamentary privilege when giving evidence, it is my contention that the use of `Parliamentary' is purely descriptive; ie, it is stating the obvious fact that the Inquiry is being conducted by members of Parliament.

I pause there because I do not see anywhere in the report where it sets out that it is being conducted by members of parliament; there is not a page within it that sets out the names and status of those who were conducting the inquiry.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I take a point of order. There is a statement in it which shows the parliamentarians who have taken part.
—That is not a point of order.
—I may have missed it. I have searched through it because I thought it was an important point. Perhaps it is hidden there somewhere. The letter goes on:

SPEECH.PARA: Would you please advise, firstly whether my use of the term `parliamentary' in this context is acceptable as a statement of fact and secondly whether my action contravenes any sessional order or convention of the Senate or Parliament as a whole.

It should also be noted that I have taken great care to inform the public, as well as individuals and organisations interested in the Inquiry, of the way in which it originated; ie, not as a result of a formal motion of the Senate.

Senator Spindler has insisted, and he has it printed there, that he has taken great care to inform the public. Why did not he take a little more care when he presented the document? The letter from the Clerk to Senator Spindler, also dated 26 May 1993, says:

You have asked for advice on the point which was made in debate in the Senate on 25 May 1993 that your report and inquiry into tariffs should not have been described by the adjective " parliamentary".
The term "parliamentary" has no official or established meaning and its use is not covered by any rule of the Senate. It is used to refer to anything associated with parliament.

I note your statements that you took steps to ensure that the public was aware that the inquiry was not established by the Senate and that its activities were not covered by parliamentary privilege. Given that you took those steps, I do not think that you could reasonably be accused of misrepresenting proceedings in the Senate within the terms of Privilege Resolution No. 6, paragraph (7).
The question of whether you should describe your inquiry as "parliamentary", therefore, is a matter of political debate and not one on which any procedural or legal opinion can be given.

Nobody in the debate on 25 May suggested that. I do not think any of us would dispute the Clerk's opinion as set out in this letter. I do not think this is the total issue. What we are talking about is what a person would think when they saw this document and what they would interpret it to mean. I maintain that it is misleading on the face of it and that it ought not be presented in that manner.

PARA.TAB: Senator Spindler has the document printed and he can distribute it to whoever he likes, but it seems to me from the way he has behaved with respect to the tabling of it that he is attempting to give it a different sort of status, which almost enhances the misleading nature of the document. I think that is a pity. `Australian Democrat inquiry' would be quite different. I seem to be intruding into Senator Evans's space.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have to say I am a little surprised at the passion this matter has generated. I should not be surprised after all these years in this place, but there it is. I originally took the view that no great harm would be done to the polity or anybody else by this sort of document getting into the public domain through the agency of the Senate. I was inclined to be a little relaxed about it. Nonetheless, it does seem to be an issue which has generated quite a considerable reaction and there is obviously a point of principle involved here. Senator Spindler, no doubt in the best possible faith, is nonetheless, on the face of it, perpetrating something which can be construed as a bit of a swiftie.

PARA.TAB: I think, in all the circumstances, it would be appropriate if the matter were given a little more mature reflection by Senator Spindler as to how precisely he proposes to canvass the matter. Under the circumstances, I move:
That the debate be now adjourned.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to make a statement relating to the work of the Standing Committee on Industry, Science, Technology, Transport, Communications and Infrastructure and to incorporate the statement in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

The newly formed Senate Standing Committee on Industry, Science, Technology, Transport, Communications and Infrastructure proposes to take up two references that had been commenced by its predecessor committees in the 36th Parliament.

The Industry, Science and Technology Committee was conducting an inquiry into the adequacy of Commonwealth fisheries legislation. That inquiry was referred on 17 December 1992. The Committee received a total of 35 submissions and had commenced a program of public inquiries around Australia in April 1993. The Committee met with fishermen and fishing authorities in Tasmania, Victoria, New South Wales and South Australia. The newly formed committee intends to continue the program of hearings as set down by the former committee. In June, the Committee intends travelling to Western Australia, Sydney and Brisbane for further discussions, inspections and public hearings. It is the Committee's intention to report on this reference at the commencement of the Budget sittings 1993.

The Disasters Management Inquiry was commenced by the former Senate Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure in the 36th Parliament. The reference was referred to that committee on 15 October 1992. It advertised for submissions in November 1992 receiving a total of 58 submissions to date. Following the amalgamation of the former Industry, Science and Technology Committee and the Transport, Communications and Infrastructure Committee, the newly formed Committee met to consider its approach to the disasters management reference. The Committee intends to continue the inquiry and to report on the date set by the former committee that is, the first sitting day in February 1994.

Mr President, this is an important inquiry which will provide a focus for national planning requirements about disaster management and the role that the Commonwealth and its agencies can play. The Committee is fortunate that in conducting this inquiry it has the services of three members of the former Transport, Communications and Infrastructure Committee as part of the newly formed Committee.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I table the report of the Australian Parliamentary Delegation to the 1992 ASEAN Inter-Parliamentary Organisation Conference, or AIPO, held between 15 September and 3 October 1992 to which both you, Mr Deputy President, and I were delegates.

PARA.TAB: The delegation to the ASEAN Inter-Parliamentary Organisation Conference was significant in a number of respects. It came at a time of heightened awareness in Australia of our position in the Asia-Pacific region. It came at a time when there was an agreement to form an ASEAN free trade area over the next 15 years and when the Asia-Pacific economic cooperation process was gathering momentum.

It was thus appropriate that Australia's representation at AIPO for this conference was the highest ever sent to AIPO by Australia, consisting as it did of the Hon. Roger Price MP, the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Defence, as leader; me as deputy leader and shadow Minister for community services, external territories and northern Australia; you, Mr Deputy President; and two senior members of Parliament, the Hon. Janice Crosio and the long serving former member for Franklin, Bruce Goodluck. The secretary to the delegation was a senior and efficient officer of our Department of the Senate, Mr Dan Barton.

The level of representation reflected Australia's heightened awareness and recognition of AIPO and, through it, ASEAN, as well as an acknowledgment of Australia's role as a participator in the formulation of, and indeed, in many respects, a leader of, opinion in the Asia-Pacific region. ASEAN is the most important organisation in South East Asia. Its success in seeking cooperation on common problems and issues, not only among member states but also with other countries in the Asia-Pacific region and beyond is strongly supported by Australia. Australia's future is linked to Asia and Australia is actively seeking to integrate itself further in the region. As part of this process Australia wishes to encourage and support more interactions between our peoples at all levels of society to continue to build the people-to-people bridges.

Meetings of organisations such as AIPO which bring together in a bipartisan way members of parliaments of the Asia-Pacific region are significant reinforcers of our linkages with ASEAN. As parliamentarians we represent various sections of our communities and, through the parliamentary process, provide input to the policies of our governments. I commend the recommendations of the report to the Senate, in particular those relating to the main purpose of our visit, the 8th AIPO conference. I draw the Senate's attention to the recommendations concerning the nature of future Australian parliamentary representation at AIPO, in particular the proposals for continuity of representation.

The delegation has recommended that the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade respond to the Parliament within three months of the tabling of this report in relation to those recommendations of particular significance to that department. In addition to attending the AIPO conference, which was the main purpose of the delegation, we arranged a number of significant appointments in Indonesia and made bilateral visits to Papua New Guinea prior to the conference, and Thailand, with the assistance of the parliaments and Australian posts in each country.

The delegation arrived in Papua New Guinea on 16 September 1992, the 17th anniversary of Papua New Guinea's independence. We were thus able to attend the Independence Day celebrations, such as the flag raising ceremony at Independence Hill, and meet Prime Minister Wingti and members of the new Government. During periods when the delegation was not required at the AIPO conference, we met with the presiding officers of the Indonesian Parliament and a number of Government Ministers including, for example, Home Affairs Minister Rudini and Transmigration Minister Soegiarto. Following the AIPO conference, the delegation made a bilateral visit to Thailand and became the first delegation from another country to meet the new presiding officers, other parliamentarians and members of the new ministry following the September 1992 election.

Before closing, I wish to draw the Senate's attention to one particular matter on which the delegation had made recommendations to alleviate perceived problems. That matter is the degree and quality of support services, including briefings, provided to the delegation by the Australian post in Jakarta, which the delegation believes bears improvement. We held a debriefing session with the department shortly after our return at which we raised our concerns. We have taken the step of also mentioning these matters in our report in the hope that the problems we experienced will be addressed in the appropriate way by the department. We await with interest the full response by the department to the matters raised.

One further matter on which I wish to comment briefly is the production of this report by the Senate publishing and printing units. I have been informed that the final section of this report was passed to the printing unit at 8.30 last night and that copies were produced within the hour. On behalf of the delegation, I wish to thank sincerely Mr Gordon Kimber and his staff, in particular Ms Jill Manning in the publishing unit and George Kuleas and Michael Marshall in the print shop, for their assistance in the production of this report in what I know is an extremely busy and testing period. I commend the report to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —Pursuant to the resolution of the Senate of 5 May 1993, I present the report of the Select Committee on Community Standards Relevant to the Supply of Services Utilising Electronic Technologies. I seek leave to incorporate the report in Hansard and to move a motion in relation to the report.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The report read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: Pursuant to the resolution of the Senate of 5 May 1993 establishing the Committee now known as the Select Committee on Community Standards Relevant to the Supply of Services Utilising Electronic Technologies, which required the Committee to report by the end of each Session of this Parliament, I wish to report to the Senate on the work of the Committee so far.

The Committee was established to continue the work of the Select Committee on Community Standards Relevant to the Supply of Services Utilising Telecommunications Technologies, as recommended by that Committee in its last report, which was presented on 3 May 1993.

The Committee's terms of reference require it to inquire into and make recommendations on the fundamental question of applying community standards in the context of existing classifications to the new electronic information and entertainment services of: pay television (whether delivered by satellite, microwave, cable, or UHF/VHF); telephone message services; telephone video and videotex services; video games; or services accessed through personal computers.

On 13 May, the Committee held a public hearing, at which the Australian Broadcasting Authority was questioned on the research program it was required to carry out under the Broadcasting Services Act 1992, on community standards of taste and decency in relation to classifications for pay television.

The ABA responded to concerns the Committee had expressed in its report presented on 3 May. Those concerns related to the way the ABA research program had been designed and was being carried out. The qualitative phase of the research program had been undertaken without consultation with the Committee. The Committee had therefore requested that the research program be halted until it had adequate opportunity to comment on its design.

At the hearing on 13 May, the ABA informed the Committee that the second, qualitative phase of the research program had been halted pending the outcome of the Committee's consideration of the qualitative phase.

The ABA has supplied the Committee with all the information requested following its hearing on 20 April 1993. This included the audio and video tapes relating to the qualitative study performed in March and April 1993; the full research brief as set out in the ABA's contract with the consultants, Keys Young; a description by Keys Young of the rationale and methodology applied during the qualitative phase of the research; and an interim report by Keys Young summarising the results of the qualitative phase and identifying the key findings and the implications for the next phase, the quantitative research.
Ms Susan Young, of Keys Young, attended the hearing on 13 May to answer questions on the research program.

The Committee intends to give consideration to the information it has received during this month on the ABA's research program, and to make recommendations for improvement to the program, with a view to its early resumption.
The impending introduction of pay television demands that the research program on standards be completed satisfactorily as soon as possible.
The Committee also took evidence during this month on standards for video games.

On 20 May a public hearing was held at which a major distributor of video games, SEGA-Ozisoft Pty. Limited, provided information on recent and prospective developments in video games technology, and on means of ensuring their compliance with accepted community standards.

Video games are not currently classified by the Office of Film and Literature Classification. At its meeting on 23 June, the Council of Attorneys-General will consider a recommendation from the Australian Law Reform Commission that video games be classified by the OFLC.

The Committee was told at the hearing on 20 May that technologies such as CD ROM/Multimedia, Virtual Reality and Holograms would spread quickly into homes around the western world during the balance of this decade, and would take many people by surprise as to the nature of these systems and the power of the new entertainment forms which they provide.
Unlike movies, videos, TV, pay TV or any other form of passive entertainment, this form is interactive.

regulated violence and sex has been part of the passive entertainment or other publishing industries, and it will become part of the interactive industry. Therefore, appropriate controls and standards will need to be established.

When the Committee was re-established on 5 May, its terms of reference were broadened in response to community concern, to enable it to inquire into the problems posed by rapid developments in electronic and telecommunications technology.
The Committee is now calling for submissions from individuals and organisations in the community who are interested in expressing views or providing information on video and computer games.
The Committee intends to report on this matter by December 1993.
Continued scrutiny of telephone message services formed the focus of a hearing held on 26 May.

At the hearing, the Committee heard allegations that Telstra (formerly AOTC) might be involved in running and receiving payment from explicit sex telephone message services through OTC Australia's 0011 international STD service.

Australian telephone message service providers drew to the attention of the Committee advertisements for sexual fantasy recorded messages of the kind which had been condemned by the Committee, and had now been abandoned by Australian message service providers and forbidden by Telecom.
The services were advertised as being available on international lines from Portugal.

Telstra representatives questioned subsequently at the hearing told the Committee that the Portuguese international telecommunications carrier had been requested, when it had first asked for access to Australia for those lines in November 1992, that Portuguese telephone message service providers be informed of the obligation to comply with Telecom's 0055 Code of Practice.
Telecom told the Committee that it would be requesting the Portuguese carrier to terminate immediately any services which did not comply with Telecom's Code of Practice.
Telstra was also investigating technical means of barring access to the particular international telephone numbers which had been identified as being in breach of the Telecom Code.
The Committee intends to hold a public hearing in Sydney on 8 June, at which Telecom would be questioned on further action it could take on regulation of international services.

The whole question of regulatory bypass—that is, the ability to circumvent national controls on the content and standards of television and radio broadcasts and telephone services by going outside the national jurisdiction—will be a focus of the Committee's inquiry in the months to come.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the report.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to pay tribute to my Tasmanian colleague and friend Senator Shirley Walters on her retirement, a senator who has been a member of this chamber for 18 years. Shirley Walters first became a senator on 1 July 1975, during the heady days of the Fraser Government and the double dissolution. Senator Walters, after leaving us, will have become the fourth longest serving female member of this chamber. She will join the annals of great women from both sides of the chamber such as Dame Dorothy Tangney who served for 25 years, Dame Annabelle Rankin who served for 24 years and Dame Ivy Wedgwood who served for 21 years. Shirley, you are in great company and we all salute you.

PARA.TAB: Senator Walters can certainly be said to have followed in her father's footsteps. Her father, Sir Eric Harrison, a founding member of the party and deputy to our great leader, Sir Robert Menzies, served for 25 years in the other place as a member for the seat of Wentworth. Her father's example and training have been evident during her 18 years in these hallowed halls. Senator Walters has shown herself to be a tenacious, hard working senator who leaves no stone unturned in her desire to obtain the best not only for the people of Tasmania whom she represented but the families of Australia in general. I think we were all very touched, Shirley, by your comments tonight about the poetry of your father. I think there were many of us who actually had a tear in our eyes because, indeed, he would have been very proud of his great daughter.

But, Shirley, your abiding passion to do what is right in health, welfare and social issues, in family areas, has seen you join such committees as the Senate Standing Committee on Social Welfare and estimates committees soon after coming to this chamber. Your commitment to committee work, attending where at all possible every meeting called, earned you the role of the chairmanship of the Senate Standing Committee on Social Welfare in November 1990 when Senator Peter Baume became Minister. Shirley held this position until 1983 when the present Government came to power. I recall a moment given to me by another colleague of Shirley's on the social welfare committee: you could always count on Shirley to be at any committee meeting called because she took her job so seriously.

It is interesting to note that, whilst in opposition, Shirley's interest in community affairs and social welfare earned her the vice-chairmanship of, at first, the social welfare committee from 1983 and, when it changed its name, of the community affairs committee in 1987 until the present time.

Such reports as The other side of the drug debate and Homeless youth were produced while Shirley was chairperson of the social welfare committee. The report on homeless youth gave a clear and incisive look into why we have so many of our youth on the street. The myth that homeless youth were merely undisciplined children not wishing to come under the umbrella of their parents was clearly broken, as the report clearly showed, and it also showed that the main cause of homeless youth was sexual, physical or verbal abuse inflicted in the home. To escape this, the teenager would leave and thus end up on the street.

The other side of the drug debate was another myth breaking report examining the abuse of prescription and over-the-counter drugs that occur within our country. This report was but the start of Shirley's endeavour to do as much as possible to encourage this Government to implement measures that will rid this country of the prevalence of drug abuse.

Her input to the social welfare committee did not stop when she became part of the Opposition. From what I have been informed, at all times Senator Walters was in attendance using her quick and agile mind to draw out the best from the witnesses called. The reports when presented were concise and resourceful. The report dealing with employment for the disabled is a good example.

In commenting on Senator Shirley Walters's committee work, we must not forget that she was also a member or a chairman of various Senate select committees covering the social welfare issues. For example, on coming here Senator Walters was able to make use of her nursing and medical interests on the Senate Select Committee on Private Hospitals and Nursing Homes. During the years of the Fraser Government she was chairman of this committee, and then she was vice-chairman whilst in opposition.

The other Senate select committees of note that she served on were the industrial relations legislation in 1992, volatile substance fumes from 1984 to 1985, video material during the same years, and the Human Embryo Experimentation Bill from 1985 to 1986. So it is a tremendous record. It has been said that it was her active involvement and attendance at committee hearings which gave her the background information she needed to ask such incisive questions whenever the estimates were in progress. Many a bureaucrat has felt the keen edge of Senator Walters's mind and questioning.

Before I leave her committee involvement, it must be mentioned that she was also active on several joint select committees. Her active participation in the inquiry into the Family Law Act from 1979 to 1980 and the inquiry into video material from 1985 to 1988 has been well recognised. It was as a result of Shirley's work on this last mentioned committee that she introduced her private member's Bill to reduce the amount of violence permitted in video classifications for mature and restricted audiences as well as prohibiting the sale and hire of X-rated videos.

This Bill covered one of the recommendations of the report from the inquiry into video material which the Government did not adopt. Thus Senator Walters was able to overcome the lack of action from this present government and, at the same time, respond to the considerable concerns within the community about the increasing incidence of violence as well as sexual violence in videos.

The Australian Institute of Criminology has noted that on the figures of rape alone there has been an increase of 159 per cent in 10 years. Disappointingly, the Government and the Democrats failed to support her private member's Bill. Instead of allowing a vote to be taken, the Government filibustered until the time for debate had ceased. In today's climate when violence is seen as second only to unemployment as the main issue of concern to voters, it is disappointing to see a government which is not prepared to support this important Bill.

Senator Walters is indeed an all-rounder. Not only is she an active member of this chamber but her energies extend to the party room and to her party. Of particular note was the fact that she was Parliamentary Secretary to the then Leader of the Opposition, Mr John Howard, from April 1987 to May 1989. It was a tribute to Shirley that John Howard was in the chamber when the main valedictories were given tonight. During that time, her advice on the status of women, family issues and community and social welfare issues was often sought. I would have to say that all party members would hold Senator Walters in high regard for her knowledge and championship of women's issues. Throughout her parliamentary career, Shirley has always been a champion of the women in Australia. When she leaves this place the women of Australia, and especially the family women, have lost an important voice.

As a fellow Tasmanian and Liberal, I can comment on her involvement in the party at the State level. She will be a loss to the party in Tasmania. From the early days of her entry into the Senate, Senator Walters proved herself a popular and tireless representative. She entered the chamber in the No. 5 position 18 years ago and it soon became apparent that the No. 1 position was for her. She has constantly led the Tasmanian Senate team to victory from that position thereafter.

Shirley has set the standard for what is expected from a Liberal politician in Tasmania. She is conscientious in all facets of her work, and when it comes to meeting the people within her electorate I find no fault. If there was a branch meeting or Liberal Party function called, Shirley was always in attendance if possible, and this was in addition to attending every community activity wherever possible. Shirley Walters has an exceptional ability to be able to explain party policy and action in a simple, down-to-earth manner. During the lead-up to the last election and while it was in progress, Shirley Walters was a tireless speaker and worker.

Shirley: as a fellow Liberal and friend, and as one who has sat beside you in this chamber for many years, I am sure that I speak on behalf of all on this side of the chamber—and hopefully many on the other side—when I say we will miss you. You have done a great deal in your life and you have achieved a lot in the Senate. I simply say: all the best in your retirement and may it bring you as much happiness and joy as your 18 years in this place have brought you. Thank you for your contribution.

TALK.START.PARA: —With due respect to the hour I will be extremely brief, although I would have liked to have said something about all my colleagues. But like Senator Watson, I cannot let the moment pass without acknowledging how proud I have been to be part of a two-woman Liberal Senate ticket from Tasmania, that little conservative State; many would not expect Tasmania to be sending women in such numbers on the one ticket.

PARA.TAB: I am proud of Shirley. She has not only been a dear friend and colleague to me but also a dear and loyal friend to my husband when he was a Minister and member for Bass. Many a fight they had in the Parliament and in the party, and she was always a great friend and colleague of his. I wanted to join him tonight in extending my best wishes to her in her retirement.

I do still feel very responsible for the fact that I was the cause of her nearly being thrown out of the Senate when I first came to this place, because it was to my defence that she rushed when I had been here only a few weeks; she thought I needed protecting—very much like a mother hen. What she did not realise until some years later was that, like any child, I was wanting to stand on my own feet.

Perhaps what she did not say tonight that I ought to mention is that our leader, the Leader of the Opposition, was highly incensed at the way Senator Walters and I had behaved in embarrassing the President of the Senate and having his authority in question because the Government had not maintained the numbers in the Senate. Consequently, the leader had us paraded like naughty schoolgirls in the early hours of the morning outside the office of the President, waiting to apologise for having brought him into such embarrassment—

TALK.START.PARA: —It would not happen now.

—It would not happen these days. Certainly, we apologised profusely because we did have a fine sense of the authority of the President and, actually, we had not intended to bring him into disrepute. I would like to say in conclusion that Shirley has done an enormous amount of work in this chamber and in our State, as Senator Watson has just said. I want to assure her that the important work that she has done on trying to deal with pornography is known by the women of Australia, is appreciated by the women of Australia, and will be continued by those of us who remain.

PARA.TAB: We are proud to have known her. We are proud to have worked with her. She was brave and doughty in everything that she took on and, unlike some people, she has worked hard to the very last day of her service. She has not eased off or slacked off at all. Goodbye, Shirley.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brownhill Sen D.G.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BROWNHILL
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I will be very quick. I just wanted to say a few words about some of the people who have passed through this place and who are leaving at the end of the session tonight: Senator Button—a doer who was always very helpful as a Minister; Peter Durack—a wise man of the House, who helped me a great deal in setting up the Family Law Act inquiry; Senator Walsh—who tried to get things done in the right way when he was a Minister, but his party would not go with him. In fact if they had gone with him then, the economy would have been in a lot better shape today.

PARA.TAB: I will always remember Senator Walsh. The assistant Black Rod had to go and get him from his office one night in the old House. I must admit, he did return to the House at some stage, but the assistant Black Rod, Mr Cleaver Elliott, was in a very shattered state when he got back with the said Minister. I will always remember Senator Walsh for that. I do not agree with some of the things that he is talking about at the moment. One of them, of course, is the reintroduction of inheritance tax or the reintroduction of death duties. I abhor the fact that that was quoted of him in the papers today.

When Senator Walters gets that deep voice of hers and starts to rumble along, you always know something is going to come out of her lips that is very worth while. I do not think I will remember her as the porn queen or anything like that because she has done so much to try to do something about pornography, but that is basically what I think it will be.

I do think that when she says she will give somebody a bit of a shot, or fire a couple of guns, she gives more than one barrel; she gives both, and a couple more. Shirley, I think you have been remarkable for doing that, and I will always remember that.

The thing I will probably remember you most for was when I was the only person of the male gender on the private hospital and nursing homes inquiry. If you remember, there were Senator Haines, Senator Giles, Senator Zakharov, Senator Crowley and myself—I cannot remember any others. That was enough. The arguments that you girls used to get into really made my ears burn, and I must say that I have never heard the same language used anywhere else on any other committee. It was really a matter of the ladies working it out themselves.

Senator Lewis is a man of quiet counsel. I hope he enjoys his golf. Austin, I do not think I ever got to know you as well as I would have liked to. I know that you will enjoy your golf; you said a minute ago that you will fix up your putting and then you will really enjoy your golf.

I remember Senator Giles from the private hospital and nursing homes inquiry of which she was chairman. As I said, it was an experience for me with all those women getting into each other all the time.

Senator Maguire was the tax man who filled in time if ever there was a need to filibuster on the economy or financial things. Plus there was his tennis ability—I played with him in the parliamentary tennis team a few times.

Senator Aulich and I came here together. I never quite knew whether Senator Aulich was from Tasmania or the ACT, and to this day I do not know whether he is a senator from the ACT or a senator from Tasmania. I am quite sure he has enjoyed his time in this place.

Senator Powell was Democrat leader and is now an Independent. I am quite sure, Senator Powell, you will enjoy your life out of this place. I appreciate what you said about having to find a job for yourself and all your staff as well when you leave this place.

I would say that Senator Sowada is the only sensible Democrat that has ever graced this place. I think she has been a great senator for New South Wales. I cannot say that I am sorry she lost because she has been replaced by a National Party senator, but she has graced this place and been a joy, I believe, to the people who have worked with her.

The one person I have to say more about is Senator Bjelke-Petersen who is undoubtedly a legend in her own lifetime. She is much more than a pumpkin scone baking, ex-Premier's wife, as I think everyone in this place has found out. Basically, she is as soft as butter, but she can be as tough as teak. I have had a few encounters with Florence Bjelke-Petersen in our party room and I can tell you, she is pretty tough. This is no more epitomised than by what her daughter said about her in the following article:

SPEECH.PARA: My daughter Helen was interviewed and asked what it was like to have a dictator as a father. She looked at them and laughed, saying that dad was the soft one in the family, mum was the hard one. I suppose that came about because I was both mum and dad, and I believed in strict discipline.
That, definitely, was Flo. In her maiden speech she said a couple of things which I do not think have been quoted here tonight. She said:
Despite claims to the contrary, the family still remains the best way of caring for Australia's children and guiding them to adulthood.
I commend her for that, and I think she has stuck with that principle the whole time.

PARA.TAB: She is a lady of strong Christian faith. Senator Florence has always maintained high moral standards, and I am sure she will continue to do so for the rest of her life. She stands as a colossus. She stood by those standards which are so hard to hold up in this day and age. I believe her willingness to stand up for what she believes is a quality which set her apart from most other politicians in this place. Her speeches were always about ordinary people and the people she represented, and I think that is absolutely magnificent.

Senator Florence had an ability to make a very successful career for herself without losing her values and beliefs about the importance of a woman as a home maker. As a politician, I believe she has excelled. When we think about some of the remarks that Senator Walsh threw at her at different times and the way that she had to take the flak that was being thrown at her husband, I really admire her because not many other people in this place have had flak being thrown at their husband or wife while having to sit through it. She has to be commended for that.

Senator Bjelke-Petersen shared her pumpkin scones with the royal family. The recipe she talked about here today got her $1,000. I think the handwritten recipe was worth $1,200. I was at an auction with her one day where she sold a handwritten recipe for $120. An unsuccessful bidder came up to her after this guy had paid $120 for the recipe and said, `I would have loved to have got that recipe but I could only afford $110'. Instead of saying, `What about a donation of $110?', she said, `Don't worry, love, I'll write one out for you and send it to you in the mail next week'. I do not know how that made the other guy who had paid $120 feel, but that was Lady Florence Bjelke-Petersen to a tee.

I most admire Senator Bjelke-Petersen, as I said, for the way she took the flak from Senator Walsh. Her ability to take shorthand was something that put her above any other politician in this place. The fact that she could take down everything people were saying about her and then quote it back to them straight away, standing up in this place, was magnificent. Another attribute is the Flo and Joh show. The Flo and Joh show will continue. They have been one of the most popular political duos in Australia's history and I believe it will continue as well. Florence Bjelke-Petersen has done much for Australia and Queensland and the people she represents. She has taught me many things. She is a remarkable woman. Florence, your presence in this place will be missed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner Sen J.P.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: VETERANS' AFFAIRS; DEFENCE SCIENCE AND PERSONNEL

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Manager of Government Business in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I know that there are many other senators who wish to contribute to the valedictory debate. That can be achieved in the adjournment debate, as has been negotiated with the Opposition. I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate do now adjourn.

TALK.START.PARA: —I recognise the time of night and I would like to speak at greater length about the retiring senators but I did not think I could let the opportunity go without saying a couple of words. One of the nice things about being in this place is that it gives one the opportunity to meet some very fine people. One of the sad things about it is that we are saying goodbye to some very fine people tonight. I would like to touch on a few of them. I cannot touch on them all simply because of the limitations of time.

PARA.TAB: When I came to this place eight years ago Senator Peter Durack was the Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate. I will not go into his most illustrious career, which I understand spans some 22 years in this place. Of all the people I have met in my life, wherever they are, I do not think I have met anyone with the integrity, principle, wisdom and commonsense of Peter Durack. He will be a great loss to this place, not just to the Senate itself but to the individuals who have been counselled by Peter in the past.

By way of a small story, there was a time not so many years ago when I was under threat of being sued by one of our colleagues in this place for defamation. I thought I would seek Senator Durack's advice. All I could hear over the phone was this roar of laughter as he rolled around the floor. I said, `It's all right for you, you're not being sued'. He said, `Don't worry, you haven't said anything defamatory; it is common practice by this individual to threaten to sue people'. It was all right for him; he was not about to lose his house. In retrospect, the counsel was very wise.

I do not know what one can say about Shirley Walters that has not been said. Here is a person who believes in the great values of life. She is a great patriot and a great Australian. She believes in the family and the real dignity of women, not the phoney dignity by the extremist feminists.

She was referred to, I think quite improperly, by Senator Evans as the epitome of Tory conservatism. If that is the case, Shirley, you have a lot of company in Australia. Even though there are people of a higher position in the political field who do not know who they are, one thing we cannot say about Shirley is that she does not know what an Australian is. Congratulations, Shirley.

When I came in here, Austin Lewis was the shadow Minister for industry, technology and commerce. I have always said that Austin called a spade a shovel. I can very well recall his tackling Senator Button with great gusto because he recognised the fact, which Labor governments often do not recognise, that governments cannot pick winners. I can remember Senator Lewis attacking Senator Button for attempting to pick winners. People should realise that companies are very expert at picking winners, and a lot of them go bust, too. As sure as the sun rises and sets, governments cannot pick winners. One of the nice things I found out from Senator Lewis is that he is retiring to Queensland. Let me say to you, Austin: you must have recently read The Getting of Wisdom.

I thought I would touch very briefly on Senator Peter Walsh. It was a great pity that Senator Walsh spoiled what was otherwise a very fine speech. But as you come so shall you go. Senator Walsh came in here and attacked the then government of the day. He had what he called a dirt file. I always thought that Senator Walsh had a great intellect and he did not need that to make his point. I believe he would have achieved a lot more without it.

My first experience with Senator Walsh was on Estimates Committee C with my colleague Senator Brownhill. We were a little bit in awe of Senator Walsh because we had heard all the stories about him. In practice, even though he had a lot of the bravado, a lot of the thumping of the chest and a lot of the macho image, he could in fact be a pussy cat. I have to say this about him because of his remarks. I can recall that on an estimates committee there was a certain Democrat who had the habit of driving us all nuts, as they all do from time to time. This fellow used to come in with piles of pieces of paper. He was not on the committee. I will not mention his name. He would come in and Senator Walsh would abuse the hell out of him so that he would start trembling at the lips and he would put all his questions on notice and go away. But the next day he would come back with another pile of questions. I recall one day Senator Walsh scribbling on a piece of paper which came down to me from the attendant, and it said, in a sort of pathetic way, `I've tried being rude to this bloke. What do I do next?' I can recall writing on the bottom, `Try harder, Peter; I know you can'.

Senator Walsh likes to look on himself as being a Chifley type of Labor person. He was written up in the media as being a person who was one of the last remaining socialists. From all the readings I have done on Senator Walsh—and he writes under the name of Cassandra in the Financial Review—it seems like he opposes the wastage of middle-class welfare, he opposes government waste, which came through very strongly on the estimates committee I was on with Senator Walsh, and he is very critical of the new class and those people in society who would like to see greater expenditure without development. My belief is that Senator Walsh has conned the media but he has not conned anyone in this place because we know that that is not the prerogative of left-wing socialists; it is more the prerogative of the Liberal Party. So perhaps we might lay that one to rest.

I should like to say farewell to my other colleagues in this place, Senator Powell, Senator Aulich and others, and wish them well in the future. I would like to refer very briefly to Senator Sowada. Senator Sowada has been beyond reproach, particularly to me in my dealings with her as a member of the shadow ministry in the last Parliament. I have found her a very intelligent lady with a keen mind who lays all her cards on the table. There is not an ounce of deviousness in her.

One might claim that she has not been here long enough to have been corrupted by the chattering class, to which I heard Senator Walsh refer tonight but which I believe is an invention of John Stone. Where Walsh is the new class, Stone was the chattering class and part of that vocal minority that is not content with the dreadful state of our economy as it is but would destroy it altogether. I suppose in a way Senator Sowada has been fortunate. I wish her well in whatever role she adopts in the future.
I say farewell to all our departing colleagues. Again, I particularly thank the colleagues with whom I have enjoyed a very close relationship here: Shirley Walters, Austin Lewis and Peter Durack.

I might mention a little point about Shirley that I earlier forgot and which I should mention. Even though I look upon Shirley as being one of my closest friends in this place, it did not mean that when I went into the party room with a proposal that she did not like that she did not tear me into a thousand bits. One day I can remember her getting stuck into me in front of everyone. I did not expect this from Shirley. She said to me, `You have gone out and said something without taking it through this party room and that is a cardinal sin'. I remember going up to her and in a lame voice saying, `Shirley, I thought I would seek forgiveness rather than permission'.

TALK.START.PARA: —I shall also be brief. I want to take this chance to say goodbye, particularly to three colleagues who are leaving. I will say very briefly what their speeches meant to me tonight and what it shows about their character which I admire.

PARA.TAB: I endorse Senator Parer's remarks. This really important occasion in the Senate when we can say farewell to departing senators was almost spoilt by Senator Walsh, but not quite, because of the quality of the speeches that others made. I have to say that his was a boorish, defamatory and unfortunate speech. I suppose that, like many of my colleagues, I was faced with the dilemma of what to do when faced with this type of behaviour. Some of us walked out and some of us decided to stay.

I was very pleased when Austin Lewis stood up. I was reminded of one of the many great sayings of Winston Churchill about meting out to the enemy the measure and more than the measure than they have meted out to us. I think that Austin stood up and defended the honour of our party. He said it with style and vigour and with a toughness that we will miss in this chamber. That speech was one of many speeches that he has made, but it showed the quality that many of us greatly admire in him. Certainly as a Victorian senator I feel that particularly deeply.
I am so glad that Shirley Walters read that poem into the record.

TALK.START.PARA: —She recited it.

—She recited it; I am always being corrected by Jocelyn Newman. I am so glad that she recited that poem. Like Senator Walters, I have not been confused by my identity as an Australian. I have always found this a very odd aspect of the debate which has come on to the record in the last two or three years. I have to say that, before I entered Parliament, I had met thousands and thousands of people during my life, and not one of them has been confused about their Australian identity.

PARA.TAB: This confusion is an invention of the chattering classes; it is an invention of those who wear the black armband of Australian history. I was delighted that Senator Walters could get up and express so beautifully and passionately the great feeling for our country that she has. She did it so well. Her father would have been proud to know that that poem will be read by many senators. Hopefully, it will be passed on to their children. It reflects a great passion and love for our country. Shirley, you are not confused about your identity and nor am I. Not one person on this side of the chamber is. I am quite delighted that you made those remarks.

I go back quite a long way with Peter Durack. I was a staffer with former Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle, whose name was mentioned a couple of times in the remarks this evening. Senator Durack was the Attorney-General, a very important and very mighty man in the Fraser Government. Although he was always polite, friendly and courteous to me, Peter was up there and I was down here. It was always a great honour to have a chance to speak to him.

Peter, it has been one of the great pleasures of coming into this chamber that I have had the chance to become your friend and, again, to have the benefit of your wise counsel on great affairs of state and small affairs of state as well. That is an aspect I have particularly treasured.

Senator Flo is not in here but I have had the chance in the course of the evening to tell her my feelings towards her, and of the friendship which I have enjoyed. Whatever the tensions between our great parties in Queensland, Senator Bjelke-Petersen has been an enormous help to me with fundraising for the Liberal Party. Those pumpkin scone recipes, which she writes out for me regularly, I am able to use very productively.

She was kind enough to sign one that she prepared for me last night. She wrote out the recipe and Sir Joh was in the chamber. He wrote on it, `These scones are great; don't you worry about that'. I think that recipe is going to be a particular treasure, and I look forward to gracing someone's kitchen wall with it in the future.

Senator Sowada, I will not say anything more to damage your political career than my colleagues have said. I will be a big help to you. I think you have been awful, Senator Sowada. You have been difficult, aggressive and you have made our lives hell over here in the Liberal Party. If that does not help you, Senator Sowada, I do not know what will.

I was going to say a few brief words about Senator Maguire, who was in here—he has lasted a long time—but has since left. I did not get to know him particularly well. As people have mentioned, he was always up on his feet, particularly in the debates on the economy, and I had the chance to cross swords with him on a number of occasions. I will let others judge who scored the most effective points. But I did particularly want to have the chance to say goodbye to my three good friends here. I will finish it there.

TALK.START.PARA: —I only want to put some very brief words on the record. It is always a sad occasion when, as I have experienced now on a few occasions, colleagues leave us whether voluntarily or involuntarily. We tend to remember them as if they have passed on. Indeed, they are in some sense moving on, but in many cases they are moving on to better things—things which will bring them, in the vast majority of cases, closer to the ones they love, the ones who have suffered most because of this career we in this place have embarked on.

PARA.TAB: I would like to say something about each and every one of the people who are leaving us tonight but I will refrain from doing so because I do not have all the names recorded in front of me and I might omit some, and that would not do anybody any particular good. But I would, for my own State, record the fact that we are losing tonight three very distinguished senators who have, in their own way, contributed enormously in this place for the people of Western Australia.

From Western Australia, the most distant State from this national capital, there is a feeling in the community that we are neglected from time to time, that Canberra really does not care about what happens way over in the west. I know all of these Western Australian senators who are leaving us tonight, and relinquishing their positions at the end of next month, have done many things in their own ways within their own political parties, in government and in opposition, to ensure a West Australian position is being espoused within party rooms and parliamentary committees, within government and within opposition.

The three who are leaving are Senator Durack from the other side of the chamber, Senator Walsh from this side and my very good friend and close associate Senator Giles. Senator Giles is perhaps the closest of the three to me. She has made an enormous and immeasurable contribution in the Parliament to the cause of women in our community. It is a contribution which others have referred to and I would like to associate myself with the very good and kind remarks that have been made about Pat, remarks which are true in every sense of the word.

I put it on the record that although people tend to think of Pat merely as an advocate for women, I know from my own experience, prior to my coming here and since my time here, that Pat, or indeed her office, does not necessarily turn away men who are in difficulty and who need political advice. She serves the whole of the community but puts a huge emphasis on redressing the imbalance against women in our community. She has made a contribution but obviously there is a lot more work to be done in that direction.

Senator Durack is a person whom I hold in high regard. Many kind words have been said about Peter. He is indeed one of nature's gentlemen and it has been a pleasure to be associated with him and to work with him in this place. Even though I did not have the intimacy of serving on parliamentary committees with him, I am aware of the work he has done in that area. I have previously referred to the fact that he has represented his State over a long period of time.

My first association with Peter happened in the mid to late 1970s when I was a trade union activist and there were coalition governments in power in Canberra and in Western Australia. Because of my trade union activities I got arrested on two occasions. The then State Liberal Government, under Sir Charles Court, decided to enact an infamous section of the police Act of the State, section 54b. I got arrested on two occasions for engaging in activities which are now quite legal and quite lawful, but the government of the day chose to use those powers in another attempt to crush the union movement. The union movement of course has survived that attack.

Senator Durack was then Attorney-General and I recall very vividly the then Premier announcing an inquiry into the validity of this particular section of the West Australian police Act. I recall that the Premier announced that he was going to have two very distinguished Western Australians examine the implications, one of whom was Senator Durack. I did not know him personally; I did not really want to know him from the comments that my colleagues in the trade union movement were making about him at the time. I am happy to record in the early hours of this morning that the comments made at that time were not necessarily true and it has indeed been a pleasure to serve with him.

I have saved words about Senator Walsh until last. Even though Senator Durack serves on the opposite side of the chamber, I have had more conflict with Senator Walsh than I have with Senator Durack. Senator Walsh is somewhat of a legend now because of his work and activities as Minister for Finance and for some of his other utterances as well. The left wing of the Australian Labor Party, with which I am proud to be associated, had cause on a number of occasions when Peter was serving out part of his distinguished career as Minister for Finance to take him to task and make some perhaps disparaging remarks about him.

Peter Walsh's contribution to Western Australia and to the parliamentary processes I think will be recorded in history as something that has been very productive, not just on behalf of the people that he represented. I do believe that he has a huge social conscience and a huge heart that has kept driving him forward to represent people who are not quite as advantaged as some others in our society. He is somewhat of a legend from Western Australia and it is a pity that he is leaving us tonight.

However, joy comes with retirement as well. He has told me quite confidentially that he is going to do nothing in his retirement and that in the past few weeks and months he has been practising that. But I am not quite so sure, judging from the depth of the speech he delivered this afternoon.

It has been a pleasure for me to serve in the Parliament with so many distinguished senators. Again, I am going to refrain from seeking to name each and every one of them. I conclude with those remarks.

TALK.START.PARA: —At this hour of the night it is not a good idea to strain friendships by speaking for too long but I would like to pay tribute to our departing colleagues. In order of seniority, I will start with Senator Peter Durack. Honourable senators may be surprised to hear that I have not known Senator Durack for a great number of years. In fact, I only met him on the day that I stood for pre-selection in 1987. I had certainly heard of him and his exploits on many occasions before that because, when I started first year at the private high school that I went to in Perth, we were told to live up to the feats and accomplishments of old boys—famous old boys, as we were told—and No. 1 amongst them was always Peter Durack. I certainly heard of him then.
—Not as a footballer?

—Not as a footballer, no. I knew then, of course, that he was a grandson of the pioneers of the Kimberley region. He has certainly done his school, his family, his State of Western Australia and Australia proud. I pay tribute to him as he leaves this place, and I wish him a happy retirement. I know that he will keep in contact and I do not think that he will leave here with any bitter attitude.

PARA.TAB: Running through the list of retiring colleagues on this side of the chamber, I come next to Senator Walters. I have to say that for the first few weeks of working with Senator Walters in the party room, I could not stand her, and I would say to my wife, `That woman again!'. But after a while she started to make sense, and we finished up great friends. I admire her for what she has done and I say farewell to her.

Senator Lewis was a great detective. I only arrived in Canberra at half past eight on the night before my first day in the Parliament. I stayed at Forrest Lodge. I did not think that anyone in the place knew me, but he sought me out at half past six in the morning and said, `I'm Austin Lewis and I want your vote for the deputy leader's job'. As I say, he was a great detective, and it has been good knowing him.

TALK.START.PARA: —Did you vote for him?

—I am not saying; that is something that I will not be telling honourable senators. Senator Bjelke-Petersen is a great lady to have known. I am honoured to have known her because, having come from a remote area of Western Australia, I did not think that I would ever meet any famous people. It is great to have known her. I think that covers everybody who is leaving from my side of the chamber.

PARA.TAB: On the other side, we say farewell to Senator Walsh. I think I have known him longer than anybody else in this Parliament. We go back a long time. It is a pity that his bitterness had to come through tonight in the speech that he made. Nonetheless, parts of his speech rang very true and to the point. I think he will be remembered for the good work that he has done in this place rather than for his bitterness. I first knew him when we were in the great Junior Farmers debating team, led by his brother, then himself and a woman from Hines Hill whose name I cannot remember. It was a great debating team. We eventually moved on to join the Western Australia Farmers Federation, as it is now known. The first three speakers on any motion used to be John Walsh, Peter Walsh and John Panizza in about that order. We stirred that place up. It was only a haven for would-be Country Party politicians. We brought it into the 19th century, if not towards the 20th century. He has always done his work, and for that reason I am sorry to see him leaving here so bitter.

I now turn to Senator Giles who is a very compassionate woman. I did not know her until I came here, although I knew the family she married into because they lived not far from the Walsh family. There must have been something in the water at Doodlakine because from that area came Peter Walsh, the family that Pat Giles married into, Ron Boswell who lived there as a young fellow and John Stone. Anyhow, I wish Pat Giles well because I found her a very compassionate woman.

I turn to Graham Maguire. We had many debates on agricultural economics even though we did not quite agree all the time. I did not get to know Senator Aulich very well, but we did discuss a lot of things. People might have noticed that I called him `Senator Aul-itch'. I have always called him `Senator Aul-itch', but that was a joke between us and he knows why. I wish him well.

I had quite a few discussions around different dinner tables with Senator Powell, who comes from the wheat belt of Victoria. Senator Powell comes from a post-war farm development block and I think that she has done very well to get from that situation to this place. Then we come to Senator Sowada, who is leaving us after a very short time here. However, I know that she will be back—whether it be in this place, in the other place or in the Parliament of New South Wales—but not as a Democrat. I have taken a wager with her tonight that she will join the Liberal Party within five years. I wish her well when she eventually does that.

I come to Senator Button who left at the end of last year. It is a pity he did not come back. He will be remembered for his great work for Australia. However, I never knew how to take Senator Button. He was a very hard character to get to know. There is one thing that I never asked him: I have always wondered why he could speak such good Italian. If anyone talks to him, I hope he or she will find out and let me know. In conclusion, farewell to everyone. I wish them all well.

TALK.START.PARA: —I very briefly want to say goodbye to some very good friends and able colleagues on both sides of the House. Florence Bjelke-Petersen and Austin Lewis were not only very effective colleagues but also people for whom I have the very highest personal regard. I do not want to run through everyone like this, because it will obviously take too long. I briefly say to Graham Maguire that, while I will naturally miss his being put up as the token economic explainer of the inexplicable by the Labor Party, I have to admit that I am glad to see him go because I will be moving into his room. It is a very nice room and I thank you, Graham, for vacating it.

PARA.TAB: Senator Tate and I have been on what is grandly called the board of governors of the Canberra City Opera. We have combined in a very bipartisan way to try to do what we could for this organisation which has played a very significant role in the artistic life of Canberra. I have a great deal of respect for Senator Tate. I look forward to his hospitality in The Hague at some time in the future.

Senator Button's highest point in this Parliament was not in fact in this chamber at all. It was when he joined Michael Hodgman and me in the parliamentary debating team that defeated the visiting Oxford University Union debating team some time ago. I prefer to think of him in that context than in any other. Terry Aulich and Pat Giles have been friendly and decent opponents.

I am put in a fair amount of difficulty in relation to Karin Sowada, because I have been a friend of Karin's family for many years. My sorrow at seeing her departure is, I regret to say, offset by the pleasure in the fact that I led a coalition Senate team in New South Wales that won three Senate seats, which is an improvement from previous years. Karin, I regret that it was at your expense—otherwise it would have been at the President's expense—but I am glad that we won three seats.

The next points I very briefly want to make are about Peter Durack and Shirley Walters. Peter Durack has failed to admit that the most difficult period he had in this Parliament was, in fact, not as a Minister at all when he had all those tensions, but as a backbencher before he went into the Ministry when he was chairman of the government members national resources committee—was it in 1976, Peter?

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes.

—Senator Durack was obliged to chair meetings of a committee full of total, absolute megalomaniacs, of whom I was naturally one. Everyone spoke at once—particularly Bill Wentworth—and Peter Durack had the incredible burden of trying to chair this unmanageable committee. He was rescued from it and sent to the cooler, quieter haven of the Ministry to relieve him of that tension. Peter, I thought you did very well trying to run that committee, and being a Minister must have been a very easy job after that. We have shared many pleasant times together, and I was overjoyed to have the opportunity to go to your farewell dinner in Western Australia.

PARA.TAB: I should admit to the chamber that about 15 years ago Senator Shirley Walters and I enjoyed an exciting week together in Paris. I regret to say that I managed to spend only a little time with Shirley. She claims that most of the time I was telephoning press releases through to the Nowra Bugle—

TALK.START.PARA: —And the Women's Weekly.

—Yes. Shirley is one of the two remaining so-called `oncers' who have been in the Senate since they were elected on our side in 1975. They were referred to, particularly in the other place, as people who would not be here long. It was said, `You're all just oncers'. I think the only `oncer' was Mr Tony Whitlam, and he was a member of the Labor Party. Not one of us was a `oncer'. Shirley's departure means that Brian Archer is the only person elected on our side in that climactic election in 1975 who has consistently served in this chamber. I think Senator Colston and Senator Harradine and three others in the other place were also elected at that time.
