It could be said that we had some popularity in the vulgar sense of popular, but apparently it was not lasting popularity. We came here to demonstrate that there is a life after political death, and it is in the Senate.

PARA.TAB: Shirley, your departure does leave Brian as the last of that group. May I say how much I certainly have enjoyed your charm, your strength, your character and your friendship. I do hope that if you do not want to come back here and see us, you will be happy for us to go down there and see you.

TALK.START.PARA: —You bet.

—Due to the late hour I do not wish to say much. I will restrict my comments to colleagues who are in the chamber. Of my four retiring coalition colleagues I would like to say that they are all good and decent people, and I think that is one of the finest things one can say about anybody. Each of them is a person that we have been able to look up to and respect, and who has always shown a lead that is dignified and that is right. Each of them displayed these qualities, and they did it very well. I will remember each of them in their own particular way.

PARA.TAB: I want to say a few words about Senator Florence; the woman I refer to as my grandmother. When I came into the chamber I was sitting next to Julian McGauran who had this particular seat here. Somebody made a comment that we were Ernie and Bert. Senator Boswell was in front and Senator Bjelke-Petersen was at the back with Senator Sheil. It was like three generations of the National party, with dad down the front, the kids in the middle and the grand folks up the back. Senator Sheil, who was an old boy of my old school, the Southport school, left soon after and that just left grandmother. It has been a great privilege and a great pleasure to serve with Senator Florence.

I want to tell honourable senators about the human side of this lady, because she has an immense capacity not just to relate to people but to remember them; and honourable senators know how difficult that is. I thought that maybe it was as a result of all those years as a Premier's wife that she knew everybody in Queensland, but about two or three years ago I took my mother's former primary school headmistress, a Catholic nun, Sister Juliana, up to dinner in the dining room because she was coming back from a retreat. As we walked in, I noticed out of the corner of my eye that Senator Bjelke-Petersen was sitting with Glen Sheil, Bruce Scott and Bruce Cowan in the members and guests dining room.

As we went out, I noticed that they were still there. I said to Sister Juliana, `Would you like to meet Senator Flo?'. She said, `Oh, yes, please'. So I took her over and introduced her to Glen Sheil, Bruce Scott, Bruce Cowan and Senator Flo. Senator Flo turned to her and said, `Now, what order are you with, Sister?'. Sister Juliana told her. She then asked, `What convent are you at?'. She named a convent in Sydney. Senator Flo then proceeded to say, `Well, you would know Sister So-and-so and Sister So-and-so'—and at that point I gave up. I knew there was no way I could ever compete with Senator Bjelke-Petersen's prodigious memory for people and her capacity not just to talk to people and to relate to them but to memorise what they had to say and to really take note.

I think what has made her a great woman and such a respected figure is that she had a humanity that touched everybody who met her. Florence: the more we had to do with each other, the more and more I grew to respect you. I am immensely fond of all the work that you have done. I think you are going to enjoy your retirement immensely. I know you are looking forward to being with your children and grandchildren. They have not just a grandfather but a grandmother whom they can really respect.

I have realised tonight that for over half of the time that Australia has been a federation it has had a Bjelke-Petersen fighting for Queensland. Florence, you have never let us down, and I do not think anybody would ever say that you have done that at all.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tierney Sen J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to pay tribute to my departing colleagues, in particular the people I served with on committees. When constituents criticise this place harshly on the basis of what they glimpse in this chamber from the TV or from the gallery, I tell them about the excellent work of the committee system. Firstly, our Shirley, with whom I served on the select committee on community standards, has kept the interests of women and family to the forefront during her career. In her maiden speech she spoke for all Australian women in the home. She said:

SPEECH.PARA: It is undeniable that the continuance of a stable society means stable citizens, and stable citizens come from a stable family background.

It is with these principles in mind that Shirley has carried out her work in the Senate. As a newcomer to the Senate in 1991, I joined with Shirley on the community standards committee to carry out a limited inquiry on fantasy phone calls on 0055. A staffer of mine at the time warned me that I would rue the day that I joined such a committee because of its membership and its particular terms of reference. My staffer said that this hearing and committee will just go on and on, and it certainly has.

PARA.TAB: It is during this time that I have really come to appreciate Shirley's tenacious qualities. We work very well as a team and have taken part in many fiery hearings. Even the ABC TV cameras turned up to last week's hearing. They probably came because they heard a rumour that the last hearing's Hansard record had been wrapped in clear plastic sealed with an R-rated certificate.

The valuable work of this committee has broadened in scope, and Shirley has been extremely anxious that when she is no longer a member of this place her very valuable work will continue. Now that Senator Herron and I will be carrying this on, she can be assured that it will.

Secondly, I turn to Senator Sowada. In 1991 upon hearing that the Australian Democrats had chosen a 28-year-old archaeologist in the Senate to replace Paul McLean, I had mixed feelings. However, through her work in this place Karin has shown that her research experience has given her great insights into the needs of the education sector. Senator Sowada stated in her maiden speech in this place:

SPEECH.PARA: If we want to become the clever country, education must not be regarded as a burgeoning budget item, but rather as an investment in our country's future, in our young people and in the intellectual and scientific base of business.
This statement is very true and Karin can be proud of the fact that she has worked constantly to see this attitude accepted in the Senate.

PARA.TAB: Karin has worked tirelessly on many issues on the Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training. In the last two years our committee has produced a number of landmark reports including Come in Cinderella on adult and community education and Wanted: our future on youth unemployment. I would particularly commend her work on the education committee since the election. Despite the fact that she will not be continuing past June, she has worked to ensure that the committee is well placed going into the winter recess with its very important mission.

I refer particularly to the establishment of the committee's latest inquiry into the future of universities and the research program. Karin is working on this right up to the last minute. She lobbied very hard for university research to be the next reference and was very keen to see that the terms of reference were expressed correctly—a real professional.

Finally, I also worked closely on committee work with Senator Terry Aulich, who was the Chairman of the Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training. Together with Senator Sowada, we made a great tri-party team. In fact, the committee was able to be very effective in producing a number of highly influential reports and this occurred in no small measure because of the chairmanship skills of Terry Aulich.

Terry is a true believer in education and this has been reflected through his dedication to the work of the committee. His previous profession as a teacher and six years as the Minister for Education in Tasmania has meant that he has always been aware of the issues involved. But you could not ever call Terry a government man.His report, New directions in higher education, was a landmark in its field, pointing out very clearly the deficiencies of the mess created by Mr Dawkins's national unified system—a disastrous experiment in higher education that we have been inflicted with over the last seven years. The measure of the success of the Aulich report was the way in which Minister Dawkins beat him severely about the head in the media after its release.

Terry will now go off into the world of literature to continue his work as a writer. His memoirs should make interesting reading after so many years in the world of politics.At a luncheon today in his honour, SSCEET members, past and present, gathered to pay tribute to Senator Aulich's work. The most fitting of these tributes came from the SSCEET secretary, Brenton Holmes, in the form of a poem:

SPEECH.PARA: When straws are drawn in politics
There's some that draws them short.
You end up down the ticket
and not quite where you ought.
Cause preselection battles are perverse and mean and
tough.
That dreaded quiet word in your ear:
"I'm sorry mate. . . you're stuffed.
And so it's on to better things,
A life that's more your own.
More sleep at nights, no caucus fights,
more time to spend at home.
And when you've finally said farewell
and departed from the fray,
You can bet your bottom dollar
that you'll hear your colleagues say:
"He shall grow not old, as we that are left grow old.
Oppositions shall not weary him, nor his peers condemn.
At the end of Estimates sittings,
and in the mornings
We will envy him.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will try to be brief. I just say at the outset that I could not go home tonight and sleep properly if I did not have the opportunity to say a few words about Shirley. There have been a lot of things said about her tonight. I can just say that some wonderful politicians have come out of Tasmania on both sides of politics. There are people like Dame Enid Lyons, Reg Wright, Ken Wriedt, Lance Barnard and Terry Aulich, who has been mentioned tonight, but no-one has been a finer senator or politician for Tasmania than Shirley. She makes you feel proud to be a Tasmanian. I think every Tasmanian admires her stand on family issues.

PARA.TAB: The only other thing I can say is that I thank you, Shirley, for talking me into coming to this place. You rang me one night, when the bells were ringing, and told me that you only had to come here for 22 weeks a year. I do not think that was quite true. Nevertheless, I have certainly enjoyed your company. I enjoyed our mad escapades around Tasmania. I was driving the bus with you and Jocelyn in it. Jocelyn was saying turn left and you were say turn right; so the only option I had was to go straight ahead.

John Panizza mentioned tonight how Austin Lewis found him, but I tell you: he found me also. He has obviously got a talent that we are not aware of and he will probably go into the private detective game when he leaves here.
I have always admired Peter Durack and I thank him for his sincerity and advice on matters that were affecting me on one or two occasions.
I have also had the benefit of Florence's scone recipe and I think my branches have been very grateful for it. I wish her well in the future.

Terry Aulich has been mentioned many times tonight. He is probably the best committee chairman I have worked with in the six years I have been here. I think he has made his mark not only as a good committee chairman but also as a good educationalist from Tasmania.

There have been a lot of nice things said about Karen Sowada tonight and I support all of them. I look upon Karen as the female version of Indiana Jones and I hope she continues her archaeological work. I will not criticise any grants you get—I promise you that.
Pat Giles was in a neighbouring office to mine. I have got to know her reasonably well as an Acting Deputy President. She is a very able and very nice person.

Graham Maguire is also a very nice person. I have had the odd game of tennis with Graham. I think he got a raw deal from his own party; nevertheless that is what happens in politics and I wish him well.

Janet Powell told me tonight that I am the only person on this side of politics who has ever bought her a drink. I do not remember—I obviously did—but I am told it was at the old House. I am pleased that someone from our side of politics was generous to Janet. I know from talking to her on the odd occasion that she is a good country girl, and like a lot of people in this place her roots are in the country.

I do not know whether Peter Walsh was a close friend of mine, but certainly we had an odd drink or two. I remember helping him up the stairs one night. I admire his knowledge and no-nonsense approach to politics and particularly some of his views on finance.
I did not get to know John Button all that well but I admire what he has done for the country. I hope I have not missed anyone.

There is another matter that I will discuss briefly. I am sorry, everybody is waiting to go home. I refer to a report that was tabled today—a summary of the inquiry into the accident involving No. 75 Squadron FA18 Hornet A21-41 at Tindal in 1991. I wanted to say a few words about it tonight because it may be too late next session.

This accident concerned an old school friend of mine. It was his son that was killed in this accident. Peter Conroy grew up in Tasmania. Michael Tate may have known him, because they went to the same school. The plane has never been found and neither has the late Cameron Conroy. The family is still very anxious to know what happened to Cameron and the plane. The inquiry found that the most probable reason for the accident was that, unknown to the pilot, the cabin pressure switch was not set in the right position; the pilot removed his oxygen mask for comfort purposes and other non-medical reasons; and, as a result, in an unpressurised cockpit, he suffered hypoxia leading to unconsciousness.

As a result of this inquiry, actions have been taken to make conditions better for future pilots. Measures have included installing a cabin pressurisation warning system, fitting an electronic locater beacon so that if a plane crashes it can be found, and reviewing the RAAF aviation medicine training scheme. It is unfortunate that these things have to be rectified after an accident which caused so much pain to someone's family, a family which is so anxious about finding its lost loved one that it is still contemplating whether to finance a private search.

I was at Tindall last year speaking to the RAAF personnel. Group Captain Moat, the commander of that base, still regrets that they have not been able to find Cameron. He is most concerned that a training exercise in Weipa which could have used the Army to look in areas where Cameron might have crashed was aborted. He felt that perhaps the exercise should have continued.

It is also unfortunate that Cameron only received—and Senator MacGibbon has explained to me the ins and outs of this—one course on the use of pressurisation. The refresher course he was supposed to take, along with his colleagues, was 12 months overdue at the time of the accident. I think this is an indictment of the penny-pinching attitude of the Government towards this squadron because pilots are allowed to fly only 175 hours a year. It is believed that that is not sufficient time to give the pilots the training they need. The reason Cameron was not sent to Point Cook for that updating of his medicine training was that the cost of flying him to Point Cook from Tindall seemed to be too high.

It is most unfortunate that this accident happened. Perhaps some good may come out of the inquiry. I hope that some time in the future, both the plane and the late Cameron Conroy will be located. When that happens it will put to rest the anxious moments and the grief that the family is suffering.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to join my colleagues and pay tribute to those senators who are retiring tonight. I include them all to start with, without naming them, because in the time available I can comment on only two or three. One thing that I found when I came here three years ago was that there was no shortage of people to give advice; what you had to do was sort out whether it was good advice or not.

PARA.TAB: Jokes aside, I would like to pay tribute to Peter Durack, who served in this place for 22 years, particularly for those first two or three months when I was trying to frame my first question and do all the little technical things. I found your quiet, wise counsel invaluable. I will always appreciate that; thank you very much.

I pay tribute to Shirley. I think the first question she asked when I walked into this place was, `What are you going to do about the wool industry?'. I think the last question she asked in this place was, `What is going to happen to the wool industry?'. While she did not get the right answer from Senator McMullan, I can tell her that the NFF is appealing that 2.5 per cent decision—so you work until the end; but it has been a very enjoyable and fruitful exercise for me.

I now want to combine my comments on what has been said tonight by Senator Panizza, Senator Walsh and Senator Austin Lewis. I do this for a very special reason. I first met Peter Walsh in about 1967 at a farmers union conference. I met John Panizza at about the same time. I first met Austin Lewis when we went up to a meeting at Merredin. Merredin is an interesting town. We also called in there on one of the education inquiries. It is an interesting town because, as Austin found out, it is no problem to get 600 or 700 farmers to a meeting at Merredin. There is a very simple reason. There are three factions there: one is the Labor Party, which is the Walsh-Chance faction; another is the Panizza-Patroni faction; and the other faction is that of Hendy Cowan, who is the Leader of the National Party. They always turned up together. I was very interested to hear John Panizza say that he and Peter Walsh sorted out the farmers union. Tonight is not the time to make a speech about that.

It was when flying up to Merredin that I met Austin Lewis. I think that meeting was an experience for him. I do not think he had been out in that part of the woods before. When he came back here after that, he had certainly seen the problems that existed in the wheat industry. We had a number of conversations about it. I think we might even have corresponded. He came into this place and fought for those people whom he had met up there once and who did at that time have a particular difficulty. I thank Austin sincerely for that.

I also want to make a couple of brief comments about Peter Walsh. There is no question that Peter Walsh, politically, had a very important role to play in changing the attitudes of farmers and how they go about running their businesses. At about the same time, a number of us—and I was a lot younger then—started questioning some of the old doctrine, which really revolved around maximising profits and socialising losses. Peter Walsh articulated that here in this place. A number of us articulated it publicly. From that, we started looking at some of our cost structures which were being socialised away in the process. I certainly recognised that, and I think that was a crucial part of the debate.

I will not comment tonight on Senator Walsh's speech, other than to say that I think one day he may wish that he had never made it. He certainly did make one important comment to me tonight—and I think now is the time to say it—when he acknowledged that the underwriting of the borrowings by the Government of the Wool Corporation increased the damage that occurred to the wool industry. That is the first time I have ever heard anybody on the other side of the chamber acknowledge that the Government accepted some of the responsibility for what occurred. I think that is a very important acknowledgment in terms of dealing with the problems we will have before us over the next year or two.

One other person I want to briefly comment on is Pat Giles. I knew Pat Giles in a totally different capacity before I came here. There is one thing I will always remember about Pat Giles. It occurred about 2 1/2 years ago when I was flying home to Perth. It was at a very difficult time. It takes me 14 hours to get home from this place. I had had a couple of whiskies on the plane and I was getting quite upset and emotional. She started chatting to me because she was sitting beside me. I said, `I'm going home tomorrow to my second son, James'—who is now in New Zealand—`and we have to shoot 1,500 sheep'. That was a very difficult thing to talk about on a long trip. I just want to say thank you to Pat for the help she gave me that night.

The last two senators I wish to comment on, while also acknowledging the others, collectively, are Senator Aulich and Senator Karin Sowada. I want to do that in the context of the education committee, and I wish to make one particular comment regarding it. Last year we were working through the youth unemployment report, which I think has turned out to be a very good report. It is a very significant report.

The important thing in terms of that report was that at the end of the day, under Terry's chairmanship and after a lot of discussion, we all came to the conclusion that we had to put down a report that, if it were going to be effective, had to have some meaty recommendations in it. We all agreed to buck our own particular party lines a little bit to get to the final conclusion. I think that demonstrated that the committee system can work. But even further than that, at the end of the day—and John Tierney and Paul Calvert will remember this—those recommendations that we made became part of our policy when we went into the last election. So I think that demonstrates something.

Finally, I wish to pay tribute to Lady Florence for her friendship and her contribution to this place and also for her wise counsel. I would like to conclude my comments by saying to all the people who are leaving us here tonight: au revoir, bon voyage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was not going to speak, but following Senator Calvert's remarks in relation to the loss of that Hornet I feel moved to expand on that topic. He said he discussed something with me. What I discussed with him was the actual pressurisation techniques. I had no knowledge that that pressurisation course was 12 months out of date or anything like that. That is information that Senator Calvert supplied, but perhaps I might seek the indulgence of the Senate to comment for a few minutes on those two reports.

PARA.TAB: They deal with serious matters, two fatal accidents with the loss of two lives and the total loss of two aircraft. The first point I would like to make is that the reports are summaries only and they are therefore of limited value unless they are read in conjunction with the full and unabridged report. The best summaries can give an accurate resume of what happened but frequently with summaries they can intentionally or unintentionally give the wrong impression, because of their brevity, as to what went wrong.

The other comment I would make, having read a number of other RAAF summaries of accidents in recent years is that they tend to be bland and uncritical. They do not attribute any censure to the personnel involved. That is a very wrong way to go. One simply cannot operate that way in aviation. Analysis must be ruthless and the correction that is necessary as a consequence of that analysis must also be ruthless. At the end of the day the RAAF in the first instance has to accept responsibility for these accidents and, beyond the RAAF, of course, ultimately the Government must accept the responsibility.

In the case of the loss of this Hornet, the aircraft has never been found. What happened was that the aircraft went out on an exercise that involved a low-level phase and returned back to Tindal at 33,000 feet. At 21,000 feet the pilot made his last radio call. The aircraft levelled out at 28,000 feet for a short while, so presumably the pilot was conscious at that time, and then resumed the climb, presumably on autopilot. It flew through the assigned altitude of 33,000 feet, climbed out to 46,000 feet and disappeared towards Cape York. It was presumed to have expended its fuel somewhere in the region of Weipa.

The inquiry showed that one of the possible causes was an unawareness by the pilot that the pressurisation of the cabin had not taken place. The very fact that this gets such emphasis in the report as the first matter mentioned means that the inquiry must have had some evidence to think that might have occurred.

The second point made is that the pilot had his mask off. In those circumstances, in an unpressurised aircraft at altitude, the loss of consciousness from hypoxia is something that occurs without any prodrome or warning at all. One just loses consciousness. It does not matter how alert one is, the loss of consciousness just occurs in an imperceptible and quite rapid way. That is why it is such a dangerous thing and why pressurisation courses are held and pilots and air crew are made aware of the need to monitor constantly their oxygen flow at altitude.

The aircraft was never found despite an extensive search, and the report hints at the need to fit electronic locater beacons to aircraft. These are simple and cheap locaters costing a few hundred dollars which have been used by the general aviation community for at least a decade. I can understand the RAAF not being keen to fit these because, if one loses an aircraft to enemy action, the last thing one wants is that aircraft or the site of its crash being identified by a beacon because it means that someone on the other side can find that aeroplane and get to it first and get any information from its equipment. But that problem is easily overcome by having an arming switch in the cockpit so that the locater beacon will not go off if one does not want it to. The other problem with an electronic locater beacon is that it can transmit accidently and one does not know it is transmitting unless one searches for the signal. But it is transmitting on known frequencies and, with a VHF radio in the aircraft, it is very simple to tune in on that channel and hear the signal if it is transmitting. I think it would be a very good move for the services to have ELBs in their aircraft.

But we come back to the two important points raised: the lack of knowledge of whether or not the aircraft was pressurised; and the fact that the pilot had his oxygen mask off. The first point suggests very strongly a lack of familiarity coming from lack of recency in flying experience. It is unfortunately true that the pilots in the FA18 squadrons are flying only about 175 hours a year, and that does not provide enough experience for a multi-role aircraft of the complexity of the FA18. To be competent, those pilots have to fly at least 22 hours a month—preferably 24 to 26 hours a month. On the other point on the lack of recency of pressure chamber experience, I do not know the precise details. Senator Calvert said that it was 12 months overdue. But that really is something that can be done very cheaply and does not involve anything much at all.

The other widespread story that was in the press at the time was that the pilot had a habit of flying with his oxygen mask off. That is something that is not mentioned in the summary of the report and we do not know whether it is true or not. But the fact that it was reported in the press leads me to assume that there may have been some substance to it. If that happened, then we have to say that there was a lack of discipline and that the more senior officers in the squadron should have laid down the law and that should not have occurred.

The second accident that we have relates to the loss of a P3C Orion which again was a total loss of the aircraft and in which, unfortunately, one person was killed. There is another point with this that is rather sad because 10 squadron, the squadron that lost this aircraft, is one of the really great squadrons of the RAAF—a squadron that has been operating heavy long-range maritime patrol aircraft exclusively for 50 years.

What happened here was that this aircraft departed Cocos Island presumably to fly back to Australia for Learmonth or Edinburgh. The Orion P3C is a heavy aircraft and, with the equipment load, the anti-submarine electronic equipment in it is really quite heavy. To fly from Cocos back to Australia it would have been close to its maximum all-up weight: somewhere around 130,000 pounds weight, somewhere around 65 tonnes. The aircraft took off, climbed to 5,000 feet and came back for an over-fly of the airstrip at quite high speed. The report says that the aircraft flew at about 380 knots, which is about 430 miles an hour, which I would have thought was pretty close to the VNE of that aircraft, at a height of between 300 and 400 feet. Then it initiated a sharp pull-up, it climbed, and the report estimates that the G-loading on that aircraft was at least 3.4 G. It may possibly have been higher than that because there is no way it can be recorded. But the fact that the report put a figure of 3.4 in suggests quite strongly to me that that was at least the minimal figure obtained.

What the pilot did was something that is as old as time itself: of beating up an airfield on departure. The fact that the aircraft was flown at a high speed and at a low level is not necessarily dangerous in itself, but it is not good practice and in this case it was specifically banned both under the squadron general flying orders and under the orders of the maritime patrol group. So there was a flagrant breach of discipline in the fact that the aircraft was flown at high speed at a low level up the strip.

But that was not the thing that caused the accident. The great error of judgment was a very savage pull up at the end. This aeroplane would have been still close to its maximum all-up weight of somewhere around 130,000 pounds, I would assume. Subjecting that to a G loading of about 3.4 G, I would think probably put it pretty close to the maximum design load of the aircraft. That means that a 60-tonne aeroplane became, in real terms, an aeroplane weighing 200 tonnes. In that circumstance, great structural loading is placed on the airframe and it is very likely that something is going to break.

There are two points here: the rate of application of the load—and there was a very rapid application of the load here—as well as the absolute dimension of the load itself. Quite bluntly, it was a very stupid manoeuvre. There is no excuse or reason for doing anything like that at all. There is absolutely no point in it. It might be one thing to fly up an airstrip at a high speed and impress people with one's skill that way, but the aeroplane could have been climbed out gently, rotated into a climb. If that had happened, with smooth hands, all of those people and the crew would have been here today and we would have an aeroplane.

By fighter pilot techniques, a 3.4 G loading is nothing. Most of the exercises flown by pilots in FA18s routinely pull about 6 Gs and sometimes they even go to 9 Gs. I do not doubt that there are times in a P3 when pilots are doing anti-submarine attacks where they are pulling a G loading of probably about 3 G or something like that. I have flown in those exercises both at night and during the day and they can be pretty violent manoeuvres. But there is a reason for those manoeuvres to be performed in an anti-submarine exercise. Like all flying operations, it is a percentage game. One does not put oneself in a position where one takes unnecessary risks. What was done here was simply very bad airmanship. One of the basics of airmanship is to have smooth hands; one does not load an aeroplane up unnecessarily. A particularly violent pulling up of a heavily loaded transport aeroplane like that or an aeroplane corresponding to a transport aeroplane is just inexcusable. It is no wonder that something happened.

The findings attribute the accident, somewhat fuzzily, to pilot error. The findings comment on the aerodynamic factors which may have been relevant, but those are clearly secondary. Attention is also drawn to what may have been a manufacturing deficiency with respect to the thickness of the ribs in the leading edge section. That may have been a predisposing factor but, again, it is a secondary consideration at this time. Under the heading `Other Conclusions', the report states:

SPEECH.PARA: a.a fly-over departure was not included in the flight authorisation;
b.the Wing operations officer was deficient in his executive responsibility . . .

There were three pilots on board, two captains being on the flight deck. There was a fully endorsed training captain qualified for flight from the right-hand seat. The captain, who was flying the aircraft in the left-hand seat, was also an experienced captain. The report further states:

While neither pilot acted negligently in undertaking what was intended to be an impressive, but nevertheless within published limitations, low fly-over, both showed a lack of professional wisdom and professional responsibility . . .

They lacked wisdom in what they did. These two men were captains; they were not just pilots. As such, they were vested with the responsibility of the lives of everyone in that aircraft, the safe operation of the aircraft and the successful operation of the mission. These people are especially selected and trained by the Air Force. They are captains. I say this with great care: they simply did not exercise the responsibility that was vested in them. I find it astonishing that—as the summary states—all that happened to them was that formal counselling of the captain, the co-pilot and the flight authorising officer took place.

PARA.TAB: The problem that we have here with these two accidents is that they are a consequence of the great loss of expertise in the Air Force in the last six to seven years. Sadly, they are not isolated examples. In the recent past, the Royal Australian Air Force has had a relatively high fatal accident rate. It is interesting that the United States air force throughout the same period has shown a diminution in its accident rate but, unfortunately, ours has gone up.

Broadly, in the recent past, we have lost over 400 pilots out of a pilot pool in the Air Force of roughly 750. In 1985-86 we lost 70 pilots; in 1986-87, we lost 107 pilots; in 1987-88, we lost 123 pilots. That is a loss of 300 pilots in just three calendar years. The people we lost were the highly experienced pilots, the experienced flight lieutenants, squadron leaders and wing commanders, the people who had the body of experience in the Air Force. That loss rate has to be compared with the long term loss rate for the RAAF of only 47 pilots per year. Six or seven years ago when this loss rate was going on, I said that it would take us 15 years to replace that experience in the Air Force because it cannot be generated overnight. I said that, sadly, we would pay a price for it.

These accidents are part of that price and they are not the full price. We will pay more for the loss of experience from the Air Force in the middle to the late 1980s. It may be that my estimate of 15 years to replace that experience is an optimistic one, because when I made that estimate the number of pilots and the number of hours being flown were far higher than they are today. Since then, we have seen the hours of squadron pilots reduced from 24 to 26 hours a month to 175 hours a year, which is inadequate. Not only that, we have seen the squadron manning strength of pilots reduced from about 18 to 12. So we have fewer pilots getting less experience, and there is simply no substitute for experience.

In conclusion, I regret that these reports ever came before the Senate. I think they are a great tragedy because we have lost two good Australians in the prime of their lives. We have lost two fine aircraft, with probably a replacement value of $200 million. I find it sad to say that we have lost those aircraft basically because of the general run-down in expertise and experience within the defence forces today.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BROWNHILL
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I will not delay the Senate for very long. I want to put on record a few comments about the election that is now well and truly behind us. I would like to raise some concerns which I have. My concerns were first raised when a letter arrived on my desk from an elderly constituent who was quite upset about having received a letter from the Australian Electoral Commission alleging that she had voted more than once. For this elderly lady, this allegation was quite a shock. Not surprisingly, it did upset her. She promptly informed the Australian Electoral Commission, however, that she had in fact voted on only one occasion at one polling booth on 13 March.

PARA.TAB: On taking up the issue with the AEC, I was quickly told how easy it is for such a mistake to occur. Since the electoral rolls are now electronically scanned using all sorts of new technology, apparently it is easily done. The computer picks up a small mark on the roll which points to the fact that a person has voted more than once when, in fact, that person has not. Could one person easily vote at different places using the same name without being detected until after the election? Or could someone have voted in her name at another polling booth?

Another of my concerns is the number of provisional voters in certain electorates. Nationwide, the number of provisional voters in Australia was 0.42 per cent of the total vote, or 46,000 votes nationally. I would contend that this is enough votes strategically placed to win government for the Labor Party.

In the very short time between when the election was called and the roll actually closed—a period of eight days—450,000 transactions were recorded, which means there were 450,000 changes or additions to the roll in that period, the equivalent of about 54,700 changes per day. This figure included 35,000 new enrolments from 18-year-olds and another 150,000 new enrolments. I wonder how closely these new enrolments, particularly those people who had re-enrolled under a new address, were reviewed. I wonder whether there have ever been any habitation reviews done regarding those people who register at a new or different address, or those who register with a new or different name. I would suggest that there have, in fact, been no reviews, nor have there been any checks. In electorates which were decided by the smallest majorities—by only a few hundred votes—I think this is an issue which should be thought seriously about for future elections.

With all due respect for the good work done by the Australian Electoral Commission, I simply ask how easy it would be for people to enrol using different names at different addresses within an electorate for the purpose of an election. Does anyone check whether this person exists or actually resides at the address on the electoral roll?To my knowledge, no such checks are carried out. The only checks are those overzealous computer checks which identify people who supposedly voted more than once, although one of my constituents will tell honourable senators just how accurate those checks were.

For example, the number of provisional votes recorded in the electorate of Page, which was won by the Australian Labor Party by the smallest margin of less than 200 votes, was 640 and, of those, almost 50 per cent were awarded to the Labor candidate, while the National Party candidate recorded just 20 per cent. In the Richmond electorate there was a similar story: 0.86 per cent of the total vote was provisional, although the Labor candidate scored more than 50 per cent of those provisional votes compared with the Nationals score of just 16 per cent. I present these remarks to the Senate not as outrageous allegations but as observations which I believe should be looked at before we have any further elections.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 5 May 1993:

PARA.TAB: (1) How many changes have been made to the method of measuring the number of persons unemployed and the rate of unemployment since March 1983.
(2) What changes were made and on what dates were they made.
(3) What was the impact of these changes on the measures of the number of unemployed and the rates of unemployment.
(4) What would be the number unemployed and the rate of unemployment in June 1992 if the pre-March 1983 definition and method of measurement were applied.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) There has been one change in the definition of labour force status since March 1983 which affected the compilation of estimates of the numbers of persons employed, unemployed, and not in the labour force, with a consequential effect on the calculation of the unemployment rate.

(2) The definition of employed persons was extended to include persons who worked without pay for between 1 and 14 hours per week in a family business or on a farm (ie unpaid family helpers). Previously, unpaid family helpers who worked for 1 to 14 hours per week, or who had such a job but were not at work during the reference period, ie were on holidays, sick etc, were defined as either unemployed or not in the labour force, depending on whether they met the criteria of actively looking for work and being available to start work. This change was made to align Australian labour force concepts with a set of changed international definitions prepared by the International Labour Organisation in October 1982. The changed definition was introduced in the April 1986 survey.

(3) Application of the present definition had the effect of increasing employment for March 1986 by 34,800, and of decreasing unemployment by 5,300 in seasonally adjusted terms. The unemployment rate (seasonally adjusted) for persons based on the previous definition was 7.9 per cent in March 1986, while the unemployment rate for persons based on the present definition was 7.8 per cent.

(4) The changes of definition that took place in April 1986 resulted in corresponding changes to the Labour Force Survey questionnaire. As a result it is not possible to produce data for June 1992 based on the previous definition for persons employed, unemployed, or not in the labour force, nor therefore the unemployment rate.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 10 May 1993:

PARA.TAB: (l) What training in peacekeeping operations is given to Australian Defence Force personnel who go to Cambodia with the United Nations Transitional Authority in Cambodia.
(2) Are they supplied with copies of the Peacekeeping Handbook published by the International Peace Academy in New York; if not, will each soldier receive a copy.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) The training in peacekeeping operations for Australian Defence Force personnel who are selected for service with the United Nations Transitional Authority in Cambodia (UNTAC) is normally conducted over a period of about 15 days in Sydney. Occasionally, where the United Nations (UN) has requested that Australia provide personnel for UNTAC at short notice, as was the case with the Movement Control Group in May 1992, some Military Police personnel in April 1993 and more recently the Aviation Squadron Group, it has not been possible to provide personnel with the full regime of training normally conducted in Australia. However, in these situations, outstanding training requirements are completed in country.

In general terms, the training for UNTAC comprises the history of the UN and UNTAC, an overview of Cambodia, area and current situation briefs, a full day on mine awareness and a half day on field defences.

Specific activities and topics covered include; physical fitness training, explosive ordnance recognition, stress management, legal briefings, navigation and survival training, additional radio training, lateral thinking exercises, security training, preparatory medical and administration as well as medical and health training specific to the Cambodian area.

ANSWER.PARA: This training is additional to the normal range of military training that every member of the Australian Defence Force receives.

PARA.TAB: Additionally, every military member selected for UNTAC is provided with a Cambodian equipment handbook (35 pages), an English-Khmer phrasebook (which includes a guide to Cambodian customs), and an information pack from the Australian Force Communications Unit in Cambodia.

(2) Copies of the peacekeeping handbook are not issued to Australian Defence Force personnel. This handbook was last published in 1986 and its relevance to the UNTAC operation is minimal. The handbook is currently being redrafted by an Australian Major posted to New York and is expected to be published by the end of 1993. When available, this book will be issued to all Australian Defence Force personnel serving on UN missions.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 13 May 1993:

PARA.TAB: (1) Why is the Australian Taxation Office (ATO) planning to bring forward by a fortnight the due date by which tax agents are required to lodge clients' tax returns.
(2) Will the only benefit of this change be to the ATO and not to the registered tax agents.
(3) Is this the second time in two years that the lodgment date has been brought forward by a fortnight, with the result that lodgment is now one month earlier.

(4) Will this change severely disrupt the smooth operation of the lodgment of tax returns by condensing the time that tax agents will have to ensure the preparation and lodgment of their clients' returns.
(5) Will this disadvantage those small offices that have not invested in electronic lodgment equipment.
(6) Given the earlier lodgment requirement, could such a tight time frame work impact on the reasonable care standard.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Assistant Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) The ATO proposal stems from its responsibility to collect revenue as soon as practicable on or after the due date set by law. The timely lodgment of tax returns is a critical part of this cashflow management responsibility, and one in which tax agents have a major role.
Accepting that return preparation and processing volumes need to be managed, the ATO has for many years had lodgment programs in place for tax agents.

This year the ATO has noted that the flow of returns from agents was unevenly compressed into the last stages of the program regardless of the understandings with the profession that returns would be lodged progressively.

The ATO has also noted that revenue collections from assessments have been slipping forwards into May and June over the last three years. Bringing forward the final dates for agent lodgments is a way of addressing this slippage.

(2) The ATO at present sees the bring forward proposals as the only way to address the revenue slippage. It acknowledges that the change will reduce by a fortnight the time available to agents to prepare and lodge returns; but notes that this outcome will still provide a less stringent program than has applied in the past. Also, the Commissioner is currently canvassing members of the national Tax Liaison Group (The ATO's peak tax profession consultative body) for alternatives to the bring forward proposal.
(3) Yes.

(4) No. The changes are being considered, in part, because the flow of returns has been compressed into the last part of the lodgment year. The proposed dates will still allow agents to spread their lodgments over 8 1/2 months (9 1/2 for electronically lodged returns).
(5) No. The proposed changes will affect all tax agents in the same way, relative to their present operations.

(6) The "reasonable care" standard assumes that taxpayers, assisted by their tax agents where applicable, take reasonable care in preparing their income tax returns. Tax agents are expected to work to appropriate professional standards in assisting taxpayers. The reasonable care standard will not be changed by the earlier lodgment requirements.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 11 May 1993 (Hansard page 377) Senator Watson asked me the following question without notice:

PARA.TAB: Did a Commonwealth official suggest or apply pressure on the Commonwealth Bank of Australia to improve its profit performance and dividend distribution. What is the Minister's response to the decision by the bank to make 7,500 of its staff redundant when the bank is operating profitably. Could the Government please explain where is the poor performance of the bank or the lack of managerial judgment that warrants such retrenchments in recessionary conditions.
The Treasurer has provided the following information in answer to the honourable senator's question:

The CBA's decision to reduce staff numbers was taken in the context of a major restructuring of the CBA's business operations and after detailed consideration of the issues over several months. The decision reflects a commercial judgment by the CBA Board and management. The Government considers that it is inappropriate to intervene in the commercial decisions made by the CBA Board and management because the CBA is a publicly listed company where the Commonwealth is one of many shareholders. It is to be expected that the CBA, like any other business organisation, would continuously strive for improved profits and dividends for its shareholders.
